text: Rocznik 2014. Um√≥wmy siƒô - to jest dobre piwo. Ale generalnie nie warto by≈Ço. W aromacie fajny porter ba≈Çtycki, wciul karmelu, sos sojowy trochƒô czekolada. W smaku jest cieliste, pe≈Çne, zakleja, ale zakleja karmelem i kikkomanem. Piwo klasy najlepszych warek porteru warmi≈Ñskiego. SERIO.
Bardzo s≈Çodkie, wyklejajƒÖce. Ze s≈ÇodyczƒÖ trzciny cukrowej. Troszkƒô za du≈ºo sosu sojowego jak dla mnie :p

Bottle pour. Pours a pitch black with a light head. Slightly smokey on the nose, soy sauce, balsamic, but slightly minty and grassy. Very complex. Incredibly smooth. Syrup vibe. Medium bitterness, umami, complex bodied and smooth finish. Hard to find any faults.

Poured from a bottle that was traded for the blood of two first born children. Smells of coffee and bourbon, vanilla and dark fruit. Chunky carbonation with a thin wispy head. Tastes like goddamn molasses with coffee and chocolate, with a lingering finish of plum and pure distilled sin. 15% alcohol expertly hidden beneath layers of syrup and caramel and satanic trickery. If this beer were music it would sound like Egyptian sludge metal. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma of licorice and soy sauce, surprising at the beginning but getting better with time. Definitely something unusual but in the good meaning. Dark Lord is the sweetest beer I¬íve ever drink and at first I thought I couldn¬ít make it to the end but that sweetness is not tiring and drinkability is over every limit. Just awesome

2016 bottle shared at tasting. Black colour, minimal brown head. Aroma of dark chocolate, chocolate sauce, soy sauce, licorice, notes of molasses and caramel - pleasant, but strange. Taste is heavy sweet and light bitter, chocolate, licorice, soy sauce, molasses, dark coffee. Chocolate finish. Full body, oily, thick texture, soft carbonation. Very sweet, with well hidden alcohol, extremely dense, complex and unique - lives up to the hype.

Dark Lord 2017 (Green Wax). A Demonic Imperial Russian stout brewed with Dark Matter Coffee coffee, vanilla, and molasses.  
 Alkohol:  15% obj. 
 Kolor:  Czarny jak otch≈Ça≈Ñ piekielna, jak oczy diab≈Ça - Ciemnego Pana. 
 Piana:  Taka piana jakiej bym oczekiwa≈Ç w piwach tej klasy.
Gƒôsta, drobno ziarnista, zwarta, tworzƒÖca jednƒÖ warstwƒô.
Fakt, ≈ºe po paru minutach opada do wƒÖskiego ≈Ça≈Ñcuszka, ale przy uzupe≈Çnieniu kielicha znowu wylewa siƒô prawie ze szk≈Ça.
Brak krƒÖ≈ºkowania. 
 Zapach:  Aromat jest monstrualny! A≈º trudno sobie wyobraziƒá, ≈ºe to standardowa wersja Dark Lorda. Pachnie jak najlepszy RIS le≈ºakowany w beczce po bourbonie.
To z pewno≈õciƒÖ zas≈Çuga ogromnej ilo≈õci wanilii dorzuconej do piwa.
Drugim z przodujƒÖcych element√≥w jest kawa - nie jest to z pewno≈õciƒÖ byle jaka kawa, a najlepszej jako≈õci ziarna. Czuƒá to bezapelacyjnie w aromacie.
Zapach uzupe≈ÇniajƒÖ gigantyczne stosy tabliczek mlecznej czekolady, karmelu i lukrecji.
Po przelaniu do szk≈Ça i lekkim ogrzaniu trunku do≈ÇƒÖczajƒÖ do profilu zapachowego ciemne owoce.
Rewelacja! 
 Smak:  Wow! Po prostu bajka! Odlot doskona≈Çy! Pi≈Çem na festiwalu w Kopenhadze kilka wersji Dark Lorda. W tym 6-tego najlepszego RISa na ≈õwiecie Dark Lord - Bourbon Vanilla Bean.
Tamte by≈Çy le≈ºakowane w r√≥≈ºnych beczkach. To jest wersja niebeczkowa, ale w niczym nie odstaje od tamtych trunk√≥w.
Rewelacyjna wysokie klasy kawa z dodatkiem mleka.
Dalej cukierki kr√≥wki, belgijskie pralinki czekoladowe, wi≈õnie w likierze, maliny oblane gƒôstƒÖ czekoladƒÖ, melasa, odrobina kakao, cukier trzcinowy.
W drugim rzucie potƒô≈ºna dawka czerwonych s≈Çodkich owoc√≥w (g≈Ç√≥wnie malin i dojrza≈Çych czere≈õni).
Wanilia dodaje nieprawdopodobnej s≈Çodyczy.
Piwo jest bogate, z≈Ço≈ºone, wielowarstwowe.
Potƒô≈ºne cia≈Ço, zbita i twarda masa oleistego trunku.
S≈Çodkie, ulepkowate, ekstremalnie g≈Çadkie.
Na etykiecie nigdzie nie ma informacji o zawarto≈õci alkoholu. Jednak jak poprzednie Dark Lordy jest to 15% alkoholu.
Przy tej g≈Çadko≈õci i delikatno≈õci degustacji, a≈º trudno w to uwierzyƒá.
Nieziemska pijalno≈õƒá, a to najnowsza warka. 
Boskie! 
 Wysycenie:  Niskie. 
 Podsumowanie:  

Mia≈Çem pewne obawy przed degustacjƒÖ tego trunku.
Wiele niepewno≈õci.
Jak sprostaƒá takiemu gigantowi? Jak zmierzyƒá siƒô samemu z du≈ºƒÖ butlƒÖ 650 ml 15%-wego trunku?
Czy Dark Lord sprosta swojej legendzie? Czy bƒôdzie tak dobry (a mo≈ºe i lepszy) od wersji le≈ºakowanych, kt√≥re pi≈Çem na Copenhagen Beer Celebration?
Te i wiele pyta≈Ñ w g≈Çowie.

Teraz ju≈º znam na nie wszystkie odpowiedzi.
Dark Lord jest najprawdopodobniej najlepszych niele≈ºakowanym RIS-em jakiego pi≈Çem.
Najwiƒôksze zalety trunku: ca≈Çkowite ukrycie alkoholu, potƒô≈ºna gƒôsta i oleista tekstura, ogromna z≈Ço≈ºono≈õƒá, bogactwo smakowe i zapachowe, wielowymiarowo≈õƒá, s≈Çodkie, mo≈ºe nawet ulepkowate cia≈Ço. 
Dla takich w≈Ça≈õnie piw jak to, zosta≈Ço stworzone polskie s≈Çowo: SZTOS!

2016. Mocarny aromat czekolady, likieru czekoladowego, trochƒô sosu sojowego piƒôkny. Bardzo gƒôste, s≈Çodkie wyklejajƒÖce. Czekolada mar pierwszym planie. ≈öwietne! Flavors are chocolate, soy sauce and molasses with. Full body, soft carbonation, thick texture, chocolate liquer.

Bottle release 2017 with green wax: pours like motor oil black opaque with tan/foamy dark brown dissipating head. Aroma: intense, complex aroma of roasted grain, almost barley wine-like malt charackter with notes of caramel, toasted toffee, supported with notes of coffee, chocolate, cacao nibs, molasses, daRk fruit esters, sherry-like alcohol, coffee, sweet vanilla beans...
Flavour perfectly follows aroma with intensity: once again barley wine-ish malt backbone with dominant roasted grain, supported with notes of caramel, toasted toffee, bread, coffee, chocolate, cacao nibs, molasses, daRk fruit esters, like plums, prunes, sherry-like alcohol, coffee, sweet vanilla beans...moderately sweet finish.
Body is thick, texture smooth, carbonation is moderate. 15% is perfectly hidden.
Well...imo: very barley wine-ish charackter, reminds me on Goose Island BCBarley wine. I would be interesting to dring it head to head.
[2016] 22oz bottle. Black with a thin ring of tan foam. Flavors are roasted cereals, chocolate, soy sauce and molasses with fruity notes. Full body, soft carbonation, thick texture.

Blue wax bottle, shared at Magic Rock. Murky, very dark brown. Barely a head. Nose has treacle and black syrup. Some soy. Spent coffee grinds. Touch of chestnut honey. Taste is sweet and treacly. Soft, savoury bitterness. Smooth and slick mouthfeel. Hides the ABV reasonably well. Sweet and savoury in equal measure, on the finish.

22 oz bottle shared, 2009 white wax, thanks Ratman! Black appearance with a small brown head. Aroma of chocolate malt, vanilla, caramel, toffee, light roasted grain and a hint of vanilla. Similar flavor, adding medium to heavy malt sweetness and a touch of bitterness. Full body, a little thin for 15%. Very slight hint of oxidation (cardboard). Drinking pretty damn well overall, now I¬íll have to try a fresh(er) one!

Pours almost pitch black with a tan head dissipating quite quickly. Aroma is pure dark chocolate, soy sauce, licorice, caramelized brown sugar, fudgy. Flavour is very sweet, full of licorice, molasses, maple syrup, chestnut honey, brown sugar, melted dark chocolate and hints of soy sauce. Overall is a licorice bomb! Full body, velvety mouthfeel, very smooth, soft carbonation perfect for the style. I wish it was a little bit more balanced though. Anyway it is very enjoyable. For the sweet imperial stouts lovers like me. (2016 vintage)

(Three Floyds Dark Lord Russian Imperial Stout) Bottle 650ml at home, served into a snifter. Orange wax -vintage 2013, ABV 15%
thick pour that gives a pitch black coloured beer with a small and thin dark brown head on top, low retention.
The aroma has soy sauce, molasses, bourbon, vanilla, dark fruits, prunes, alcohol.
Taste is sweet with dark fruits, prunes, fudge, bourbon, vanilla, sugars, molasses, alcohol.
Thick body, fizzy carbonation, sticky palate.
Great.

My first perfect rating. This was the 2015 version and it holds up to the hype. Wonderful and unique. Roasted malt with a well balanced bitterness. Slight sweetness and chocolate with coffee. Beautiful color and smooth and oily. Carbonation was just right. I¬ím sure there are others out there but this was astounding.
Fuck you. I have no other words. Literally nothing to say. It¬ís like a beer in a beer in a beer. 10/10. And i had a lot of imperial stouts. But seriousely, fuck you.

This was a bottle share with Matt, Jess and their friends. Jet black pour with an aroma of plums, figs and other demonic dark fruit. Taste is more dark, aged fruit with dark (natch) chocolate and a rich sweetness. I enjoyed the 2011 and 2015 vintages and I thought there was much more going on in the 2011 Dark Lord. Both were impressive beers.

Backlog Beer Ratiing 2017.01.29
650ml bottle @ Alex¬ís. 2016 Vintage
Pours an opaque black with a small tan head. Nose presents dark fruits, leather, and molasses. Flavour is quite sweet, again with dark fruits, leather, and molasses. Full bodied with a semi viscous oily feel.
I enjoy pretty much everything coming out of 3 Floyd¬ís and the Dark Lord is no exception. Strong sweet flavours mask the 15% kicker

650ml bottle (thx, Louis-Philippe B.!) at Alex¬ís. Vintage 2016. Pours an almost black with a dark beige head. Aroma is oily, leather, dark fruits. Taste is veeery sweet, dark fruits, very oily. Crazy stuff.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2017 Butelka z 2016 w Chmielarni. W aromacie pumpernikiel, owoce, czekolada. Smak mocno s≈Çodki, kakao, wino, melasa, lukrecja, marmalada. Piwo jest potƒô≈ºne, wykleja i jest super g≈Çƒôbokie. Jak na imp stouta zaskakuje potƒô≈ºnƒÖ owocowo≈õciƒÖ, niczym marmalada z czekoladƒÖ. Wybitne.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2017 Panel #15Rami Rami is drinking a Dark Lord (2016) by 3 Floyds Brewing Company at Chmielarnia Marsza≈Çkowska

W aromacie pumpernikiel, sos sojowy, reszta oczekiwana. W uscie czad, fajowo pralinowe, owocowosuszone, przyprawowe, rodzynkowo-figowe, slodkie, inne niz w aromacie bo jak przyprawowy ris, super geste, wowNa pudle paneluskrypt siƒô na nim wywalil :) wiec recznie uzgadniam ocenke zgodnie ze skryptem ;)

Rocznik 2016 - To co dzieje siƒô w tym piwie to po prostu poezja - w aromacie czekolada, pumpernikiel, spieczona sk√≥rka od ciemnego chleba, d≈ºem figowy, daktyle. W smaku mega s≈Çodkie, zalepiajƒÖce usta, akcenty chleba, fig, czekolady. POEZJA!

22oz bottle from 2014 vintage bottle from my buddy Brian.

Nice aroma with good flavor but overly sweet flavor. Maybe because is been ages for a couple of years. 

Not complain because it¬ís dark lord
Bottle shared at mikkeller bar in copenhagen. one of the biggest experiences i had in stouts. nice, rich and enormous.

Very dark brown/black with brown head. Aroma and taste are like maple bacon, minus the bacon. It¬ís surprisingly even-toned, with a little smoke. A nice RIS, but nothing I¬íd stand in a very long line to buy.

Vertical tasting of 2006-2008.Average rating above. Poured deep dark brown with no head. Aroma is increasingly vinous with age, dark, alcohol soaked fruit, fudge, dark chocolate some coffee. Full body, flavour as the aroma, generally smooth, 07 drier. Dry, sweet end.

Wow, what a beer! Thanks Brunnsbe for the bottle! Beautiful orange head that could last a bit longer. Deep and complex aroma, mostly chocolate. Taste is filled with roasted and chocolate notes. Mouthfeel is like yoghurt, so thick! Kind a weird... I love it!

Poured from a 2014, 22 oz bottle. 
Aroma is rich and chocolate forward with a balanced, moderately strong roast note. Some light anise notes with a bit of dark fruit. Light leather and ash notes with a bit of what could be described as a meaty aroma. 
Pours black with a medium sized, thick, dark mocha head that recedes to a thin film that recedes to the edges with a bit in the center. Faint lacing and moderately long legs. 
Flavor is fairly sweet with a lot of chocolate notes with a bit of caramel and toffee. Medium roast notes with some light ash and leather. Light dark fruit notes with some raisin and prunes. Hints of that meaty character. 
Mouthfeel is fairly full bodied, silky and creamy with medium low carbonation. Low astringency and medium low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a better beer than I remember, but that could have been a worse vintage. It¬ís a too sweet for my tastes and the meaty note is off, but definitely faint compared to my memory of it.

Bottle shared with Luc, Pat and Chantal. Aroma: Strong molasses, candied fruits, licorice, soya sauce. App: dark burgundy, minimal brown ale, no lacing. Taste and palate: full body, medium high sweetness, light acidity finish. Overall: doesn¬ít deserve this hype. Another overhyped beer from Three Floyds. It¬ís good but really far vein amazing or even great. This is so sweet. Too many strong flavors. Ok.

2016 on draught. Pours black with a quickly fading coffee colored bubbly head. Aroma is of molasses, dark chocolate, dark fruits, liquorice, caramel, biscuit, fudge. Taste is of dark fruits, liquorice, fudge, vanilla, molasses, really rich, dark chocolate. Sticky oily mouthfeel, soft to medium carbonation.

Rating #2291 - 2015.12.29 - DarkLord Bottleshare -. Black as a horcrux escaping that ugly locket, with a tan head that caps nicely. Aroma is heavy roast malt, espresso, molasses. Taste is heavy on roast malt and coffee flavours, lots of burnt sugar, toffee, blackstrap molasses. For 15% the alcohol burn is less pronounced - very well rounded. Worth trying to kill Harry Potter for.

Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupe≈Çniania profilu na ratebeer. 

2014 vintage. Lepkie, niesamowicie s≈Çodkie, intensywne i bogate arcydzie≈Ço.

October 28, 2016. Bottle, vintage 2014. 
Black with a minimal brown head. Aroma is sweet, malty and roasted with molasses, prunes, raisins, roasted coffee, dark chocolate, soy, ash and licorice. Taste is sweet, malty, smooth bitter and warming. Finish is malty and sweet with caramel, dark berries, prunes, raisins,roasted bitterness with chocolate, coffee and ash, some inky and light salty soy notes.
Full bodied, soft carbonation, oily texture. 
Good but not spectacular.

@Hopishop BUMB

Nice beer, not the ¬ílegendary¬í imperial stout I expected. Misses some complexity in my opinion.Too much soy sauce. Sorry. Nevertheless good
Aroma of coffee, syrup, toffee, chocolate, raisin. Taste is very very sweet, syrup, raisins, port wine, vanilla, chocolate, molasses. 5 oz is more than enough, but the first sip is pretty good.
Black pour with a ring of khaki. Coats the glass. Aroma is maple syrup, chocolate, and some roast. Taste is soy sauce, maple syrup, chocolate syrup, and some roast. Thick chewy body.

Bottleshare at Steampunk Bar. 2014. Black color beige head. Coffe, melasses, raisins, Dark fruit. LOTs of Dark fruit, Dark cherry chocolate, raisins in taste. Very sweet, thick mouthfeel. Good imperial stout but wasn¬ít as good as I expected, too sweet and not enough complex.

From bottle at Camping Ratebeer ¬í15, blue wax edition. Pours pitch black with a medium tan head. Aroma is overly sweet with licorce, molasses, some roast and sugar. Taste is very sweet with sugar, molasses, a bit of roast. Full body, soft carbo. Too sweet for my liking.

2015 bottle with Hugh. Paired with excellent Pizza at La Coppola, Redfern who charged nothing for corkage!

Pours pitch black. Hugh reckons there is a bit of a red hue about it, but I reckon it could be caused by the wood fired pizza oven beside us. Brown head disappears pretty quickly. Looks exciting. Monster aroma with coffee, very dark chocolate, dried fruit. Almost a fortified red wine smell, which in combination with raisin reminded me of Amarone (i.e. the partially dried grapes dealy).

Mega full bodied, probably not far off being a solid. Raisin like characteristics keep trucking alongside typical imperial stout traits. Also very sweet, but this is in no way off putting, and nicely balanced by bitterness and malts coming through on a long long finish alongside very high cocoa chocolate. 

Overall, absolutely tremendous and one of the few things I have had recently that lives up to the hype.

As an aside we both reckon this was superior to the 2012 we had a couple of weeks ago, which had a bit to much in the way of a fortified/sherry like aroma. Was still excellent though.

2011 still to try

On tap at CBC 2016, Red Session. Pours black with small tan head. Chocolate, vanilla, dried fruit aroma. Roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, vanilla, licorice. Warming, even a bit boozy, but not over the line. Huge, thick body, can¬ít remember anything being so full bodied. Very sweet with some bitterness. Oily, very complex, also smooth. After lots of beers at CBC certainly not easy to drink, but outstanding stuff.

July 2016 ¬ñ Rating #6000. Bottle share at Craft Beer Co Islington as ¬íThree Floyds Dark Lord¬í. Orange wax 2013 version. Many thanks indeed to Leighton for the Ratebeer bucketlister. Black, opaque with a foamy brown head. Aroma is molasses, some chocolate, demerara, coffee. Body is smooth, soft carbonation, oily. Taste is chocolate, coffee, plum, molasses, spicy with a touch of booze showing up but minimal considering the hefty ABV. A good beer without a doubt. Meaty sweet up front but improves the more you drink it ¬ñ or gets you drunk enough to overlook the sweetness. Either way, I like it. Probably consumed at the perfect age, I¬íd say. Old enough to gain some complexity and lose some sweetness, but young enough not to have any noticeable oxidation. Good. (3.9)
2014 bottle. Pours black. Aroma and taste are lots of sweetness, coffee, chocolate, and bourbon.
Bottle and tap, several times. Dark colour, sweet aroma, nice sweet vanilla flavour.

Pitc black with a beige head and lush oily viscousity. Aromas of roasted malts, coffee/espresso, alcohol drenched vanilla pods and some herbal impressions develop, surprisingly lean on the aroma side. Very fine perlage just enough to lift the palate with a smooth, creamy slick texture and a full body. Sweet, mouthcoating, with a light alcohol bitter stench developing being kept though in check by the sweetness. Lasting finish with a slight herbal spice burn. Potent.

Shared 2008 bomber with a black wax finish in July 2016.
Dark thick motor oil appearance with a fine light brown head.
Rich deep flavor with moderate-high sweetness.
Dark roasted grains and a modicum of hops kick in eventually in the aftertaste to cut the bitterness, leaving an excellent dark roasted grain flavor.
Like a Kylie Jenner Lip Kit this is all hype. Got a free bottle of 2016 wouldn¬ít buy or go through the carnival-application-ticketing-process. I had high hopes üëéüèª

DLD 2016. Gazing into the cup, I finally arrive at the end of my quest. Constant rain, cold, end less lines, porta johns, countless tasters of other lesser pretenders... Now at last the nectar of the gods... Or is it the other place?

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared at the CBC big bottle share. 7/7/2016. Huge thanks to Leighton for this one. Aroma is tangy plum, dark choc, berry, Warming alcohol, spicy woody, sweet brown sugars. 
 Flavour is composed of. Super sweet nutty choc, praline, toffee. Choc. Praline. Marshmallow. Palate is super sweet and sticky, . Too sweet.
Mooi z art, prima schuim. Chocola, klein beetje rook. Mondgevoel is perfect, dik, super! Smaakt ook erg lekker, sterk, beetje alcoholisch, zoet. Vol van smaak.

22oz bottle shared at the July London Tasting @CBC Islington. Many thanks to Leighton for this one. It pours a dark brown color with a small beige head. Aroma is sweet and bold with notes of vanilla, toffee, bold white chocolate. Taste is super sweet and lightly boozy with notes of vanilla, milk chocolate, light espresso and sugar. Medium to full bodied with light carbonation. Overall, massive and sweet

Bottle share. Big thanks to admin of the year Leighton. Pours black with a dirty tan head that dissipates to cling to the glass. Aroma is boozy molasses, bit of dried fruit. Taste is sweet fruit cake, bit of caramel and booze. It¬ís good but top 50?

Bottle.
Pours black with low beige head. Aroma is of molasses, malt, smoke. Taste is of molasses, umami, smoke, alcohol. Palate: Full bodied, soft carbonation. Overall: Good.

Tasting of the 2015 bottle. Pours totally black with a light brown head. Aroma is malt, licorice, prune, coffee, chocolate, and moderate roasty. Taste is high sweet leading to a roasty finish. I was worried I¬íd built it up too much in my head but it totally lived up to expectations! Brilliant.

Bottle, 2015. Opaque dark brown with a minimal head. Aromas of molasses, roasted malts, dark chocolate, dried fruits, brown sugar, alcohol. Full bodied with moderate carbonation. Thick and oily. Heavily sweet, medium bitter. Incredible complexity and flavor profiles. Incredibly heavy, Legendary beer.

Bottle, 650ml. Burgundy wax. A dark beer with no head. Aroma is of chocolate, alcohol, molasses and nuts. Robust bodied, creamy and with a sweet chocolate aftertaste. Surprinsinly not bitter. Very milky with flat carbonation and dried fruits at the end. A perfect sweet Imperial Stout.

Sampled at Mechazilla¬ís epic insanity tasting session. 2014 vintage. Obviously had very high expectations as a 3F fan. Rich syrupy body, lots of chocolate, vanilla, sweet coffee, unwelcome notes of soy sauce with a fishy edge, lingering sweet finish. Very happy for the tick but quite unimpressed, more thick of a sweet malt liquor than a beer...

Bouteille 650ml au Qu√©bec Ratebeer Gathering. Couleur noire opaque, mousse moka, huileuse. Ar√¥me de sauce soya, malt torr√©fi√©, caf√©, un peu fum√©. Go√ªt de malt torr√©fi√©, caf√©, sauce soya, sucr√©. Carbonatation faible, corps dense.

2014 Bottle with Herr Angstmann. Pours motor oil black with a quickly receding beige head leaving it to look like a cola. Aroma is up front molasses, brown sugar, and coffee. Taste follows accordingly with loads of molasses and coffee, with candied cherries, dark chocolate and toffee also making an appearance. Mouthfeel is wonderful. Super sweet but in a good way (for me). Had back-to-back with a Midnight Sun Bezerker. I prefer the Dark Lord but it was too sweet for Angstmann, with the tobacco-ish taste/texture of Bezerker providing a great counterpoint on two exceptional imperial stouts.

Just tons of molasses, coffee, malt, brown sugar and a bit of dark chocolate plus vanilla blended together in a bottle. Very sweet. Great mouthfeel. A fresh bottle is boozy and messy. It definitely improves after a couple years of aging. Anyway, awesome stout.

On tap at CBC 2016 - day 2. Pitch black with a thin tan head. Thick and rich flavor, with notes of caramel, cocoa, chocolate and vanilla. Very well balanced, though leaning a bit towards the sweet side. Definitely a world class stout.

Tap at Mikkeller Bar. Malty; Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, liquorice, dried fruits, melasse. The flavours starts heavy sweet but finish light bitter. Light alcoholic with roasted notes. The body is full and the texture is oily. Soft carbonation. Heavy and complex. Great

@Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2016, REDblack. Malty coffee beansdark chocolate. Intense flavour. Semi sweet, soft sweet soy. Malty porridge. Soft smooth. Really nice. Intense, sort of drinkable still.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone

duft: s√∏d dadler rosin m√∏rk sukker.
smag: s√∏d lidt rosin tung og fyldig. chokolade kakao vanilje s√∏dme meget s√∏d og varm eftersmag
CBC2016. Schwarze Farbe, mittelgro√üe br√§unliche Schaumkrone. S√º√ü r√∂stmalzig, Lakritze, Sirup. Geschmack sehr s√º√ü, Vanille, bourbon, Lakritze.

Tap @ CBC -16. jet black with a dense dark tanned head. rich roasty aroma with burnt sugars and molasses. leather and liqorice. taste is very sweet, chocolate, roasted malts and just abit of well hidden alcohol. Full body with a thick mouthfee. soft co2.
Tap@ CBC 2016 day 2. Pours black with a thick brown head. Dark chocolate, cocoa powder, plummy notes. Flavor has sweetness, roastedness, licorice, spicy notes, syrup. Overly sweet. Balanced.

2016, from tap, Tiefschwarz, fast Sirup, leichter brauner Schaum, schokoladige r√∂staromen in der Nase, mild im antrunk, relativ spritzig, cremig, sehr schokoladiger Geschmack, s√º√ü, massig, lecker, Alkohol gut verpackt, nur leichte bittere im Abgang

On tap At Mikkeller Bar. Pours black with short tan head. Aromas of dark chocolate, creamy coffee, vanilla, and sugary roasted malts. Flavors of sweetened dark chocolate, sugary coffee, and sweet molasses. Sweet and sticky. A bit messy but still very nice.

Bottle at a tasting in Portland-Oregon, many thanks to douglas88 for hosting and offering. 2010 vintage. Dark brown/black pour with ruby highlights, no head at all. Nose: top leather blast, post brewing malt mash, malt leftovers, a bit smoky. Mouth: boiled milk with cocoa powder, in perceivable ABV, little chili chocolate silky finish. Top beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2014 blue wax bottle shared at Mechazilla event. Deep, oily evil black pour with a small tan head that lingers. Sour plum and prune, blackstrap molasses, soy sauce with lots of treacle notes and a bit of marshmallow. Sticky and syrupy on the palate with more of a sorghum or molasses feel. Sweet and with lots of umami notes. The cacao is there but it feels more wine-like...almost like single origin cacao with that berry nuance. Finish has more soy sauce and winey berry notes under the chocolate. Not bad, but not really my kind of impy. Really happy for the chance to try this monster though.

2009 White Wax shared with JB. Pours opaque black. Dark brown quickly fading head. Nose is dark candied fruit, caramel, molasses, figs, and hints of spice. Flavour is complex dark malts, toffee, vanilla, cloves, dark chocolate, and dark dried fruit. It's amazing that even after 7 years the sweetness is still balanced by lively hops. Mouthfeel is medium. Smooth on the palate. One of the best beers I've ever had.

Bottled 2016. Pours dark black. Has a huge taste. Crazy caramel and chocolate taste. Small coffee taste. This beer is super sweet fresh. Holy moly it¬ís sweet. Awesome stout. Needs a little age on it to mature the complexity in which I know this beer has.

Shared 2016 bomber with sparkled, charcoal wax covering the cap, courtesy of "Fn" Cramer, poured to snifters displaying a clear, ruby highlighted, darkest brown color, with a modest layer of brownish tan head froth that left a clingy coating of leggy & foamy spots on the glass. The nose was mocha notes, caramel & treacle sweetness, a touch of vanilla, dark fruit, some vinous nature, and ready alcohol. The taste was similar notes, medium+ bodied, sticky & syrupy textured, with low carbonation, a touch of tartness, obvious booze, and a presence that was too sweet, and a bit thinner than I remember to be totally enjoyable for me. Needed more hop bite as some past offerings. Participated in many DL tastings, verticals, and attended a number of mind numbing DL days in the past, so maybe this wasn¬ít the year to finally break down and review this iconic brew?

2015 edition. Aroma of dark chocolate, cocoa & coffee, spiced by the high alcohol. Black with low dark brown head. Lightly sweet & spicy taste. Full bodied, oily texture & soft carbonation. Very smooth & very long finish.

2014 bottle. Thick and sludgy black liquid topped with a thin brown covering of foam. Nose of fudge brownies, BBQ sauce, smoke and molasses. Maybe some faint hops too? Taste is definitely quite sweet but not as much as I¬íd feared. Rich and thick mouthfeel. There isn¬ít really enough going on for me. Expected some more from it.

Syrupy sweet and touch of soy sauce. Super sticky sweet like a barley wine, raisiny with touch of roast character. Not what I expected. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

We had an evening of darkness devouring the 2011, 2014 and 2015 (all waxed in demon blood). I¬ím surprised how delicate and easy to drink they are. The base is red wine with a hint of raisin in the darkness. Not at all the "in yo face!" that one would expect from a dark lord, but rather smooth and sophisticated. The 2011 won being the smoothest and most unordinary but the 2015 was possibly a bit better then the 2014. I never before experienced alcohol this well hidden. -- Instagram Beer.Nerd.Malmo

Thick black pour with a thin but crema like head. roasty, smoky, coffee, maybe a little licorice. Taste is a big oily sweet bomb. Molasses, roast, coffee, chocolate and a little licorice and vanilla. No alcohol hit, it is just beautifully balanced. Worth the pursuit of a bottle.
Tachada de la lista. Gran resultado y no lo ten√≠a f√°cil, el mito era muy grande... Amor de un d√≠a pero que deja huella. Era una 2014.
22oz bottle of 2014 release. Viscous and silky smooth texture. Raisins and plums. Overly sweet.
2011 bottle. So smooth! Pours thick black with no head. Nose is coffee, dark fruit. Taste is similar. Some coffee. Can¬ít get over how smooth this was.

Rating #6200. Bottleshare for Mr. Mitch Ermatinger¬ís last day in Denver. Deep inky black with a thin rocky light tan head. Lovely sumptuous nose of boozy brownie batter, roasty chocolaty and port wine with coffee malt. Mellow alcohol burn with a thick roasty character, brownie batter with marshmallows, thick biscuity boozy roast malt, mellow dark chocolate and booze finish. Quite thick and monstrous. Big sweetness. Desert like and roasty.

66 cl bottle @ home (2014 vintage). Pours black with a tiny tan head that leaves no lacing. Aroma and flavour are roasted malt, chocolate, molasses, liquorice, and dried fruit - with a bitter and slightly alcoholic finish.

Poured from bottle thanks Willrunforbeer red wax 2012. Dark chocolate pour with a thin lacey tan head. Aromas of coffee caramel vanilla and chocolate. Taste is sweet and smooth but somewhat flat with a hint of oxidation. Still a great beer but needed to be opened last year.

Red wax 2012 bomber in honor of the new Star Wars movie. Pours dark brown with a ring of beige. Aroma is dark chocolate, licorice, dark coffee. Flavors are a bit sweet.., caramel, chocolate, raisin, wet cardboard, coffee. Flat and a bit oxidized. I held this too long.

Bottle share, 2015 version, purple wax. I was thinking this would be over-rated, but I was wrong. Really enjoyed it. Poured a deep dark black, medium foamy tan head. Aromas of sweet malts, coffee, vanilla, caramel, chocolate. Flavor had a pepper bite, coffee, vanilla, chocolate, roast nuts, and caramel. Very smooth and well-balanced. Full body, thick oily texture, good carbonation, and a very easy finish for such a big beer. I didn¬ít get much alcohol either so that was hidden well. Very nice.

2011 vintage. Finally getting a chance to try this. Cheers for the trade, Clint! The mouthfeel lives up to the reputation -- it¬ís so thick and viscous that it feels almost like a tasty beer syrup. The flavor was the real surprise and let down. Lots of caramel malts (and possibly sugar / molasses), but close to no perceptible roasted or chocolate malt. It tastes like a solid barleywine, but it lacks a number important characteristics of a stout.

Pours black with a very thin nougat colored head. Complex aroma; smokey, molasses, chocolate, some toffee, vanilla, coffee a touch of of dried fruits and bourbon notes. Flavours; sweet and smokey, chocolate, vanilla, roasted malt, some coffee, molasses and some dried fruits underneath in the taste palette. A good and complex imperial stout.
A: Pitch black, no head with a thin lacing N: Plum, coffee, cocoa, hint of smoke, bbq T: Molasses, hickory, dates, bbq sauce, plum O: Very sweet, extremly complex! Loads of flavours!
so many layers, so many levels. incredible imperial stout. fulfilling density, balanced aroma with different layers and flavors. overall a great beer.

Tadah. Poured from a bottle it is dark dark brown with a slight head. The aroma is wonderful and luscious Lovely smells of bourbon and coffee and the taste is amazingly. Smooth and creamy and absolutely delicious. It finishes with a sweet bourbon flavor.

Bottle shared. Red wax 2012. Pours pitch black, thick, dark brown head. Aroma is huge chocolate, molasses, roast, toffee and some vanilla. Taste is very sweet. Thick, cloying, oily mouthfeel. Very sugary. Really good. Very full bodied, a real sipper. Long, fruity, sweet finish and hardly any carbonation.

Bottle @ bells 30th, huge chocolate and roasted malts on the aroma.. taste is chocolate, molasses, soy sauce, and smoke. Coats the mouth and lingers for a while. Very nice glad I finally got to try it!
Thick as hell. Very good. Molasses. Roast. Moscovado. √Ålcool. Very goodtt brown head. Great finish. Bottle to share

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2016 I finally took up the courage to dig out this bottle from my cellar: the famous Dark Lord. Must have been one of the first (deliberately) hyped craft beers, but being European, not having obtained it from Dark Lord Day which is apparently the only day per year on which it is sold, and not being too susceptible to hypes, I will try to rate this without prejudice. Rating concerns the blue-waxed 2014 edition. Pours ink black and visibly viscous yet burgundy on the edges, leaving deep yellow, oily stains on the walls of the glass, with a dark reddish beige, very loose head forming only with some forcing, sparkling and crackling but almost instantly dissolving, much like the head on Coca-Cola; all that is left in a matter of instants, are some small, loose, unstructured bubbles on the edges, cautiously escaping from the unfathomable darkness beneath. The very last remnants of the bottle consist of patches of muddy proteins and, likely, unfermented molasses...  As for the aroma, the ¬ísmoke¬í hung around in the neck of the bottle upon opening and by inhaling it, I already caught a glimpse of the sheer intensity of this beer. Putting my nose in the sherry glass in which I poured it, makes me fall passionately in love with this beer immediately - all the burdens of every day life are forgotten, this is utter beer heaven: a deep, rich, extremely complex and seductive tapestry of the purest quality chocolate, both dark and milk, vanilla beans, Flemish red cabbage (a wee bit iron-like) cooked with brown sugar, candied cherries, molasses and dark rhum, fine coffee but rather subtle and peeping through the chocolate from time to time, treacle, slowly stewed beef and even whiffs of cured meat every now and then, toffee and ¬íHaagse hopjes¬í, leather, suggestions of marmelade, pipe tobacco, mocha ice cream, black peppercorns, chocolate liqueur, sweet hazelnut oil, cloves, cognac, pear syrup and a clear hint of teriyaki sauce - this is totally addictive, I cannot get enough of it. I cannot wait to take a small sip of this, and the taste is even more impressive than the aroma: a strong, enormously intense yet fine-tuned and noble candied sweetness opens this adventure in flavour, with all kinds of candied cherries, dates, peach, even oranges dancing among each other, kept in place by a very refined, tingling carbonation, almost of the same level as a coke which has been exposed to the air for a while, but providing a little bit of sourness to balance the big candied sweetness. After this friendly overture, I am plunged head first in an abyss of malts, layer upon layer of toffee, caramel, chocolate, even hints of toast, enriched with the deep, thick molasses sweetness and a strong presence of vanilla, which reveals itself retronasally in even more glory. The mouthfeel gets a bit of relief from the refined, gentle carbonation, but needless to say, is otherwise big and fat, syrupy, yet smooth and supple. The - aptly named - Dark Matter coffee remains something of a background presence: there certainly is a coffeeish flavour in the end, with a very pleasurable retronasal effect along with the vanilla, but it stays fairly modest in comparison with the gigantic ¬íchocolateness¬í which dominates the palate; roasted bitterness stays gentle as well. Maltiness squared best describes the finish: the lingering chocolate sweetness carries everything, and even manages to bring balance to the unavoidable glow of throat-warming, rhum- and liqueur-like alcohol which goes down deep into the chest. The balance does not quite succeed, and in this particular case, for once, this is a good thing: in a beer this sweet and sugary, the peppery, drying alcohol effect in the end prevents too much cloyingness, though the thick texture does coat the mouth and tongue for a long time after swallowing. A dim, earthy hop bitterishness resides in the deepest caverns of this demonic stout, while the vanilla and elegant coffee flavours haunt the nose cavity after swallowing. A meaty umami flavour accompanies this whole ¬íparcours¬í but it too remains subtle - it seems all the other flavours are afraid of this vast ocean of dark chocolate. Sorry to go all lyrical about this beer: I sometimes have that in really big imperial stouts. This one, to my taste, is worth the hype and worth every penny; I have been waiting to open this one and now that I did, I regret not possessing a second one for a dark and gloomy winter night, when this beer type - to my personal experience at least - truly comes into its own. Go out, wait for hours in line if necessary, but if you are into imperial stouts, you must do everything in your power to get a sip of this, this is simply divine. It has an almost unmeasurable complexity I have rarely seen, every time I sniff from it, I get different odours, one more endearing than the other, and it has an intensity of flavour rarely matched. Agreed, it has an intense chocolate and candied sweetness which sticks to the mouth cavity for a while, but the alcohol and the coffee provide enough balance for that.  I am very happy that I finally, after having read about this beer for years, had the chance to taste a bottle of this - heck, I could care less about the fact that the 15% ABV in a bomber of 65 cl will likely make me too drunk to taste other beers properly afterwards...  Still, even this iconic beer is not beyond criticism, and a more recent (2015) sample I had this year, was a little over the top in its umami-like ¬íbeefiness¬í - though still a beautiful beer - so my rating here is an average of both.
Version 2011. Bombe sucr√©e. Chocolat, caf√© et l√©g√®rement des fruits rouges. C¬íest excellent mais vaut elle vraiment tout le show ?
incrivel cerveja. muito doce numa garraga de 750 ml.compartilhada com amigos dificil toma la sozinho. incrivey

Bottle shared awhile ago. Poured into a small snifter. Deep brown, nearly black with a tan head. The aroma was solid with dark chocolate, sweet malts, caramel, vanilla beans, oak barrel and bourbon. The taste was sweet milk chocolate, carnation sweet milks, vanilla beans, chocolate chip cookie dough, and dark plums. Mostly balanced but it was very sweet and boozie. Not exactly smooth. Full body and chewy. I don¬ít get the hype but it is very good.
Huge beer al around. Big roasty malty aroma. Some subdued hops. Vanilla and licorice and alcohol all big and balanced. Thick rich mouthfeel. A sipper for sure.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2015 Sample at Great Taste of the Midwest. 2015 vintage. Aroma is sweet, very sweet malt with vanilla and chocolate. Appearance is black, thick, brown head. Taste is sweet malt, licorice, vanilla, soy, booze, great. Mouthfeel is thick, oily, great carbonation. Overall, finally got to try it and, while I don¬ít understand the hype, it was good nonetheless.

2010 Bottle. Pours deep, dark brown. Aroma is dark fruit, booze, vanilla, rich chocolate, and coffee. Flavor is extremely smooth chocolate with dark vinious fruit, barrel character, and light vanilla. Medium/full body.

This is the 2014 vintage. Black pour with almost no head. What head exists is a brown. The aroma is potent with alcohol, charred meat, smoke, coffee. The flavor is remarkably smooth. I¬ím really surprised how sweet this beer is. It¬ís much more drinkable than I was expecting. It packs a punch. It has a soy sauce and teriyaki vibe. Almost no aftertaste which is also surprising. It dies really quickly.

Originally reviewed 11/25/2011. 22 oz. bottle poured into a snifter. 2010 vintage. Standard stout appearance. Jet black. The small head is actually surprising, considering the ABV. The sugars are damn near visible as it streaks down the glass.
 Intense aromas. Coffee, chocolate, booze. The booze actually smells great, despite that it¬ís practically burning my nose. Fruity aromas as well. Not as roasty as I would expect.
 Tingly alcohol throughout the taste. Incredibly sweet. Coffee flavors and chocolate malts through the middle. Slightly bitter in the finish and an alcohol burn that lasts for a few moments. It¬ís a pretty complex flavor, but it¬ís immensely sweet.
Pretty well carbonated for a 15% stout. Pretty boozy, too, though. And the sweetness just makes it so hard to drink. Small quantities is the most I can muster with this thing.

My views on this beer have changed dramatically since originally trying it. It is what it is. Too sweet for me, but it¬ís something I would have enjoyed in my novice drinking years.

2008/Black Wax. From notes in 2010: 
Strong aromas of roast, bitter chocolate, coffee and toffee. Black, almost jet color and tan head that dissipated to lacing rather quickly. Flavor is right in stride with that aroma! Holy Hell!!! What an amazing impy stout.
UPDATED: DEC 23, 2015 2014 Vintage. Pitch black, Huge, I mean, enormous sweetness, chocolate, dried fruit and raisins. I goes surprisingly well, end even enjoyable, for a beer that massively sweet.

@Camping Ratebeer 2015, Blauwe wax editie. schenkt zwart met kaki kraag en goede plakkerige rand achterlatend. Aroma van gebrande en geroosterde mout, vanille, chocolade, koffie, siroop. Smaken zijn werkelijk enorm dik/romig, vanille, chocolade, volmoutig, zoethout, alcohol, zacht/romig, dik, donkere fruiten. enorm dik en zoet maar wel complex en lekker ! puur genietbier voor over de gehele avond...

2011 bottle from some dude at me roommates work. 
This pretty much drinks like a port. It¬ís so sweet it¬ís like... Woah. Pretty much imagine drinking a jug of molasses full of enough alcohol to fuel a drag racer... It¬ís pretty crazy...

Let¬ís put molasses in a beer they said... It¬ís interesting is what I say. I¬ím not sure if I¬íd put it in any of my beers unless I¬ím bored or drunk or both. That said it does taste unique and that¬ís pretty cool. I still like KBS or bourbon county stout better.

2012 bottle from cellar. Black thick liquid. Aroma is very rich full of sweet dark fruits, coffee , complex amazing and chocolate. Don¬ít k ow quite to describe it. Taste is sweet with nice raisin chocolate going on and complex flavours. amazing beer for beer day :). One of the better stouts I¬íve tasted and def. Best in a loooong time :).

Bottle, thanks Linden! Opaque deep mahogany, almost no head. Bright raspberry, vanilla, light spiciness, molasses. Quite sweet, earthy, light bitterness. Exceedingly long finish, fairly upfront alcohol, but very well balanced. Heavy body, fairly oily. Excellent.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2016 Had again in 2016.  Tried 2014 and 2015, thx Jandd1983!.........previous rating:  2014 vintage. Ummm amazing.  Lives up to hype.  Thx chris. Super sweet. Honey/molasses. Some raisens. A lot of chocolate. Lasts on the palate. Sticky. Coffee.  Coats glass.  Tasted at chris¬í ultimate bottle share.

Dark Lord 2015 drank June 27, 2015

Look - Not surprisingly the thickest, blackest looking beer I¬íve had. Thin head with aggressive pour. Tan head. No lacing.

Smell - Alcohol. Chocolate. Coffee. Raisins. Bacon.

Taste - Chocolate, tootsie roll, coffee hit hard followed by toffee and raisin. Alcohol is there but we¬íll balanced throughout. Raisin after taste.

Feel - Viscous. Heavy. Sticky but smooth.

Overall - My first Dark Lord. I¬íll make it a birthday tradition. The 15% is not as scary as I thought it would be.

2015 bottle, at home. Only black pour, nice brown head that fades to a lace. Aroma is light chocolate, coffee, smooth a bit of faint fruitiness. Taste is smooth chocolate, espresso, lightly sweet with a bit of chocolatey bitterness. Very smooth, hides the alcohol. Smooth body, thick and syrupy, medium carbonation. Very good.
Bottle - Pours dark black. Nose is sweet, chocolate, boozy, slight coffee. Taste is sweet, fudgy, lots of booze, dark fruits, slight anise.
UPDATED: SEP 1, 2015 re-rating 2015 bottle after 2012 one ..jet black big light brown head..aroma of coffee,booze,roasted nuts,cocoa..dry roasty,coffee,boozy flavor..very good..but overrated IMO.

Weekend bottle share, big chocolate and coffee aroma, taste is huge chocolate and hop profile, really nice

Brown bottle, 650 ml, 2011 vintage, trade with rfraga (thank you!), savoured on June 14 2015; eye: black, opaque, tiny ring of brown head, slight lacing; nose: roasted barley, molasses, slight burnt barley, slight spent grains, anise, light vanilla, light coffee; mouth: roasted barley, molasses, light burnt barley, anise, light vanilla, alcohol, alcohol warmth, light pepper, light bittering hops, light coffee, malt, malty finale with good presence of molasses, medium body, slightly below-average carbonation, mildly sweet, silky texture; overall: quite good

Bouteille brune, 650 ml, mill√©sime 2011, √©change avec rfraga (thank you!), savour√©e le 14 juin 2015; ¬úil : noire, opaque, petit anneau de mousse brune, tr√®s l√©g√®re dentelle; nez : orge torr√©fi√©e, m√©lasse, tr√®s l√©ger orge br√ªl√©e, tr√®s l√©ger dr√®che, anis, l√©ger vanille, l√©ger caf√©; bouche : orge torr√©fi√©e, m√©lasse, l√©ger orge br√ªl√©e, anis, l√©ger vanille, alcool, chaleur d¬íalcool, l√©ger poivre, l√©ger houblon am√©risant, l√©ger caf√©, malt, finale malt√©e avec bonne pr√©sence de m√©lasse, corps moyen, carbonatation un peu sous la moyenne, moyennement sucr√©e, texture soyeuse; en r√©sum√© : bien bon
Black color. Vanilla, dark fruits, roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. SLightly bitter aftertaste, but sweetness dominates. A bit overrated.
One of the few stouts I enjoy. Very thick and very sweet. Has a definite taste of raisins. A must have if you¬íre a craft beer lover.

2011: Molasses, horehound, soy sauce, charred oak, walnut nose. Black, headless. Very sweet molasses and soy sauce, walnut also present but in a much lesser degree. Earthier upon warming. Full body, easy carbonation. Well....this was a beer I never thought I¬íd get to try. It¬ís likely more expensive than I¬ím willing to pay and not a style I seek out specifically. Still it¬ís considered one of the best beers in the world. Luck smiled upon me and I find myself with a bottle. How disappointed I am! Maybe it has been cellared too long but this was a cloying mess. It¬ís not as boozy as I feared, and it has tons of complexity, but it¬ís far too sweet for my tastes, devoid of balance. Maybe it¬ís better fresh, but thios didn¬ít do it for me. My rating is generous.

2015 burgundy wax. Gift from a guy at work who¬ís wife got him 9 btls at brewery. Pours thick as any with fluffy, 1 inch, dark brown head. Aroma is roasted barley, soy sauce, alcohol esters. Flavor hits you with sweetness off the bat. A little rich and toasty flavors sneak through but sweetness dominates. As the sweetness fades, the caramel and molasses come through with a little chocolate and coffee aftertaste. Very big and very sweet. Hard to rate palatability high. A great novelty and must try.

Draught sample at CBC 2015. Pitch black with a thin, tanned head. Roasted aroma with rich, dark malts: Chocolate, coffee, caramel, vanilla, bourbon barrel, licorice and molasses. Taste is sweet, very rich. Full body with a thick texture and a soft carbonation. Finishes long lasting sweet-roasted with rich, dark malts, vanilla and coffee. Subtle warmth from the booze. Excellent Stout, very American, very vulgar, very rich. Maybe even too much of a good thing?

Wow! Tasted the 2015 bottle. Huge aroma of chocolate, vanilla, dark fruits, coffee. Taste is moderate to heavily sweet with mild to moderate bitterness. Oily and syrupy mouthfeel. Very complex. Lots of dark fruits. Prunes, plums and other stone dark fruits with lots of coffee and chocolate. A little vanilla and caramel. Incredible beer. Probably my all time favorite imperial stout. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Blue wax bottle from mikkeller shop. Pours a heavy black with tan head. Nose is loaded with fruit, coffee, bourbon. Very thick sweet syrupy mouthfeel. Taste is coffee, vanilla, bourbon, chocolate and finishes very sweet. My only knock is it¬ís just a bit too sweet for me. Cracker beer and if you get the chance it¬ís a great beer to share with a mate or two (I chose not to share)

Tap at CBC 2015, Copenhagen. Originally rated 20150501. Colour is black with very small brownish white head. Aromas and flavours: Sweetness, some bourbon, coffee, hints of chocolate and roasted malts.

@yellow cbc 2015
wood, vanilla, full body, mid bitterness. extemly sweet. overly sweet.

May 8, 2015 - shared a bottle of 2011 Dark Lord. This ones been aging for four years. Pours a deep black, very thick, small brown head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, some vanilla, molasses. Taste is very sweet, not boozy at all. Creamy finish. More sweet than I expected...I can see why the barrel aged stuff is higher. But this is still a phenomenal beer. Glad to finally try one.

Tap cbc15. Pours a beautiful all black thick with one finger everlasting crazy head. Aroma is sweet, roasty malts, dark fruits, fruity, vanilla and milk chocolate. Taste is heavy sweet, barley, malt, brown sugar, vanilla loads of chocolate and some toffee. Subtle sweet bacon in there! Sweet berries, dates. No presence of ABV, full body.
Tap @CBC15. Black with brown head. Roasted malt and syrupy booze aroma. Flavour is syrupy sweet with licorice and coffee. Thick and sticky, just the way I like it.
Thx you friendly Americans at CBC 2015. Black with low Brown head. Alcochol. Sweet(Very Sweet) Roast, chocolate, cocoa, licorie Carbonation is low. Alcochol. Sweet, Full body. I did expect more

Black and roasty. Sweet and full body with a taste of roasted malts, dark chocolate, coffee, molasses, licorice and a bit of vanilla. I¬íve now had this one 3-4 times over the past year and there¬ís not doubt it¬ís really good. Grossly overrated but a solid beer nevertheless. I¬íve rated it slightly under the vanilla version but I may have rated that one a bit too high though.

01-MAY-2015, draft @yellow session @CBC15.
Black with low Brown head.
Roast, chocolate, cocoa. Carbonation is more lively than I expected. Some alcochol. Sweet, very full body. This is wonderfull.

Few awesome things have a perfect run. The 2012 version of Dark Lord is known as the least successful vintages in Three Floyds¬í awesome lineup. Perfect or not, though, this is still motherlovin¬í Dark Lord. Having the chance to drink one is an amazing experience, no matter the year. It poured pitch black and virtually headless. Aroma was very fruity with cherry, apple, and syrup. Flavor has a lot of sweetness, and yes, sad to say that apple juice flavor dominates the whole thing. However, there were some touches of cream and toasted dark fruit. Mouthfeel was exceptionally smooth. While I definitely want to try a better vintage, having the "worst" Dark Lord is akin to listening to the "worst" Beatles album. It¬ís still enjoyable and better than a hell of lot else of what¬ís out there.

(Thanks Josh, "StFun")

Bottle.

A- Green apples, dark fruits, chocolate.

A- Black color, black liquid, minimal brown head.

T- Green apples, red apples, dark fruits, chocolate, sweet.

P- Full body, average texture, average carbonation, sweet finish.

O- Damn. My holy grail beer since I got into craft and I finally get a bottle, a 2012/red wax to be exact and it was hit with acetaldehyde, tons of green apple in here. So much for it being the best beer I¬íve ever got to try. It certainly wasn¬ít pitiful. A green apple tasting stout makes for an interesting drink. I researched a bit and found out that in fact the 2012 bottling had this issue. Oh well, still got to finally try DL! Maybe the next time it¬íll be a better bottle. Still getting a solid rating from me, although probably not what it could be. Did I mention I finally got to try a Dark Lord!?
UPDATED: JUL 18, 2015 Pretty good. Had a 2010 bottle today. Most the 3 floyds stuff I have had so far hasn¬ít been great but this was.

Still too sweet but better than previous years.

Pours black with brown foam. Sweet. Coffee, chocolate, roasted character. Smooth and good balance.

On tap at CBC- K√∏benhavn. Pitch black color, good brownish foam. High aroma intensity ; roasted, licorice, leather, malt. Full body & high complexity . Some sweetness- then some bitterness, ends up a little on the sweet side. Very enjoyable

Braved the rain this year at Dark Lord Day to get my hands on an allotment of Dark Lord. Pours pitch black with a nice mocha head. Aroma is heavy in chocolate, dates, cherries, and prunes with some slight roasted malt, coffee, and black liquorice notes. Taste is really sweet for an imperial stout, a little dry and an almost imperceptible bitter bite in the finish. Full bodied, good carbonation, and thick and creamy on the palate. Quite unique for an imperial stout and overall pretty close to perfection.

-bottle, mikkeller bar. Thanks Daniel!!!- Black with brown head. Sweet aroma of brown sugar, molasses, caramel, chocolate and vanilla. Super slick and complex palate. Sweet finish. Overall: Very enjoyable. Great sweetness. Hides the ABV well.

Tap at Mikkeller bar.Pitch black colour with small beige head.Aroma is vinious and sweet with mild vanilla note even wood dark roasted coffee and bourbon flavor as well smooth and oily with good full body.Still ther is better stouts then this one.

2015 on tap. Black. Nice tan head. Great sweet chocolate, coffee nose. Full creamy body. Tastes of dark chocolate with a mild coffee profile and the slightest note of dry hopping to balance it out. Very solid.

2015 on tap. Aroma of brownie batter. Appears like coffee with caramel foam and lace. Tastes very sweet of milk chocolate and biiter coffee grounds. Mellow fizziness. Overall, needs to be aged 1-2 years, but very good.

2010 bottle shared with my Girls Pint Out chapter. I¬íve had this every year since 2009, and I somehow forgot to rate it. Dark fruit, chocolate, coffee, molasses, and vanilla aroma. Black, viscous with a small tan head. Dark fruit, , molasses, coffee, chocolate, anise, roasty malt, and vanilla flavor. Full silky body, soft carbonation. Very rich and complex. I drank some in 2010, and it cellared beautifully. It¬ís much smoother and the flavors have melded and become more complex.

Dark lord ¬í11 vintage

Many thanks to Kevin for providing the bottle.

Pours a viscous, black color, with a decent, fizzy head.

Exhibits an intriguing nose between bakers chocolate, molasses, toffee, toasted malts and marmelade among a warming alcohol presence. The chocolate aromas are incredible rich on the nose, with all other flavors illustrating it, and chocolate being easily the most dominant ingedient of the beer. The aromas promise a sweeter, complex beer, leaning on toffee, caramel, dried fruits and cane sugar, against charred malts and cold, black coffee. 

The beer provides an incredible smooth mouthfeel, revealing its intriguing depth.

Tastes of milk chocolate and earthy toffee, both flavors building the luscious foundation of the beer. Cold pressed coffee acts as a counterpart to the sweeter ingedients, effectivly supported by charred malts and a note of tobacco. On top of that settles a decadent amount of molasses, coating up the other flavors of the beer. During the finish a warm alcohol burn supports the sweet chocolate, providing a rich taste of alcoholic, glazed and earthy pralines.

The beer reveals an incredible depth of flavors, which convince, based on the interplay between chocolate and cold coffee, accompanied by carbonized, earthy malts, setting the balance of the brew. The beer ends just the way it started - sweet, while its middlepart lends a huge amount of bitterness and dryness to the taste, handling its sweeter aspects in a very convincing way, while dried fruits act as a hot peak to the taste. It drinks dangerously easy, no alcohol is detectable at any stage.

650ml bottle enjoyed @ home, 2014 bottle. Pours black with a tiny tan head. Aroma is sweet and light roasted malt, molasses, raisins, hint of cherries, coffee, some alcohol. Flavour is very sweet balancing just on the edge too overly sweet. Full bodied, oily texture. Very soft carbonation. Finish is complex and well balanced sweetness.

Poured very dark black, with a two finger brown head that receded to a quarter inch thick foam, great lacing. Aroma was coffee, dark roast malt and licorice. The dark roast malts really stood forward in the flavor, with some coffee, dark fruits, and alcohol. The mouthfeel was thick and creamy smooth - very nice. Overall, TF hardly ever disappoints, and this beer is no exception.

750ml bottle, v2014, at the Hoppy Pub, Thessaloniki, courtesy of skullgeorge. Black color with beige head. Aroma is malty, roasted, quite fruity - dark dried fruits and chocolate, brandy-like alcohol, caramel and light vanilla. Heavy sweet and light bitter taste, chocolate and fruity like aroma. Full sticky body with flat to to soft carbonation.

It's been more than a few years since last having a taste. It's heavy molasses hung on the back of my tongue. Initially, I was not blown away but the more I sipped the more I wanted. Would have loved to have tried it cellared for a year or 2. Now if only I could trade for a bottle...

2009; The aroma is malt, coffee, figs, vanilla and roasty. Pours Black with basically no head. The taste is bitter. The body is full, the texture creamy, the carbonation lively and the finish bitter. OK Wow this is really good! The years haven¬ít hurt it any, in fact probably helped. Lots of flavor no alcohol. Glad I have more of this aging!
From a shared 2014 bomber in a taster glass. Flavor is sweet, slightly chocolatey, malty, slightly fruity, moderate alcohol burn. Quite good and well balanced. Don¬ít understand the hype, but good.

Bottle at a big tasting (N√∂rprovning 2015). We tried the 2008, 2009 and 2010 versions. The 2010 was the best so I used the score from that beer. The 2008 and 2009 was much sweeter then the 2010. 2008 was the most roasted. Dark malty and nutty smell with some roasted sugar. Sweet taste with roasted sugar, dark malts, roasted sugar. Awsome beer!

Bottle received from elyts_dlo, cheers! Pours a deep motor-oil black with a slight brown head. Aroma is vanilla and cocoa. Taste is vanilla, milk chocolate and slight cloying caramel. Full bodied with a silky texture.

Bottle ¬í13, tasted side by side with Huna and Darkness. Pitch black with a tan head. Nose is sweet, vanilla and milk chocolate. Taste is sugary, syrup, oily, vanilla, milk chocolate and some caramel. A bit too sweet and cloying but still solid!

2013 version on draft at Dark Lord Day 2014. Dark, mostly opaque brown with bet limited khaki head. Aroma is vanilla, bourbon, dark fruit, and coffee. Very sticky though somewhat thin for an RIS. Taste is vanilla, light coffee and oyster sauce. Very good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A- bam. Pours a syrupy deep cola brown with thin ring of medium khaki head and no lacing. S- just mince meat, rhubarb and soy sauce. Some middling chocolate and figs. A little charcoal, and soil. M- full body with a strong oily character. T- so cloying. Chocolate covered cherries, port, Terry's milk chocolate orange, vinegar tang and lemon. Raisins, grasses and a meatiness in the middle. Ending is dry and efficient with some lingering plastic chocolate candies, toffee, molasses, caramel and hops.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2015 Blue wax 2014 poured into a taster glass. No head despite a very aggressive pour. Seems to be black, oil, and light bodied. 

The nose shows mostly soy sauce and very faint hints of sweet malts. 

The palate on this is where it begins. It¬ís probably the most oily and slick bodied stout I¬íve ever tried. Very full bodied and smooth. The 15% alcohol is definitely apparently as it gives it a lot of heat akin to chili. There is a raisin/port wine-like sweetness and ends on a strong coffee/espresso note of bitterness. A lot of people complain about the sweetness but if you chill it well, it¬íll numb your tongue enough not to notice. Personally, I don¬ít find it cloying at all. This has to be tried at least once!
2013. Finally got to try this. Nose is of dark fruit, like chocolate, a bit of anise and sherry notes. Taste is much the same but it¬ís a bit too sweet. Perhaps better when fresh. Meh.
Bottle 2012 vintage. Had alongside a german chocolate cake, which I would highly recommend. Deep chocolate flavor, thick viscous pour, great nose. Worth all the hype.
redwax 2010---Not too complex, oily, a lot of (portish) sweetness, chocolate, liquorice, alcoholic, light roasted and no bitterness anymore.

2009 bottle. Enjoyed 12/31/14. Pours like oil with nearly no lasting head. Aroma has awesome, slightly sweet notes of caramel, roasted malts, mild dark fruits, chocolate, nuts, and a slight creamyness. Taste is sweet with roasted malts, caramel, chocolate, and sweet cherries. Full body with a low carbonation. Creamy smooth texture with nearly no carbonation and no trace of alcohol. Overall awesome.

Served from 22oz red waxed ¬í12 bottle. Served in Teku. 

Aroma -- sweet cherry, oak-like aroma unlike other Imperial Stouts I¬íve encountered. Rightfully so, the aroma of this beer, unlike many other world-class beers, is one of the most unique attributes of this beer. It should be admired for its magnificence. 

Appearance -- possesses the consistency of an oil well: abysmal, hellish, beyond the cusp of foreboding darkness. 

Taste -- true full-bodied, pleasantly deep, Imperial Stout that engulfs your palate and pushes you to the limit, Ross. Booziness has died down, still 15%+, nonetheless.. Subtle burnt char-like, smokiness after you have had many sips. I would not consider the beer smokey, though, by any means (i.e., I have a hard time appreciating smokiness in beer; the smokiness that is present in DL ¬í12 is enjoyable for any IRS lover).

Palate -- encourages your palate to step its game up and appreciate the uniqueness of this remarkable concoction.

Overall -- Dark Lord is not the greatest Imperial Stout ever made; nonetheless, it surely stands in a category of its own: pure damnation, emboldening me to set my own substantial precedent. Merry Christmas, Ratebeer lovers.
user_location: The Garden of the Beer Gods, North Carolina, USA

text: 2011 batch consumed 10 Aug 14 - Gift bottle from Eric K: Breakfast in the infield of Watkins Glen. Luscious, viscous pour, wisp of a head. The palate twists and turns befit the road course setting. Nothing I¬íd change.

ok, so i just noticed now that i never reviewed this even though i drank an entire bottle out of the bottle myself at the very very end of RBSG 2010. Most of this got crushed as me and some other drunks stumbled towards the hotel from the Grand Tasting venue across from Founders. Drinking on the street was never better. I should have wrapped it up in a brown paper bag. Beer was blackish but maybe that had to do with the lack of real good street lights. You know it was fucking tasty as all get out but I became more focused on not being found in a dumpster in the morning. Staying awake for the next 30 hours didn¬ít turn out to be the best idea I¬íve had but those automatic flushing toilets in the Chicago airport made it all worthwhile.
2014 bottle. Thick motor oil black pour. Heavy black licorice smell. Very sweet plum tasting. Wow is there a lot of flavor. Lots of fruity taste and sweet licorice taste.

2011 vintage bottle shared at RichTheVillan¬ís, 27/11/13. Pours black, tan head recedes. Huge sweet nose of booze, roast, stone fruit, chocolate and dark sugar. Tastes sweet with notes of cherry, vanilla, roast malt, some coffee and chocolate. Extremely sweet, too much so for me. Complex stout, no doubt, but if it¬ís still that sweet after 2 years will it ever dry out?
Sample from Bottle - black pour with thin beige head. Roasted malty aroma and taste, some lovely sweet notes, chocolate, coffee, caramel, vanilla, wow this is good.

22oz bottles all vintages pour a oily dark black with almost zero head. All are extremely sweet with the following differences in each vintage
2009- soy sauce
2010- vanilla 
2011- chocolate 
2012- dark cherries
2013- coffee 
2014- very sweet malt and molasses
2011 bottle shared at Darkness day. Pours dark brown with minimal head. Strong chocolate and sweet smell. Taste slight smoke with sweet toffee and caramel. Really easy to drink. Amazing beer!

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2015 Bottle from a trade. Many thanks artmcd8! Vintage 2014. Oily syrupy texture. Black, almost no foam. Aroma of sweet molasses, sweet brown chocolate, sticky toffee pudding, caramel and vanilla. Very sweet, boozy and sticky. This is not a good stout. Overly sweet without complexity. Impossible to drink a lot of this, so with the rest of the bottle we made a cake, which was very good with Dark Lord as ingredient.

Orange wax 2013, bottle into glass
A - dark black with thick brown head
A - sweet, chocolate, molasses, fruit bread
T - Very sweet delicious stout, some coffee and chocolate, vanilla, red fruits
P - smooth, not very complex
O - delicious liquid dessert, a little sweeter than I like but still quite amazing

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2014 600ml bottle served in a snifter glass.
I¬íve bought this one at one of my last visits to California, in 2010. This is the 2010 Edition which can be recognized by the green wax on the bottle neck.
A: Pours a black color forming a small and bubbled tan head. Low retention and only few lacings left in the glass
S: Strong roasted malts, dark chocolate, dark fruits and wood. Excellent! Licorice and vanilla to compose. A bit boozy in the end
T: Sweet and roasted upfront. Notes of dark chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, oak, licorice, vanilla and dark fruits. Cherry notes. Complex. Maybe a bit too sweet and too booze in the end
M: Heavy, creamy and molasses body. Low carbonation. Smooth with a bittersweet and roasted and woody aftertaste
O: Great drinkability. A masterpiece. Worth the three years that I¬íve wait to drink it
[ BA Review @ 7/24/2013 ]
Various bottles at Craig¬ís - 07, 09, 11, thank you! Coffee, chocolate, liquorice, sweet and rich. 2011 slightly edged the other 2.

22oz bottle ( 2013) in a teku. Pours black with a lacy, beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, some chocolate and coffee, light vanilla, some molasses, and some dough. Flavor the same with a lot of dark malts and coffee and chocolate. Smooth, thick texture. A really good beer - not getting too much soy sauce like a lot of people said, and the alcohol was well hidden.

"09 release...obviously pours jet black, with a better than expected (but quickly disappating) dark brown head. the aroma is a little on the sweet side, but way complex. chocolate soaked cherries, wood, molasses, brown sugar. some alcohol present too. body is thick and smooth, but not cloying. feel is awesome...coating and warming at the same time, without being hot. like a toned down World Wide. flavor is awesome. lots of the same qualities of the aroma, but they work better in the flavor. a little charred flavor as well. very wine/port like. overall, an awesome beer. worth the price and hype? yes and no...probably more no. Not when World Wide is similar (though not the same) at about $8 a bottle, and other great RISs are out there for way way less. Glad we tried it the once. MAYBE i¬íll revisit an aged bottle in the future. 11/11 - 2009-2010-2011 vertical: 2010 was amazing, maybe even a 4.7, while the aroma was just a touch behind on the newer 2011 (though the cofee presence was more obvious and very nice), and the 2009, while still great, is just starting to fade a little and become excessively sweet...but only when in comparison to the nearly perfect 2010 batch."

2014 version.  Pours black with very little head. Aroma is of dark fruits, roasted malt. Taste is strong but nice. There?s a bit of a saccharin taste at first with some dark fruits. Not as good as Bona Fide but darn good.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2015 Tasting of 2012 edition. Aroma of soy sauce and molasses, taste is soy sauce, molasses, chocolate, coffee, sweet and very sticky, alcohol hidden extremely well, no head, no carbonation, motor oil pour. Glad to have tried but not worth the hype in my opinion. 4.2
Tasting of 2013 edition> Aroma of lots of coffee, sweet molasses, taste is dark chocolate, sweet coffee, lots of sugar, super sticky mouthfeel, no alcohol present, taste at DLD 2015. 4.5

Aroma of sweet molasses, booze, and coffee. Pours dark and thick without much head. Very viscous mouthfeel. Hugely sweet with flavors of molasses, oak, licorice, coffee, and light hops. Very sweet, but very good. Probably awesome with vanilla ice cream.
Intensely huge...so good chocolate and roast with rich fruity esters and caramel. Flavors matched with rich caramel and roast and prune. Alcohol warmth was fantastic. Sucha great big brew

Vertical tasting of 2006-2008.Average rating above. Poured deep dark brown with no head. Aroma is increasingly vinous with age, dark, alcohol soaked fruit, fudge, dark chocolate some coffee. Full body, flavour as the aroma, generally smooth, 07 drier. Dry, sweet end.

Blue wax. Interesting soy sauce, chocolate, malty, metallic aroma. Long lasting brown head, a lot of effervescence. Completely black, but redish when observed under light. Complex and smooth flavor, amazingly well balanced and deceptive in alcohol content for it¬ís ABV. Upfront a sweetness/soy character, with molasses and sweet malt coming through later on and a very mild, sweet, roasty finish. Not much coffee evident, interestingly. Thick bodied and average carbonation. A great imperial stout. although may be slightly too hyped for it¬ís own good -- would be interested to see how this one holds up with age. Grateful that I got to try this beer though!

Horizontal with some other whales: Dark Lord ¬í12, Darkness ¬í13, Cinnamon Roll¬íd Wake ¬ín Bake ¬í13, Hunahpu ¬í14 -- Poured into a snifter sampler. This beer was incredibly tasty, super sweet, and it completely masks the alcohol. Very impressive beer, and one I am very happy to cross off my list.

Catching up on RBAG 2014 notes backlog...bottle sent to me by northropfrye-- thanks Andrew! Orange wax, 2013 vintage. Incredible viscous pour, motor-oil-thick, with a slow to rise dark brown head. Densely malty, sticky sweet and chewy, loads of residual sugars but the dark malts keep me interested and happy. I was prepared for a syrupy mess, but even though this is definitely over-the-top and incredibly unbalanced, I still loved it! It¬ís like a stack of thick hot syrup-soaked pancakes-- a hot sugary mess that you can¬ít help but love!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
22oz bottle - 2014 - pours black with thick tan head . Huge vanilla and coffee aromas with a bit of alcohol burn . Taste is smooth cocoa , vanilla , coffee and hints of molasses . Outstanding beer . Always enjoy this one . 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

FINALLY! thank you GothGargoyle!

2010 bottle. Very dark brown, with a light edging. Aroma of sweet cocoa, espresso, vanilla, plum. Taste is vanilla ice cream sweet, and molasses coffee bitterness. Palate is initially refreshing, but develops to a creamy, sticky dry finish.
Bottle. Pour is dark as night. Aroma is cocoa. Malty. Taste is caramel malt. Toasty. Chocolate. Not boozy at all. Chocolate heavy. Very nice imperial. Well done.

Transfer from BA review on 1-1-13- 

 Poured from a 2010 bottle into a snifter glass

 I have been saving this one for quite some time. I have had years prior as well as this vintage a year prior. This is my first review of it however. I have always enjoyed drinking this quite robust and thick brew. This is the last of my bottles and I thought it appropriate to drink on occasion of the new year. 

 Appearance ¬ñ Pours a nearly pitch black color with a tiny tan head. The head fades very fast leaving almost no lacing. Upon swirling, the thickness and huge body of the beer can be seen with it clinging to the sides of the glass and it slowly receding back to the pool of beer at the bottom of the snifter.

 Smell-The aroma on this one is huge. It is heavy of a sweet chocolate and espresso smell. Mixed with this aroma are smells of stone fruits, with aromas of cherry, raisin and prune. Other aromas of vanilla, bourbon and caramel are also detected in the nose giving an overall robust and quite complex, but delicious smell.

 Taste ¬ñ The taste begins heavy of cocoa and some dark fruits. The dark fruits, mainly of cherry and prune, were light in comparison to the sweet cocoa which creates a thick and robust base for the taste of the brew. Flavors of vanilla and caramel come to the tongue more toward the middle of the taste creating a chocolate covered fruit like flavor. At this point the taste is quite big and sweet. Toward the end a big boozy flavor comes to the tongue. The boozy flavor is largely bourbon in nature and when combined with the sweet and cocoa flavors of the brew, it creates a warningly sweet flavor to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel ¬ñ This is one thick brew. The body is massively creamy and thick. It coats the tongue and baths it in all the intense and robust flavors of the brew. With the carbonation (not surprisingly) being on the lower side, the thickness when combined with the alcohol taste creates a very warming and thick feeling.

 Overall- A quite delicious brew. I have never been disappointed. The massive flavors that meld quite well with one another and warming feel make it a brew of high regard.

2014 version. Thank you to Brad for this very generous gift. Pours an oily pitch black in color with a thinner, reddish brown head. The aroma hits you with a potent bourbon and heavy chocolate. These elements are rounded out with vanilla, coffee, some light toffee, roasted malts, and slight mint. The main impression from the taste is that its extremely sweet, probably to sweet. Its big on bourbon and vanilla, with caramel and chocolate found and becoming more pronounced at the end. Aftertaste of bourbon, more chocolate, and less vanilla sticks with you for a long time. Full in body and milder in carbonation. The texture is very oily, like syrup actually. Without a doubt this is excellent. Its unique, strong, and intense. Its great for the experience of actually getting the chance to try this. However, as much as I enjoyed it, I would have been even happier if it wasn¬ít so sweet.

Bottle at Mikkeller & Friends, july 25th 2014. Black body, nice tanned head. Aroma of licorice, fresh roasted coffee, ash, dried fruit, dark chocolate notes. Taste of sweet chocolate, strong coffee, raisins, plum, oranges, bittersweet finish with a long complex aftertaste of coffee and dark fruit. Nice complexity throughout, and a beer I¬ím ecstatic for finally getting to try.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2014 Pours oily black. Nose is pretty impressive with chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, maybe some nuts.

Taste is less impressive, pretty one-dimensional with lots of (read: TONS OF) sweet chocolate, which totally overpowers the coffee notes that are hidden somewhere. Good balance on the alcohol, 15% but not disturbing.

Very good beer, but I expected more.

Waaaaaaaaay to sweet! Sugar was very over powering which limited the beginning and finish! Had a 2014 and was very disappointed!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2013: Pours thick, viscous black with little/no head. Smell of dark chocolate, espresso, roasted malt, hint of bourbon. Taste is very sweet with chocolate covered cherries, black coffee. Hint of booze. Thick, velvety texture. Long smooth finish. Amazing for a 15%

2014: Blue wax - Pours again thick viscous black with little no head. Same dark chocolate, more prominent espresso this year. Slightly more boozy. Taste has more prominent coffee. Mildly sweet. Hint of spices. Very thick, velvety. Long smooth finish. Better than 2013 I think.
Orange wax 2013 version. Completely overrated. Hard to drink, it¬ís like an alcoholic version of dark caramel topping syrup. The taste is strong, but it¬ís gone in no time. Very sticky stuff.

2013 orange wax bottle. was very eager to try this beer, had an immediate smell of molasses and dark fruit. when tasteing i picked up caramel, plums, raisens and cherries. quite frankly this was a truely unique stout ( almost like a blend between a stout and a quad) but when compared to others on the market it doesnt quite measure up to me. i have a 2014 and am going to let it sit 4 years to see if it balances out a bit. but although it didnt reach the hype it was still a fantastic beer and worth trying

Bottle at the Beechner Blind Beer Bash. 2014 bottle. Nose is a ton of fruit. Like crazy amounts of fruit, some tart cherry. Light chocolate and roast. Taste is like a thick cherry liquer. I¬ím not sure if this is all a factor of being fresh or if something in the recipe has changed. I¬íve had 3 older bottles, three or four years or older and found the beer to be way less fruity and more well balanced. This one is fruity dominant and lacks almost all coffee components. weird.
Pours dark, smells amazing. Incredibly smooth for the alcohol content. Great after taste.

Sweet, coffee, cola. Pours a thick dark syrup-y carbonated goodness. Drank at Ravinia with good friends and other craft beer assholes. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark and thick pour, slight sour on the first taste with a bit of a sour soy sauce .very sweet sugary stuff.maybe a big over the top but better than I had been led to believe.

Tried a 2011 and a 2012. Quite similar, not much seemed to have changed in that year. Both delicious. Dark, thick, very roasty aroma. Taste is strong, boozy, a little spicy. Coffee is there but not overt, at least at this age.

22 oz bottles of the following vintages: 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2008, and 2009. These are notes from the mind-blowing Dark Lord Vertical tasting hosted by Huhzubendah on January 23, 2010. This vertical was only a small part of a much larger tasting that went late into the night. A huge thanks to Matt for setting this up this overwhelming event!

Pours a pitch black with a dark brown foamy, sticky, lasting head. Aroma is full: roasted malts dominate, with coffee, chocolate, and a general sweetness. Flavor is unbelievable: smooth with more chocolate complexity and bitterness. The ¬í09 batch has more coffee flavors up front. The ¬í04 was thick and chewy and amazingly smooth. Alcohol flavors virtually non-existent in the ¬í04,¬í05,¬í06 batches. ¬í07 and ¬í08 had a slightly thinner feel and taste than the other batches. Finish is long and complex, with a continually developing taste. The sweetness was done very well, and more subdued in the earlier vintages. Mouthfeel is mouth-coating and seeps into your palate - chewy and delicious. ¬í09 was the most carbonated, as it was the most recent, and was bolder than earlier vintages. Always an event to have this world class beer.

From notes 1/23/10 (Geist Dark Lord vertical tasting)
