UPDATED: OCT 14, 2016 Bottle during RBSG 2014 Grand Tasting at Schlafly Tap Room thanks to Adam. 2014 release. Black with tan head. Aromas of dark chocolate, dark fruit, caramel. Tastes of dark fruit, raisins, roast, chocolate, caramel. Full body with a dry finish. Nice.

Bottle courtesy of Shrubber 85, cheers! Shared at #EBBC14 (25ml pours)2010 vintage (green wax)
Thick rich dark brown black with minimal grey-brown lacing. No carbonation, viscous, unctuous, chocolate, coffee, touch of vanilla, tonnes of treacle, molasses, mouth coating, warming. Gloopy, roasty

Finally! Rating number 500. 2014 blue wax bottle. Thanks Ben (SourNrare)! The pour is a viscous oily black with a finger of dark khaki, maybe brown, head. There is not any lace present. The aroma is really good and complex. The molasses is really up front with a strong roast and malt presence. There is just a hint of coffee, as well as an extremely light booziness, but overall, it is just great! The flavor is pretty sweet, but very good. There is a nice caramel or toffee sweetness and a great roastiness. I am not picking up on much else, but it is very good and there is just a hint of chocolate on the end. The mouthfeel is perfect. Thick and oily, almost like a syrup, minimal carbonation but it coats extraordinarily well. The mouth feel is light and sweet, almost like a caramel-ish note and lingering. Beautiful. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2010 bottle thanks to trade with boamr. Pours a thick black with nice ring of tan brown head that leaves little to no lace; impressed there is still carbonation. Aroma is burnt sugar, roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, booze, and honey. Taste goes straight to chocolate with a nice molasses and bitter coffee back end. Amazing how well this has held up, would love to try it fresh to compare.
Bottle from 2010, oily brown-black, aromas of tobacco, leather, gravy. Palate has earth, toffee, gravy, old leather. Touches of molasses, date and sultana. Dry and dusty texture yet syrupy too.
Sampled at Grand Tasting during RBSG. Pours a black color with white head. Roasty, deep burnt,

2009 white wax bottle. shared with 2 other friend. poured viscous dark black with a never lasting caramel head. long alcohol lacing on the side of the glass. dark roasted malts, caramel, pot, cherries, some dark chocolate, dark fruits, big long lasting sugar palate. soy sauce, big alcohol notice. thick mouthfeel, I don¬ít get at these high ratings, way to over hyped. it¬ís a beer you need to try once you get into craft beer. and when you try it it¬ís a big let down!

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2014 2014 bottle. Poured from bomber into pint glass. Black in color, little brown head. Not overwhelming aroma. Super sweet. Almost syrupy mouth feel. A little booze flavor, as well as malt and coffee. Really thick and heavy, a whole bomber is a lot to drink. Pretty tasty. Side note: awesome label.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2014 Recently got into beer so I had to trade some wine for this as I am a long time wine collector. I had high expectations but wow. The nose has some marzipan, sweet malt and even a hint of smoke. The palate is just shy of perfectly mouth coating. Heavy in weight with amazing sweetness and little carbonation. Almost a fig note to it. Delicious beer.
Second and third bottles just as good.

Look: pours a dark black oily color. Thick dark brown head. Dark black.
Smell: chocolate. Malty. 
Taste: sweet malty. Chocolate. Soy sauce. Very sweet.
Feel: thick heavy low carbonation
Overall: extremely good. Very sweet. No bitterness at all. 
First drank: 6/14/14 Jenna's graduation

Pours a dark black color with little tan head. Roasted malt, vanilla, coffee, molasses, and some caramel on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with a roasted malt note and a little sweetness.
Bottle..Pour is dark black with a thin tan head..Nose is roast, some sweetness, chocolate, sweetness...Taste is sweet tea, spice, chocolate, roast, hidden alcohol..

Wow. Finally. What a treat from kathouse. Great guy... Great trader. Pours a thick sludgy black. Big tan head. Aromas are big molasses, chocolate, grapes, coffee, soy sauce. Mouth feel is thick and syrupy. This is a sugar bomb. One of the sweetest beers I¬íve ever had. Flavors are cough syrup, dark fruit, sherry, molasses, grape kool-aid. This is cloyingly sweet.. I was prepared to give this a higher rating but it¬ís just too sweet. However still crazy complex and really well made.

Its a 2010 shared with my brother, dad and a friend. Pour from a bottle is pitch black with little head. Aroma is straight dates figs and raisins. The taste is a nice malty sweetness with hints of chocolate. Goes down smooth.
Bottle thanks to Cavie. Wow. Incredible. Amazing. Awesome. Can't say enough about this beer. Tastes like heaven.

B-day tasting ¬í14. From a trade with jrallen-thanks, man! 2011. Deep black with brown rim, no lace. Not as thick as I expected but full bodied plush mouthfeel...velvety. Nose is some molasses, rich roasted malts, light vanilla. Coffee pretty much faded, maybe a light bitterness. Sweet, but not cloying or out of balance. Complex, fairly long. Preferred this a bit over Baller side by side.

This was the surprise beer on 2014 Sucr√©versary. Patrick Rue of The Bruery was walking down the line pouring 2013 Dark Lord from a pitcher. Deep brown with tan foam, but not quite opaque. Sweet toffee and milk chocolate aromas emanate from an Imperial Stout that looks and tastes more like a cross of Olde Ale and Barleywine. Figs, raisins, vanilla, and toffee. Thick mouthfeel and long finish. Really surprising from an RIS label although not unwelcome.
Sweeter than most others and that sweetness makes the beer different than its peers. It approaches being cloyingly sweet but doesnt ever cross that line.

Bottle to glass. Pours a pitch black with a creamy brown head. Aroma is amazingly complex, roasted malts, nutty, oats, brown sugar. Flavor is instantly sweet, caramel, molasses, brown sugar, light roasted notes, not overly coffee. Creamy body with a long lingering nutty sweetness and a hint of coffee and chocolate. Very excellent stout! But maybe a bit over hyped.

Backlog. 2009 Vintage bottle @ Mikkeller Bar, CBC12.
App: Pitch black and syrupy with a short dissipating brown head.
Aroma: Soy, molasses, dark chocolate and some minth.
Taste: Very sweet, dark chocolate, muscovado sugar, coffee, soy.
Palate: Sticky smooth and thick mouthfeel. Almost no carbonation, but that might be cause the bottle had been standing for a while.
Overall: Thick like snot and very powerful and sweet. Still it has some balance. Need to try it more properly.
Backnote, had this beer at the zeebra extreem beer festival 2014. superb beer 2011

Serving: 750 ml. bottle via trade. 2011 vintage. It pours a murky black with a small, dark brown head. Nice notes of coffee and vanilla in the nose. Rich, dark malt on the tongue. On the sweet side, but not cloyingly so. Notes of mocha, coffee, vanilla, and a bit of earth. Thick and viscous stuff, but very smooth. Overall impression: A great imperial stout that lives up to the hype. I¬íve heard people say they are too sweet, but this bottle wasn¬ít and had enough alcohol dryness on the end to keep it from being cloying. I would seek this out again.

2013 bottle at Mikkeller CPH. Black pour, tan frothy head - viscous looking. Sweet chocolate, light vanilla and some sweet caramel on the nose. Taste gives big coffee and sweet chocolate, lots of brown sugar, spices, sweet vanilla pod. Full bodied. Sweet cocoa finish with a touch of booze. Sweeter than I¬íd hoped for - class brew, but surprisingly sugary.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2016 Had the 2011 at zebf 2014. Great imperial stout with some nice notes of coffee and vanilla. I truly enjoyed it, but it doesn?t live up to the hype. (although that is nearly impossible of course) Had the 2015 a year later, lot sweeter and less complex than 2011. Rating is for the first one.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2015 Sampled @ Zeebra 2014. My first beer of the festival (recommended by Thijs). Very sweet. Agreed with Evan that the aftertaste is weird, which is a shame. Nice bournon, black beer, still. 

Edit: rated higher after drinking a 2010 bottle during the tasting at Bram 20-11-2015 (the bottle was a courtesy of Thijs).
UPDATED: JUL 8, 2016 Bijna zwarte kleur met een goede bruine kraag. Ruikt koffie, vanille, beetje cr√®me. Smaakt bitterzoet, vanille, cr√®me. Bittere afdronk.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2016 2011 bottle. Pours a pitch black beer with a good tan to brown head. Smells rye, vanilla, chocolate. Tastes pretty sweet, rye, chocolate with a gopd astringent finish. Thick body, low carbo and a sticky oily texture. 
2015. Jaar oud. Betere geur. Betere smaak. Goede rijping.

2013 DL on tap at DLD 2014. Looks crazy good - viscous and brown foam. Aroma is soy sauce and some mild raisin. Taste is overbearing malt sugar totally destroying any dark fruits. It¬ís like cordial on the palate - syrupy and sweet. Not overly likeable this one honestly. Finish is syrupy. Overall, the small pour was enough with this one. Not a big fan.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2015 Bottle at Mikkeller bar (original). Pours Black as the night. Head is fluffy and nut Brown. Aroma is almost barrel aged. Lots of chocolate, Rye bread, vanilla. Taste is sweeter than i recall. Raisins, dades, caramel. Not too burned. and very smooth! Very mellow in general, and not those aggressive and over burned notes, you often get in this kind of abv. Extremely smooth, soft and swallowable.
---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Rerate in head to head with Surly darkness and Huna: Much sweeter than i recall. Swedish rye bread sweet, and maybe a little over the top, so i have to turn it down a notch.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2016 Bottle thanks to Bursprak. Cheers buddy! :) Pours pitch black with a medium dark brown head.

Aromas of fresh dark fruits, prunes, dates, figs, vanilla, coffee, dark sugar, soy, some booziness. 

Taste is sweeeeet, dark fresh fruits, prunes, dates, figs, vanilla, milk chocolate, sweet filled chocolates, some coffee, light sweet licorice, soy, dark sugar and a syruppy finish.

Surprisingly sweet and smooth for the ABV. Slightly toasty with a roasted marshmallow note. Got at DLD 14. Great event. Don't understand some of the bitching about it. Well organized for such a massive crowd in a small area 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2015 I have had the opportunity to try all years of Dark Lord from 2009 to present and each is slightly different. For 2014 the wax is Blue. I did not get to try this on tap but am drinking it poured from a bottle into a Three Floyd Teku glass. Aroma for 2014 is alcohol, brown sugar, and some dark fruit. Appearance is as always dark like old motor oil. When poured into the glass there was virtually no head, just a slight tan ring of bubbles around the perimeter of the glass. When swirled in the glass I was able to produce a nice 1/2 finger tan head which disappears in about 45 seconds. Taste is sweet. If you don?t like sweet you will not like this. In the flavor I definitely pick up some smoke, brown sugar, maple, some prune/raisens, and alcohol. Palate is good but was slightly thin, however as it warmed it seemed more viscous and similar to previous years. Carbonation is there but relatively laid back. Overall a very good sweet beer on par with a sweet Reislings sweetness. Not my favorite year, though this is a very fresh (drank day after DL day) bottle. We will see how this does in the years to come. I found this most enjoyable at 65¬∞F.

Update:  I had the 2014 18 months after it was originally bottled and it improved dramatically.  It is more balanced, less sweet, and just amazing.
Cheers!

UPDATED: APR 18, 2016 Sampled at Boise¬ís Imperial Stout get together, over 120 bottles to choose from. Going with the flow on this rating. 2011 yellow wax seal. 2009 white wax seal sampled on 11/14/15 and 4.16.16.

Excellent imperial stout. Super sweet with a nice caramel finish. Smooth for as much alcohol is in there. Had at dark lord days 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2013 Bottle shared by Prufrockstar April 2014.

9 years waiting to try this beer, and finally it happens. Thank you! Now let me preface this by saying it was a tough night to shine -- DL was sandwiched between Dark Horizon 1st ed. and Prairie Bomb. Pours black with red highlights, abundant carbonation Dark Horizon. Aroma of soy sauce and dark grain. Very sweet, a bit cloying. I¬ím thinking Southern Tier here. Toothpaste, even, early. Prufrockstar says "marshmallow" and he¬ís got it nailed. Mrs. Prufrock comes back into the room a few minutes later, tries, it, and says exactly the same thing: "marshmallow". It¬ís a nicely toasted marshmallow, but in the end it¬ís too sweet for the style and certainly too sweet for the Metal label. We only drank about half the bottle between the three of us before moving on. I can see how this blew minds in 2005 but it¬ís a whole different world out there today. 

tl;dr summary: Marshmallow.

2012 bottle from Justin, thanks a lot!
Pours dark brown with red hues, hardly any head or bubbles. 
Miso/Soy/Umami, lots of sweetness, toffee, sugary malt, balsamic vinegar in aroma.
Taste has chocolate, port wine, dates, coconut, loads of sugary sweetness, peppery notes, some alcohol.
Full body, low carbonation, sticky mouth feel.
Short after taste.
Shared with 3 people and we had a hard time getting it all down. too much sugary sweetness. And I thought that Surly Darkness was sweet.

2013 bottle opened in Apr-14. Pours black, no head, lots of booze around the edge of the glass. Aroma is raisin/prune, molasses. Taste is dark fruits, molasses, honey, brown sugar, caramel. Not picking up any coffee notes but some vanilla is present. Quite good. Looking forward to the rest of the vertical I have assembled to see how this ages.

At big Seth¬ís going away party on 11/2/2013; was an awesome day! White wax, 2009. Pours motor oil black with small head. Armoa is big thing smooth fig and burnt malt. The burnt malt is smooth though and the notes are really well rounded and complex. Taste is beautiful roasted fig, some nice caramel sweetness, smooth burnt malt, very complex maltiness. The beer is absolutely fantastic. I love this shit. Just lay them down for 6 years and they are phenomenal.

Noir aux reflets rouge√¢tres. Presqu'aucun collet. Tr√®s riche. L√©g√®rement aqueuse. Fine effervescence. Sucr√©. M√©lasse. Vanill√©. Bien balanc√©. Ne fait vraiment pas son pourcentage. Chocolat. L√©g√®rement torr√©fi√©. Caf√© vanille/ au lait. Fruit√© framboise. Baie. Prune. Banane. Truffe au chocolat. Un peu de r√©glisse. Raisin sec. Finale l√©g√®rement am√®re avc beaucoup de sucre. Tr√®s complexe. J'aime beaucoup.

2013 Vintage

Pours dark and thick. Boozy and sweet aroma. Thick mouthfeel. Nondescript booziness, dark malt and turbinado sugar on the palate. Overall unimpressive IMO. I don¬ít get where the hype comes from on this one.

FINALLY GOT TO SAMPLE THIS!!! Green wax, at the 2014 HMOG in Decatur, GA. Pours a deep coffee brown with a nice tan head. Aroma has notes of roast malt, quality coffee and raisins. Somewhat sweet flavor has notes of good coffee, chocolate, raisin and toffee. Mouthfeel is viscous and fizzy, leaving a very pleasing finish. A real treat to get a snort of this legend.

Bottle 2012. Wow am I disappointed. Was really looking forward to trying this beer but didnt live up to hype. Aroma of soy sauce, molasses. Taste follows nose. Huge molasses Sweetness. No hop presence. Really Really sweet. Disappointing.

Bottled. Black beer, lacy tan head. Licorice and soy sauce nose, some alcohol, thick caramel, grains, roasted barley notes. Port wine berries, woody notes and chocolate increase after a few whiffs. Full of dried fruits, green hop notes, some earthy notes. Very complex. Sweet and heavy flavor, raisins, wood, leading into a slightly tingling bitter finish with hints of ash and tobacco. Alcohol is very well hidden, some warmth remains. Extremely full-bodied, port vinous body. Balance is amazing for such a strong beer.Bottled. Black beer, lacy tan head. Licorice and soy sauce nose, some alcohol, thick caramel, roasted barley notes. Port wine berries, woody notes and chocolate increase after a few whiffs. Full of dried fruits, green hop notes, some earthy notes. Very complex. Sweet and heavy flavor, raisins, wood, leading into a slightly tingling bitter finish with hints of ash and tobacco. Alcohol is very well hidden, some warmth remains. Extremely full-bodied, port vinous body. Balance is amazing for such a strong beer.
2013 bottle. Good but not blown away. Too sweet for me and I¬íd like some more alternate flavors - but it still is a great stout.

Thanks to BelgBeerGeek for sharing this one. (Do I have to thank you for this I¬ím wondering ;-) )

If you want to smell & taste alcohol, molasses, sugar; this is your beer. 
Sugar all over the place. Boring & untasty. Overhyped American beer. Actually, imho this is not beer. Thoughts when I see ratings above 10/20 for this one: 1) Beer has to have some presence of malts & hops. 
 2) Somebody think of the children. 

Price/quality ratio: below par.

2013 bottle. Aroma is extremely sweet, lots of dark fruits, raisin, molasses, more unfermented sugars, coffee and booze. Pours a dark chocolate color with a thin mocha colored head. Taste is unbalanced. Way too much sugar in these last few vintages. Soy sauce. Roasted coffee...hints of chocolate, dark fruits....and booze. Finish has a slight bitterness to it, but it ends up with, still, too much sweetness. Very thick, syrupy, sticky mouthfeel. Not sure what has become of this beer, but it is not even close to one of my favorite Imperial Stouts anymore. Sloppy beer. And, I am a huge Three Floyds fan who keeps wanting to love this beer.

Flaska fr√•n 2009 (white wax). Mogna dofter av fikon, kaffe och portervibbar. Rund och len. Sammetslen. P√•mminer lite om √∂versockrat kaffe, som n√§r man f√∂rs√∂kte l√§ra sig dricka kaffe som lite och lastade i socker. Svagt v√§rmande (chili?). kaffe och choklad med l√•g beska.

2012. From bottle to tulip glass. Overt alcohol, sweetness and lack of complexity on the nose. Near jet black with a brown head that fades quickly, as expected due to the alcohol. Flavor is dominated my massive residual sweetness. Seems under attenuated. Some slight chocolate and roast in the background. Low bitterness. Was very excited to try this but it did not live up to the hype for me. Still, not too bad!

22oz bottle (2013 vintage) pours jet black with small thin layer of foam. Nose is roasty dark fruits, boozy, plum, raisin, coffee grounds. Taste is oily earthy roast and big dark fruits, sweet, molasses, spices, booze, bitter cocoa notes, grapes. Finish is slick and bitter raisin, ash, and cream. Definitely unique, a beast of a beer.

Bottle of 2011 courtesy of BK.... Deep black with no head... Aroma of light chocolate, roasted malts, chocolate... Hint of bourbon, coffee... Flavor is really chocolatey, sweet initially, gives way to bourbon and vanilla notes.. Hint tobacco... Great great beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2013: Give this one a few years in a cellar, and it could be great. As it is, there¬ís just too much heat and sweetness for me. I think a little aging could temper some of the extreme flavors and allow them to meld and round out. Still, a good beer. One of a four or five Dark Lords I¬íve had and I don¬ít

First sampled at one of the Woodshops, yellow wax and also red wax. Pours the usual inky black with small tan head. The nose is syrupy sweet vanilla and maple, the coffee notes I find sharp and green, and some dark fruits. The palate is a bit flabby, viscous with flavors of Hershey¬ís syrup, ash, and molasses. Nice beer, but comes off as disjointed at times.

Bottle kindly shared by Cuso, thank you! 2007 vintage, grey (silver) wax. Aroma strong chocolate, light dark fruits, very rich, enticing. Plums. Alcohol. Light cognac. Colour is almost black, texture is oily. Taste is very rich and complex. Initially milk chocolate, strong. Toffee, toasted. Light plums, dark fruits. Alcohol completely hidden. Very smooth, creamy mouthfeel, easily drinkable. Top league.
2010 Bottle. Pours inky black with thin mocha head that dissipates quickly. Big coffee, chocolate, sweet toffee on the nose. Taste is the same. Not as good as expected.

Appearance: viscous, sludgy, ink-black into a snifter, with a transitory dark tan head that vanishes to nothing; syrupy legs when swirled.  Aroma: huge nose of vinous port, molasses, chewy black licorice, chocolate, vanilla, black currants, peat, smoke, espresso, and whiskey.  Taste: smooth mouthful of dark, bittersweet chocolate, raisins and cherries in heavy syrup, molasses, port, roasty coffee, vanilla. Finish: lingering sweet dark fruits in syrup over slightly roasty chocolate and coffee and a hint of black licorice and smoke. Notes: Holy balls. Bottle from 2010 (green wax), cellared with an open date of January 2014, opened on New Years Day. Was apprehensive; never had such a hyped beer before, and was prepared to be disappointed. This was one of the most magnificent beers I¬íve ever had. Not disappointing in the least. This lives up to the hype. Huge nose and full mouth, giant flavors that complement and don¬ít war, and a delicious, lingering finish. Smells boozy, but the alcohol is extremely well hidden. I can¬ít believe this is a 15% beer. Compare to Dogfish Head Worldwide stout, which kicks you in the face with booze. Felt like I was sipping the greatest dessert pudding of all time.

2009 bottle, white wax, from trade with MtGoat, cheers!
Black thick liquid, small brown head.
Aroma: roasted, syrup, chocolate sauce, sweet coffee, corn. 
Taste: roasted, cocoa, coffee, brown sugar, syrup. grainy, m√ºsli, whipped cream, light buttery red wine.
Full-bodied, sticky.
Well, it is too sweet actually.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2015 2012 bottle pours a flat black, aroma is sweet roast, taste is big sweet and light roast with a thin sweet finish, not my thing

fresh 2015 bottle not nearly as sweet, decent improvement
aged 3 yrs. pours very dark. tastes of dark fruit and coffee. taste got better and more complex as it warmed. unbelievable how good this was

Bottle. Pours black, viscous, thick, motor oil. Aroma is Lucius, chocolate, coffee. Taste is strong coffee, chocolate, very oily. After taste sticks around for a bit, finish is getting sweet as it warms. Yum , yum, dim, dim, boom.

5 year old bottle. Thank you Beechner224! Pours a black color with a nice brown head, especially for a 5 year old bottle. The taste is chocolate, malty, , a little burnt chocolate, maltiness. its heaven. It¬ís toasty, chocolate, very awesome. Need I say more.

¬í08 bottle, black wax (5+ yr vintage)....Bottle share thanks to beechner224. Pours a thick, dark, syrupy, black color with brown head. Aroma has a dark malt, syrupy, boozy character. Much more going on in the flavor , dark, viscous, syrupy, boozy, melanoidans, caramel...so much going on here. Have had many vintages, this stuff ages nicely but would never drink fresh again this 08 is amazing.

Vintage 2011 - yellow wax

A: Pours dark mahogany brown. Little mocha head falls quickly leaving a simple, oily surface. Excellent clarity, actually surprisingly thin appearing with light passing through a full pour, a bit disappointing. No lacing. Surprised there was no head given the description on the bottle bragging about the head quality/quantity. Really a pathetic showing.

S: Green apples, bacon (WTF), caramel, wood, vanilla, anise, licorice. Dark molasses and sweet malts. This smells really interesting and actually keeps me intrigued as the beer warms. On second thought, just smells like sugar, apples and a hint of bacon. 

T: Sweet, cloyingly so, with burnt sugar. Caramels. Sweet malts. Smallest hint of alcohol - which makes it fairly well hidden given the ABV. Toasted rye crisps with honey. Overly sweet, like it just didn¬ít finish fermenting - not good.

M: Much thinner than anticipated or adverted on the side of the bottle. Low to no carb. Slick and coated finishing feeling. Resonating.

O: Really a shitty beer. This is the first time I¬íve had DL, and there¬ís been discussion about it being: a) not as good as previous years; b) really much better after it has a year or two on it. I can say this for the beer, it carries a high degree of baggage, and it is difficult for me to be satisfied with a beer that carries sooo much clout and then deviates from it¬ís own description of the beer. I likely won¬ít seek particularly aggressively next year; especially given the exclusive nature of the beer, and how shitty it is fresh.

Serving type: bottle

06-24-2011

Appearance: Pitch black color with a beige layer.Aroma: Chocolate, dried fruits and coffee.Palate: Full body. A bit sweet, and a mild bitterness. Soft carbonation. Oily texture.Taste: Chocolate, fruity, vanilla, coffee and whiskey.Overall impression: Pure pleasure.Personal stats: Bottle (White wax)from a trade with BoostIPAImperial Stout #100US State #30

Backlog. Black wax. Pours black with a thick brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, with a sweet notes and some vanilla and chocolate. Flavour is roasted malt, with liquorish, coffee, chocolate. Very nice beer

2013 Orange wax. Very dark brown colour, almost black with a beige head that quickly diminishes. Aroma has notes of toasty and roasted malts, caramel, toffee and slightly coffee. Flavor is incredible sweet with notes of sweet wine, slightly wood and toasted malts, some molasses and plumbs are present, also anise and dark berries. The final is sweet, almost cloying, with a good toasted mouthfeel on palate, creamy and dense.

Bottle, courtesy of yespr, many thanks. Vintage 2007 (silver vax).  Black colored beer with minimal beige head. Roasted malt, cocoa nibs, plums, cognac/brandy. Complex taste of roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, prunes, dates, caramel, molasses, vanilla, anise. Alcohol slowly appears by warming. Coffee bitter finish with sweet caramel touch. Delicious beer.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2015 Black wax bottle (2008), generously shared by Bruce. So we¬íre all standing around the table, sharing beers and salivating over smoked ribs that haven¬ít yet made it to the table, and he pulls this out and is like, "oh hey, anybody want this? Wonder if it¬ís any good." I picked a hell of a night to be the driver. A few small ounces will have to do. Thick, black, viscous, no head by nice legs. Pretty light on the "old beer" flavor. Chew; rich; sexy; chocolate; awesome. Sweet, but not at all cloying. I love how the first taste enters my mouth and is all like "I¬ím a sweet old rich stout, no biggie," and I¬ím ready to tick it right there cause that¬ís how I roll (not really - well, kinda), but then it just sort of hangs around in there, and the flavor seems to resonate and build into something bigger. Maybe that¬ís just how it seems because I¬ím savoring the few small ounces I have (so as to ensure I¬íll stay sober enough to be a responsible driver and parent and all). Anyway, pretty cool beer and an awesome, unexpected treat. (8/5/9/5/17)
 
2013 bottle consumed 4/24/2014.  Completely different beer and experience this time around -- I wonder if it¬ís the loss of the mystery, the age, or if the beer is different than it was, but this one is all kinds of sweet, cloying, and big on marshmallows.  Not that I have anything against marshmallows (that¬ís sort of a lie -- I don¬ít like marshmallows), but this is hard to finish even a small glass of.  Definitely knocking this down -- I¬íd say to 3.7, but that¬ís reactionary.  3.8 or 3.9 is probably closer.  I¬íll average that with the 2008 and leave it at 4.1.

 
Blind imperial stout tasting, sample 3 of 13. Inky pour. Viscous. Tan/brown head. Smells sweet, chocolatey. Holy fuck sweet. So sweet. Marshmallow, soy, graham cracker. Cloying. So damned cloying. Slight cardboard. Cherry cola. Syrupy, thick. Blech. Cannot finish. Dumped. 7/5/6/3/11 = 3.2. Revealed to be orange wax Dark Lord. Knocking this down yet again.

Poured from bottle. Dark brown. Aroma: prunes, chocolate, cocoa. Flavor: Full bodied. Warming alcohol which is well hidden. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, courtesy of Cuso, many thanks. Pours nearly black, beige head. Aroma is plums, cognac, chocolate, dark berries. Taste is sweet, EXCELLENT, plums, dark berries, coffee, alcohol very well hidden, dark chocolate, black cherries. Just WOW, the best beer I ever had.
Bottle by Cuso, many thanks! Bottled in 2007. One word: excellent! A lot of dried plums, alcohol, I don¬ít know how for 15% abv, is almost absent for me. Overall fantastic!

2103 bottle to large tulip at Craft Heads, Tokyo
I was amazed to see this on their menu...I didn¬ít get it the first night, but eagerly anticipated the return trip. Let the adventure begin. It was served way to cold, so I had to sit here 15 minutes warming it with my hands savouring the aroma wafting over. I may be biased already.

Aroma of dark candied fruits, raspberry, loads of caramel, honey, molasses, oak, chocolate, soy, and maybe a touch of cherry. Pours a deep black with a thin creamy tan head. Starts off really sweet, winch fades somewhat when the chocolate taste begins to build, and then molasses comes on and finally ending with a light bitterness. Throughout, there¬ís a nice oak and toasted malt flavour as well. It¬ís full bodied, very smooth and creamy, with an alcohol warmness.

It¬ís everything, I expected, my only complaint is that this May be a tad too sweet, but otherwise...a awesome.

beige head that disappears fast. cola coloured. aroma of soy, nuts and a lot of booze. taste is hazelnut, sugarwater and hypersweet. quite dense mouthfeel, medium carbonation. abv quite well hidden. i really don¬ít get all the fuss and the hype surrounding this (version of the) beer. very one-dimensional and disappointing.  65 cl / red wax 2012
Sweet chocolate straight up. Coffee and raisins with a wonderful depth of flavour keeping everything in balance. A touch of vanilla on the back end great in respects. A big thank you to cgarvieuk

Extremely rich. Can really taste the coffee and molasses. Excellent, worth the price tag

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at FoCo Stout Tasting 2013, courtesy of Dave. Thanks man! 2010 Vintage. Pour is deep brown with a small brown head and decent lacing. Deep cocoa, bready, soy, slightly oxidized, tangy, dark cherries, caramel, and toffee in the aroma. Taste is dark chocolate, coffee, stale bread, malty, caramel, toffee, tangy, and bourbon with a lightly roasted finish. Slick mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Decent stuff, but definitely doesn¬ít live up to the hype.
Bottle thanks to dave. Cheers! Aroma is chocolate, kind of salty, some dark fruit. Taste is dark chocolate, solid beer.

Black pour with almost no head to speak of. Soy and molasses aroma. More molasses, brown sugar, soy, a bit of cocoa powder. Full body with light carbonation. If this is indeed the beer of the Dark Lord and Satan is a type 2 diabetic.
Bottle at Craig¬ís house. Very dark. A strong flavour. Didn¬ít think I liked it at first sip, but that changed.
tried this beer and gotta say, not bad at all!! will try to get my hands on it asap! label looks strange tho....

2010 bottle. Hard to find anything wrong with this beer. Black gold. The second I uncapped it I was greeted with a wonderful aroma of dark caramelized barley, chocolate, coffee and Bourbon. Opaque and completely headless. Like a black mirror it reflects the image facing it. Amazing. Tastes like it smells but with some noticeable cherry notes and a smooth Bourbon flavor. Sweet and bitter. Heavy viscous body that coats the mouth and lingers forever. Truly great.

Bottle at Craftheads. Thanks CT! 2009 version. Dark brown colour. Very little head. Ultra thick. Unbelievably easy drinking, taste is burnt, treacle, fruity, every taste is different, malty, great stuff. Sweet. Aroma is liquorice and fruity. Vinous. Very dark chocolate. Booze further down. Walnuts or almonds. Plums, raisins, brown bread. Justifies the hype.

[2008 vintage] Pour is pitch black with a dark brown head that leaves light lacing. Aroma is downright boozy but no fusel alcohol at least. Some nice roasted coffee beans notes here and there. Taste is sweet and almost cloying but the dark chocolate impressions save the day. Caramel flavors in there also. Mouthfeel is smooth, carbonation low. Not much alcohol can be felt other than on the nose. Cool to try once, I don¬ít care if I don¬ít ever get to taste it again.

2008 bottle. pours a bit dirty dark brown with a disappearing beige head, little lacing. chocolate-plenty, raisins, molasses, burnt caramelized and burnt nuts, spices, lactose, booze. moderate carbonation, medium to full body - oily, syrupy. boozy and cloying. it did cellar well. nice but very far from bourbon-ba version..

Bottle (22 oz).2008 vintage. Thanks to Tom for this one! Black with reddish reflects and a small reddish beige head. Fruit cake aroma with chocolate/fudge, coffee, molasses and liquorice (and the list goes on). Taste is very sweet and, again, like a fruit cake along with chocolate, molasses and liquorice. Alcohol is well hidden. Full bodied. Low carbonation. Oily/sirupy mouthfeel. Complex fruit cake beer. Not as terrible as expected, but still overly sweet and much inferior to the barrel aged versions of this beer (bourbon and bourbon vanilla). The bottle is 5 years old, but we don¬ít feel the age on it at all. Good, but not a top-50 beer anymore.

Bottle via queenholly in trade. Pours very dark, little to no head. Aroma dried fruit, chocolate, booze. Body smooth and sweet, really hard to believe this is 15%. Not my favorite beer ever, but the hype is justified.

Hands down the best beer I've ever had. Rich chocolate, cherry, roasted malt, and Carmel aroma. Smooth from beginning to end with a very sweet smooth after taste. Amazing beer. The best. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2009 Vintage... Black in the glass. Coffee and cocoa liqueur aromas. Very sweet flavor, some herbal notes, more coffee, and cocoa. With the sweetness, it gives a bit of a chocolate syrup note to it. Overall, this is way too good, almost the perfect brew! Thanks as always to BarZigKin for sharing.

2010 vintage poured into a wine glass. Aroma of strong dark liquor and intense sweet chocolate, reminiscent of a tootsie roll. Fades into a faint, but disagreeable, rubbing alcohol smell. Taste lacks the chocolate of the aroma but maintains the sweetness and adds cherries and other dark fruits. Some welcome funkiness from the age. Mouthfeel is a lot thinner than I anticipated. Not really a bad thing, but unexpected nonetheless. The masking of the ABV is world class. Despite the boozy aroma, you can't find the alcohol anywhere in the taste. Exceptionally done in that regard. 

It took a while to finally track it down, but I'm glad I did. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2010 bomber.

Aroma: tootsie roll chocolate, subtle caramel, some soy sauce. Sometimes, LOTS of rubbing alcohol. This a three year old beer though, so...Appearance: looks motor oil, basically no head. When head tried to appear, it was khaki. Taste: burnt sugar sweetness. Soy sauce is the middle note. Then a bitter chocolate/burning alcohol. Palate: surprisingly thin. Definitely NOT a motor oil consistency.

This is delicious, dont get me wrong. But I wonder if the 4.1 is too generous.
The aroma was all soy sauce but the flavor delivered the goods. Just a touch hot but overall a really good stout and super smooth.

2012. so, this is the infamous dark lord. i was worried at first as the aroma was slightly soy sauce, which with other imperials ive had is a bad sign. but luckily, the soy flavor was minimal. i got dark chocolate, dates, coffee, raisins, some soy sauce yes, bourbon. i get the fuss.
Huge thanks to tectactoe on this share. A very nice imperial stout by Three Floyds. Would love to try again and try the variations.

Impromptu first review, just finished this bottle and figured it would be a good one to start reviewing with.

2011 bottle, served at 50-55 degrees in a snifter.

A- Jet black, a mocha head quickly appears during the pour but quickly dissipates to nothing. Some alcohol legs. 

S- Extremely sweet- Cherries, molasses, and alcohol. No roast or coffee detected. 

T- Very sweet, but not overly so. I can taste cherries, figs, molasses, and a bit of an alcohol bite. Finishes like a port, absolutely delicious. 

M- Silky smooth, a bit of alcohol bite but it is an easy sipper. 

O- This is an excellent beer, but I feel it could use another year or two and hopefully some of the sweetness will die down. It was very enjoyable, and surprisingly I could have drank quite a bit more than the half a bottle I had without getting the full feeling I sometimes get from RIS.

I tried a bottle of the 2005 dark lord around 2006 so I cannot recall all of the specific notes. I remember slowly sipping this beer and spending the course of an hour reveling in this beauty of a beer. Incredibly balanced, great chocolate/coffee tastes, and the limited quantity makes it one the greatest triumphs for me in tasting beer as well as acquiring beer.

From a 650ml brown bottle. White wax indicates it was a 2009 bottle. Thick black pour, inky. Holds a faint ring of deep brown foam. Cocoa, roasted malt and some alcohol in the aroma. Taste has thick and deep dark chocolate and cocoa powder, roasty. Finishes with some smooth booziness, roasty and chocolately aftertastes. Thick bodied, midl carbonation. Impressive.
Had a 2011 and wow. Huge flavor. This is a great brew to sit back and chill with.

2009 bottle courtesy of CaseyK. Sweet and port like cherry tones. Rich chocolate. Some soy sauce notes, but really surprisingly mellowed out...maybe not to it¬ís benefit. A pretty classic beer, but I prefer it fresh.

22oz bomber (2010). This is my 1,000th rate. HUGE thanks to dmac for opening this one for the occasion! Pours a thick pitch black color with zero head. Aroma of caramel, chocolate, smoked meat (pepperoni?), vanilla, and roasted malt. Taste of roasted coffee, smoke, dark chocolate, caramel, vanilla, and dark fruit.

white label. This is definitely a beer to age. Very boozy, and probably the only beer I have ever had that actually coated the glass after drinking. I don¬ít know if it was something went wrong but I had a Green label one a year ago and it had a soy sauce flavor to it.

Pours a deep burnt umber color with two fingers of bubbly khaki foam that fizzles out quickly. The nose has lots of liquid brownie, dark fruit and more chocolate ! The palate wicked sweet... so sweet... lots of vanilla, dark chocolate sauce a touch of umami, burnt brownies and a long sweet mouth coating finish.

2012 bottle. Pours jet black with a brown head that dissipates quickly to leave a minimal ring that hugs my glass. The aromal is of robust roasted malts, potent sweet carmel malts, booze, coffee, vanilla, and dark fruit. As for flavor its impressive. Its extremely sugar sweet and sticky. I noticed sweet carmel malts, roasted malts, chocolate, mild coffee, minor booze, dark fruit, more dark malts, vanilla, and much molasses. The finish reminds me of water downed syrup that?s so sweet with minor tones of coffee bitterness, and vanilla. The more sips you take the more the booze shows up in the finish and it kind of hinders the experience. Overall this was a delightful beverage.

Poured rich dark chocolate color with very little head and little lace. Aroma of alcohol prunes chocolate and coffee
Same with taste almost identical malts ad molasses silky in the mouth.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 bottle shared amongst friends, thanks to Bry and Tommy for sending me this! Pour is thick motor oil sludge with nice tan head, the aroma is big, lots of sweetness, chocolate, sherry, plumb and so on. Taste is a bit off putting at first as there is so much sticky sweetness. I warmed up to it after getting used to the taste, brown sugar, plumb, chocolate, and virtually no heat from this 15% ABV monster. Very decadent, and bottle to share and enjoy with friends. Tasty stuff.

Bottle with yellow wax (2011).
APPEARANCE: pitch black beer, small unstable beige head.
NOSE: tobacco, sweet, grapes, smoked, coffee, chocolate, fruity.
TASTE: sweet, bitter aftertaste, roasted coffee, bourbon, little sourness, very fruity, coulis, red fruits, red wine like.
But, not living up to the hype in my opinion...

2009 bottle. Pours used motor oil black both in color and pretty close to consistency. Some tan head but not a great deal. Low carbonation. Aromas of cocoa, coffee, molasses, dark fruits, and brown sugar. Big flavor with the cocoa and molasses coming through initially with the roasted malt character. So much going on. Finish is warm and long-lasting. Definitely a slow sipper but absolutely magnificent. This beer deserves all of the hype that surrounds it without a doubt. One of the best imperial stouts I have ever had

2013 from bottle. Great malty aroma of chocolate and caramel. Black pour with light brown head. Tastes sweet, with no apparent hop flavors intruding. Plenty of chocolate, coffee, and caramel. Nice and thick on the palate. Great beer.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2013 2006 Bottle. Black with a beige foam. Aromas are coffee with berries and marzipan alcohol. Light smoke with dark chocolate and medicinal notes. Molasses with soy and traces of seawater. Creamy oak barrel with hints of vanilla. Flavours are sweet berries and raisins with dates and other plummy fruits. Earthy with roast coffee and earthy notes. Smooth as hell with chocolate and marzipan and warming alcohol. Very easy to drink for it¬ís strength. Amazing.  Cheers to Brigadier for the share.
Shared with timfoolery. Great russian imperial stout with fitting name! Lives up to the hype.
Rich, frothy and delicious. Yeah it was that good. 2012 edition, red wax. Aged over a year, drank on 7/14/2013.

I am reviewing the Black wax 2008 vintage cellared for 4 years.

I put this bottle away after purchasing it at Dark Lord Day 2008. It had moved with me across the world to the tiny U.S. territory of Guam. I knew there would be very slim pickings, so I brought it along. This review may be the furthest from the point of origin for Dark Lord ever written.

Two friends of mine had graciously opened thier home for a get together of workers from the University Of Guam¬ís Marine Lab, where my wife works and attends school. I decided this would be the perfect chance to share a beer they would never have a chance to try, and I didn¬ít realize it at the time, but the day was Dark Lord Day in the states too! A miracle day!

The beer dissappointed me on it¬ís official release. There was no head, it had a bitter acrid metallic taste and smelled sort of like bitter Soy Sauce.

 Well, after 4 years of aging the difference was amazing. The room temperature beer poured black with a chocolate head 2 inches tall! The head very slowly dissolved leaving a thick viscuous lacing behind. The Stout had lost it¬ís acrid smell and taste, and picked up the rich nose of chocolate, robust coffee, raisins, dark fruits and pepper. And the taste? Now this is how Dark Lord is supposed to taste! It burst instantly on the tongue with a strong smooth flavor of chocolate and coffee, which slowly dissolved into the complex blend of raisins, fruits and cofee, finishing with a throat tickling dry scratchy pepper, coffee and a chocolate aftertaste that happily lingered on the tounge seemingly indefinately. This was a revelation to me of how good a fine beer can taste if allowed to mature properly. It was as if the original brew was a bunch of complicated parts thrown into an empty garage and untouched 4years later emerged as a Rolls Royce. Dark Lord aged is now my favorite beer of all times. A lofty thing indeed considering I have been experiencing hundreds of different fine imports and craft brews since 1982.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2015 Rating #1000! Thought I would celebrate with a top rated Imperial Stout. Been wanting to try this for a while. 2012 red wax bomber from trade with Dfonorow. Pours near pitch black with almost no head. Looks a little oily. Very sweet aroma of vanilla, molasses, raisins, soy sauce, light espresso, chocolate, and booze. Taste is very sweet as well with almost no bitterness. The flavors are great but absolutely no sweet/bitter balance. All of the aromas come through nicely, especially the vanilla, molasses and raisins. Gets boozier as it gets warmer but no indication of 15% abv at all. Tastes like it could be 8%. Medium to thick body, oily and syrupy mouthfeel. This could be top notch if there was some bitterness to balance the extreme sweetness here. Might like to try a fresh one some day to see if any hops show up as well. Overall, a really good imperial stout but nowhere near my favorites in this style.  Re-rate 5/6/15 - Enjoyed  a 5 year old 2010 bottle shared by Couch.  Thanks!  Flat black pour.  Aromas are fudge brownies, dark fruit, cherries.  Moderate to strong sweetness.  Chocolate syrup, dark fruit, light booze.  Very smooth.  Has aged very well but still not the great imperial stout this is rated as.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2016 2013 Bottle, acquired by trade, split at the pre stag tasting in the ¬íSham, 20/06/13.
Pitch black with a dirty tan head that dissipates to a film.
Nose is roast malt, booze, treacle, burnt sugar, molasses, dark fruit - over cooked too much roast and raw booze.
Taste comprises a big roast bite, bitter chocolate, sweet sugars, tar, molasses, treacle, syrup.
Full bodied, fine carbonation, warming alocohol and boozey heat.
Decent enough Impy but didn¬ít have a great nose for me - a little harsh, classic overhype but one I¬íd happily try again.

Re-rate 07/07/16 many thanks to Leighton.

Dropped 15 overall to 14. Was 3.7 now 3.6. Again ... unimpressed.  Molasses/malt heavy and overly sweet .... really don¬ít understand why it. Commands such a high score ??? #2016 ... way better impy stoots aboot !!!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Tap. Black with no head. Aroma is molasses, vanilla, sweet wort, Kahlua. Taste is heavy sweet with some bitterness slowly coming through, but the overall impression is sticky Kahlua sweetness. Full body, Kahlua texture, flat carbonation. This stuff is sticky and sweet.

Trade from BrewMane. 2013 Orange Wax bottle, drinking fresh because cellars are for chumps ;-)

Pours syrupy dark black with a sub-one-finger creamy dark mocha head. Aroma of sweet roasted malts, raisins, molasses, chocolate syrup, candy sugar, and a hint of alcohol smell. Flavor is sweet molasses up front, sweet powder sugar, a bit of dark fruit, a little bitter chocolate on the finish. Nearly no trace of the 15% abv. Sweet sweet stuff. Super velvety smooth mouthfeel and very thick. Only other stouts that have had this mouthfeel come from CCB (Hunapuh, Marshal Z). Plenty of carbonation to keep it from feeling syrupy. I was expecting more on the chocolate side, but this balances sweet molasses with dark fruits prominently. The best part to me of this decedent stout is the mouthfeel. So glad I finally got a taste of this. I can see how this would blend nicely with bourbon and vanilla. ISO now I guess...

Black wax bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours thick, oily black with no head and a dark mocha lacing. Aroma is raisins, chocolate, espresso and molasses. Tastes is huge - feels like I¬ím drinking a mudcake. Plum, raisins, sweet vanilla, red wine, dark chocolate and port sweetness all very present. Thickest beer I¬íve ever had, actually made me thirsty. Sticky with little carbonation. Wow, can finally tick that one off the list.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2014 Viscous pitch color, thin brown lacing. Sticky aroma of molasses, sugary chocolates, toffee apple, cold coffee, a hint of vanilla, and an uneasy soy sauce undertone. Initial sweetness is very strong, and emphasized in the finish. Full-bodied and thick with the booziness masked by the sugar.

Bottle, huge thnx to Kermis for sharing this! Cheers!! 2012 vintage, red wax. This pours a black beer, no light or whatsoever shining trough this pure liquid devil. Aroma is sweet, light alcoholic, raisins, molasses and some boozyness. Well balanced. Very sweet, full sugary moutheel. Incredibly sweet, slight touches of roast. Great balance between booze and flavors. Great sipper, this will knock you out of your socks. Awesome!!

Just outrageous good on tap at Mikkellerbar Viktoriagade. Complete black pour with a thin lacy head and booze on the glass. The nose is absurd with a huge roasted malt, cocoa and espresso with big warm boozy notes. A hint of earthen malt with sweet vanilla. Just an incredible flavour with big intense roasted malts, smooth and sweet with big intensity that makes you shudder a bit. Finish is heavy and warm with a huge full bodied nearly syrupy leftover in rhe mouth. Just incredible
Bottle with yellow wax. Black beer with no head. Dark fruits, chocolate aromawith coffee notes. Sweet, chocolate, coffee, roasted malt flavour.

Sample at CBC 2013.

Black with a beige head. Aroma and flavour of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, vanilla, licorice and caramel.

Tap at Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2013 - Session 1. Vintage 2012. Pours thick black with a fine, creamy tan cap. Very sweet and syrupy with notes of licorice, molasses, chocolate and blackcurrant. Full bodied with fine carbonation and oily texture. Warming, sticky sweet finish with raisins, alcohol and chocolate syrup. Rich and decadent, but not as good as some older bottled versions I¬íve had in the past.
2012 pours nice dark color but not motor oil thick. Still seems to have some unfermented wort sweetness. Good chocolate roasted aroma with a good flavor. Overall okay.

My first impression was quite negative due to circumstance.  I was assisting AndyReynolds with his brewing outside on one of the hottest days in a while, smoking a strong cigar and tasting various strong beers.  Between the heat, the smell of the brewing process, the cigar smoke and the tipsiness, my body screamed switch to water and then Andy says, "here try this beer; it¬ís one of my favorites..."  I try it and went inside to cool off and switched to water.  Now, I can rate it: bomber (2013) - pours dark brown with coffee cream head and deceptively large head with great lacing.  Nose is milk chocolate.  Flavor adds brown sugar, booze and roast.  well balanced but ends very sweet.  does not live up to the hype.  metallic aftertaste.

On tap @CBC13. Aroma is powerful and sweet; dark sugar, caramel, licorice and cocoa. Taste is super sweet, caramel, ash, coffee, syrup, chocolate. Hides the alcohol well. Decent, but the hype is insane...

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2013 2011 yellow wax. Thanks Tommy! Pours a thick black with a 2 finger brown head. Super strong aromas of molasses, some roast, some alcohol. First sip reveals heavy residual sugar, no coffee notes at all, no hop notes. Slightly bitter from the roast, but this is mostly a sugar bomb. Lots of chewy molasses. Some sweet apple.  Not as good as I thought it was going to be.

UPDATE: Also had a 2009. More mature and more enjoyable but nothing significantly different to my inept palette.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2013 Bottle - Vintage 2011 - Soy sauce, molasses and dark fruit with some nice vanilla sweetness.  Jet black and minimal brown head.  Oily and rich with notes of a huge finish.  Creamy chocolate with some coffee and dark roast.  Vintage 2013 - Roast malts, liquorice, soy sauce and espresso.  Very sweet, with molasses and dark fruit dominating.  Same texture, but sweet throughout.  Still nice, but not as complex.

Draught @ Mikkeller, Viktoriagade. Pours near black with a frothy light brown tiny head. Aroma is brown sugar, molasses, roasted malt, sweet licorice, raisin, burnt malt, vanilla, soft coffee and dark fruit. Taste is heavy sweet and near medium bitter. Body is medium+, texture is thick and syrupy, carbonation is soft. Finishes sweet with molasses and roasted bitter malt and and alcohol.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2014 Re-rate from 2014 DL opened at the day of the release. As fresh as it gets right? Big chocolate and coffee this time and way less soy sauce in the aroma. Much better experience this time around but it is super sweet and hard to drink a bunch.

2010 bottle with a big thanks to stfun. Pours a deep brown to black with practically no head. Aroma is definitely sky sauce and chocolate. There is some alcohol in the aroma. The taste has lost its coffee. Unfortunately this is my first experience with DL. Sweet and malty with a slight alcohol heat. Consistency of motor oil. I can¬ít wait to try a fresh one. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2013 Bottle 2010 thanks to artmcd8 via StFun. Poured black with minor head. Aroma of soy sauce, slightly fruity and stings the nostrils. Extremely smooth slightly smoky taste. ---Rated via Beer Buddy

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2014 03.05.2013, (superfresh) tap @ CBC:
Ok, what¬ís the f****** hype!!??!! It¬ís time to not only swear in the church, it¬ís time to burn the shit down!! This beer it the biggest disappointment EVER!
Absolutely no sign of any head. Aroma is sweet, unripe banana, dark sugar, caramel, some licorice and cocoa. Taste is just sweet, sweet, sweet! Unlimited amounts of dark sugar, unripe banana, caramel, ash, some coffee and chocolate. Medium bitterness. If I was to open a fresh bottle of this one by myself, 95% of the bottle would go straight in the toilet. This one needs many years in the cellar, at least. And even then I don¬ít think it will end up as nothing more than a middle range beer.
2012 vintage.  I had a lot of plum wine taste in my bottle.  Personally not sure what all of the hype is about.

I was on an other planet for a short while ... so I was lucky to do a vertical ¬¥04 - ¬¥12 .. with some amazing friends javit, Forgetfu, gEUS, amongst others nice people in Brussels in the basement under Moeder Lambic Fontainas .... the best beer experience I have had until now! ... My favorite is ¬¥10 ... so imo the dark lord should not be more than 2 -3 years old... This was one fantastic experience!!
Bomber into glass..shared with special fam!   Pitch black pour..very sweet aroma and taste..pretty hard to believe its high alc

1 pint... Bottle, dark pour light head, very sweet, strong alcohol % :) yum!!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2011- Pours a dark black with a nice tan head. nose is of roasted malts, coffee, and chocolate. As for taste its a nice roasted bitter coffee and molasses. I do get a bit of a port wine taste in the aftertaste. No alchohol whats so ever on this. Good but definetlly not my favorite RIS.
On tap at CBC. Black colour with small beige head. Dark fruits aroma, also wood and roasted malts and coffee. Sweet taste, dark fruits Full body. Well hidden alcohol.

This was the 2012.   Very thick consistency.   Bourbon/alchohol aroma.   Very rich and heavy which I expect from an IS.   Very sweet taste, a little more than I prefer.   After ageing a year, no carbonation at all.   Like drinking a liquor.

Poured at the epic AZ crews¬í driveway tasting curtesy of dcschiller I am pretty sure.  Its been embarrassing being on this site for so many years and not having ever tasted this.  This was 2011 version pours jet black with huge nose of bourbon and molasses.  tastes of chocolate, bourbon, molasses, coffee, woody, light vanilla, soy sauce, resin, and licorice.  probably too sweet for my normal palate but today it worked just fine.
Crazy sweetness!  Pours black with thin red head.  This beer has a ton of syrup-like sweetness that is way overpowering of the vanilla and coffee.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2013 From tap, CBC 2013. Deep dark blackness with a head so small, you might argue that it is not there at all. Aroma is roasted malt, syrup, vanilla, nuts, smooth coffee. Thick oily texture, full body, very low carbonation. Very sweet, dark fruity flavor, with well hidden alcohol, leading to a sweet, roasted finish. Too sweet for my palate, but well crafted and somehow even well balanced. Not worth the hype, though.

Pours viscous. Blackest black. Tight creamy brown head, partially lasting, drippy brown lace. Aroma is chocolate, roasty, some coffee, sweet dark fruit, caramel apple, vanilla, a little alcohol. Flavor fully compliments aroma. Thick, full, creamy, slightly syrupy body. Soft carbonation. Wow. Delicious. Sweet and bitter beautifully balanced. The nicest soft alcohol warming in the stomach. finish that lasts and lasts. Complex and accessible.

Sampled at DLD 2013.  It poured a deep brown color with a tan head. The aroma was mostly of cinnamon and liquorice. The taste was sweet, like a cinnamon toothpick. There was a slight alcohol burn. Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2015 Pours black with low, thick velvety tan head. Aroma of coffee bitter, cocoa, roasted malt, melasses, light vanilla. Taste is WOW! Amazing! Vanilla, milk chocolate, coffee. A sweet RIS yet with a light, perfectly balanced bitterness. Incredibly rich and creamy body. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours pitch black with a slight head. Nose is vanilla, chocolate, coffee, molasses, honey, roasted walnuts. Taste is.... Words do not do this justice. Incredibly smooth and creamy, with coffee, chocolate, dark fruits, liqourice, honey and sea salt and everything comes together in absolute orgasmic bliss.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours dark with brown head
Aromas of coffee in loads, black malts, bitter notes in general
Fuck me silly what a freaking taste. Enough said

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Duft af kaffe, sort. Brun skum.  Kaffe, chokolade bitter eftersmag ......xxxxxxxxxxxx

Free F√∏royar!!!

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2014 2013 Bottle, first taste of my allocation. Pours viscous. Blackest black. Tight creamy brown head, partially lasting, drippy brown lace. Aroma is chocolate, roasty, some coffee, sweet dark fruit, caramel apple, vanilla, a little alcohol. Flavor fully compliments aroma. Thick, full, creamy, slightly syrupy body. Soft carbonation. Wow. Delicious. Sweet and bitter beautifully balanced. The nicest soft alcohol warming in the stomach. finish that lasts and lasts. Complex and accessible. I didnt expect it to live up to expectations but it more than held up its end. 


5/22/14 Update: 2013 vintage, been aging a little over a year. Coffee had eroded some. Fruitier. Port. Almost richer. More soy sauce. Sweeter. Very complex dark maltiness and fruitiness. No booze. At all. Subtle warmth. I definitely liked it better fresh.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2014 5/2/13
aroma of vanilla, caramel apple, molasses, malt.
medium to heavy body.  velvetly smooth.  liquor, sweet candy, dark fruit, molasses. slight warming aftertaste. very thick, smooth, sweet, malty/alcohol. 

Second bottle, after sitting for a year. 5/22/14
Very sweet, kind of sugary, malt, dark fruit. Almost like a thick fruit pie filling, spices
Taste is similar. So, so sweet. Still a warming aftertaste. The sweetness/sugariness is fairly strong, probably stronger than it was initially. A little more alcohol burn but still not as much as you may expect from such a strong beer.

What can I say about Dark Lord? Well it starts with my experience of it and that clouds my rating which Dark Lord received a perfect score. My first courting of the DL came at Dark Lord Day this past Saturday. I went with my buddy who got the tix (big thanks to to Big Mike). I had so much fun standing in line for 5 hours, who would of figured that. I got to share some of the best beers I the world with new friends that we met that day. I also got to taste 3 different vintages and types of Dark Lord. 
This stout is close to perfection. I hope to get tickets every year because it truly is an honor to be at DLD. The event is fitting for a stout this good. Completely black, wonderful nose, tastes of chocolate and balanced better than the suspension on a Ferrari. It takes a festival to honor the 'craft' of this beer. I refuse to say more about the beer as you must taste it...experience it for yourself.  Three Floyd's is a world class brewery that has mastered the stout, the pale ale and the IPA, please don't grow FFF you are perfect now. I bow and submit  in honor of this brewery and a perfect stout. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 red wax:
Pours thick, dark brown/black/oily/purple...
Chocolate, raisin, vinous aroma.
Thick...dark fruit taste..vanilla, locorice, molasses..
Incredibly smooth despite the ABV...
But still, a massively epic concoction...
wow.

2011 Vintage at DLD. Pours thick black with mocha creamy head. Nose is off toffee, chocaolate, a bit sweetness. Very thick going down with a complex mix off coffee, cocoa, malt, and some slight fruit sweetness. Can¬ít say enough about the body of the beer, velvet smooth. This beer delivers.

Orange cap at DLD. DAMN. They just dont make a bad DL.  Fortunate to have had 8-12 and thought last years was excellent.  13 is a slight notch better.  Can¬ít wait to lay my down to join another vertical down the road. :)

2013, orange wax. I¬íll start with this: pretty disappointing Dark Lord. Aroma is a combo of bacon and sun tan lotion, coupled with molasses and sweet notes. Pours as it should. Dark motor oil color. Almost no lace to speak of. Taste is very sweet for a Russian imperial stout, strong cherry flavor. 3 Floyds went way out of the box this year. Palate is thick and syrupy. Overall, this is a sub par Dark Lord.
This is a pile of chocolate piece of heaven. So big. Can't even put this on the grid. So big

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2015 Ok, its Dark Lord Day. I¬ím at home taking care of our twin babies while my wife is at work. 2012 vintage. Pours thick, dark, dark brown and with essentially no head (just a tiny bit of tan bubbles around the edge of my snifter). Big legs on this beer when swirled around. Vanilla and then a bit of roasted coffee in the nose. Yes this is a sweet one for sure - almost no hint of 15% alcohol anywhere. I can easily see why the barrel aged versions are so sought after. I really like this but it didn¬ít quite live up to the hype.

Update 2015 version, just a month after it was released. I like this more fresh. I can find th vanilla and the coffee in the taste that seemed to be missing before. Bumping from a 3.9 to a 4.1.
2011 Bottle.  Very sweet with a slight tartness and a mellow coffee presence that seems to have faded over time.  Overall kind of boring and too sweet.

22 ounce bottle shared, 2011 yellow wax. Abundant aroma of sweet dried fruit, malt and oats and chocolate whoppers candy. Appearance is motor oil black, brown head, syrupy thick and gulpy out of the bottle. Taste is molasses, very sweet, black cherries, chocolate, oats, and a small amount of vanilla. The mouthfeel was big, vinous and mouth coating, durable flavor, and most of all, highly drinkable despite the ultra high abv.  All around delicious stuff that somehow manages to live up to its reputation. I can¬ít wait to get some more.

2009 version.  Bought at Dark Lord Day, before the event jumped the shark. But the beer is still top notch. Pours a can of motor oil, thick and black. Aroma and flavor are full of coffee, malt, marshino cherries and a sense of alcohol. Very complex. Definitely a top 10 beer.

Bottle, about a year old. Pours black, some spotty tan head. Aroma is sweet, brown sugar with molasses, chocolate and toffee. Flavor is similarly sweet, almost too much so. My mouth feels very sticky.  Weird type of aftertaste, not sure what it is. Good beer but not as good as I was hoping.

Hail Justin for this Dark Lord 2011.

Nose is coffee, dark fruit and a little booze.
Fruit, molasses/syrup. Hints of coffee, vanilla, tobacco and leather.
Body is smooth and full, sweet and complex. Gets a little sweeter as it warms
Just awesome!

Rating #2000! Imperial Stout rating #200! - 650ml bottle from a trade with stawn. Thanks!
2009 vintage, white wax - Pours pitch black with a tiny sticky head that disappears quickly. Intense and complex aroma of roasty malts, sweet vanilla, hints of syrup, molasses, salty licorice, tar, alcohol and caramel. Taste is quite robust and complex with strong roasty sweetness and notes of molasses, rye, sweet vanilla, plums, ripe fruits, caramel, coffee and licorice. Finish is warming, sticky and long lasting with roasty rye notes, hints of molasses, vanilla and tar. Quite complex and massive, but surprisingly well balanced imperial stout. Surprisingly drinkable and tasty considering the sweetness, which I¬ím usually not that fond of. Here the heaviness overpowers it nicely. It would be interesting to get to taste the barrel aged versions of this one, I¬ím sure I would love them even more...

UPDATED: APR 26, 2015  2009 version(white wax) for 5500 yen at Craft Heads in Tokyo shared with David. This beer blew me away!  It poured a dark inky black with almost no head and little carbonation which is what you expect from a high ABV stout. The mouthfeel was thick and filling. A powerful aroma, boozy, port like. Malty sweet, plum, lots alcohol burn. You get the heat but it¬ís not overpowering. Smooth, each sip is quite different! It is a really complex beer which changed as it warmed up.  Amazing, it lives up to the hype. A must try for all beer lovers. ----2014--- Dark lord 2014 

Bottle through a trade with Charule in Chicago drunk a year later on Dark Lord Day at a tasting in Osaka. Pouring pitch black with a rusty wisp of foam that vanished in the blink of an eye. The nose is phenomenal: molasses, maple, sweet burnt sugar. Full bodied, surprisingly chewy nuttiness, Nutella, rich caramel, vanilla - as with the 2009 every sip gives you something new. Jaw-droppingly good. Maybe not quite as mind-blowing the second time around but it¬ís intense nuttiness really wowed me.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2014 Silver wax bottle - ¬í07 with Vin and Bill, courtesy of Bill. Pours a thick black with almost no head and leggy, syrupy coating around the glass. Aromas of molasses, raisins, figs, chocolate, vanilla, caramel.  Really smooth.  The molasses flavor is pretty strong.  This was possibly past its prime but still delicious.

6/5/2014 - small pour of an ¬í07 bottle courtesy of Steve at Alla Spina. Definitely past its prime. Pretty oxidized now. Still enjoyable. Lots of sherry notes but getting a little soy sauce coming through. Thank you Steve for the pour.
Bottle 2011. Color black with medium brown head. Aroma malt, coffee, chocolate. Taste sweet, coffee, bitter chocolate.Great beer.

Bottle at Craft Heads, Tokyo. 2009 vintage. Black colour with no head. Thick aroma of dark fruits, plum, port with some alcohol in it. Very heavy mouthfeel. Oily. Getting thirsty from drinking it. Strong but well balance flavour of plums, coffee, plum, dark fruits, raisin. An excellent beer.

2009 vintage.  No head, but I didn't expect any.  Ultra complex while not overpowering.  Very rarely have a had a beer with so many deep favors without them competing against one another. Roasted notes, coffee, molasses, and dark fruit all seem in perfect balance. Somehow retains its smoothness while remaining unapologetically bold.  Worth the wait.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2015 2009 bottle. Pours viscous black, dark tan head. Nose is fudge, vanilla, espresso, big roasted malts. Taste is dark fudge, molasses, vanilla, some dark coffee. Really thick and creamy mouthfeel. 

2015 bottle. Viscous black pour, tan head. Nose is coffee, vanilla, chocolate green apple, molasses, ash. Taste is green apple, metallic, chocolate, brown sugar, as it warms there is a lot of soy sauce which makes it hard to gulp down. Syrupy mouthfeel.

Split a 2009 and a 2008 bottle, in that order, 3 ways; my first-ever Dark Lord exposure.  Thanks Brandon and Ryan.  Never had anything like this before.  Probably the thickest beer I¬íve ever had; grips the glass unlike any human-consumable beverage I¬íve ever seen; could just about eat this with a fork.  Oozes licorice, cherry, molasses, brown sugar, vanilla, coffee, chocolate, and more.  Shockingly sweet flavor, even after 4 and 5 years.

The 2008 bottle was significantly different from and better than the 2009.  Even at 4 years old, the 2009 was too syrupy and sweet.  The 2008, with an extra year to mellow and possibly a slightly different recipe, exhibited less sweetness and more roast.

Probably not quite top 3 material but this was a real treat.  What an insane beer...

750mL bottle in a sniffer. thank you Ben! 2011. Jet black with thick white head. Complex aroma of toffee, coffee, vanilla, malt. Thick mouthfeel. Sweet, complex taste of vanilla, caramel, chocolate, and toffee. Best beer I have ever had.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2009 bottle shared at Hunaphu Day. Thick viscous black pur with a dark brown head. Huge dark fudge aroma with espresso, vanilla, roasted malts earth, currants and plums. Mouth coating fondue like chocolate, coffee, dark fruits, licorice, molasses and vanilla. Super thick mouthfeel and light booze. This beer is pretty gnarly.
black color, aroma of molasses, chocolate, dark fruits, same flavors, some soy, coffee, vanilla, smoke, booze, chewy, thick, very good but a little to sweet

2011 vintage. Pours jet black with a coffe colored head. Aroma is very intense coffee and chocolate with a touch of booze soaked dark fruit and wood.  There¬ís almost a cognac quality to it. Taste is super rich chocolate, char, licorice, peat, and maybe a bit of sambuca. There are also notes that I can¬ít quite put my finger on. Hides the 15% abv incredibly well. Viscous and oily on the palate. Incredibly complex and rich.

Very thick like molasses smells of dark currants chocolate vanilla bourbo. Taste is sweet velvet chocolate. Faint vanilla background and prunes. This is such a good beer and I see why it's number one!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Incredible aroma of vanilla and chocolate with a perfect midnight appearance, sweet taste that favors molasses and sticky but satisfying mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2008.  Pours black, oh so black.  A small tan head that disappeared quickly.  Aroma of smoked peat, alcohol soaked prunes, currants, molasses, and sweet, sweet, alcohol.  My eyes welled when I tasted it because I had to chew it.  Chocolate fudge with heavy cream.  It coats my glass like oil.  It really tastes like smoky melted chocolate ice cream with bourbon poured over it.  Finishes rich and bittersweet.

2011 - yellow wax. This one truly lives up to the hype. Black color, chocolate, molasses, vanilla, roasted malts, small hints of coffee.. very complex - It¬ís quite sweet, yet not cloying.. very very good
2012 bomber. Jet black and oily. Almost no head. Dark chocolate, raisins, plums and other dried fruit. Slick mouthfeel.
Rich in every aspect, this is close to perfection! [short review due to it coming from my backlog]

Vintage 2010. Pitch black, light head, disappears fast. Huge aromas, coffee, roasted barley, chocolate, molasses, vanilla, somewhat coconutty. Low carbonation, big mouthfeel. Also nutty taste, sweet, malty malty sweetness, lots of malt flavors coming through. Well balanced, although a bit on the sweet side

Bottle. Opaque black liquid with small tan head. Aroma of fresh coffee, licorice, bitter chocolate, light ash, raw sugar and light portish oxidisation. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter with notes of raw sugar, licorice, fresh coffee, soy and raw sugar. Nice, lots less boozy than I expected. Full bodied with low to medium carbonation and very viscous liquid. Really nice stuff.

2011 bottle at tasting...Pours black, no carbonation, smells sweet and chocolaty.  Booze is super well hidden but after nearly 2 years of age it¬ís pretty sweet.  Honestly, for me, too sweet.  I think I would like a fresh one better.  Still pretty impressive beer.  Amazing what they can pack in to a beer!

Location/Date:Yellow wax Bottle on January 25th, 2013 during day 1 of Nerd Beer Epic Weekend.
Appearance: Pours motor oil black.¬†
Aroma: Aroma roast, coffee.¬†
Taste: Light bitterness, chocolate, roast.¬† ¬†
Palate:Medium body, slick, lingering aftertaste.
Summary: Thanks Andy for bringing this tastiness! Second time I¬íve had Dark Lord after having the bourbon barrel one at an event in DC a few years back. Very good beer.
Fantastic Beer, I drank this beer in Ribeirao Preto, Brazil, in the reunion of Confrabacon - Perfect, best !!

Bottle 2010. Color was jet black with a very slight and quickly dissipating tannish brown head. Smelled strongly of wood, malt, molasses and hay. Taste was woody, malty with a slightly bitter end like a citrusy hop. On the palate you could feel the thickness and complexity of the beer but when swallowed the beer almost magically becomes weightless and lighter than air. Its hard to describe but you cant feel anything go down your throat until moments later a light alcohol burn radiates up from your stomach. The alcohol is very well hidden. Truly one of the top 2 or 3 beers i¬íve ever tasted. Its right there with the Westy12 and Goose island King Henry.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2013 2010 Served at 55F  As dark as night, very little head but of great brownish color -- poured very slow, so will award a 5 for appearance which I would have had there been more head.   Aroma is intense of wood, roasted malt, molasses sweetness.  At initial whiff, it reminds me of a barley wine more than a stout.  Start to smell a bit of vanilla after warming.  Beer is ultra smooth for the ABV.  Very light in the mouth.  Tastes of serious malt, molasses, vanilla.  A slight bit of off taste, like a metallic bitter orange peel... but awesome beer.

Bomber shared courtesy of GranvilleTim. 2010 vintage. Wow. Impressive. Pourse thick and black. Intensely roasted sweet aroma. Coffee notes. Syrupy mouthfeel. Alcohol completely hidden. Finishes with a balance of slight hoppy bitterness and sweet vanilla. Wonderfully complex yet so easily drnkable. Absolutely yummy.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2014 6 year vertical 6.1.13

13 - 4.2/5 Black as night pour.  slow forming head.  this one is all sweetness.  Like someone added a crap load of sugar to my coca pebbles.  chocolate, dark fruit.  Thick, thick, thick.

12 - 4.2/5 3rd time trying this.  Had fresh on tap, 9 months old, and now.  Definitely improving with time.  Way to sweet new.  Sweetness has died down to the point where it is actually about as sweet as 13.  Main difference here is that there is a lot of cherry, especially on the back end.

11 - 4.6/5.  This right here was my favorite of the bunch, for some reason this had an insane amount of coffee.  But backed up by chocolate, dark malt.  Insanely thick.  A lot less sweet than the previous.

10 - 4.4/5  Less sweetness, most balanced in my opinion.  can actually taste a bit of alcohol in this one.  Previous ones it was completely covered up by the sugar like jungle juice.

09 - 4.5/5 - sweetness died out even more.  Somewhat European, has a Baltic maltiness to it.

08 - 4.3/5 - still sweet, dark malt slightly burnt.  Sludge in the bottle. 

Edit - figured out how to format
This is everything a Russian imperial stout should be. I was fortunate enough to get 2 bottles this year. Very good.

Drank a 2012 version of this great beer. Tasted of coffee and cherries. Very little head on the pour.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2010 Green Waxed Bottle.  Pours a thick dark black, no head with just a touch of carbonation bubbles comes up.  Aroma is deep dark malts, dark fruits, sweetness.  Taste is big sweet dark chocolate, sugar cane, thick toffee, coffee, and even some leather/tobacco.  Very nice brew and came across very approaceable despite the massive ABV.  For the hype it quite nice.  Would I drive 10 hours and deal with the line for DLD?  Maybe to try a barrel treatment....

Gold wax, 2006, tasted blind at Paul¬ís place. Pours near black with a beige head. Lighter roasted malts, sweet dark chocolate and dark fruits, medium sweetness, and some molasses in the finish. Big thanks to Paul for pulling this one out.

2009 white wax. Black, molasses-y sludge pours nearly still and headless in my glass. Slightly oxidized aroma, burnt malts, coffee. Huge body is this beer's strongest quality. Traditional DL soy sauce on the palate, sweet, some vanilla too. 2010 is the best vintage since '08. Perfect example of why all DL should be barrel aged.

2012 bottle.  Pours deep brown with a slight tan head.  Aroma mostly of cinnamon, liquorice. Taste is sickly sweet,  huge cinnamon bomb. Slight alcohol burn.  But incredibly unbalanced. Need something to wash this taste out of my mouth.

Chilled brown bomber with yellow wax poured into a snifter at a JStax tasting.  Pours black with small light brown head.  Some lacing, thick body, medium carbonation, and vinous aroma.  Taste is sweet malt, cherry, and roasted malt.  Very good beer.

Poured from a 2011 bottle. Pours a still black with no head. Aroma has licorice, cinnamon, dark chocolate, coffee, toffee, caramel, oats, cola, and molasses. Very sweet and malty. Molasses really comes through in this beer. Reminds me a great deal of horehound candy. Pretty thick and syrupy. Nice beer overall.

This is the beer to end all beers. This is the standard all others must meet. The pour is dark thick and fragrant. Notes of coffee and chocolate waft from the glass. The taste is dark deep and complex. Vanilla comes through the darkness. The beer is very cloying on the palate.  If there was one beer left to drink in the world till the end of time this is the one. I tried to be critical of this beer but it¬ís everything a beer could be.

2009 bottle from long ago. Reviewed from back log. Consumed in early 2012, though, so around 3 years old.

A: Pure, unadulterated blackness with a very thin mocha head.

N: Rubber, dark chocolate, and loads of sea salt. Mmm, soy sauce.

T: Raspberry, chocolate, and soy sauce. Oh, that delightful Chinese topping for beers like this. Blech.

M: Thick and oily. Certainly can¬ít go wrong with this feel. 

O: Maybe not as bad as Baller, and it¬ís better than previous vintages I¬íve tried, but this beer never ceases to amaze me. It¬ís not good, but it¬ís proof that DLD has power over its visitors.

Bottle shared on Christmas Day with northropfrye! I can smell and taste the coffee vanilla and molasses that it was brewed with, but I also get fruity notes. Decadently sweet. A most delicious Christmas treat.

Christmas Day treat 2012. Bottle shared with dreamflower. Thanks for the trade, Brian! Yellow wax (2011). Exquisite appearance of dark black with creamy brown head, nice lacing, fairly active carbonation at first. Aroma is very sweet and bready, dried fruit. Taste is also dominated by sweet malts and dried fruit, cherries and chocolate, with a faint bitter coffee backbone. Abv completely masked. Not boozy at all. Excellent stuff.

2012 red wax bottle - thanks BelgianBeerGal! Pours opaque black with a small brown head that leaves some lacing. Aroma - whoah, this is a chocolate bomb! Strong notes of milk chocolate, roasted malt, raisin, and a bit of coffee. Flavor is about the same - kind of like grown up chocolate milk. Very sweet and milk chocolatey, with a light bitter finish. Full bodied and creamy. This would be tough to drink by yourself, but as an after dinner sipper with a friend it is quite nice. There is some alcohol warming present, but surprisingly little given the ABV.
