Dark brown color, good head and lacing for a stout. Aroma is mostly milk chocolate, some raisin, fig too. Chocolate flavor too, sweet in the beginning, bitter coffee coming through in the middle, warming alcohol finish. Tobacco note comes through sometimes. A bit of a dessert beer.

2011 yellow wax, courtesy of smith4498. Thanks a ton, man!  Pours a thick black with a 2 finger brown head. Super strong aromas of molasses, some roast, some alcohol. First sip reveals heavy residual sugar, no coffee notes at all, no hop notes. Slightly bitter from the roast, but this is mostly a sugar bomb. Lots of chewy molasses. Some sweet apple. Alcohol is hidden quite well for such a beast of a beer. Not as good or as bad as I thought it was going to be.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2013 Bottle from beer trade Madmitch76; 2011 yellow wax version, dark brown pour, tan head, roasted malt nose, flavour is molasses, raisins, some vanilla, slight bitterness absolutley glorious stout. Hope our paths cross again, wished I¬íd save it for a few years. 

Just diving into a 2009 white and what can I girlfriend said if was like bovril could have a point because it had a slick mouthfeel, the alcohol in your face not unpleasant, Glorious lucky to have had again.

2009 white wax, poured at a small tasting. This smells like chocolate and a little coffee. The color of the abyss is what you see in the glass. No head slight ring of chocolate milk bubbles. The taste of sweet an oxidation exists. Hints of burnt and roast come through past the sweetness. The feel is heavy with a thick chewy body. Overall this seems to be on it¬ís way down but it¬ís drinkable.

Sampled from bottles as part of Zwanze 2012 at West Lakeview Liquors in Chicago.   Thanks to the generous folks who shared their beer with a few gifted souls at Zwanze...one from a beer tender behind the bar...another just in the crowd around the pool table...life is indeed good.

Added note...one was a 2008; the other a 2010...both were the ¬ístraight¬í DL as best as I could tell.

What can you say?  Pours black...no head...nose and initial taste (which is all I got...no complaints) is expresso, licorice, bitter chocolate, cherry...amazing.

We need to break out our own supplies for a vertical some night...

2012 vintage
Aroma- big toffee, barrel qualities, licorice, coffee, booze
Appearance- mostly black, somewhat murky in the lighter areas of the glass, not much head
Taste- cherry juice, coffee, intense candied sugar sweetness, some licorice
Palate- relatively full bodied with the flavors but a thinner texture
Overall- Big letdown.  Many people warned me of the overwhelming sweetness but this was out of control.  I split the bottle with a close friend and 11oz was twice as much as really wanted.

2007 vintage, thanks to whoever had brought it. Drenched in rum raisin ice cream, sugar beet molasses, mint, Hershey¬ís chocolate syrup, espresso grounds, toasted hops and booze. Black pour, there¬ís no denying it. Its shea butter hued head was quite impressive. Was passed around on Black Friday, Scottsdale.
2011 bottle shared by Andy Overby. Definitely get the molasses. Also notes of chocolate, coffee, malt, caramel.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2014 Well WOW I¬ím having it again....big thanks to BeersIveKnown for sharing this bottle at EBBC14, Dublin
2010 bottle [280614]
Pitch black, pours like engine oil (4)
Aroma of big soy, rich dark milky chocolate, no booze at all, huge rich meaty malts, massive intense malts, big complexity, massive aroma (9)
Taste of dark chocolate, massive rich dark malts, rich dark toffee, dense rich dark fruits, huge complexity, dense deep chocolate, incredible (10)
Palate - soft carb, full body, very sweet dense malts (but not overly so), alcohol is hardly noticeable, very oily, slick. Finish is as main flavour (5)
Overall - This is the real deal...better than the others I had at Craig¬ís...just stupidly brilliant 9/4/10/5/18 4.6  - Average 4.5

Big thanks to Craig to get the chance to try TWO of them at the same time. Should have been rate 900 but its #896 [103012]
2007 bottle
Pitch black, no head (3)
Aroma - Dark fruits, soy sauce, soft dark roast, only of hint of booze, very complex aroma, chocolate, red wine, red berries, very slight sour note, much more complex than 2011 (9)
Taste - Complex rich fruity dark malts, chocolate, rich red berry malts, touch of that sourness and there is a strange taste in there, maybe savoury that¬ís not in the 2011,  great flavour though (8.5)
Palate - no carb, rich full body, very smooth complex finish as main flavour (5)

2011 bottle
Pitch black, frothy tan head, no light thorough (4)
Aroma - Softer than 2007, more chocolately nose, light spicy , no slight sourness, rich dark fruity roast, less complex (8)
Taste - Rich sweet fruity dark chocolate, touch of dark treacle, again less complex than 2007 but it¬ís more chocolately and doesn¬ít have that unusual savoury umami note, rich meaty dark roast, slight salty soy (9)
Palate - Full body, finish as main flavour, less complex than 2007 (4)

Overall - The 2007 was more complex and the beer had changed a lot, the 2011 was more chocolatey but the taste was possibly more balanced. I preferred the 2007 - better aroma and palate but they were both great beers. It¬ís a great Imperial Stout - only criticism it¬ís rather sweet. But there are better impys out there....Magic Rock Bearded Lady I¬íd still rate over this -  8/4/9/4/17 4.2
black no head with a good brown tan rim thinner than expect some treacle  long sooothing not at all heavy biggest but suave

Bottle (bomber with yellow wax), courtesy of tkrjukoff. Black with no head. Sugary, surupy, with raisins and figs, intense dark chocolate, some coffee. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. Sweet, medium bitterness. What is all the fuss about here?

Bomber courtesy of tkrjukoff. 2011 vintage. Thanks for finally getting the chance to try this. Pours viscous black with a small dark chocolate head that quickly dissipates while leaving a small trace on the glass. Smell is sweet with roasted malts, quality dark chocolate, molasses, dark roast coffee, vanilla fudge, burnt caramel, toffee, salty liquorice candy, wood, black pepper and raisins.¬†Taste is very sweet, malty and fruity with roasted malts, prunes, dark quality chocolate, raisins in rum, alcohol, burnt sugar, molasses, burnt caramel, vanilla fudge, sweetened coffee, American oak and Madeira wine.¬†Mouthfeel is round, sticky sweet, boozy and full bodied. Finish is sweet and tiny bitter with roasted malts, prunes, raisins, bitter chocolate, port wine, I feel I¬ím missing the point.

Sampled at USSkovde
Pitch black. No head. 
Sweet chocolate, hint of milky chocolate in the aroma. 
The flavour is sweet. Milky chocolate, dry cocoa, figs, prune, dates
Sampled at UCTS testing. Pours pitch black with almost no head. Smells coffee, salty, sweet roasted malt. Tastes creamy chocolate, abit coffee and roasted malt. Very well balanced and lovely.

(65 cl bottle, 2012 vintage courtesy of steasy66, huge thanks!) Pours pitch black with little, toffee head. Good lace. Aroma is roasted malt with notes of rye bread, smoke, syrup, coffee and a hint of vanilla. Creamy texture, viscous, full body, soft to no carbonation and a sweet, roasted finish. Taste is mostly sweet and filling to the point of being cloying with hints of dark fruit. Alcohol is well masked by the massive layer of sweetness. I find this one too sweet to be really enjoyable, though.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2013 (Vintage 2008): Un nez aussi intense que la 2012 mais moins fruitcake malgr√© le fait qu¬íelle est brass√©e sans caf√©, beaucoup de m√©lasse et de petits fruits tout de m√™me. Je monte la moyenne de 0.2. (Vintage 2012): G√¢teau au fruits monstrueux, limite trop riche, ce qui m¬íemp√™che de profiter du caf√© et des subtilit√©s qui pourraient s¬íy camoufler. J¬íai un peu plus appr√©ci√© la 2011 mais √ßa reste une d√©ception pour moi.

2010 vintage shared by ThomasHardy in line at the CBS release. Poured into my Deschutes snifter.

A: Pours like motor oil with some very dark brown hues around the edges where the light hits. There is some legs on the bad boy. No head.

S: Dark fruits and chocolate with a roasted malt. Faint coffee in the background.

T: Lots going in the flavor. Black licorice and bitter chocolate are upfront with some dark fruits and a slight alcohol taste, but there is no heat behind it. A nice roasted malt as well to finish it out.

M: Viscous and palate coating. Heavy with a subtle carbonation. Really feels great.

O: My first Dark Lord. This met the expectations for me and I¬ím excited to try other vintages now that I¬íve had my first. Another big thanks ThomasHardy for sharing.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-02-2011

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2015 From a 2012 vintage bottle shared at Borefts beer festival, de Molen, day two.  Thanks Kermis!  Pours thick and black with a tan head. Molasses and dark cherries in the aroma.  Complex layers of dark fruits, raisins, prunes and bread dough.  Fabulous.

2015 vintage from Peabody¬ís in Blowing Rock.  A huge thanks!  Still fabulous!

66cl Bottle @ RBBSG, Courtesy of Vincent. 2010 Vintage. Black coloured beer wiht a small off white head. Strong roasted malty and alcoholic hinted aroma. Almost an oily full texture. Finish is strong sweet slightly roasted herby and malty. Strong, but very nice.

Bottle courtesy of and shared with Kermis. What can you say! Almost jet black pour with a thin tan head and broken lace. Roasted malt aroma but the real treat is in the richness of the flavour. You could almost cut this with a knife, or so it seems. It's sweeter than expected, but that works well with the malty chocolate and vanilla flavours to produce a truly outstanding beer. There is little bitterness to this beer, but its not something you will drink to refresh yourself on a hot summer day. This is one to keep you warm on a cold winter night!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2010 courtesy of Beerwolf77, thanks Todd!

A: Pours absolute onyx with a massive khaki color head. Retention is amazing. Two things you wouldn¬ít expect given the high ABV. This is the absolute thickest looking beer on the planet, no question.

S: Big raisin and fig right off the bat, big time black strap molasses, ripe chocolate berries give a little sweetness, and super rich fudge. Not necessarily as complex as other examples, but still amazing

T: All of the above plus a little char, maraschino cherries, definite but subtle coffee/espresso, and a noticeable enough hop presence to balance. More charred/molasses notes than sweetness.

MF: Absolute thickest beer on the planet, more so than FBS, KBS, or Hunaphu¬ís. The finish is of char, molasses, and subtle coffee.

O: Amazing...not as complex as some other world class stouts, but certainly awesome in its own way. Deserving of the hype and rating, must try.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2016 Wow bottle from 2010. Hard to explain the aroma so complex dark fruits molasses vanilla. Color is jet black. With almost no head. Taste is vanilla dark fruits molasses. Has a sweet and burnt taste. One of the top beers all time.

2010 Bottle from Mane Liquor.  Pours A pitch black almost car oil like resemblance with very little head. Aromas of coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate and burnt raisins.  So much chocolate!! Taste is coffee lingering with warmness from the alcohol. This is fantastically blended. Very smooth and leaves a dark chocolate coating around your mouth. This is amazing.
2011 from bottle. Thick, dark, vanilla and coffee tones. Hits the bitter and sweet tones with smooth, shuddering feeling.

2007 bottle, silver wax, reviewed from notes taken 05/11/2011.  Pitch black pour, viscous, with little head that fades quickly, leaving a slick glaze.  Aroma of rich milk chocolate, coffee and toffee.  Taste is smooth, sweet chocolate, hint of vanilla, rounded with roast and coffee bitterness.  Smooth and creamy, not much carbonation, no alcohol presence.  A bit sweet, but still very tasty.

2012 bottle pours jet black with a small brown head. The aroma is heavy sweet black roasted malt, liquorice, light coffee, tar and chocolate. The flavour is roasted malt, sweet caramel, liquorice, and chocolate. Super complex but a bit on the sweet side. Thick and full bodied.  More hype than beer, but I still enjoyed it

Uploading from Beer Buddy App. Notes from memory. My first experience with this beast. Palate reminiscent of port wine. Enormously complex. Chocolate, coffee, dark fruits etc. Every sip a little different than the last. Huge expectations and wasn't disappointed. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Did a tasting of 10-12, did a blend of the three. Scent was chocolate cake with a nice whisky/bourbon flavor blend. Taste is an outstanding chocolate blend with some nice whiskey character, outstanding beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2016 Bottle of the 2009 for my birthday. Pours a thick solid black with a minimal beige head. Aroma is dark chocolate cake, coffee, roasted almonds, soy sauce, molasses. Slick and oily mouthfeel, sweet and nutty on the palate with a long chocolatey finish. Taste is almonds, chocolate, coffee, gingerbread, hazelnut, brown sugar. Absolutely delicious and definitely worthy of all the hype.

2009 bottle. This beer of destiny pours a oily black with a light beige head. The nose is raisin, soy sauce, bourbon and molasses. The pallet is black forest chocolate cake, red fruit, hints of coffee, burnt toast, cocoa nibs, and bourbon oak. That is a phenomenal beer!! Very complex, with each taste showing a new character. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2014 Pour is dark. Head is small, thick and lasting. The aroma is malty with licorice and lightly roasted coffee. Chocolate bean and christmas style fruit is also pressent. A little hop is coming through also.. The aroma is surprisingly mellow and unthreatening. Now the flavor is an entirely different thing.. I was surprised at how potent this beast was. So rich and thick without getting overpowering or too sticky - its not totally ballanced though. And the aftertaste is looong but its not completely perfect. Just slightly too soy ish and too much on rich molasses.. But still very very good! Thanks to @motherbrother for sharing this legend.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2013 As with so many other ratebeerians, this has been a long time want, and I am quite excited to have a go at this. Also my # 400 rating. Cheers to me;)
Pour black, with a reddish/brown hue, small light mocha slightly creamy head, and a good amount of alcoholic lacing. 
The smell of this is pretty "green" with some, to me, slightly off notes of seaweed or moss, but on the palate this truly is some tasty shit!! Molasses, coffee, vanilla, rum spacked raisins, chocolate, toffee, roasted malts, slight tobacco, brown n¬í burned sugar, syrup, some slight hoppy notes perhaps (this is a 2012 vintage, so it is quite fresh) taste is quite sweet upfront, with a rather long, roasted bitter aftertaste (with a whole lot of coffee lingering) .... Hell yes!!
Full and sticky oily body, with a semi-flat carbonation. Rather filthy indeed... Thanks to Tom for sending me this!!  .... Oh, where is did the 15 abv go??

11/VIII/2012 bomber bottle @ RBBSG - 2010 vintage (2012-912) Thanks to Vincent for sharing the bottle!
Clear very dark brown beer, no head. Aroma: mocha, caramel, pretty sweet, sugary, some vanilla, bit bready. MF: soft to no carbon, medium to full body. Taste: lots of chocolate, dark chocolate, sugary, some mocha, bit peppery, lots of caramel. Aftertaste: caramel, dark chocolate, sweet sugary, surprising yet moderate hoppy ending. As 77ships stated before: chugging this shit is not a good idea.

2012 Bottle. Pours a cloudy brown with medium creamy beige head lasting awhile leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is a strong raisin malt and caramel. Thick mouthfeel with a sweet malt chocolate, molasses, and sweet finish. Alcohol present but not overpowering, a very good Imperial stout from Three Floyds.

Thx. to VIncent // BIG long time want // #1200 Rating // 2010 / Green wax vintage // 66 cl. sampled & partially chugged @ RBBSG 2012 // this is not very chuggable plus some of the was broke of and I accidently swallowed // this does not taste taste better with the wax, just a culinary warning // the label saying Dark Lord Russian Imperial Beer is pretty cool // although Russian Imperial Bear would have been cooler // cover art is all D&G or Magic or something, not bad, I know where this appeals to and it is // its black dude, like spinal tap black, something in the way of a mocha head // smells sweet, smells like sugar, molasses, mocha, lots of chocolate, syrup // taste is sweet  but not like unbearable like people would have you believe, sweet yes but not the sweetest, not like Creme Brulee or 3rd Dark Horizon, those are very sweet, this is just sweet, lots of chocolate, mocha, chocolate truffles, smooth molasses, malts, malts and malts, solid like a rock, brown sugar, syrup, there are actually still hops in the back, touch dark fruits // creamy smooth body // wouldn¬ít have guessed that this is a 15 % the sweetness must cut the booze // the thing with this beer is that it is a good stout but has been surpassed by others, it is good but there is much better, back when this was first released it probably blew peoples minds, how many 15 % stouts did even exist back then? // the hype, the difficulty and more important, the cost of acquiring this are simply no longer worth it, I understand the lower ratings // if I would have payed the 80 euro¬ís they were asking at the store for this, I would be cross about this too but luckily I didn¬ít // I don¬ít think I would have ever convinced myself to do it // this doesn¬ít go up to 11

Oh my god! I had been saving this for a while. I had the 2007 vintage. Upon opening I was hit with the sweet smell of molasses. The pour was jet black and very syrupy. There was pretty much zero head. I couldn¬ít believe how thick and smooth this was. I almost felt like I needed a knife and fork. Lots of molasses, coffee and sweet chocolate in the taste. Little to no carbonation. This is by FAR the best beer I have ever had.

A 2004 vintage was opened at my college graduation party in June. The pour was inky black and thick with a rich, sugary taste of syrup and coffee. The bottom yielded thick globs of sludge that were lapped up by some of the attendees. It was an honor to say I had a chance to sample on this special occasion.

2009 vintage

A-- Dark, thick syrupy looking pour. Very little if any carbonation. No head at all. Just a bit of film with this. Massive and evil looking beer. Bordering on port. No head retention, no nothing. Lots of alcohol lacing on the sides of the glass. 

S-- Dark fruits, raisin, and a lot of malt. More I worked into this it smelled like a port or a Thomas Hardy Old Ale. Early on a lot of booze ut once it settled down it was closer to a Hardy in every way in the nose. 

T-- Thick, syrupy, rich and a lot of raisin, dark fruits and port like qualities in the nose. 

M-- Over bearing and rich. A lot of fruit and syrup. Can tell this was a mess as a pup but with age this changed to a huge old ale. A lot of fruit and leather. Thick as hell and sweet to boot. Booze was well hidden for how sweet it was and drew a comparison to a old school Thomas Hardy profile. Little carbonation and a lot of body to this. 

O-- 09 had to be a mess. Has developed into something good but very port like. no way I could drink the whole thing on my own. A lot of sugar and very thick. 15% ABV is well hidden in it, the thickness it is there as well as the sweetness. By lore this is pretty overrated but it was quite interesting as it changed to a massive strong belgian strong dark ale. not for the faint at all. Total sipper.

yellow wax: Opened 7/27/12. Aroma of dark chocolate and cherry. Deep plum and alcohol. Black pour with a little dark head. flavor is more dark chocolate, cherry, coffee and molasses. This is one absolutely incredible beer, and it is amazingly smooth for a 15% beer.

Epic tasting ending with Dark Lord 2012 vintage
Thanks to woodjjacct for sharing this one!

Appearance: Black as night with no head formation. Swirling does create a one finger head but it does dissapate quickly. Absolutly no light penetration at all even when held up to light. Your typical RIS in appearance.

Smell: Big time molasses notes with the dark fruits taking a center stage. Sweet very sweet with alcohol soaked figs. Some dark maybe blackberries evident and some tobacco notes. Leather is also noted at the tail end.

Taste: This is one enormous beer! Very, very sweet with alcohol soaked dark fruit jumping out at me. Molasses and brown sugar very evident and the sweetness lingers forever. I feel as though the beer has literally stuck to my teeth, gums, and tongue. A trip to the dentist tomorrow may be needed. The sweet sticky feel just does not leave at all. It is very chewy at the same time. No alcohol to speak of. 

Mouthfeel: This is very creamy and no carbonation and so so palate covering that its hard to believe. It covers all of my mouth and lips to the point that it is cloying. 

Overall: This was an enjoyable experience but wow what a sugar bomb! If you don¬ít have a buddy or two to share with you may by in trouble IMO

enjoyed this as my part of the beer tasting with dennoman and gEUS. a yellow wax ( beeing 2011 ) wich i got with the much apreciated help of the guy in bruges, i should learn the name of once and for all ! many many thanks to the guy who knows who he is if hes reading this.

this beer is ¬íthe legendary¬í beer of the best brewerie in the world, they made a day for it, its ultra hard to get ( spented months searching for this , i didnt know about the trades yet ) and it has such a nice label, its called dark LORD,.. what more can i say? expectations where HIGH

but, back to reality than. no smell, almost no had. colour isnt black like i expected , but dark brown. i¬íve heard this years edition was way to sweat, the yellow wax would be way more balanced. wel, lets just put it this way. i DONT wanna taste this years edition. what is this beer? liquid brown sugar? almost no complexity, one third from the bottle was already to borning... i think if you¬íd drink the whole bottle , you¬íd get sick , and not due to the alcohol. its just one step away to even taste the structure of sugar still in this. thats all i tasted. sugar sugar and sugar. dont get why this is so high in the rankings ? because they made it hard to get with their dark lord day and everything? look its not a bad beer, but its just nothing to overrule the ¬íbasic¬í specials . to compare : i¬íd rather drink a rochefort 10 than this ... i¬ím glad i tasted this, for sure, but i will not easely buy another one ...

2012 bottle to taster glass.  Opening my first bottle from this year¬ís DLD.  mahogany brown color with a short-lived cream colored head.  Aroma of molasses and...sherry vinegar?  Others described it as "tart apple". Was told that this had to do with the beer¬ís not being fully developed and the off aroma and flavor would go away in a couple of months.  The standard flavor is still good with lots of golden brown sugar and dark molasses.  The sourness was definitely noticable in the taste, though.  It definitely got better as the beer opened up.  More molasses flavors emerged as the bottle sat open.  Highly recommend decanting this year¬ís vintage until it ages a bit more.  Will rerate when I open my next bottle.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2013 Tasting of all vintages of Dark Lord so far : 
DL 2012 : Way too sweet, too unbalanced and the only thing i taste is molasses, candy sirup and booze, nothing else, boy this is bad !
Ok i¬íve had worse but whoowy this is far away from some of the best stouts in the world ( Cuv√©√© Delphine/Black Albert, Hel & Verdoemenis, Parabola, Stone ) 
Big dissapointment ! ( ratings will be on this release)  more to add later ...

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2013 Kindly shared by Dylan Verduyn (2011). and Jeffo (2012 and 2008). All 660 ml bottles (duh...). 2011 review: pours dark red brown with a thick oily consistency, no head. Aroma of coffee, coffee beans... and lots of booze. Body is fully sweet, overly sweet, and sweet. Taste of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, some port hints as well - no balance whatsoever. I am apologising to all of the Dark Lord adepts... Despite the fact that it is a good beer, this is the most overrated beer I have ever tasted.... There¬ís a dozen of other beers out there that are much more balance such as the Hunahpu, Hel & Verdoemenis, Stone (sweet as well, but way more balance), Struise BD series and Cuv√©e Delphine... 

------- to average score of a full vertical tasting (2004-2012). Beneath are overall impressions per vintage.
2012: coffee, apple, liquorice, chillies, very sweet - 2.5/5
2011: greens, coffee beans, cold coffee, blackcurrent - 2.3/5
2010: faintest aromas and taste of ¬íem all, salty, syrupy - 2.5/5
2009: soy sauce! liquorice, oyster sauce... - 2.6/5
2008: soy sauxe, liquorice, rhum & raisins, plums - 2.8/5
2007: furniture polish, leather, cigare, toffee - 3.1/5
2006: chocolate, coffee taste - 2.5/5
2005: the most flavour and aroma components - held up very well - my favourite: coffee bomb! - 3.5/5
2004: soy sauce, cough syrup - 2.6/5

All in all, they are almost eaqually bland and bleak. I hate hypes, but I got caught in this one. Had almost the full vertical traded with decent geuzes (back when I was a trading virgin). I was very happy to share them with fellow beer geeks and we had a great time. The space freed up in my cellar is now more worth to me than Dark Lords will ever be. Come on people, there are wayyyy better imperial stouts out there, even American :-p

Chiunque si avvicini al mondo della birra artigianale dopo pochi mesi forse settimane sentir√† parlare di una Imperial Russian Stout legendaria, introvabile, ovviamente deliziosa. In effetti la Dark Lord, bevuta grazie a un caro amico americano (Matt) √® una stout sui generis, forse estrema ma davvero eccezionale. Ci√≤ che mi ha lasciato stupito √® l¬íaroma, siamo abituati a cogliere l¬íarome nelle birre molto luppolate e di meno in altre tipologie, tra queste le stout. Qui invece si sprigionano note di cioccolato fondente, vanilla, caff√® tostato che subito esaltano l¬íolfatto, in bocca conferma e risulta si aggressiva (l¬íalcool si sente eccome) ma perfettamente in linea con la complessit√† dell¬íaroma. Sar√† pure una leggenda ma rimane una grandissima birra. p.s. welcome to the dark side of the force ....

2009 Vintage BOMB!
Quiz√° lo m√°s especial que he probado en su g√©nero, Aroma realmente complejo a fruta madura, frutos secos, caramelo muy oscurito,  caf√©, chocolate. Un postre! La cremosidad, textura etc rompen con todo. Pero d√≥nde est√° el alcohol que dice que tiene?
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 Much sweeter than anticipated..hint of dark cherries and coffee make this an ultra special experience.  Drank out of a baloon glass, 2012 version

2010 vintage bomber obtained from Hank at Whirlyball (thanks Austin!) and shared with ck1, Jan and my other brother. Pours inky black, thick and opaque with very little carbonation and no head. Nice lacing as I work through the glass. Aroma has dark fruits (plum/raisin), molasses and roasted malts. Multiple layered taste is of syrupy thick plums with sweet molasses, coffee, soy and caramel with some woodiness and a touch oily. A bit overwhelming with all the flavor. Finishes long and strong - alcohol in the end with a malty syrup and some sweetness. So thick and so strong it is the definition of a sipper. 9/5/9/5/16.  2011 vintage surprise from ck1, shared with Jan and my other brother - thanks bro! Somewhat distinct from the 2010 in the sugary-ness. Aroma more significant choco/coffee presence with less molasses. Taste much sweeter and not as thickly set up yet, but also less alcohol presence. Tamer, but in some ways not as good. 8/5/9/4/15 = 4.1.

Vintage 2011. Quickly vanishing off white head producing no head or lace. Nose is big time organic coffee, hand picked in Colombia by Juan Valdez. ¬†
What can I say that hasn¬ít been regurgitated already. I LOVE coffee stouts and for me, I get excited to the point where my girlfriend would want to drive 15 hours to buy tickets and get a case of this.¬†
My taste buds are in overwhelmed with deep rich, high quality coffee. ¬†
Body is luscious. Full and creamy and really a boner in a bottle!! ¬†The best hyped brew I have had in a bottle.

Acquired in a trade at some point. I have ¬í07, ¬í08, ¬í11 and ¬í12. Decided to open the 2011 vintage with friends as it has a year on it as of this writing so it¬ís at a good place along side our Surly Darkness try. Served 60 degrees F in a Hill Farmstead Glass.

A - Dark brown pour, not midnight black as I had hoped. In the glass, midnight black with no head at all. SOLID alcohol legs. 

S - Molasses is very dominant. The coffee is super fleeting..burnt and sort of watery. Nice Vanilla notes and oak.

T - WOW! This is incredible. Okay, where to start. Huge toffee and molasses. Almost like Cane Syrup I used to have on pancakes as a kid. Coffee has faded. Burnt wood. The biggest thing after molasses is the bittersweet chocolate that totally dominates the taste buds! Finish is an ultra-sweet vanilla and espresso crema sort of finish. Wow. Incredible. For 15%, there¬ís nothing boozy about this beer. It¬ís all delicious tastes in a bottle. 

M - 80% carbonation on the mouth feel. VERY heavy body. Viscous and "hellishly smooth finish"

O - This is THE king of Imperial Stouts. It¬ís incredible how tasty this is! As explained to my friend, "If this was at Wal*Mart for $10 a bottle, it would be the last beer I ever drank and I¬íd have it each and every night." Simply amazing. The best imperial stout I¬íve ever had.

2010 bottle. Black, with lacing minimal beige head, complex aroma with molasses, coffee, vanilla, tobacco, dark fruits. Dense, oily, with a long lasting aftertaste. No surprise it is one of the top imperial stouts, it is almost like a dessert. Excellent!

A long time want for me. Trade with totoropanda @ BA. S: Alcohol, burnt sweetness, toffee, and molasses. A: Black with brown lacing. T: Upfront sweet chocolate, vanilla, coffee, and a bit of bitterswetness from the molasses. M: thick, low carbonation. O: Really got to enjoy really sweet beers to enjoy this one as the sweetness can become overpowering. I enjoyed this one and I couldnt believe how damn well the alcohol is hidden,

rate no. 2000. Thanks Balazs!
Poured deep black as hell, small tan head. Aroma of cherries, plum, roasted barley and raisins, liquerice, leather and caramel. Dense aroma, dense flavor. Liquerice, cherries, liquer, roasted grains and sweet caramel. Brutal hatd character, no choise, reallyreally good!
Grass, coffee, coffee, nuts, nuts, herbs, floral, hay, bread, coffee, floral, nuts, toast, floral, chocolate, chocolate, hay

Vintage 2010. Poured into a snifter. Pours gluggingly a deep black. Sits heavy in the glass, and from it proceeds a thick mocha frothy head. The aroma is reminiscent of a stepping into the dwellings of a chocolatier. Big sweet chocolate notes, licorice, ethanol burn on the end. 

The body is warm, viscous, and palate-coating. Has held up well after 2 years of utter darkness. Subtle carbonation play on the tongue. Starts out with a sweet kiss of milk chocolate. The sweetness melds well with the mildly bitter character, but then the soy sauce-like flavor kicks in. Alcohol is noticeable, and adds a nice touch of warmness on the back end. This is good, though, this beer seems lacking somehow. Glad I had it, and glad I aged it, but I¬íd like a fresh one to compare it to, no doubt.

2012 bottle. after trying a couple times and hating it I am glad to check out this ¬í12 vintage. get some soy sauce, very caramelized, brown sugar and dark fruits. much better than the previous bottles. I don¬ít despise this beer anymore.

Have had multiple vintages a few times and finally deciding to rate.

Pours thick oily jet black, with some mocha head that dissipates. This beer¬ís got legs!

Aroma is of rich burnt coffee, with a lot of sweet milk chocolate to complement; also hints of pine. See differences in vintages below.

Flavor is rich alcoholic burning cough syrup sweetness, then a bitter chocolate finish. 

Very light carb, thick oily mouthfeel.

Overall a fantastic beer but there are huge differences between vintages.

Here are general notes between vinatages:
2007 - Smooths down quite a bit and you get a huge dominant mocha flavor
2008 - VERY huge fruit aromas and flavors. This has currants, cherries and chocolate covered raisins
2009 - Definitely very hot, some licorice and tobbaco flavors as well
2012 - tons of molasses and burnt sugar, hints of coffee

Serving type: bottle

Dark Lord vertical: I was fortunate to sample all six years of this great brew (2004-9) side by side at a tasting I hosted. Thanks to Brad for providing ¬í04,¬í05,¬í06 and to Tony for providing the ¬í09. Review is from my notes taken last night.

A: Awesome artwork on the label. Pours pitch black with a brown frothy, sticky, persistent head. Picture perfect for a big RIS.

S: Roasted malt and lots of it, chocolate, coffee, sweetness

T: So smooth, more chocolate. The ¬í09 batch has more coffee flavors up front. The ¬í04 was thick and chewy and amazingly smooth. Alcohol flavors virtually non-existent in the ¬í04,¬í05,¬í06 batches. ¬í07 and ¬í08 had a slightly thinner feel and taste than the other batches. Complex, long lingering taste that continues to develop after you swallow. The sweetness was done very well, and more subdued in the earlier vintages.

M: This brew coats the mouth and seeps into your palate. Chewy and delicious. ¬í09 was the most carbonated, as it was the youngest, and was bolder than the earlier vintages.

D: This is a huge beer and slightly sweet, which is natural, given that it is a 13% RIS. I look forward to the next time I can open a bottle of this. This will always be on my wants list.

Notes:
Paired with gourmet dark chocolate.

The ¬í04 left a thick stain in the bottom of the glass. This brew was going strong after six years of age. Plenty of carbonation left and no off flavors. This was an incredible experience.

2010 vintage consumed November 5, 2010.
The 2010 is noticeably hotter and sweeter than the previous vintages. While it¬ís still a great beer, the latest version could stand to spend some time aging in the cellar.

2012 vintage from trade. Black, with low head and soft carbonation, and strong aroma of raisins, dates and soy sauce. Flavor is sweet, with strong notes of chocolate, sweet oranges, and cherries, a little bit of soy sauce and somewhat vinous. Complexity makes the sweetness very tolerable. Finishes sweet, without any bitterness at all, and a slight tanginess lingering on the palate. Really unique, very enjoyable and interesting. A great sipping beer.  I see why it has a following.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2015 2011. Slight soy sauce int he smell. The flavor manages to not be too too sweet. Good cocooa and coffee flavors. Big dark fruits, not too much of a face slapping bitterness, this one is a sweet sipper.

2012 bottle. Port wine, maltose. Unfermented sugar. Liquid diabetes.

Pours a nauseating pitch black with a ruddy brown head. Half-decent lacing. Disturbing bready nose, punctuated with cola and coffee. Minimal maple palate, maybe a little lilac and circus peanut. Non-descript mouthfeel and disappointing finish.

2012 vintage, red wax.  Black and sticky with no head and very little carbonation.  Molasses/malt nose.  Flavor was disappointing compared to previous vintages of DL I¬íve tried - very very sweet, mostly molasses and malt.  No real alcohol taste.  Agree 2012 may improve with cellaring.

Bottle to oversized snifter (2012 vintage).  Looks fine; black and viscous with no read head or carbonation.  Smells pretty good; molasses and malt.  Tastes like liquid molasses with a pedestrian mouthfeel.  After previously trying the 2011 vintage, I can say that I was VERY disappointed.  Hopefully it improves with age.
Pure molasses in aroma and flavor.  Alcohol is very well hidden.  Soooooo sweet.  Good.  Very unique flavor.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2013 


New rating.
I am not sure why this is sold as IMPERIAL STOUT there was no roasted malt or smoke ash. it was simply MOLASSES AND SOY SAUCE.. i am very upset at how these new fan-geld brewers get away with the massive price tag let alone a ticket party who can afford this stuff? not me. i need to watch my beer dollars that¬ís why i enjoy the sam and leiny mix packs. the leiny fireside nut brown is closer to a imperial due to all THE ROASTED NUT LIKE MALT. come on three floyds lets think about the little guy and his beer budget.
2012 bottle from DLD. Does not disappoint, intense flavors or dark malt and molasses. I can¬ít wait to see how the bottle of Barrel aged tastes down the line.

Bottle at home to celebrate my no. 5000 rating on ratebeer! Black wax. Pours jet black with a small brown head. The aroma is heavy sweet black roasted malt, liquorice, light coffee, tar and chocolate. The flavour is soy, hard roasted malt, sweet caramel, liquorice, salt and chocolate. Super complex yet drinkable too the sweet side. Thick and full bodied. I saved this for my 1000 tick but it never fit in so better late than never :)
Tried 2008 and 2009, Very creamy, viscous, and full of chocolate, coffee, sugar taffy and a hint of soy sauce.

Had the 2012 dark lord red wax bottle. It was the first time I¬íd had a Russian imperial stout, and I wish I could have it more often than 4 per year. I agree with a lot of reviews on this beer. It does have a motor oil consistency going down. It is dark as night with a light head and carbonation. Tastes like cofffee , chocolate, and the alcohol content is very well hidden. I live 40 minute from the brewery and am currently moving to California. I will definitely be flying back next year for my 4 beer allotment.

Rating the 2012. Pours a dark brown almost pitch black. In the glass there was little head and the edges had a nice red hue. On the nose I got chocolate, dark fruits, sweetness like I¬íve never smelled before in a RIS. Faint coffee background as well. As it opened up this beer became a fine port! Very creamy texture but the viscosity was not as thick as I expected. Absolutely no trace of alcohol, it tasted like a port. This is the sweetest RIS I¬íve ever had.  Damn fine beer, just go out and find one
Bottle shared with Timfoolery and DgdrBlu. Pour a dark brown with little to no head. Tasted of Dark chocolate molasses and all that good stuff. This was my kind of beer and it lived up to the hype.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2012 Bottle from Stfun trade. I heard bad things before I tasted this from some trade partners, and we did a side-by-side with Darkness. I was surprised that Dark Lord took the cake. Darkness had aroma of slight soapiness, and the palate was rather bright and lingered. I have to add that the Dark Lord was 2009 and the Darkness was 2011. The Dark Lord really had an aspect of brandy and had a similar hint to Utopia. There was absolutely no lacing or legs, funny for a 15% beer. Overall, there was a nice bitter chocolate flavor and wasn¬ít too cloying. Amazing beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
22 ounce, 2009 on Memorial Day Weekend from the broker.  Notes and taste of extreme dark chocolate.  I won¬ít waste your time; just drink it.
La mia esperienza con la Dark Lord √® stata una vera delusione. Troppo dolce, troppo sbilanciata, troppo spessa, si tagliava col coltello. In giro c¬í√® di molto meglio.

Pours a thick pitch black appearance with a two finger mocha head, looks amazing! Aroma of chocolate, coffee, sweet fruits and alcohol. Reminds me more of a port than a beer but it¬ís a good thing that I love ports. Taste follows the nose yet sweeter, I am amazed by the complexity of this beer as it warms it gets even more complex.

2011 bottle Pours opaque brown with little to no head.  Aroma is nutty, malty, rich, and mollasses.  Taste is exceedingly sweet for my tastes with absolutely no roasty "stout" characteristics.  This is a barley wine to me.  Its not black, its not roasty, its very low carb.  Its a very good barleywine though.
UPDATED: MAR 28, 2014 2011 vintage a year later. This one needs a bit to warm up. Starts like vodka and molasses. After a big it tastes like a very good malty barleywine.

2007(!) bottle @ Mikkeller Bar during CBC week, split with a generous group from Switzerland. The pour¬ís thick, deep brown in color with virtually no head. The nose is hot oatmeal raisin cookies and after-tea liqueur. Notes of deep chocolate, burned malts and coffee rind. This smell¬ís quite spicy and hot for a 5 year-old beer. The taste is burned brown sugar and heavy milk chocolate syrup, port wine and blackberry jam. Big, sugary notes of oatmeal cereal and dark chocolate. Vinous and smoky, too. The texture is very oily, the body¬ís quite thick and oaky. This is a very viscous beer. Overall, the 2007 vintage is still drinking actively and a bit hot. I see now why people don¬ít typically recommend drinking young bottles. This beer has such a huge profile that it¬ís hard not to feel a bit let down. It¬ís not a bad imperial stout by any means, it¬ís pretty nice indeed. It just felt a bit flabby and ungainly at times.

Bottle, 2007, silver wax. Pours pitch black with almost no head. Smells of peat, vanilla, caramel, malt. Tastes extremely sweet, medium-light bitter. Full thick viscous body, no carbonation, syrupy texture. Quite amazing.

Poured a dark black color aromas of coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, and booze.  Flavors of sweet chocolate, coffee, dark fruits, some oak and a hint of vanilla.  Medium body feel, real nice beer overall, glad I go to try this one.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2016 2012 vintage poured into a Duvel tulip at 46 degrees. Pours a midnight oil black. 2 inch beige head quickly shrinks to nothing. Lacing is  minimal. Aroma is dark fruit, plum, raisin, molasses, mild pine, maple syrup, toffee, and caramal. Taste is very sweet. Candi sugar, dates, raisins, molasses, toasted malts, raw earth in the back of your mouth, dark baking syrup, faint grass, and roasted barley. Mouthfeel is thick and syrupy. There is hardly any evidence of alcohol, which is amazing for a 15%abv. Awesome beer. So complex and amazing. I cannot wait till i try this over the next few years in my cellar.

Update

2012 edition rated. Spent 3 years in the cellar. The beer pours motor oil black with a tiny dark tan head that immediately disappears.  Aroma is stone fruits, molasses, wood, hints of bourbon, roasted barley, dark roast coffee, cocoa and milky dark chocolate. Really complex. On to taste. The complexities of the aroma have nothing on the taste. Brown sugar, molasses, cocoa, milk chocolate, espresso, maple syrup, soy sauce and some darker fruits, mostly plums , prunes, and raisins. There is a lingering flavor that reminds me of maple and brown sugar oatmeal. The beer lingers in my mouth for a few minutes and different flavors keep developing and changing. The mouthfeel is very sticky and heavy, but I cannot detect any alcohol. This beer was amazing fresh, and 3 years has only improved it.

2012 Bottle purchased at the source on Dark Lord Day. Pours absolute motor oil black black black. About half of a finger of khaki head, and some small drips and dots of of residual sugar lacing. Smells of so much sweet sugar, dark fruits like raisins and maybe some figs. There¬ís coffee malts in there as well, vanilla bean too, a wine scent as well. Caramel, toffee and booze. Tastes incredibly sweet, it¬ís like eating a chocolate cake that¬ís been soaked in rum or whiskey. Obviously chocolate, coffee, booze, toffee and caramel. There¬ís an oil like texture on the palette. It¬ís smooth. Great stuff, however I would recommend that you share with others.

2011 vintage thanks to beersis.

300th review and Drinko de Mayo.

Pours a lighter black (if possible) with almost no head. 

Smell is sweet raisins and boozy. Dark red fruit. This smells way closer to an English Barley Wine than a RIS. Almost sickeningly sweet. 

Taste is also very sweet and boozy. It has some roastiness and faint chocolate, but mostly the deep red fruit from the smell. Lots of alcohol heat for sure. It is very complex, I will admit that much. 

Very waxy mouthfeel, full bodied. Heavy, and you can tell the abv is there, but still reasonably drinkable. A sipper. 

Not what I was expecting, and not even close to one of my favorite RIS. First FFF I have been genuinely disappointed in. I now understand why this is described as a "sweet boozy mess".

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2015 Sample from a 2012 bottle (thanks a ton to the person that shared). Pitch black color, some light brown head. Bit of lace (slides down slowly). Very interesting nose-smell - like some sort of seasoned sea food. Big body, very light carbonation. Dry texture, slightly sticky aftertaste. Molasses aroma is the first thing I notice (maybe that¬ís what that fishy spice aroma was). Some coffee. Kind of a unique sweet taste. Slight, light bite (alcohol is well hidden, though). Very interesting, but overall, I can¬ít get past the molasses. Would be very interested to try some of the special variants, though. 7 / 4 / 7 / 4 / 15Re-rate, 5/17/13: 22oz bottle, 2009 vintage, shared by b3shine. Pitch black color. Good thin brown head. Fades quickly to a very minimal ring around the edge, no lace really sticks. A loose clear thick brown sheet on the glass, though. Way less molasses and sweet notes in the fresh ¬í012 I previously sampled, that¬ís a good start. Huge body. Nice big chewiness. Lighter carbonation. More dry finish. Big roastiness, some light coffee. Actually a really good imperial stout now, my kind of stuff. Night and day difference between aged and fresh 8/3/8/4/15 Re-rate, 11/8/15: 2014 bottle, thanks to Chris R for sharing. Black color, with no head. Super-sweet malt here, too sweet for me. Decent dark chocolate, some mild coffee in the finish, along with the big sweet malt. Big body, kind of slick. Chewy for sure, but unnecessarily malty and unbalanced. This is big just for the sake of being big. Some fig and dark fruit. Too sugary sweet for me overall. Hard to sip, not very appealing. Yeah, this is a dumb beer. Probably represents a lot of whats wrong with beer geek culture. Would anyone care about this if it there wasn¬ít so much hoopla behind it? A prime example of what artificial scarcity can do to perception. ~6oz was probably too much, takes effort to sip through the rest of it.

Tried on draft at Hunahpu¬ís Day. Small few ounce pour. Quite a beer. Opaque black color with a quickly disappeared tan head. Aroma had traces of coffee, but lots of chocolate (bitter and dark), roasted malts, and alcohol. The taste brought that sweetness right away, maybe some dark fruits with the chocolate and oak. I also got a slight trace of vanilla.
Of course, this baby was full-bodied, sludgy, thick, and a tongue-coater.
That is a big beer. Would to try aged which might temper some of that sweetness. Glad I got a taste, maybe I¬íll meet the dark lord again some day.

Dark Lord 2012 bottle from DLD 2012.

Aroma- Semi-Dark Chocolate, Plum, Raisin, Leather, Chocolate Covered Cherries.

Appearance- Very dark, the head is about a finger¬ís worth, lacing is great. Pours a really thick oil-like consistency.

Taste- Lots of plum, chocolate covered cherries and raisins, semi-sweet chocolate. The sweet plum is strong in the back end as well. Not as much coffee presence as I has anticipated at all. 

Overall- Very good Imperial Russian stout. A bit sweeter than I would like, but great nonetheless. If you are looking for that really bitter stout then this might not be the one for you. The coffee was barely there, if at all. I would definitely recommend this stout. Some aging might help tone the sweetness a notch, although it drinks very smooth already.

¬í09 on DLD¬í12 Nose of chocolate, hazelnut, smoke, salt, caramel. Thick and sticky with modest carbonation.  Tastes of malted milk balls, dark roast coffee, caramel, bourbon, toffee. Many say ¬í09 isn¬ít great, but this has held up very well.  Honestly, didn¬ít have high expectations, but this is excellent.

2010 bottle.  Figured I would crack my first DL on the eve of DLD. Pour is black with a warming head.  Aroma is huge with coffee, malt, and molasses. Taste is amazing and the aroma just flows into what you actually taste. Finishes clean and exactly what one desires from a RIS. This one actually lived up to its hype.

Pours a pitch black color and minimal tan head. Aroma of roast coffee, sweet molasses, dark fruits, and chocolate.  Taste is heavy on molasses and caramel, alcohol, roasted malt, and chocolate.  Nice warming alcohol burn and goes down easy. Full bodied.

Black with a brown head - sweet malt aroma with some dark fruites - very good malt with hints of roasted malt and again dark fruites with some coffee in the back ending with some alcohol warmth - this was very good

2011 bottle with yellow wax, big thanks to Scott. Split the bottle 7 ways. The little bit I was lucky enough to get was fucking pretty. deep black with light to medium brown head. all ingredients considered, it was pretty well pulled together. nice big velvety mouthfeel. very subdued coffee and only slight roast. just beautiful. absolutely no booze whatsoever. very impressive.

17/04/2012 - Green wax (2010) bottle shared by Matt (thanks 50belair!) @ Brasserie 4:20. Nera, impenetrabile, densa, schiuma color cappuccino, non molto abbondante, ma persistente. Aroma di una intensit√† senza pari, malti tostati, cioccolata fondente, vaniglia, chewingum, alcol, nettamente sbilanciata sul dolce, a tratti quasi zuccherosa. In bocca √® potente, aggressiva, dolce, con note di cioccolata, ciliegie, rum, molto alcolica. Corpo pieno, carbonazione soft. Birra estrema come concezione. Eccellente.

Pricey 2009 bottle (white wax) shared by KyotoLefty. Thank you! Heavy prunes, thick chocolate, and burnt rubber in the nose. Black as a moonless night, very dark head which flattens out quickly. Strong dark fruit flavors, also port wine. Thick, viscous body. A very substantial stout, yet perhaps over hyped? Maybe a bad year? or a bad bottle? This one wasn¬ít as good as another I had, maybe two years ago.
Gedronken bij dutchdrebus samen met joes. Ruikt naar koffie (beetje), drop, alcohol en smaakt heel zoet, siroopbier achtig, chocolade.
Composite rating for 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2011 vintages. Dark fruits, beautiful on the nose, vanilla, some chocolate, light molasses, wood. Smells better than it tastes, full oily body.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2013 Cosecha de 2011, cerveza negra giste beige. Aroma tostado con un toque de melaza y un peque√±o toque herbal, de sabor exquisito e intenso. Una de las mejores cervezas que he probado.

My first dark lord, sent by pantanap? Thanks Kan! Green waxed bottle.
Pours black with about a half inch tan head, a little watery on the pour, almost no lacing just a few little spots. The nose is sweet, caramel, burnt sugar, rasion, some rum and dark fruit maybe plum. The flavor is also sweet, dark fruit, vanilla, booze, burnt candy sugar, some almost Belgian like spice. Very interesting. The body is silky smooth, the carbonation is suprisingly high. Interesting brew.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2013 2013 and 2012 pours side-by-side. Pours very dark brown with the slightest of mocha-colored heads and no lacing. The aroma is dominated by boozy bourbon with some slight woody notes, raisins, and a bit of burnt plastic phenols. The taste is smooth and sublime, with dates, burnt molasses and subtle vanilla that all linger thanks to an oily palate that coats the tongue. Strangely, I didn¬ít really detect any coffee tones. For a beer with such a boozy aroma, the taste did not come across as hot at all and it hides the 15% ABV very well. The only real difference between the 2012 and 2013 versions is a general mellowing of the 2012. Great sipper, but a tad overrated.

Yellow wax. Delicious. Deep flavor. Sweet on the tip of the tongue. Very dark brown, pours black. Aroma, dark fruit, some booziness. Full, molasses, warming. So delicious. It is worth all of the wait and want for this beer. I will be always trying to get this beer year after year.
Pours a dark brownish black, awesome aroma with alcohol and some dates and other fruity favors...full bodied...flat out excellent to drink.
Great beer! Dark lord day is something to be seen. Tickets go lighting fast so get them quick

Excellant. I have a had multiple years of this beer all are very good. The flavors change as it ages. 08 was I felt the best very balanced and smooth. 09 was very light and smooth as well.  10 and 11 are both very good but will benefit from a couple years in the cellar.

Yellow wax 2011 edition from trade with Jeffo1. Thanks a lot Jeff!! Shared with Dutchdrebus, Joes and Ansjelaah. Pitch black color, small light brown head that becomes a brown lacing fairly quickly. Smell dark and roasted malts, lots of chocolate, liquorice, alcohol. Taste dark malts, lightly roasty malts, lightly sweet, medium bitter, liquorice, chocolate, molasses, plums. Very complex but at the same time, considering it¬ís 15%ABV, dangerously drinkable. Good balance, soft carbo, full body.

Bottle thx to benzai. 2011 version. Pitch black opague colour with an off-white head that¬ís quickly gone. Smells roasty, alcohol, coffee, hops. Tastes roasty, coffee, vanilla, sweet, liquorice, dark chocolate. Full body, warming, perfect carbo.

Everything I look for in an imperial stout. Sampled at Hunahpu¬ís day. Pours almost black with a red thin half finger head. Aroma is rich, deep, and luscious. Coffee, chocolate, creamy and smooth. Flavor follows, but not heavily alcoholic at all. Sweet, smooth, chocolate, rich coffee, slight vanilla and cream. Awesome beer overall. Really pleased

Super dark pour.  Thick like sludge. Aroma is toffee and sugar.  Coffee and raisin taste.  Tons of sugar.  Slight chocolate.  Alcohol blast as it warms up.  The chocolate and coffee really linger.  This sure is special, but the best Imperial Stout out there, I dunno.

This is one of my most sought after beers since first joining Ratebeer. Finally, I get to try the 2009 vintage thanks to Marco (NorCalgrowler). Thanks bud!!! Shared with Chipalsa for a Bday present! I expected a lot from this one. Nose is a slight amount of booze with heavy notes of chocolate, some thick roast and molasses, bourbon-like notes, and a nice amount of dark fruits, namely raisins and plums. The body was typical of a russian imperial. Black body with a dark khaki head. Sweet. Taste wise, this one did not disappoint. Loads of raisin and chocolate with some roasted coffee and sweet mocha flavors filled the palate. Some prunes and red fruit were also playing in the mix. Great stuff. This is an excellent brew that that can¬ít be passed up. BA version, here I come!

2009 Vintage thanks to the talented OmegaX! This damn fantastic beer pours a robust, dark body with a dark head as well. Aromas full of dark chocolate, coffee, raisins and molasses are impressive; coming together like raisinettes! The mouth-feel is smooth and sweet - lots of cocoa, raisins, mocha and warm alcohol. As it warms up the finish is like chocolate covered coffee beans and that is f*cking crazy good.

2011 - Yellow Wax, 22 oz bomber into a DFH signature glass. It was a bit of a struggle to open this, I had to saw and peel off all the wax on the cap in order to get the opener to fit. 

A - Looks like most RIS¬ís. Pitch black motor oil body with a thick mocha head. Dies down to a nice cap and edging. Light lacing and retention, has alcoholic legs to it.

S - Ummmm. I don¬ít know? Super roasty malts, coffee beans, sugar, plums, cherries, leather, oak, vanilla, tobacco, more sugar, soy, booze, and about 20 other things. There is so much happening here its a bit overwhelming. 

T - I will just preface this by saying that I love sweet beers. This is by far the sweetest one I have tried. It makes ST creme brulee look like a health drink. Its just a diabetic mess, and I love it! Starts off with an unbelievable sweetness that is very strong on the vanilla. This lasts for a while. It really isn¬ít until the sugary coating leaves my tongue that I can taste some other notes. Burnt oak, cherries, caramelized dark fruit, coffee, and cocoa nibs. Not as complex as the nose, partially due to the cloying sweetness.  I drank a few glass of water to get through this beer.

M - Medium to thick body that really coast the tongue. Carbonation is surprisingly high. Could not detect the high abv in the taste at all.

O - One of the most interesting stouts I have tried. I was not prepared for how sweet tasting this is. Its like drinking a vanilla stout syrup. Despite the sweetness, its delicious in the same way that a decadent dessert is. The base beer is nuts, I can¬ít even fathom how they can work in brandy barrels and vanilla beans for the variants. This is a must try beer, but I won¬ít be trading for one in the future.

2011 Vintage poured into Darkness Snifter Tulip.

Pours a viscous black motor oil like appearance. Low but apparent tight head which dissipates very quickly (to be expected)

Smells boozy, chocolate, espresso, leather, smoke, dark fruits, toffee, lots going on in this bottle. 

Taste, unbalanced, a complete mess actually. Seems like the bottle is trying to capture a little bit of EVERYTHING into the taste profile, sadly it just feels confused.

Overall: Great RIS and example, a few years to lie down and settle will do this pup good.

2008-2011 Vertical Tasting. Bottles. (from sporadic notes) 2008 Complex but balanced. Sweet with a silky mouthfeel bordering on oily. Very enjoyable. 2009 Good depth with a nice balance and medium body. 2010 and 2011 are both higher in acidity and lighter in body, slightly unbalanced and disappointing. Older releases show much more complexity and body. Wide range across vintages from unbelievable to disappointing. Rating is for the overall range.
UPDATED: JAN 26, 2014 What a beer!! Served on tap at DLD. Strong coffee, molasses and vanilla flavors. Strong, thick and oily. Dark fruits.

From notes.  First reviewed 1/31/2001.  Poured from a 22 oz. bottle into a tulip. This was the finishing touch on an epic tasting. 2010 bottle.

This is just black as ink, all the way through. It pours out thick as molasses into the glass, leaving a small brown head to fend for itself for a minute before fading and leaving no lacing. Foreboding, this is a Dark Lord indeed.

There is a ton of character packed into this aroma. Roasted malt, dark chocolate, roast coffee, molasses, and lots of alcohol.

Very dark roasted malt, espresso roast coffee, molasses and soft caramel come into the flavor up front. The chocolate flavor reminds me of fudge, both in taste and consistency. The flavors intermingle and dance on my tongue, eventually leaving an aftertaste that is mostly sweet with a soft bitterness. The alcohol can barely be found, except in a stomach warming sensation. 

Dark Lord is extraordinarily thick, although I don¬ít think that surprises anyone. It starts getting into the syrupy realm, but is not overly so, at least for my taste. This is creamy and buttery, with a medium level of tight carbonation wrapped in a huge body.

This is definitely one of the best stouts I have had. I would not crown it champion, but it is up there for me.

22oz bottle, yellow wax, 2011 vintage, purchased at DLD. Pours a jet black color with a thin tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, black licorice, Coffee, a little smokey, a little booze. Heavy on the palate with soft, smooth carbonation. Flavor is sweet, chocolate, anise, a little bitter coffee, roasty, some vanilla, with a sweet chocolate & vanilla finish. Amazingly complex. Doesn¬ít live up to the hype for some, but it¬ís a world class beer in my opinion.
Yellow wax. Brown to black. Tan head. Smell is cherries and chocolate with a mild tastiness. Taste is roast with more black cherry and burnt toast character. I¬ím into it. Cool.

I have read about this beer for a long time.  Even before I was into beer I knew of Dark Lord and Dark Lord Day.  When I got into beer and began trading this was one of the first whales I searched for.  When I finally got a few I drank one.  Disappointed.  

I opened a 2011 bottle at a tasting. It was very good, and the alcohol was mostly hidden, but it was by no means the best beer I have ever had.  It was painfully sweet.  Maybe more time will help this beer and I hope so because I still have another bottle.  I loved the coffee aroma and flavor, but I could not imagine drinking any more than the 6oz I had myself.  It was a fun beer to try and tastes rare, but don¬ít trade your whole cellar for it.

2008 Black Wax version...bottled courtesy of a trade with sersdf...saved this one for my 100th rating...poured a thick motor oil like black with a brown head...aroma is dominated by chocolate, malts, wood/oak, as well as coffee...flavor was a mix of chocolate, dark fuits, and malts...by far one of the best, if not the best beers I have ever had...feel lucky that I was able to obtain one so easily since the whole Dark Lord Day thing has turned into a lottery.

Two bottles tried.  Started with with 2011 then went to 2009. Taste smell of two were diff it was nice to compair. For the 2011 taste smell wascaramel, floral, alcohol, butterscotch, soy sauce, raisin, molasses,burnt sugar clear, minimal head, heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, light body, medium body, oily feel, soft carbonation, Over all very sweet almost tangy with the smallest hint of hop bitter at end. 2009 was better to me not as sweet had more alcohol smell not bitter hop at all was just better all around my friend said seems like to completely different beers.

Black. Head is virtually nonexistent. Nose is dark dark fruits, sweet molasses, and tobacco. fruity chocolate, sweet alcohol, figs, raisins, roast, mollases, and licorice stands out in the flavor. Sweet and muddled. Bitter is lingering along with the sweetness. Lios are sticky sweet minutes after a drink. This isn¬ít bad but not overrated as most beers.

Green Wax Bomber---A Christmas present waiting for the right day to open, turns out that day is the Super Bowl.  Pours tar black with a medium, dark tan head.  The aroma is overwhelming, you can smell it five feet away, it consists of dark chocolate (lots), coffee, raisins and smashed cherries.  At first taste, the beer is too much for me, but as it warms slightly, the taste comes into focus.  Note, I¬íve stored it in our wine refridgerator.  The flavor is chocolate, coffee and alcohol, but not as strong as expected.  The high alcohol stuff is a bit hard for me, this is a beer to sip, not drink.  Thanks Vic!
2010 Bottle (Green Wax) - Smells of smoke, alcohol, and a bit of toffee. Pours pitch black with a beautiful brown head. Very smooth, smokey flavor. Well-balanced.
Opened a bottle of 2010. Very big. Pours near black with some chesnut brown highlights around the edge. Molasses, muscovado, burnt sugar, coffee. Buttery and really thick. Worth the hype.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2012 Tasted courtesy of cgarvieuk. 2006 vintage. Thick black viscous pour. Nose is fascinating - soy, marzipan, salty, definite mushroom, hint of dark chocolate. Full, rich body and savoury palate - more mushroom funk, dark chocolate, clean but roasty bitterness on the finish. Sweaty notes also. Coffee in the linger. So much depth, incredibly complex. Wow. Would love to try it fresher, but still quite incredible. Thank you very much for sharing! 4.3....... 2007 vintage. Similar to 06, more coffee. More soy maybe? Hints of marzipan, amazing amazing thick mouthfeel, proper roasty molasses, hint of booze, some earthiness, soft roast finish. 4.3....... 2011 vintage. Amazing treacle, dark chocolate syrup, big big molasses, soft coffee, big booze, mouthfeel slightly lighter but I think I actually prefer this version. 4.5

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2012 Bottle from Mane Liquor. Orange wax 2005 edition. Pours viscous black with a small, dark tan head. Aroma is big, sweet and aggresive. Loads of vanilla mingle with thick, dark chocolate and sweet molasses. A touch of milk chocolate and fudge entertain a touch of smoke and burnt malts. Heavy stuff. Booze is quite subdued which is nice and surprising but I suppose thats in part due to it being almost 7 years old. Big, sweet vanilla tones in the taste. Heavy cocoa powder and molasses with charred malts and tobacco tones. Full, oily mouth feel with nice bitter sweet length. Good beer and rather happy to have tried this. I have had better though but still a world class brew

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2012 Bottle of the 2009, white wax seal, Craftheads, Shibuya, Tokyo. Colour is dark dark brown with burgundy edges. No Head. Nose is red wine, earthy, port fortified wine, touch of bourbon, but mainly red wine aroma. Taste is red wine, like a fine burgundy, but with more of an alcoholic kick and there¬ís a bitter earthiness, malty chocolate and some wood fire smokiness. Yes, and the molasses. Not getting much of the coffee although maybe it¬ís in the bitterness. About three sips in, despite drinking most of the evening I felt a distinct alcoholic fug go up my neck and into my brain. Like when drinking something strong like whiskey. It¬ís a sipper this one. Is it a beer though? I¬íve never really had a beer like this in my life. Would I want to drink this every week? The answer to that is ¬ínot really¬í. And therein lies the conundrum. It¬ís sophisticated, complex and possible subblime for a couple of mouthfuls, but it¬ís not really a beer. It¬ís more like a glass of fortified liquor to be drunk as an aperitif. And for that reason I¬íll never rate it as highly as some, because I don¬ít crave it like I do other simpler beers.

From bottle. Thanks Craig for sharing. Pours black with tan head. Massive aroma, ovaltine, soy, lots of dark chocolate, vanilla. Taste follows suit, lots of chocolate with a beautiful roasty finish. Massive palate, sweet but cleans away nicely. Tremendous

2006 bottle, thanks Craig! Pours a black colour with a thin, tan head. Aroma of coconut, salty liquorice, roasty malt, marzipan, chocolate and soy sauce. Beautiful flavours of chocolate, oak, roasty malt, salty soy sauce and a nice nutty character. Moderate carbonation, an oily mouth-feel and a long roasty malt linger. Deliciously chocolatey with very well masked alcohol given the abv.

Black colored with vanishing yellow head. Extremely rich aroma with roastiness, salty licorice, dark chocolate, vanilla nicely here as well. Near full bodied. Flavor is nicely roasted, with vanilla, berries, licorice, fine alcohol note here too. Nothing which comes out too much, excellent balance!

65 cl bottle @ Timo A. 2009 vintage, white wax. Thanks Jukkabro!
Pours pitch black colour with minimal head. Aroma of vanilla, rum, dark mildly toasted malts, caramel and toffee notes, slight ripe fruity notes, distant syrup, chocolate and mild salty liquorice. Flavour of vanilla, mocha-like coffee, rum, oak notes, topacco notes, roasted malts, tar, caramel, coffee, distant toffee notes. Extremely smooth and oily texture, slick palate, long sweetish aftertaste. Very balanced and certainly a complex brew.
6428

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2015 650 ml bottle. White wax, 2009 vintage. Thanks Jukkabro!
Pours a black colour with a small white head on the edges. Aroma of strong vanilla, wood and strong licorice. Strong flavour of roasted malts, vanilla, wood, salty licorice and strong coffee. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel and a long, warming, roasty finish with strong licorice notes. Very well balanced and even better than Bell?s Expedition Stout. I love the finish as it lasts and lasts. Excellent, but still not the best Imperial Stout I?ve tasted. 9-4-9-5-17 4.4

Draught @ CBC2015. Dark brown, almost black colour. Medicin aroma. Sweet flavour. Not complex. Way too sweet. Not as good as before. 8-4-8-3-14 3.7

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2015 
65 cl bottle vintage 2009 (white vax, no ABV info). Thanks Jukkabro!
Aroma has cocoa, vanilla and hints of licorice. Flavour has licorice, cocoa and vanilla. Also some very dark chocolate, coffee and stinging alcohol. Palate feels malty and soft. Rather good but somehow I expected even more.

Draught @ CBC¬í15
Quite sweet and sticky, drinkability suffers. Harsh score estimate: 4.0.

Bottle thanks to my Secret Santa. Pours black with a grayish dark brown head that dissipates slowly to the edges. Aroma has notes of coffee and roasted malt with backing dark chocolate and just a bit of anise. Flavor starts with roasted malts and dark chocolate but finishes with sweet chocolate and a hint of toffee. Really thick and nice on the tongue.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2012 Pours black with red hints shining through. Smells like chocolate, booze and raisins. Tastes on chocolate, booze, vanilla and dates or dark fruit. Dynamic. Sweet and full flavored.

2011 vintage. This is a very sweet beer, almost too much so. Pours a very thick, dark black, with small head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate and alcohol. Flavors include chocolate, some fruitiness, coffee, licorice, and so forth. The alcohol is very noticeable in the flavor. I wish it weren¬ít quite so pronounced. This is an interesting beer, but not quite the incredible experience I was hoping for. For my money, Surly Darkness is a much better version of a Russian stout behemoth.

I still can¬ít believe I didn¬ít get around to rating this dark motor oil which seems to have the right amount of coffee and chocolate malty sweet flavors with a chewy texture, strong aroma but right balance to keep it from exposing the alcohol content hidden underneath the flavors. I¬íve had 2009 and 2003 versions. I think its improved since then.

Oh the irony! I have gone to Darklord day several times. I dont really like Darklord. My memory is of a molar melting sweet booze bomb. Anyhow my wife suggested I break this beer out. When the AverageWoman ask for a beer. Who is the AverageMan to say no? This beer is the 2010 version.  The beer has been cellared since 2010 Dark Lord day. The beer was lightly chilled and served in Imperial Pint glasses.

Ar- Very sweet! Burnt sugar notes, milk chocolate, dark cocoa, and cocoa nibs, sweetened and fortified port wine notes, molasses and of coarse the expected roasted and chared notes. Even still this beast never lets up on the sweet. 

Ap- High marks for presentation. The body of the beer is a impenetrable blackness. Yes this beer has a darkness no matter how it is back lite. The head is a burnt tan coloration and resolves too fast. Perhaps the Darklord could use some Viagra? Because the Enzyte aint working so well. 

T- This beer is very very very sweet upfront. Burnt sugars almost rescue this wreck but not enough. The burnt sugars are backed by milk chocolate, dark cocoa, alot of people claim fruit of a dark nature, I just get a fortified port wine like note, darkly roasted flavors try to head this into a drying ashey flavor zone to no avail. Think of a Gomjabar box. Instead of pain its sweet upon sweet upon sweet upon sweet. The alcohol peaks out from time to time but again more sweetness. 

P- Full bodied the way I like my RIS. Low carbonation makes this one seem fuller. Alcohol is a bit hot but not in a bad way. The oilyness in the body makes the sweetness almost diabetic coma inducing. 

O- This is one overly sweet candied beer. Its not a drain pour but oh my what a train wreck.

I got this in a white elephant from noble squirrel. Thanks! This beer is huge and retarded. Extremely fruity and sweet as sugar. I am down. It¬ís like port wine with roast malt. For those who like big beers, this is the ultimate. For those who just like beer, it¬ís pretty damn good. I prefer stuff a bit more drinkable but would buy a pony of this once a week if I could.

2009 edition. Pitc black and almost no head. Chocolate and coffee aroma. Deep coffee taste with lasting chocolate taste and some kind of warm alcohol rum aftertaste. The carbonation is not visible but still there in the taste.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2015 1000th rating, white wax.  Really had to play some with the different scores to give this one the end result it deserves. With some more gas this should be pretty awesome, but even without, this one is one to enjoy for sure. Pitch black at the glass. Just a quickly disappearing lace. That is something that costs some points. Nice liquorish, without an overwhelming alcohol getting trough. Lots of coffee, sugar and a hint of vanilla, a very decent roastiness, some yeast gets trough. A very nice mouthfeel, good oily and sticky... Had to add like 0,1 after retasting on 26.08.15 Maybe just a bit to sweet to get even higher points. But I like it anyway.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2011 2010 offering - Does anyone think this has a serious belgian flavor to it?   Seems like a super-duper quad to me.  I wonder if they are using a belgian-style yeast to achieve high attenuation.  The notes of raisin and caramel malt are unmistakable.

2011 Very oily, black/brown/red in color.
In the nose very much coffee, toffee, fudge, burnt sugar, floral and some grassy notes and alcohol.
Taste is sweet, thick, milk chocolate, coffe with sugar and very low bitterness and not long aftertaste.
Boozy and sweet, molasses and anise. Acquired through trade for a surly darkness.

15.10.2011. 0,65l Bottle. White wa x =2009. Thanks Palme for writing that down!, it does not show on my photo! Dark brown or black without head. Aroma and flavours of dark roasted malts. Dry bitterness and very rich body. Very complex and good beer!

It turned Vader to the darkside.
The instant you pour it into your glass and take your first smell is the moment when you¬íll finally appreciate its lure, pure happiness in a glass, an intellectual beverage to say the least. You¬íre nose is bombarded with waves of pungent aromas, sweet dark chocolate, cocoa, vanilla, coffee, and most eloquent of all is its rich dark fruits, cherries, dates, raisins, a port wine like undertone that would make the Trappist Monks of Belgium rise their glass in approval. 
 Taking your first sip is now inevitable as the lure of Dark Lord¬ís demonic character comes to life, although caution is advised as you¬íre approaching the point of no return. You raise your glass to your lips only to be led deep into a dark abyss as it shows you all phases of the moon at once. The viscous mouth-feel leads to a masterful gustation of vibrant flavors, as ancient Belgium meets new age America. Intelligently well put together, Dark Lord¬ís well balanced nature gives it a sophisticated character that stands alone among other craft beers. You¬íre enticed by an astonishing array of dark fruits, sweet chocolate, caramel, coffee, and molasses all so perfectly blended that they seem to be orchestrating a symphony in your mouth. Sip after sip the draw brings you deeper and deeper into its sinister domain. Dark indeed you¬íve become, as you franticly savor every taste that passes through your lips, each sip inversely superior to the previous.From the disturbing creature on its label to the different colored wax that seals each year¬ís bottle; Dark Lord has risen from the deadly hollows of the underworld to become a mythological figure in the world of craft beer. So does it defy description? Without a doubt. Is it demonic and evil? Well, cellar a bottle long enough and you may very well find out.

Thanks again Sean Yellow Wax 2011 650ml bottle.Good Tan head darkest of pours rich dark fruit the first aromas with chocolate liquorice coffee tones vanilla plums a soft carbonation and flavours sweet like cherries currants and raisins plums and prune so good on the palate liquorice caramel mocca coffee dark smooth chocolate a medium ibu swet port and vanilla to smooth through the stout so balanced though a sweet one in aftertastewith dark fruits good body rich smooth maltiness as good as it gets lasting bitter a fine imperial indeed by these masters

2010 Green wax bottle.  Part of Thanksgiving feast.  Pours black with small tan head.  Aroma of malt, caramel, chocolate and dark fruit.  taste is sweet dark chocolate, coffee, vanilla, molasses and dark fruit.  Each taste is better than the previous one.  Awesome !!

Bottle green wax 10 sampled. Pours pitch black with a thin brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, alcohol, vanilla and a hint of dark fruit. Sweet & rich flavor of chocolate, molasses, coffee, dark fruit, licorice and notes of brown sugar with a sticky syrupy texture.  Shared at roberts tasting 10 22 11 thanks.

0.65l bottle @ RBNAG11. This is actually our last beer of the night @ RBNAG11. Have of course really been looking forward to trying some of this famous beer. This is the one with the white wax, so I guess it¬ís from 2009. The pour is black as a blind man¬ís vision and it surprisingly enough has almost no head. Perhaps a thin chocolate film the moment you pour it, but it fades really quickly. The aroma heavy dark and heavy roasted! It has a lovely bourbon-barrel aged swing over it with licorice, leather and sweet alcohol and vanilla tones. Really nice and definitely something I could sit a evening and just smell. The carbonation level is actually quite average  (I had expected it to be less) and the mouthfeel is really thick, rich and smooth. Flavors are also roasted as hell, with bourbon-tones, lots of dark bitter chocolate, rich black coffee and it ends in a really warming and light burning aftertaste. Fantastic beer!

¬í11- Pour is jet black and oily, with a small tan head. Nose is of vanilla and bourbon mostly, outside of a slight coffee note. Taste is exactly like the nose, with a little more chocolate note, and a sweet little fruit kick as well, though very hard to discern through everything else. Flavors blend very well.

¬í10- Very similar to the ¬í11 though a bit more bourbon-ish.

2010 bottle.  Pours jet black with small tan head.  Complex aroma of raisins, dark fruit, molasses, licorice, and soy sauce.  Taste of molasses, vanilla, malts,  alcohol, and ash on the back end.  Wow.

This beer pours thick like oil. Sexy head and the smells comes off as molasses figgy goodness. Taste more like a fruitty stout then your normal coffee or chocolate. Definitely a beer that will get better with age.

Bottle, silver wax, 2007, Pours pitch black, with a non existing head, Aroma, lots of oak, vanilla, fl√∏dekaramel, caramel, sweet cream, butterscotch, salted caramel, browned butter, nutty, vinous, bourbon,  liquorice, lakridskonfekt, chocolate,  almost has a savoury quality to it,  mouthfeel is full, and somewhat oily, very low carbonation, covers your palate completely, Taste: vanilla, Bourbon, vinous, nutty, caramel, sweet cream, fl√∏dekaramel, butterscotch, sirup, dried fruits, prunes, raisins, figs, some earthy notes, sweet liqourice, oak, light herbal, tingly sugarburn, light dusty hop bitterness, pretty sweet but not overpowering, balanced, alost sweet and savoury at the same time, very complex, nuanced, very smooth and velevety, rich, between each sip you take you wanna keep coming back for more, excellent!
