(2011 vintage) Rich black color; Heavy creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, bourbon, coffee, vanilla, dark fruit, & some licorice; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, oak, molasses, dark bittersweet chocolate, espresso, dark fruit (notably figs & prunes), and vanilla; Warm finish; Nicely balanced & very complex; Considering the alcohol, it¬ís fairly well hidden; Overall, on the sweet side but still delicious!

#1 RBESG Sheffield 2009 Grand Tasting @ the Harlequin Vintage 2009.
Pitch black in color with brown head tht quickly disappears.Strong aroma  of coffee, chocolate,some wood, very sweet malt. Very sweet taste, complex mix of malts, chocolate, vanilla, wood, lots of coffee, though  it is a bit overpowered by molasses sweetness. The bottle is quite fresh so I do believe that with a couple of years on it it will be much better. Rather bitter finish.

#2 September 2011 ata local tasting. Vintage 2009
It has overall balanced much more than the first try, yet there is still a certain degree of molasses sweetness that bother me a bit . World class for sure especially if you are into mollasses sweetness. I usually prefer the more bitter and dryer ones.

Black wax. Black beer with a brown, small head. Aroma of roasted malt, molassus, raw coffee and a bit moaldy (oxidation?). Oily mouthfeel, taste of roasted malts, coffee, burning alcohol, liquorice and molassus. A bit sticky at the end. O.K, a good beer, but absolutely not in my top 20.

Pours a jet black color with higher viscosity very little noticable carbonatipon, aroma: milk chocolate,dark chocolate burnt fruit , dried dates,  dried plums, raisins, currants, coffee, black strap molasses, cherries. Finish is coffee bitterness but then malty sweet. Amazing beer. I think I saw God.

I shared a 2011 vintage bottle with a friend: yellow wax.  It was poured into a footed chalice.  The beer pours a slick, jet black color with a finger of roasted, coca-cola colored head that followed through all the way to the end of my glass.  My friend got the second pour and the head was absent entirely.  Overall, the beer looks impressive and strong.  The aroma was where I felt the beer was the strongest.  It was giving off pungent waves of deep coffee, syrupy raisins, malty grains and dark, complex chocolate.  The nose was an experience in itself.  On first sip, this beer slams you with flavors of molasses, dark fruit, vanilla, prunes, massive raisins again, and a sticky, dark grainy flavor.  If you poured out a bowl of raisin bran and then left it to get soggy in molasses instead of milk, that would give you an idea of the syrupy graininess of this stout.  The beer finishes cloyingly sweet with bitter coffee and dark fruit again.  Overall, the mouthfeel is very syrupy and viscous and it is also VERY sweet.  This is a beautifully crafted and amazingly complex beer with tons of intense flavors to show off, but I feel it suffers a bit under its own weight; it¬ís a bit unwieldy and too sweet to be drinkable.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2012 Rating Oct 2011: Vintage 2008
Black colour, tan head. Vintage 2008. Aroma of liquorice, malts, alcoholic, vanilla, fudge and coffee. Roasted bitter flavour, somewhat sweet, liquorice. Lasting bitter, burned malts finish. Nice.
(650mL bottle @ DRBM 2011, courtesy of Menno)
8-4-9-4-16: 4.1.

Rating Aug 2012: vintage 2010
Black colour, small tan head. Sweet aroma, coffee, chocolate, malts, fudge, unbelievable sweet (didn¬ít notice that last time). Sweet flavour, sweet chocolate, chocolate milk, mocha, sugar, roasted malts. Chocolate finish, alcohol, malts.
I disagree with 77ships: it¬ís surprisingly chuggable. Just make sure you don¬ít swallow the wax.
(From 66cL bottle, partially chugged @ RBBSG II, Wilrijk. Courtesy of BelgBeerGeek. Thanks Vincent!)
7-3-7-4-15: 3.6

Bottle @ DRBM. A pitch black colored beer, with a dark beige head. The aroma of vanilla, wood, dark fruits and chocolate. The taste of dark fruits, burny of some alcohol, some hops. Its syrup thick. The aftertaste of bitter chocolate, some sweets with alcohol.

2009 bottle... black with a minimal dark tan head, viscous, sticky, crazy lacing... relatively alcoholic aroma, big roast, black licorice, anise... crazy coffee finish, full bodied in a rare way, alcohol is masked nicely... not nearly as sticky as i would expect since my lips are sticking together... starts out with molasses, some light licorice, alcohol, raisin, possibly prune but i dont eat those, thinner than expected up front, followed by a fuller finish of roast coffee, bitter dark chocolate... anomoly: seems to get easier to drink as it really warms even though the alcohol gets more present... worthy of its own day... id rate this a 6 on palate...

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2012 pours pitch black with a medium mocha head...looks thick.  Aroma has some dark fruit, bold coffee, anise, molasses and caramel...boozy.  Flavor also has some dark fruit and coffee...anise faded a bit but still subtley noticeable...also some very dark chocolate...sweet sugary caramel.  Mouthfeel is heavy and sticky...finish warms with loads of dark, bitter chocolate.  All of the flavors in this are typical of the style but much more intense and less muddled.  Pretty amazing.  #666

Bouteille de 750ml. Cire verte mill√©sime 2010. Un √©norme merci Patrick et JB84. Cette bi√®re est brune, elle n¬ía pas de mousse mais qui lui en voudra et √† 15,0% c¬íest normal. Le nez est complexe et invitant. L¬íamalgame de fruits noirs, de m√©lasse verte, de sauce soja (merci Pat), de rhum brun ou d¬íautre alcool brun sucr√© ce qui rend cette bi√®re vineuse. La bouche est tout aussi complexe et agr√©able. Les saveurs de fruits rouges c√¥toient le g√¢teau for√™t noir soit un m√©lange de chocolat et de cerises. L¬íalcool est doux, le liquide coule bien malgr√© les 15 degr√©s qui sont bien dissimul√©s, tout comme le caf√©. L¬íamertume est marqu√©e en fin de bouche. Une bi√®re qui est loin d¬í√™tre sur√©valu√©e. On frise la pefection.

(Courtesy of JB84.  Thanks a lot John for this world class beer!)  Brassin 2010.  Le liquide a une robe tr√®s fonc√©e, √† la limite d¬í√™tre noire, bord√©e par des reflets profond√©ment rouges.  La t√™te mousseuse est bien petite et se retire rapidement, sans doute affol√©e par les obscurs d√©ploiements de la concoction.  Le nez est un spectacle grandiose, une mise en sc√®ne d¬íune inqui√©tante beaut√©: les grains r√¥tis sont complexes, les malts riches, d√©bordants de caf√© et de fruits rouges, de cerises et de chocolat noir, touch√©s par des effluves de rhum et des parfums de porto, effleur√©s par des pointes de sauce soya et ind√©niablement balay√©s par un souffle chaud et enfum√© qui revient sans cesse, comme une enivrante complainte, des profondeurs des t√©n√®bres.  Sur les papilles, le th√©√¢tre est grandiloquent, un v√©ritable dialogue qui illumine les plus sombres d√©dales de mon √™tre: les flaveurs sont d√©cadentes, touch√©es par une m√©lasse fruit√©e, noircies par le chocolat et les grains torr√©fi√©s, baign√©es dans un alcool riche et color√©, go√ªteuses en prunes et en cerises avec, en filigrane, des petites touches sal√©es √©tonnantes.  En bouche, le corps de la b√™te est habilement muscl√© et intelligemment sculpt√© par une effervescence douce et contr√¥l√©e.  La texture du liquide est une liturgie passionnante, une caresse asservissante, une ode √† la tentation de la chair.  En finale, le chant est bien long et vivant, secou√© par des saveurs justement imbriqu√©es, poignantes de notes r√¥ties et de notes plus douces, tonitruantes de fruits et bien chaudes d¬íune eau-de-vie ensorcelante.  Un chef d¬í¬úuvre noir?

2011 bottle. Pours a pitch black color with a small firm roasted looking head. Aroma is really complex with roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, molasses, syrup, vanilla, sugar, liqourice, espresso, dark fruits like prunes and raisins soaked in rum or whiskey. The flavor is also super complex, and the alcohol isn¬ít noticable at all, except the burn. I get roasted malt, a subtle tartness, dark fruits, liqourice, brown sugar, vanilla, molasses, chocolate, syrup and espresso coffee. The body is full with a creamy mouthfeel that leaves a sugary gloss on you lips. Overall a world class Imperial Stout!

UPDATED: APR 23, 2012 Had this from bottle. This was a 2010 and poured into a ommegang glass. Poured a almost pitch black color with a good head.

Very vintage port-like on the aromas. Deep and rich with aromas of dark chocolate, raisins, some alcohol, and plums.

full bodied and powerful. Rich feel, but very well layered and deep. The flavors are fill with a lot of dark chocolate and raisins.

This was like a great port, but in beer form. Rich and layered with a great finish to it.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2012 Dark black body, no head. Aroma is actually quite mild with coffee and raisin. Taste is nice and strong, some alcohol in the very back. Really high quality brew. (DRbM 2011) (Rating re-indexed)

Also had some of the 2012 version thanks to Kermis. Still very sweet, but also packs lots of dark fruit. Strong, rich and very sweet flavour, which I don¬ít mind at all. (Rating averaged)

75cl bottle. White vax, so 2009 edition. Pitch black colour with no head. Aroma is alcohol, roasted malts and coffee. Flavour is coffee, roasted malts and of course alcohol. Some acidious notes, but this could be the alcohol. Long aftertaste.

Bottle @ DRBM. Generous donation from Molenbrouwer, many thanks. Vintage 2008. Black color. Aroma is sweet, molasses, roast, vanilla. Sweet ¬ín¬í bitter flavor, roasty. Not too strong alcoholfeel, but quite syruppy. Glad I finally had the opportunity to try this.
Green wax.Pours black with a beige head. Aroma of roasted malt,grains, chocolate.Flavor is sweet and roasted. Super nice.
looking forward to the xv anniversary party. and of course the xv anniversary beer!

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2014 Bottle, vintage 2009, 13% ABV. An opaque black beer, with a small. frothy, fully diminishing brown head. the aroma is moderately to heavily malty (roasted grain, chocolate syrup, caramel, some coffee), with notes of fudge, vanilla, alcohol, hint of dark fruits. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Full body, creamy/syrupy texture, soft carbonation, very long finish with moderate to heavy bitterness, moderately to heavily alcoholic. First of all, the 2009 version is not supposed to be the best vintage and I hope so, because, even though it¬ís a very nice beer, it has more than one flaw to deserve its astronomical rating. It has almost no head and it has a good, but standard aroma. The balance is pretty good. The palate is certainly the best department, due to its huge body, a mainly creamy mouthfeel and the right amount of carbonation. Boozy, but not bothering alcohol feel. Overall I hope the other three bottles I have will be better, and each one is from a different year. A good beer, but like many other impys oit there. Good, but let¬ís hope for the other vintages... (8/3/8/5/16=4.0)

Bottle, 2008 vintage. An opaque black beer, with a small, frothy, mostly diminishing brown head. The aroma is moderately to heavily malty (roasted grain, chocolate, caramel, molasses, coffee), very lightly hoppy (resin), with notes of vanilla, berries, alcohol, with a touch of sherry. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Full body, creamy texture. soft carbonation, very long finish with moderate to heavy bitterness, moderately alcoholic. Considerably better than the 2009 version. Just a touch of oxydation, but it looks better (the small head never fades completely and it¬ís lightly lacing), and it¬ís best structured. It seems even fresher and less boozy. Probably my 4 rating at the 2009 version was excessive. This is a really good stout and is enjoyable in larger amounts than the 2009 vintage. (8/5/9/5/18= 4.5)



Vintage 2010. An opaque black beer, with a small. frothy. almost fully diminishing brown head. The aroma is heavily malty (roasted grain, chocolate, caramel. some coffee and molasses), with notes of alcohol, vanilla and perhaps a touch of licorice. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly sour, lighlty to moderately bitter. Full body, creamy/oily/syrupy texture, soft carbonation, very long finish with moderate bitterness, moderately alcoholic. Incredibily thick and viscous. Impenetrable body, good, pleasant aroma, but not outstanding and similar to many other impys out there, but excellent taste, wonderful palate, with the right alcohol bite, absolutely not excessive for its size. It tieswith the 2008 vintage and it¬ís a lot better that the "normal" 2009 version. (8/5/9/5/18=45)



2011 vintage. An opaque black beer, with a small, frothy, fully diminishing brown head. The aroma is moderately to heavily malty (roasted grain, chocolate, coffee, molasses, caramel), very lightly hoppy (grapefruit), with notes of brown sugar, alcohol, licorice, some plums and raisins. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Full body, creamy/syrupy texture, soft carbonation, very long finish moderate bitterness, moderately alcoholic. Incredibly thick, viscous and sugary sweet. 15% are well hidden. Many nice notes. More or less at the same level of 2010.  (8-4-9-5-17=43)

2013 edition, bomber. An opaque black beer, with a small, frothy, lacing, mostly diminishing brown head. The aroma is heavily malty (coffee, molasses, roasted grain, caramel, chocolate), with notes of alcohol, licorice, vanilla and dried fruits. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Full body, oily/syrupy texture, soft carbonation, long finish with light to moderate bitterness, moderately to heavily alcoholic. It still scores pretty good, thanks to the pitch black body and a powerful and after all various (although not particularly complex) aroma. In the mouth it¬ís only average since the sugary sweetness becomes overbearing and fatiguing after a few sips. It¬ís almost harsh and a bit oxidized, too. We¬íre still talking  of a nice beer, still a shadow in comparison to its glorious past (4.5 in 2008). I¬íll still keep that score hoping something will change. (8-5-6-3-14=36)

2011 vintage. I also have 2009 and 2010 that I haven¬ít had. Im really excited cause this will be better aged. It¬ís slightly hot. Nice aroma and great taste. I was really surprised about the body. More carbonation then I wanted and a lot lighter. I¬íll throw down my review for e other years cause I feel it will be better. As of today 10/3/11, I like speedway better...even hoppin frog Doris.

Pour from a bomber 2011 vintage shared with some friends at a tasting. Dark black color and small tan head. Aromas are quite sweet with molasses. In your mouth the beer is full bodied and somewhat heavy and syrupy. The flavor predominant is much like the nose with sweet vanilla, coffee, caramel. The flavors tended to be kind of muddled together. Alcohol was fairly apparent but not over powering. Pretty good beer but would not seek this vintage out.

WTF- This is three floyds Dark Lord- Listen til the record ends, and then there will be no more. flavor is both born and dies in this bottle. the Alpha and omega- white wax- aged ~ 2 years. delightful hints at dry sourness as a result of just "layin¬í around on its butt for two years". Enjoyed with friends with the most discernible and complex palates, and we relished in it¬ís astounding glory. all hail the dark lord - who¬ís sledge hammer of flavor is the only thing who¬ís forcible thrust can infiltrate the nearly impenetrable barrier of light and malt.

Bottle via trade with noblesquirrel, thanks!  2011 bottle.  Pours a typical dark brown with next to no head.  Aroma is more roast malt forward and is overpowering. Taste is more of the same with a bit of coffee grounds and some dark chocolate but not abrasively sweet.  Harsh on the mouth that lets you know there is some level of heat to this.  Overall, a different stout that I don¬ít think I¬íd seek out again.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Bottle 2010 vintage Green wax. A top notch beer for sure, but slightly overrated in my opinion. I had several better beers before and after of it. Too much booziness and quite hard to drink. you know the rest: black, brown head, chocolate, dark fruits, rostiness, malt, vanilla, etc etc

Poured Black with small tan head. Aroma is mostly deep, rich Dark fruit with some Cocoa and a hint of roasted malts. Flavor is as smooth as it gets with a hint of alcohol, Coffee, chocolate, sweet malts and thick heavy molasses  that stained the glass with every sip. Several layers of flavor. This is a real good Imperial Stout, But just as good as what I can get around Ohio & PA.
(Voodoo, Hoppin¬í Frog.....) And I don¬ít have to stand in line for those.

2010 vintage. Pitch black, very little head and lacing. Aroma and taste of licorice, chocolate, hint of chocolate, with some alcohol on the back end. A little bit of burn going down, but nowhere what you would expect from 15%. A nice treat to have from time to time.

Bottle with silver wax, courtesy of papsoe through meilby. Pours oily pitch black with no head at all. Looks like used motor oil. Aroma of dark chocolate, licorice, fresh coffee beans. Taste is very sweet, medium bitter. Full body, thick, flat carbonation.  20110421

Thanks to an amazing Secret Santa for providing me with this unicorn.  fear025 I am forever in debt.  Pours a thick inky black syrup with very little carbonation.  Dark brown fizz on the pour and it quickly disappears.  Aroma is loads and loads of roasted malts, dark chocolate, vanilla and a hint of coffee.  Taste is a big body, fully roasted malts and vanilla swell in the mouth followed by dark chocolates and a little plum and coffee.  Great beer but definitely something I couldn¬ít drink regularly.  Awesome treat though.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2011 2011 bottle; pour is murky brown, with amber highlights. Modest off white head that doesn¬ít retain particularly well in this glass. The nose is dark fruits, caramel, brown sugars, bananas, vanilla, and booze. I feel like this brew hides the alcohol well; caramel, vanilla, earth, oak, vanilla, booze, dark fruits, chocolate malts and of course - the coffee note.; ill be honest: I have a sweet tooth, and I love dark lord. a lot.

Had the 2009 and 2010 bottles thanks to my wife, who got them as an anniversary present.  Pours black with a medium brown head.  Aroma is rich dark chocolate, coffee, vanilla, dark fruit, and some booze.  Taste is very sweet and rich with flavors of dark chocolate, sweetened coffee,  vanilla, molasses, and dark fruit.  A bit of roasted character in the background - seemed more apparent in the 2010 bottle.  The big punch of flavor is amazing, but not one to drink by yourself due to the heavy syrupy body combined with the extremely rich and sweet flavors.  The overall sweetness can be overwhelming to the palate, but this one is most definitely worth the hype.

2009 bottle courtesy of GandGKevin via ksurkin (thanks to both Kevin and Kenny).  Pours black with a creamy cinnamon brown head.  Aroma of dark chocolate and coffee with faint dark fruit in the background.  The flavor is a beautiful blend of dark cocoa, espresso, and tart fruit.  Sherry-like mouthfeel.  Alcohol is actually very well integrated considering the 13% ABV.  Surprisingly worth the hype and easily one of the best imperial stouts I have tried.

Big thanks to Deuane for busting this one out of the basement for Hojaminbag and myself to try at 2am on DLD. 2007 silver waxed bottle poured into a taster glass.

A - Pours opaque black with a small half finger tall dark tan head, dissipating down to almost nothing, leaving my glass tinted a dark shade of brown.

S - Smells of rich chocolate sweetness, dark roasted coffee, dark fruits like figs and raisins, light vanilla sweetness, and a very faint cherry twang. This one has aged beautifully over the last four years.

T - Plenty of chocolate sweetness up front slowly giving way to a mix of dark roasted coffee and more chocolate malt. As the sweetness begins to die down you can detect some of the vanilla, dark fruits, and a bit more of that cherry twang. Finish has tons of sweet roast lingering for quite awhile. This is one of the better vintages of DL I have had.

M - Heavy body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Sticky sweet feel with plenty of lingering roast in the finish. I have had this fresh and aged, and aged is by far the way to go.

O - I have had a few of the other vintages of DL before and they have all been excellent. This one has aged very well with most of the rough edges being smoothed out and the over the top booze dieing down a bit. Excellent stuff. Thanks again Deuane.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2012 2012 bottle.  Aroma: Lots of sweet fruit, candy, molasses.  Chocolate and coffee notes, a bit of alcohol, vanilla, moderately earthy, roasty malts.  Pours black, although not as opaque as many others in this category, barely any head, a thin ring of tan foam develops and presists.  Flavor: again a big fruit component; figs and raisins, also plum and some dark sweet cherries.  Very sweet, molasses and caramel, malty and rich.  Coffee and cocoa, some chocolate, fairly low bitterness. Full, syrupy body.  Carbonation is low-medium, very smooth going down with a slight alcohol bite at the end.

On tap at GTMW 2011, pours pitch black with a thin brown head and spotty lacing, aroma was pretty awesome for this one, full of dark fruit mixed in with chocolate, the flavor is a little too sweet for me, every version of Dark Lord I¬íve tried seems to be overly sweet, pretty darn good but not life changing at all.

The most over rated stout ever. I wish I had Dark Lords press agent, if I did I¬íd be 6¬í6" weight 220 solid muscle and attract ladies like George Cloony used to...

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2011 At a long last.... here it is.  4 years of devout Floyds consumption has lead up to this very moment, the Holy Grail of beers!  2009 bottle pours absolute black with little brown head and no lacing.  Aroma is intensely complex with notes of fertilizer, peat, molasses, cherry, smoke, coffee, chocolate, intense earthiness (among other smells that I can¬ít identify).  In fact, this is the earthiest beer I¬íve ever had.  Taste is ethereal with smoke, vanilla, coffee, licorice, dark fruit, molasses, and warming alcohol.  Body is the fullest I¬íve ever had.  Wish I could give it more than 5 points on body alone.  Soft carbonation, mouthfeel is somewhere between syrup and whipping cream, lush bittersweet finish.  Overall, this is hands down the best beer I¬íve ever had the priviledge to pass my lips.  Totally lives up to the hype, maybe even exceeds it.  Absolutely divine!


Update: 2011 bottle opened in August 2011
11 vintage is much more syrupy, heavy on the molasses, stale coffee, cooked vegetables, roasted garlic, sweet potato, mocha, are all much too apparent.   overall super sweet.  Too sweet.
Definetly not as good as the 09.  This beer needs time.  Do not consume until it has sat in the bottle for at least a year!!
All that said, it¬ís still a legendary brew and merits a rating of 4 even when fresh.

Bottle pours thick and almost black color with minimal tan head.  Aroma of molasses, dark fruits and booze.  Complex taste with flavors coming and going - molasses, dark fruits, vanilla, faint chocolate and coffee, alcohol, licorice, slight char.  palate thick without being syrupy or oily, surprising amount of carbonation.  Finish of molasses and slight roast.  Alcohol apparent.
Worth the hype.  I likey.

Bottle (from the november 2005 RB-tasting at Dixens place - notes have been damaged by flooding of my basement, but this was such an insane tasting for me as I was new to such massive tastings, so I gave up on the detailed notes quite early). 2004 version. Licorice allsorts, burnt coffee, good bitterness. GREAT! All that was readable...my first and only one of two I¬íve scored with a 5.0. Love this beer!

2011 vintage. Aromas of leather, tobacco, port, honey and dark fruits. Sweet, super rich and decadent. Palate is dominated by dark fruits and a port like sweetness but with just enough tar and roast to balance. Viscous and oily body. Alcohol only hits you in the chest, overall for 15% this is incredibly smooth. A fantastic RIS, didn¬ít disappoint. Cheers to Lukie + the IBS guys.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2015 2011 Bottle shared with friends (thanks Dick!).  Pitch Black pour with no ahead.  Sweet aroma with prunes, raisins and coffee.  The flavour is sticky sweet caramel with dark roasted malt, chocolate, licorice and plums.  The 15% alcohol is certainly noticable in the warmth of the finish.

Re-assessed rating for 2010 bottle shared at Beer Temple on  11 April 2012.  Maybe it¬ís the extra year on it, but it was more enjoyable than the fresh 2011 bottle.  Increased ratings for taste and overall.  Can¬ít wait to try an older vintage some day..

2009 vintage shared at Mikkeller bar on 10 May 2012.  Noticeable difference on this one was a lot more raisin in the flavour.  Amazing as always.

2012 vintage shared towards the end of Borefts 2012.  Expected it to be young and not at it¬ís best but the flavours were truly astounding.  A lot more fruity than past vintages.

75cl bottle shared with kermis.
Very little head. Very dark pour. Lovely beer

Candied date, fig and fresh flowers own the aroma with a little sharp soy sauce at the end.  Only dark brown with crimson, not the black pit in appearance that I expected.  Huge double cream, syrupy mouthfeel that harkens a ruby port.  Flavor is unrestrained sweetness that overcomes any background roastiness.

Poured from a 650 ml 2011 bottle into a darkness snifter glass.

A- Pitch black motor oil, ¬Ω finger mocha brown head dissipates quickly, very attractive lacing.
S- Very unique, a lot going on with this one. The alcohol aroma is present but not too overpowering, very sweet, hints of chocolate as well, caramel, hints of cocoa, some vanilla as well.
T- Wow big sweet dessert beer, caramel, very syrupy, just sweet, and complex, some chocolate and vanilla are present, very tasty and rich..
M- Big mouth feel, coats the palate, medium carbonation
O- My first Dark Lord, was not disappointed. A little too rich for me, but still was blown away. Definitely a sipper, great too share with a friend, look forward to trying one that is aged a bit.

Bomber with yellow wax 2011 big suprise from tkrjukoff (many thx) cons 2011-07-09 S√§tila
AR: cocolate, coffey, caramel
AP: ..., balck dark beige head
F: vinos, coffey, vanilla beans, low carbonation

ottle, thanks to tkrjukoff. Black beer with a brown head. Roasted malty aroma, cocoa, quite hoppy, licorice, chocolate, cocoa and some leather. Great sweet cocoa flavor, chocolate, licorice, sweet fruits, hops, some toffee and some alcohol. Long bitter vinous chocolaye finish. A huge but still well balanced beer!

UPDATED: APR 5, 2013 Date: July 3, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Beer Tasting, Bloomington, MN Appearance: Opaque dark with slight amount of head Aroma: Sweet licorice Flavor: Thick, delicious, chocolate and very complex Other: This was the 2010 vintage and no surprise was the best at this tasting.  Thanks for sharing bvery!!!

September 2, 2012 - did a 3 year vertical of the ¬í10-¬í12 at home with Brandon.  Some chocolate in the aroma for the 10, some alcohol in the 11 and the 12 had a stronger alcohol aroma.  Still very good, but I have had so much since trying this for the first time....so dropping my taste rating to a 9, appearance to a 4 and overall to 18, so went from a 4.9 to 4.5.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2012 This was the yellow wax 2011 bottle and sent to me by Strykzone, and I will be eternally grateful.  It pours what look to be at first glance jet black though held up to the light shows it is really very dark red, and has a small, dark brown head, that disappears relatively quickly.  The nose on this is amazingly powerful, with lots of dark ripe fruit. Very complex, but I get plum, fig, raisins, citrus, dark chocolate, and roasted caramel malts. Wow.  The body is very rich, and the mouthfeel is oily and coats the inside of the mouth. Really smooth and no sign of the alcohol.  How do they manage this?  The flavor starts with the dark chocolate and moves quickly to the ripe fruits, with plum, figs, licorice, caramel, a little chocolate, and a good taste of what heaven must be like. The finish is very long and a little bit dry with a roasted malts and citrus bitterness. Overall this beer is incredibly complex, and is about as mellow and smooth as a beer can be.  In some respects this is like drinking a fine vintage port or world-class cognac.  I shared this with my brother and wife, who both said it may have been the best beer they have ever consumed. I agree. I am still saving that 5.0 for the beer yet to come and can only downgrade this a fraction on appearance. Again I can not thank Strykzone enough for sending the incredible beer my way. I am overwhelmed.  Best beer every for me.

Addition.  Just had the red wax 2012 version. Again I am amazed at how 15% alcohol can be completely hidden. Just as good as ever.  Thanks to Strykzone (Dave) for sending  this best of breed my way.

One of the blackest and thickest beers you will find. Pours like oil releasing heavy aromas of sweet chocolate, tar, leather, honey and grapes. Palate is heavy and sweet black malt. Its massive all the way from malty and chocolate, to spicy prunes and figs, to the inside of a catchers glove - all sweet and all powerful. It finishes a little too boozy to be amazing for me. Big crazy flavors, yes... Masterful refinement... not yet...

2011 at Dark Lord Day festival - bottle.  This is truly a special beer and lives up to the hype.  Pours with motor oil consistency into a pitch black reverse cascading head.  Complex olfactory notes set in immediately including cherries, licorice, vanilla, and raisins.  Taste is not overwhelming, building levels of sweetness and alcohol.  High ABV is surprisingly well-masked.  Typical coffee notes are pleasantly absent on the palate as well as a satisfyingly smooth lack of carbonation.  Deeply aromatic.  Take your time and appreciate this beer, few can live up.

Bottled 65cl. Courtesy of hallinghansen. Vintage 2009. Smallish dark beige head. Quite a lot of vanilla, raisin, plum and roasted malt showing up in the nose which is very inviting. Full bodied, warming on the swallow. Syrupy. Complex. Smooth palate. Some lacework. Slightly salty finish which makes one me eager to take another sip. This imperial stout lives up to the hype in my opinion. Thanks a lot hallinghansen!

I opened up my first Dark Lord (green wax 2010) 22oz bomber pours a thick syrupy black color into a snifter. smell is of dried fruit sweet and burnt sugars. The taste is full and mouth filling a little hot but then you get the coffee vanilla chocolate and sugar sweetness.  This is a huge beer and amazing.  Wow I¬ím happy I have 5 more of these, because it totally lives up to the hype!!!

¬í11 DL pours black but not as thick as I expected very little head. As I swirl the brew around it sticks to the sides of my snifter. Smells of expresso, dark chocolate, licorice, leather, some dark fruit, brown sugar and some booze. Taste expresso, chocolate, brown sugar, molasses, tabacco, marshmellow and a fresh sugar cookie. Mouthfeel is thick and the finish is roasted bitter, chocolate, cookie sweetness with the alcohol being very well subdued.

Aroma is floral hops, chocolate, lots of coffee, burnt coffee, roasted malts. Citrus hop notes. Pours jet black. Minimal tan head. Chewy body. Thick. Lots of coffee notes, roasted chocolate. Sweet malt notes with a great hop finish. Hoppy in the end. Really thick and delicious. Lots going on. Huge bodied beer.

From notes.  May 2010 tasting.  Dark black oily pour, with a spare mocha head.  Aroma is fantastic.  Heavy caramel, molasses, lots of bitter chocolate and coffee, nice roasty malt tones, light toffee and brown sugar under it all.  Some vanilla.  Taste is much the same, but with an odd lingering metalic note underneath the residual sweetness that really hurts the beer overall, as it is the flavor that I am left with.  Overall, a good RIS, but the metal flavor does not do it for me.

09 white wax thanks to daknole.  Dak is truly the man.  Shared with the old man on Father¬ís Day.  Black pour, viscous consistency.  Small dark brown head, faded quickly.  Quite an incredible aroma from this one.  Chocolate covered cherries, light roasted malt and some brown sugar.  Flavors were equally intense.  The coffee came into play a bit more.  Rich chocolate throughout, some cherry too, light roast, bittersweet coffee-esque finish.  Super rich mouthfeel.  Carbonation was perfect.  Light.  Overall this is outstanding, well done on all accounts.  A stout this big shouldn¬ít taste this good...

2011 brought back from DLD thanks to Ontbeermaker and Scottatron. so hard to explain the awesomness. motor oil pour with good chocolate brown pour. amazing flavours which were all over, my only complaint was that it was a little too sweet for me, but still an amazing beer.

2011 Bottle:

A: Rich opaque beast! Not much carbonation, just a few stray bubbles surfacing here and there. No head, although I tried to create one with my pour.

S: Smell is ok, nothing to write home to mom about but its decent. Some coffee and chocolate, typical of stouts, maybe anise and Malt O Meal?

T: Extremely thick and low carbonated, I love sweet stouts but this is just not doing it for me at all. I taste coffee and chocolate and TONS of sugar...

M: Nice and thick but the lack of carbonation makes this hard drink.

O: I¬íve tried a few years of this beer the 09¬í was by far the worst I¬íve had and the 11¬í is the best. Still not a fan of this and I am not sure if time will make me appreciate this beer more...

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2011 ¬í11  The pour is actually a bit thin, no head formation, and no lacing.  Smells of rich heavy roasted coffee, booze, port, over-ripe plums.  Nuts come in a bit later with sweet aromas of honey, figs, and a burnt char followed with soy.   After warming, the aroma changes and some deep cocoa is available with some lactose sugars making this more like milk chocolate.  Heavy rich burnt coffee with a char and smoke quality.  Sweet over-ripe fruits like plums and cherries.  Milk chocolate, honey, brown 
sugar, chocolate, cinnamon, with a warming effect.  There is a nice tobacco presence.  The finish is rather long and sweet.  No alcohol burn at all, but a nice gradual warming.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2012 Getrunken beim RB Treffen in D√ºsseldorf am 6.1.07 
R√∂stmalzerner Geruch. Absolut klebrig malziger Geschmack, das Bier ist wirklich sehr klebrig. Das Bier l√§sst sich kaum anders beschreiben als malzig. Der Geschmack bleibt einem noch Minutenlang am Gaumen. 	 
Test vom 7.1.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 10,10,10,12,10,10 - 10,30

Vertical 2008/2009:
Intensiver Schokoladengeruch. im Antrunk ebenfalls schnell schokoladig, minimal s√§uerlich, trockene R√∂stigkeit. Schokoladig, r√∂stig, dann recht s√º√ü, intensiv schokoladig und nussig, komplex und rund - Wow! 13/14/9/14/15/14
Bottle from 2009 @ Mikkeller. Black with small dark brown head. Flavour is roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, vinous, liquorice, dark fruit, sweet and notes of alcohol.

Vintage 2009. Black with a dark brown head. Aroma is very sweet, roasted malt, coffee and alcohol. Flavor is very sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet finish with lots of alcohol. Full bodied, oily and sticky. Too sweet and too much alcohol. Unbalanced. Disappointing but still a very good beer. 250511

2009 vintage with white wax topping the 22 ounce bottle.  Got this at Craftheads bar in Tokyo while on a business trip there a few days ago (4800 yen = US $59...glad that I get to expense this).  Pours a near pitch black color with some translucent brown around the edges and only the thinnest whisper of a head.  Aroma has lots of booze up front, candied cherries, port wine, chocolate, vanilla, burnt malt, and tobacco.  Flavor also has some big booze right away along with notes of very thick molasses and caramel, really rich nice fudge, chocolate covered cherries, brown sugar, but only vague hints of coffee.  Creamy and soft on the palate especially considering how big and thick this beer is.  Really, where is the coffee (none in the nose and only a little in the flavor)?  Also I am surprised how boozy this actually is.  Quite good but I was somehow expecting more...especially as this is the #4 beer in the world according to RateBeer.  I would take a KBS or Speedway any day over this.  But I am still glad that I got to try this.  (1235, 567)

22 ounce bottle, 2010 vintage (olive green wax).  Big thanks to TrebleStauter for this brew, I¬íve been holding onto this for a while now and figured I¬íd finally try it.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours black with a half inch brown head that didn¬ít stay around for too long.  Small amount of lacing left on the glass.  Very sweet and rich aroma, it smells like dark fruit, chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, vanilla and some molasses.  Taste is pretty much just like the aroma, it¬ís very sweet.  It tastes like roasted malt, dark fruit (cherries), milk and dark chocolate, vanilla, coffee, molasses and a bit of charred/burnt malt.  Mouthfeel/body is full, it¬ís viscous and coating with low carbonation.  It¬ís very smooth and extremely easy to drink.  The alcohol is pretty well hidden, it certainly doesn¬ít seem like it¬ís 15% ABV.  I think this is a very good brew, I¬ím glad I was able to try it.  If you like sweet stouts/RIS¬ís, then this one is a good choice.  Definitely recommended!

2008 bottle, enjoyed with the guys of √òlkonsortiet. Black color, almost no head. Aroma has prunes, serious sweetness, smooth chocolate, coffee, espresso, vanilla, oak, almost perfectly balanced. This is one thick and chewy SOB, very baroque. Packed with smooth chocolate, vanilla, espresso, oak. Very nicely balanced. A damn near perfect imperial stout.

2010 Bottle shared GT2, thank you kindly sir. Pour is black with a tan head, leaves decent lacing and poor retention. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, vanilla, rumcake, hazelnut, roasty notes. Flavor is excellent, chocolate, blackstrap rum, vanilla, a touch of cherries and hazelnut. Palate is oily, creamy, with some bourbon. This is truly a dessert beer, but a good one at that.

Nose is acidic on glue,, alcohol, heavy dark roasted malt, rotten fruit galore, feel is fat, carb is quite low, taste follows Nose with some bitter chocolate, port and a sweet hazel note. 2009 edition

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2011 651mL 2010 ed green wax thanks to TheTomG. The pour is a clear cola color- looking sort of deep cola brown with a medium, dense, creamy brown head that requires some major league coaxing to get out. Poured this from about 15 inches above the glass to generate a head. Holding up to the light this is pretty much opaque black though from the pour the SRM doesn¬ít looking quite as inky as BCS or Midnight Sun Berserker or Obliteration VII. No lace remains however making it look similar to BCS. Nose is very nice: lots of old cellar notes that remind me of a really nice barleywine- toffee, raisins, port, wet wood, hazelnut, nutella, muted but very deep and rich hazelnut liquor and rum soaked cherries. Taste up front is heavy on the olives and then settles down to some serious spice with oak and raisins and mint chocolate. Sort of comes across as a cross between an oily stout and a dark barleywine like Bells Batch 6,000. Mouthfeel is oily and soft but the finish is ashy and dryer than I expected. A little bit of sawdust is not helping in the finale. 5/24/2011 8/4/7/4/15=3.8 651mL 2009 ed white wax thanks to bigmmartin. The pour is a deep, clear cola with no head and no lace. No up front is lots of volatile DMS like tomato soup, beef chili, and black pepper. Taste is ashy and dirty with tangy lemon. No good. I actually resealed the bottle with a wine stopper and drank the remaining 2/3 of the bottle the next day. It had substantially improved with no more off-character in the nose. Still poured with soft carbonation but no head and no lace still. Nose is more like the 2010 that opened up: tawny port with spicy ganache. Taste is oily, bitter, and thick like a pretty decent bottle of Bell¬ís Expedition. 3.8 level is about right for the decanted 2009 version. 5/31/2011

White Waxed:  Doesn¬ít look as breathtaking as expected, gooey and thick and intensely black, but lacking any head or lacing.  The aroma is monstrously large, though, full of chocolate and coffee and roasted malt and vanilla.  Huge nose.  Massive.  As big a smell as beer can muster.  The taste is, well, Dark Lord.  Nothing really matches it, like a chocolate-covered cherry cordial with a Raisinette inside the cherry consumed while drinking an unsweetened vanilla coffee spiked with black rum.  Feels amazing, heavier and thicker than all beers before it, as warm as it should be without any spiky residual heat.  Life-changing?  Well, kind of, yeah.  (5/29/09)

630 ml bottle in Germany from shrubber85. 2010 Release - Pours jet black color with a chocolate brown head. Aroma is complex bourbon with cherries, smoke, molasses, and chocolate. Taste is molasses, chocolate, bourbon, smoke, coffee, and cherries. Palate is both oily and creamy and way too strong. Is like one of thoose Belguim desert beers that you want to have once and not again.  This is not beer but a good beer gag drink.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2014 Bottles shared with Pat, Andrew, Dallas and Bobby. Tasted 2011, 2010, 2009, 2008, and then finished with the barrel aged. 2011: It pours a deep black body with some lacing. Aroma is like a perfected version of KBS - with dark chocolate, magnificent dark coffee roast, and lots of sweet molasses notes. Mouthfeel is nice, with notes of sweet maple and molasses dominating, tobacco, coffee roast, marshmallows. Although a bit too sweet. I¬íd give the 2011 year a 4.5. On to the 2010: the sweet notes in the aroma are much more subdued, with much more roasty coffee flavors coming out. The flavor is leaning towards the chocolate side now , with the sweet notes definitely still present ( a still a bit too much) but now with some great cherry flavors bleeding through. Also, still a strong maple presence. The 2010 sits at around a 4.6 for me. The 2009 boasts a much stronger transition towards the chocolate notes with the sweetness definitely mellowing out with age. Now the beer really comes to focus - see this at a 4.7.  The 2008 bottle was by far the best, proving either the DL improves drastically with age, or there were some serious recipe alterations after year 08. The 2008 is a near perfect imperial stout - 4.8.

Bottle of yellow green white and black split with james andrew pat and bob. Aroma is sweet with lots of sugars. Semi mocha head. Pitch black pour. Taste is intensely sweet young and ages to a tight awesome imp stout. Retains a sweetness reminiscent of sweet cherries and raisins. Smoke flavor balances it out and becomes stronger with age. Fantastic brew and a true experience tasting them in order. Cheers.

2011 bottle with James, Dallas, Pat, and Bobby.  Super sweet upfront... Rich molasses, fig, and slightly peppercorn.  Finish is burnt tabacco and roasted malts.  Mouthfeel is full... Maple popping through toward the end.  2010. 2009. 2008 as well.  2008 is by far the best... Much more balanced with a smokey, almost bourbony flavor.  Incredible!
Purchased this while attending Dark Lord Day 2011! I enjoyed this much more than the 2010 Dark Lord. Strong bitter and sweet texture, taste of coffee with various sweet notes

2010 Vintage tasted at DLD. Pour is pitch black with a roasted coffee colored head that quickly fades into nothingness. Aroma is of brown sugar, coffee, molasses and espresso beans. Flavor is much more on the sweeter side with notes of darker fruits, roasted coffee and molasses. Just a hint of alcohol in the end but masked very well for 15% abv. Solid medium/heavy bodied mouth-feel, good carbonation and bitterness.

Enjoying 2010 with friends. We are group rating this. Smells like alcohol and a drunk wet dog. Dark as hell. Burped up a little coffee. Medium bitter, light sour, medium sweet. Very creamy with alcohol finish. Its goooooood!

Sampled at The Yard in Santa Monica alongside Kate the Great and Old Rabbit¬ís Foot.  Pours brown/black.  Initial smell is medicinal which fades as the beer warms up.  Roasted notes but not a big coffee hit.  Very smooth but also a touch too sweet.  I cannot discount the hype factor in my slight disapointment.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2015 FINALLY! . Bottle from 2008. Pours black with a nice espresso brown head. Aroma is milk chocolate, espresso, vanilla, dark fruits (prunes, figs and dates), coffee, roasted malts and smoothness all the way. Taste is silky chocolate, roasted espresso-like coffee, vanilla, prunes, figs, dates, overripe plums, toffee, sweet liquorce leading to a dry end. Creamy texture and a very sick balance. Thanks to the guys from √òlkonsortiet for sharing this monster! Rating: 9-4-9-5-18

Bottle 2011: Rating 9-3-9-5-17                                   Bottle 2013:                                                                 Wow this one was quite a different experience. So mellow and smooth. Not much roastyness but has all the stuff you want from an impy stout. Sooooo smooth and very balanced. You gotta give this beer some credit.. Numbers are the same

2010 bomber shared with mattyb83.  Pours motor oil black with a small fluffy head after an aggressive pour.  Big aroma consisting of strong coffee and molasses, some roasted malt, and some booze present.  Based on the intensity of the aroma, I definitely was expecting more from the flavor. A somewhat oily mouthfeel compliments the sweetness of the malt.  Some over ripened dark fruit, coffee, bittersweet chocolate, and molasses dominate the senses on the palate, yet there still is a stong booze presence that distracts from the rest of the beer.  Still a very solid impy, yet it lacks a little balance.

2010 Bomber shared with Mattyb83 pours dark brown/black with some amber highlights and a thin tan head. Aroma is boozy with soy, dark fruits, roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, and molasses. Wow this is thick! Really great sweetness not overbearing, chocolate and toffee flavors into a bitter coffee dark fruit finish. Pretty damn good.

Bottle 2010 vintage from drfabulous.  Deep, dark brown color that is almost black.  Small amount of mahogany highlights around the edge of the glass.  Slightly boozy aroma with chocolate, slight roast coffee, raisins, and figs.  Pretty nice other than the booziness.  Taste is toffee, roast coffee, slight anise, chocolate, with more toffee towards the finish.  Much better balance than the aroma.  Thick and heavy mouthfeel, but what else should I expect from Dark Lord.  Really solid imperial stout, but I¬íd take a Speedway over this any day.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2012 Apr 30 @ DLD, courtesy of bnutz. Finally I get to taste this. Aroma is very sweet, fruity, roasted, meaty and caramel. Lean velvty fullbodied mouthfeel. Very sweet, meaty, excellent flavor, thick but still very drinkable, fruity and roasted malty with nice touch of alcohol. Sweet, tart and fruity finish with burning alcohol tones.

121020 @ rlgk¬ís tasting. Bottle 2011. As above but also a touch of smoke in aroma and flavor. Well balanced sweet vinous and has nice bitterness to finish with.

was able to get just a taste of the 2011, thank you beckman...aroma was good, body was good, taste was of buttery toffee, caramel, chocolate and coffee with an alcohol burn on the end. basically in that order. not bad. just dont know if i could drink a bomber of this...very rich...but yet worthy of a taste.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2011 Vintage 2010 sampled the day before and 2011 the day of. Poured dark black with small head. The 2011 was much better in my opinion. 2010 was a little bit bland with not much body. Kind of weird taste to it. I plan to crack open the rest over time to see how it ages. 
Edit: Had the 2011 version. Much better. Much more coffee comes through.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2011 Tried for the first at DLD ¬í11, Overall not sure what I was expecting but It wasnt quite it. I tasted the ¬í10 and ¬í11, Enjoyed the ¬í11 more so. The ¬í10 was weak in chocolate and other flavours. it tasted kind of bland. But the ¬í11 had much more life to it I thought. The flavours really came out it was a roasty malt/choc/coffee taste and really it was quite good.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2011 I have been waiting to try my first Dark Lord for many, many years.  Thankfully it did stand up to the hype.  ¬í10, dark pour but not motor oil, big vanilla towards bout midway thru persisting thru to the back end.  Other flavors fairly identifiable as well.  This has a lot going on, is balanced and is huge.  Looking forward to meeting this one again.

¬í11 wasn¬ít as good, served warmer than the ¬í10 but I¬íd knock it down to a 3.8 TS.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2013 Location: Bottle at Paul¬ís Blind Impy Stout Tasting, 1/5/13, 2006 Bottle - Gold Wax 


Aroma: The nose is full of dark malts, with chocolate, caramel, and light boozy notes

Appearance: It pours an almost black color with a small tan to light brown head

Flavor: The taste is malty and roasty, medium sweet, and with lots of chocolatey goodness

Palate: This one had a fairly full body and a super creamy/smooth feel on the mouth

Overall Impression: 
It was quite exciting to try a 2006 Dark Lord, so big thanks to Paul for this one!  Your Impy Stout collection was exquisite!  I¬íll drink a Dark Lord anytime I can, what a great beer.  I didn¬ít go quite as high on the 6+ year old one as I did on the one year old 2010 bottle, but I still liked it quite a bit.  I¬ím leaving the RB entered score alone, as that one was a year old full bottle and this one was much older and only a sample.
4.2:  9/4/9/4/16

Location: 22 oz bottle from NickD717, 4/29/11, 2010 Bottle - Green Wax


Aroma: A huge bouquet of sweet and roasted malts, coffee, vanilla, molasses, a touch of booze

Appearance: Pours a pretty much pitch black with a very small light brown head and minimal lace

Flavor: This beer has a ton of malty flavor, medium (plus) sweetness, similar notes the nose

Palate: I¬ím not sure that I¬íve even had a 15% beer with this little alcohol burn, I mean wow!  This stuff is full bodied and really really smooth.  It has a long and lasting sweetness and a great mouthfeel.

Overall Impression: 
Thanks, Nick!  I¬íve been holding on to this one for a while, but I¬ím celebrating, so I decided today was the day I should finally drink this one!  I can see why this one gets so much acclaim, it is rather good.  It has a really complex flavor.  An incredibly well hidden booze for a 15% beer.  Seriously, a wow beer.  One of the best things I¬íve tried in a while.  Again, many thanks to my friend Nick for hooking me up with this one!
4.4: 8/4/9/5/18

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2011 Bottle 660ml vintage 2007 @ Zoney
[Trade by Papsoe] Pours pitch black with no head. Aroma has notes of chocolate, caramel, earthy, coffee and alcohol. Taste is heavy sweet and light bitter. Body is full, texture is sticky, carbonation is flat. [9 3 9 5 18]

Bottle 660ml vintage 2009 @ RBNAG-11
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, vanilla, oak, chocolate and coffee. Taste is heavy sweet and light bitter with a very long finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. to flat. [9 5 9 5 18]

Svart som natten, tjock som olja. Tydliga br√§nda toner, stor smak av kaffe och choklad.
Eftersmaken sitter kvar b√•de v√§l och l√§nge. Det √§r mycket som h√§nder i denna √∂len, men faktisk talad tycker jag att den inte n√•r helt upp till de allra b√§sta.

Brassin 2009. Bouteille de 22 oz, avec de la cire blanche, partag√©e avec MartinT et Fred82. Ar√¥me: Odeur de caf√© avec une pointe de viande fum√©e et de vanille. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Pr√©sence d¬íun mince col beige mousseux et d¬íune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Go√ªt de chocolat et de caf√© avec une pointe d¬íalcool et de cerises. Dur√©e moyenne de l¬íarri√®re go√ªt. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture l√©g√®rement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. L√©g√®re pr√©sence de chocolat en arri√®re go√ªt. Un gros merci √† Fr√©d√©ric pour m¬íavoir fait d√©couvrir cette bi√®re. (Rating #3603)

Bottle shared at Funky Buddha.  10¬í version. Dark jet oil color. Pour is pretty thick and rich. Aroma has molasses and chocolate. The flavor was a little sweet but nothing that made me uncomfortable. It had a good amount of carbonation for this style. I was very impressed with this one. Definitely lives up to the hype.

Pours a murky black with decent tan head. Aroma is boozy bacon, vanilla, coffee malt. Taste is bourbon, coffee, chewy depth. Alcohol is so well worked and yet still potent. Smooth as hell. Roasted coffee in the finish and again a warming alcohol hit.

2009 bottle (white wax), thanks to the generosity of tdtm82. It pours opaque black with the thinnest tan head and almost no carbonation. The nose is charcoal, caramel, smoked bacon, toasted sesame seed, soy sauce, liquorice and seaweed. The taste is caramel, vanilla, charcoal, toffee, sweet cherry, black jacks, plum, white grape, lemon, icing sugar, tar and soy sauce, with a very sticky mouth-feel. The balance is good and the monster alcohol % is well hidden. It¬ís complex and enjoyable to drink in small doses, but it doesn¬ít live up to the hype of being a top 5 beer. There are much better and easier to get a hold of Imperial Stouts out there. Don¬ít meet your heroes, you will only be disappointed.....

Bottle; bomber, 2009 edition, shared @ The Kernel Brewery with Evin; Reakt, Scopey 

Juet black opaque appearance; nice mocha-lacing, aroma is  tar, cocolate, oak, wood, vanilla, smoke, blackcurrant, taste is velvety chocolate, oak, black currant, sour cherry, oil,  wild berries, lemon, sweet sugar, vanilla, 

This is also another beer I¬íve had which is highly rated yet sickly-soy source rich; balance is ok but I¬íve had better, drinkability for the abv is extremely high. A good brew but WAY over-hyped. I¬ím happy to have tried this but don¬ít get the hype.

2010 green wax. Let me first start by saying that I first had a DL about a month after the release. That first bottle was low carbonated, syrupy and was overall not a good experience. This review reflects when I opened one on Christmas day. It was black with a small but decent head. The aroma is very bready, roasted, bakers chocolate, dark fruits, tar, and just very rich. The taste has a very nice breadiness, tar, and a very oily chocolate like liquid. Its nice oilness causes me to lick my lips. Like liquid oil which made for a nice mouthfeel. May very well be the biggest baddest Imp Stout out there. There is a gritty bitter bakers chocolate that in my opinion balances the sweetness but does not get rid of the diabetes that this beer may cause.

2010 bomber (green wax) courtesy of woosterbill.  Thanks Bill.  Pours a dark black with a reddish tint at the edges when held up to the light.  A small light chocolate head leaves a ring at the edge of the glass after it dissipates quite quickly.  Not very mach lacing at all left on the glass.  The aroma has a very strong roastiness to it.  Also huge molasses and some licorice as well and a little bit of coffee.  There is also a quite strange metallic copperlike  aroma that comes through pretty strong as well.  Light alcohol noticeable on the nose as well.  The initial taste is really sweet with the copper note coming through as well as the molasses and licorice.  This transitions into some coffee.  The finish is strong roastiness as well as a bit of booze with a pretty decent bitterness.  Full bodied.  Low carbonation.  Syrupy.  I don¬ít really see this beer is that highly regarded.  I found it to be way too sweet and syrupy.  The strange copper note was not enjoyable either.  It does do a good job of hiding the 15% alcohol, but overall I just did not find this beer that enjoyable.  I split the bottle with one other person and we had trouble finishing it.
Bottle. 2010 vintage. Pours black with thin tan head. Aroma is dark fruit--fig especially. Flavor is fig, caramel, molasses and chocolate. Delicious.

Bomber thanks to viggo. White wax ; 2009.
Appearance : Pitch black no head.

Aroma : Big molasses and roasted malt. Very syrupy. Rich oily hops.

Taste : Big molasses and roasted malt. Some alcohol. Finish huge molasses and roasted malt. Some spicy hops. Long finish. Very syrupy, nice sweetness. Light bitterness. 

Overall : This is a big one. Very rich and syrupy. Big molasses all around. Nice roasted malt. Well hidden alcohol. Nice soft carbonation. Very enjoyable long finish. I will need to revisit this one with a fresh palate to give it true justice.

Bottle. Pours a pitch black beer with a weak chocolate colored head. The aroma is malt, sweetness, roasted, tobacco and licorice. The flavor is following the nose with some additional soya. The palate is sweetness and smooth. Overall a fantastic beer with complexity and smoothness. Awesome!

DrBayern came off this bottle from his secret stash, kept hermatically sealed away in his dungeon of Draft!  Enjoyed with the good Dr, Brian the Beer Pimp, Uncle Tom, Barrister Bob, and Uncle Steve.
Poured a very dark brown.  There was no head, light lace on the edge.  The aroma was sweet malt and molasses.  The flavor was of a sweet chocolate, coffee and vanilla.  It was velvety smooth to drink.  The aftertaste was wonderful.

2010 verision re-review. I had this at dld day but i was pretty hammered. I figured the Lost finale was a good time to break out a new one.

I drank this from the bottle into my Orval glass.

The beer pours a jet oil black, hardly any brown with a only a little light tan head. Disappointing a little.

The aroma and taste are super awesome and sweet. The malts show off tons of vanilla, but its so fine its not overly sweet it just shows off so perfectly. Light roasty coffee on the finish with a slight alcohol burn. Hides the 15% extremly well. Super easy to drink.

The 2010 is clearly superior to the 2009. Its really awesome, super easy to drink. New ratings are the 2010. 

2009 white
I drank this from the bottle into a chalice.

It pours motor oil black with hardly any head at all. No carbonation very dark color.

The aroma is very strong of vanilla, coffee and cherries.

The taste is complex with a start of cherries, moves onto vanilla, and coffee.

The taste lingers for several seconds and for its abv its very drinkable.

2009 was 4.0, 4.5, 4.0, 4.0, 4.0.

UPDATED: APR 9, 2011 Had an 09¬í white wax bottle at Ebenezer¬ís pub in Maine.  Paid a hefty price but it was worth it to have this rare gem.  Very smooth for 15% abv.  Though you can definitely taste the alcohol, it¬ís not overpowering.  All other flavors come through, chocolate, molasses, prunes(?).  Great beer, believe the hype.

Bottle courtesy of kbutler1. Deep black appearance with a fairly small dark brown head. Deep thick chocolate malty nose with light espresso. Very thick consistency that¬ís somewhat syrupy. Very roasty, dark, mildly chocolate, dark malty flavor. Roasty dark malty aftertaste.

2006 Magnum big thanks to Patrick! Poured thick and black, relatively no head. Nose had dark fruit, raisins, chocolate..there was a LOT going on. Tasted of dark fruits, chocolate, full bodied, viscous, smooth, and utterly delicious. All hail the Dark Lord...I would never say no to this beer.

2006 edition, courtesy of some very, very generous RateBeerian at Hunahpu¬ís Day 2011. Thanks again for allowing me to try this want. Pours a deep, deep, black, almost a thick molasses aroma, very boozy, sweet aroma, vanilla, and that same over sugared taste, Good thing is that I cannot tell that this is 15%. I¬ím not sure if that is because it is so well hidden, or because I¬íve been drinking so many huge stouts that my mouth is numb. Otherwise, in a day of drinking some great, great stouts, this one is near the bottom of the list.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2013 22 oz. bottle, split with manuchampions, pours black with a tan head. Huge aroma of vanilla, dark fruits, and caramel - a big decadent caramely treat. Flavour is decadent, with caramel fudge, deep dark fruits, especially raisins vanilla, coffee and a little chocolate. Very complex flavour profile, full of many different complementary flavours. The sweetness is extremely high, but it ends up not being cloying. Very enjoyable, but not exactly worthy of its reputation. Good stuff, but not the most elegant.

(22oz bottle courtesy of jcnd9803!).  2010 version-green wax.  Pours black with thin khaki head.  Taste is sweet with some nice roastiness.  The vanilla and molasses are present.  This is subtle for a beer with an abv at 15%.  I would like to have this aged a little as well.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2013 Shared a white wax 2009 vintage with a few friends to celebrate my buddy Steve√¢¬Ä¬ôs first born son, Telfer. I was anticipating this beer for quite some time, so I√¢¬Ä¬ôm glad I finally got to crack it open with good friends. Pours pitch black with absolutely no head, but that√¢¬Ä¬ôs to be expected with such a high ABV. Rich brown lacing around the snifter though. Aroma is complex; subtle hints of port, dark fruits, burnt oak, roasted chocolate malts, coffee, etc. Flavor is even more complex; heavy alcohol backbone is beautifully covered by flavors of chocolate, raisin, vanilla, coffee notes, burnt molasses, oak, etc. Mouthfeel isn√¢¬Ä¬ôt as thick as I was expecting, but still heavy enough for an imperial stout. Very impressive RIS, to say the least. Luckily, I√¢¬Ä¬ôve got two more waiting in the beer fridge for another special occasion. Can√¢¬Ä¬ôt wait to try this again!!! Re-Rate 10/08/11: Had the 2010 vintage with some friends. Poured black as night with a thin, dark brown head that dissipates into a small ring. Aroma is foreboding. Molasses, vanilla, dark fruits, and coffee. Flavor is a little sweeter this time. Mouthfeel is right on the money though; velvety and rich. Overall, just as good as the first time around. I sampled BCS Rare and Old Rasputin XII alongside this. Would I say this was the best? No. Was it delicious as hell nonetheless? Yes.

2010 vintage poured into Snifter.

guess what? It was black, ya know what? there was some garnet/ruby/dark red hues on the edges.
there was a decent head, not quite as dark and thick as i was expecting, but it existed and it clung.

the smells on this are heavy port like smell with fig and raisin being the forefront. definately some roasted notes with heavy malt/chocolate smells.

Tastes very port-like, the OG on this is probably high enough to make a 6% ABV beer out of. my lord, lol. i get a lot of that dark fruit flavor in the taste amongst the roast and coffee with syrupy chocolate laced with vanilla. This stuff packs a punch of flavor and complexity. amazing.

mouthfeel is thick and creamy, slightly syrupy but not disgustingly syrupy. there is enough carbonation to lighten it up. lots of sweetness battling through the heavy roast.

drinkability. this is tough to get through, 15% ABV and the alcohol is definately noticeable. enough residual sugar/unfermentables to give you diabetes. 7 oz is enough for sure.

this IS your dessert.

2008 bottle courtesy of Kristina<3. Aroma: Dark ripe fruits, big malt backbone, raisins, vanilla, touch of coffee, hint of smoke. Pour: Ridiculous black with a thin coffee brown head leaves a lot of residue on glass. Taste: Mind blasted don¬ít know where to start vanilla, amazing coffee, roasty, chocolate, dark fruit, raisins, grassy, great maltiness, and a touch of caramel. Palate: Creamy smooth and super thick like a milkshake of pure win. Amazing mouth coating effect that leaves me wanting more. Almost no trace of the abv. Very mild carb. Overall: This beer is a champion that has lived up to all the hype the only tragedy is that I now only have 2 bottles left :(

(beer tasting @ Monty¬ís Krown - Rochester, NY: bottle - 22 oz - 2010 vintage) Thanks to Joe for busting this guy out. Pitch black pour with nearly no head or carbonation. Sweet and fruity aroma with lots of wine notes. Some very mild roast. Can definitely smell the molasses. Flavor isn¬ít as roasty as I was expecting it to be. Wine, dark fruits and sweet notes with some very light coffee hints but more molasses and vanilla than anything. Alcohol is really well hidden. It¬ís nice, but I definitely was expecting a lot more roast to it.

Yes, finally, the Dark Lord! 2009 bottle: pours a pitch black beer with a very small and quick disappearing brown head.
Smell is a good and bit strange mix of dogfood, liquorice, soya sauce, slight hints of coffee, alcohol and molasses. 
Taste is a delicious mix of liquorice, sweets, soya, roasted malts, coffee, barleys, dark dried fruits, prunes, raisin, brown sugars, molasses, hints of rice and grass.
Aftertaste of brown sugars, grass, coffee and raisins.
This one is indeed pretty sweet but in a very well balanced way with a great taste to evolve. 
Very low carbo, full body, and soft silky, light oily mouthfeel/texture.
Personally, this hype is correct! Delicious beer!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: 2009 - pours a thick, oily body, pitch black. Aroma of moccha, toffee, mild coffee liquor. Taste is overwhelming; strong toasted malts, tingely and bitter mouthfeel, molasses, mild hops, soy sauce, raisins. Incredibly full-bodied. Well worth its reputation.

2007 Bottle Received in trade from Grub, Thanks for the opportunity. Sampled 1/26/2009

Pours a solid black with a thin mocha head that dissipates quickly. Smells of chocolate syrup, coffee, dried dark fruits faint hops in the background. Tastes of chocolate and dried fruit, a bit vinous, leaves a roast bitterness in the finish. Thick body, although I thought it would be thicker. Syrupy mouthfeel, light carbonation. Well I finally got to try it. Good solid stout, there are better out there, but this one ranks pretty high in my book. I would have loved the roast to be a bit more in the foreground and the fruits a bit more in the back.

I had to go back and this comment to my review after we poured the second half of this bottle. The bottom half of the the bottle was thick and chunky when poured. The second half was actually better tasting with a much thicker mouthfeel than the first. I guess I didn¬ít realize that this beer wasn¬ít homogenized.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2014 One word.  Damn!  2010 poured from a 22.  Pours black with a nice tan head and great cascade.  The nose is heavy on plum, molasses, raisins, and other dark fruit.  Taste is molasses, coffee, vanilla and malty goodness.  There was a lot of hype that preceded this pour and it certainly did not dissapoint.  If you enjoy big stouts it is worth a sizable trade to have this vintage.  EDIT No vintage that I have had after 2010 has been close to this rating.

2010 Vintage.  Poured from a 22oz bottle.  Pours very dark brown, nearly black.  Aroma is prunes, vanilla and roasted malts.  Taste is prunes, dried fruits, chocolate with lots of sweetness.  This has elements of an Imperial Stout, but also seemed to have some of the sweetness and dried fruit elements of a good quad.  Damn, this is great stuff.

So its taken a while to rate this considering the bottles are from 2008 DLD but I have to say they sure seem to be peaking right now. Hugely viscous pour, dark as night, with a well balanced nose that is no longer overwhelmingly bourbon and booze. Great mouthfeel, coats everything in a smooth delicious covering. Chocolate, vanilla, bourbon and burnt toffee on the tongue, finish just keeps on going, like a delicious peaty scotch. Will open another one in 6 months and see if its gotten any better but if you have a 2008 I¬íd recommend opening it now - absolutely delicious.

Vintage 2009
Dark! Thick, syrupy and black. Usually terms reserved for palate but you can see the viscosity in the glass!
Nose reminds me of Harviestoun Ola Dubh. Rich, dark chocolate, alcohol, oak and maybe whisky soaked raisins.
Full body, viscous and syrupy. Mouth-coatingly amazing, though mostly flat.
Taste is grape juice and rich dark chocolate, almost chocolate syrup.
Amazing! some fruit, like currant or blackberries.

Pours a rich, viscous, extremely dark brown body. Head is pretty small and mahogany brown in color. Head retention and lacing are pretty average for such a strong beer. Appearance gets half a point extra for such a thick pour. 

Smell is of sweet chocolate syrup, roasted coffee, and some booze. Thats about it, chocolate and coffee overpower the nose.

Taste is very sweet. At first I get Hershey¬ís chocolate syrup, Kahlua, and burnt malts. Reminds me of Sothern Tier Choklat mixed with GI Bourbon County minus the apparent bourbon, also tasted some characteristics of port as well. Hops are very light and alcohol, for being 15%, isnt too strong.

Mouthfeel is very rich and thick. Carbonation is good which lightens the syrupy consistency. Unfortunately head died rather fast and didnt add much to the beer.

Drinkability was good. For such a strong beer I was able to finish the bomber but I dont recommend it if you¬íre planning on doing else for the rest of the day. The only downside to this beer was that after about half the bottle the overly sweetness started to get to me and I wished it was balanced a bit more. On the other hand, this stout pairs great with a Brownie a la mode and is the perfect desert beer.

2010 bomber broken out at a buddy¬ís party. Serious deep and viscous black pour with a 1 inch brown head and nice lacing. Huge cocoa nose. Thick mouthfeel with molasses and dark chocolates, some rich toffee and slight heat. Had the 08 this past summer, which seemed a bit oxidized, but this version is nearly flawless. A big, delicious stout, Mucho rich and  tasty!

[22oz bottle courtesy of cgarvieuk ¬ñ 2009 vintage] Black Black Black. Thin lacing of non-Black, but mostly Black. Viscous and syrupy, dark roast aroma with plenty of alcohol and plenty of caramel. Flavourwise it¬ís a great imperial ¬ñ Dark, heavy flavours ¬ñ oak, raisins, coffee, port, molasses, vanilla, brown sugar. They all make an appearance now and again. The balance is tremendous ¬ñ the alcohol does take you on, but it¬ís incredibly smooth. Fantastic beer. I¬ím just not down with the exclusivity of the Darklord Day. Share the wealth, that¬ís what I say. Is this the fourth best beer in the world? Maybe ¬ñ but it¬ís no Westvleteren [28012010]

Bottled @ tasting cgarvieuk. Many thanks for bringing this on. Black colour, dark brown head. Aroma is deep roated malts, lots of dark chocolate, dark fruits, port and boozy. Flavour is roasted malts, coffee cream, massive chocolate, port and dark fruit. Oily and thick texture, long roasty finish. Absolutely amazing beer.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2012 Bottle. 22 oz. (2008 - Black wax) shared with Annie. This beastly, epic brew comes sealed in a dripping, candle wax-sealed, shiny bottle with a badass evil lord destroying foes on the label. Pours straight cola, dark chocolate black with a thin, creamy amberish-red head that fades quickly. Aroma of raisins, figs, dates, walnuts, plums, vanilla, chocolate, espresso, barley, roasted malts, toffee, caramel, oat, and hints of coriander and pepper. Heavy, deep body with a rich, velvety-full mouthfeel. Finishes with a slow, insane warming through the throat and entire chest. Alcohol is nearly invisible. Re rate, had a ¬í05 with Bill, Frank, Allen, Christine, Paula, Brian, Tim, Liam, and Simon. Notes were rich flavors of caramel, fudge, nuts, and light peat.

Recently had an ¬í09 and ¬í10 vertical. ~7 oz each, poured into pint glasses. Scores above are the 2010 version.

Dark Lord 2010

A: 4.0 - One finger tan head with less than average retention and little lacing.

S: 3.5 - Something weird that I can¬ít put my finger on, almost like a candied plum though there¬ís a vegetal component as well. Roasted barley.

T: 4.0 - Milk stout like sweetness. Lots of fruitiness with plum and some tobacco. Could use some more roastiness.

M: 4.5 - Thick and viscous, which is the way I like it. Good moderate carbonation. Smooth

D: 4.0 - Good brew, great mouthfeel, good taste, but is missing the roastiness that I love in imperial stouts. Strangely, I thought the draft version at DLD was a lot roastier. Perhaps I was just drunk.

Dark Lord 2009

A: 3.5 - One quarter inch tan head. Doesn¬ít seem very carbonated as it pours very syruppy. Poor retention and no lacing.

S: 4.0 - Main smell is soy sauce, which I came to like as I smelled it more. Sourish dark fruitiness. Roasted barley, but much more sweet than roasty. Slight coffeeness.

T: 3.5 - Sweetness dominates roastiness. Tangy (the only work I could think of) fruitiness, roasted barley, and coffee with lots of cream.

M: 4.0 - Thick and viscous heavy body. Low carbonation. Smooth.

D: 3.5 - Okay but pretty weird. High sweetness, which is fine, but could use some more roastiness to balance.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-22-2010 23:17:29

2009 650ml bottle (trade with Xmarcolenx) Virtually zip carbonation when popping the cap. What head is poured is dark brown, but dies very quickly. STRONG STRONG aroma of soy sauce. Flavorbis one of the most unique barleywines I¬íve ever had. TONS of soy sauce in the flavor too, along with a smudge of brown sugar. Reminds me of the one and only time I ever tasted chewing tobacco in college. Body is somewhat thick, though not as much as I expected. All in all a bit disappointed :-(

2010 release.

Black, syrupy beer. Head recedes quickly and leaves little lace. Looks like it¬ís going to be a big one.

Smells super sweet and rich and complex. The aroma is almost like that of a quad.

There must be a ton of ingredients in this beer. It¬ís enormous. Dark chocolate, molasses, caramel, raisins, raspberries, licorice, and dry flavors too like a chocolate espresso and brown sugar oatmeal. Molasses and dark chocolate big time though. And the alcohol is definitely a presence.

Slow drinker. Intensely rich and flavorful but also the alcohol catches up and slows you down.

Really amazing.
2006 in snifter at RBSG 2010. Complex, thick, warming, smooth, bursting, coffee, chocolate, dark fruit, elegant,  deep, intense, earthy, ... just amazing.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2013 20th January 2008  2005 Orange Wax bottle. Sumptuous smooth imperial stout. Bags of soft fruit, cherry, raspberry, blueberry and blackcurrant. Milk chocolate, malt, molasses and a dry coffee finish. No bitterness. Fantastic! Lives up to the hype! 14th May 20112004 Red Wax. Opaque black beer. Tidy coffee coloured head. Minerall nose with mild coffee. Smooth airy soft palate, viscous and sumptuous. Sweet molasses and coffee with traces of wood and chocolate. The coffee gets stronger - rich and tangy and creamy. Dry finish. 2nd half of the bottle was pure sludge! 15th May 20112006 Gold Wax. Opaque black beer, tidy chocolate coloured head. Rich malty nose. Sumptuous soft palate. Rich coffee malt with a streak of dark chocolate. Tiny bit of molasses and soy. Trace of red berry fruits. A little warmth in the soft finish. Coffee aftertaste. Nice but not a patch on the 2005. 9th June 20112007 Silver Wax. Smooth and quite mild dark malt! Traces of coffee and chocolate. Brief and mild yeasty molasses. A little Port Wine. Nice cherry and blackcurrant fruits. Good year!
Wow this is like chocolate milk for adults.  So thick, I didn¬ít even know that beer could be this bold and crazy.  Thanks FFF for this brew.

The aroma is chocolate, cherry, vanilla, maple. Immense alcohol that singes the nostrils.

The appearance is impeccably jet black; pure motor oil.

The flavor is burnt grapes, mocha, vanilla, plums, dates, chocolate and coffee.

Feels oily but also rough and sandpapery. Really burns on the way down. What an oustanding beer (akin to DFH Palo Santo Marron). Smooth, oily, viscous. Dark chocolate.
2010 bomber shared -black pour brown head-aroma and taste of chocolate ,coffee dark fruit,sweet thick syrupy,some vannila ,dark cherries,-nice beer lots of flavor- great!!!!!!!

Thanks to my good friend ljay6880 22oz bomber aged from 2009 served in a tulip pour was a black as a moonless night with two fingers of dark chocolate head with excellent lacing. The nose was coffee,vanilla,peat,soy and just a explosion of other smells.Taste was full bodied almost like eating a meal.Coffee,chocolate,sweet malts and thick heavy molasses that stained the glass with every sip. I must say i felt quite privileged to endulge in such perfection.
2010 vintage courtesy of wunderbeer.  Well, not too much to say on this one.  Really thick, not too much alcohol but not syrupy either.  Good show.

2010 bottle thanks to Andy shared at Joe¬ís NY goodbye tasting - Incredible dark milk chocolate, dark roasty malts with a touch of booze. brown sugar, molasses. throat warming pepper note and some bitter rooty notes. Wonderful chocolate, creamy smooth body. I get why people line up for this.

2010 version.  Wow.  What a powerhouse beer.  It was very bitter right out of the fridge but after breathing and warming for 10 or 12 minutes it was incredibly smooth.  Almost no head and black as 5 year old motor oil.  The high alcohol content is definitely there, but nicely disguised with dark fruits. Raisin-y.  Malty.  Thick and rich.  Awesome.   Thanks Rodney!
Merry Xmas everyone!! This Beer is amazing .. extra dark fruit, smooth thick taste, Raisins and dates. Awesome Im so lucky to have this beer thanks to Hopper!!!

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2011 2010 vintage poured into snifter.  Merry Christmas!  Black with mocha tan head.  Aroma is mostly dark, deep, rich fruit with some mild chocolate and a hint of roasted malts.  Also very sweet in the nose.  Flavor is as smooth as it gets with no hint of booze.  Deep chocolate mousse, fruit cake, brown sugar, with a very small hint of coffee.  Creamy, thick mouthfeel.  Very different from expectations, but very good nonetheless.  Will wait awhile to try the 2009 vintage.

Re-rate: 2011 version at GTMW.  This version seemed way sweeter than previous that I have tried and detracted a bit from the flavor. -1

Tasted on 12/19/10 from a bomber bottle, 2008 Vintage.  Pours oil black with a thin tan head that recedes to a very thin lace collar.  The nose is sweet with dark chocolate, molasses, brown sugar, vanilla, dried fig, and there is a bitter element which may be from the malt, or may be from the coffee.  There is also a bit of oxidative nuttiness at this point.  The flavor is sweet molasses, vanilla, and burnt brown sugar with the coffee bitterness coming through much more than the nose would have suggested.  There is also strong hit of dried figs and raisins on the back of the palate.  The body is massive with light carbonation, and a long complex finish that, at one time or another, hits all of the flavors mentioned above.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2015 2010 Bottle ...
