Black pour tan head ..... aroma of sweet dark fruits (vinous) and lightly roasted/chocolate  ... taste of dark fruits, molasses, roasted bitter coffee and light chocolate/vanilla .... very balanced with a warming boozy bittersweet finish full bodied .... sweeter than I imagined it would be but very good no doubt ...2009 bottle white wax black pour tan head aroma is vinous and of dark fruits and a combo of chocolate and molasses ... Taste is of sweet and dark fruits..... Has a molasses and sweet chocolate with roasted malts .... Different than all of the bigger imperials ... In my humble opinion. Overrated

03/10 0.65 l bottle, courtesy of ogivlado, huge thanks for sharing! We had a 2007 bottle that poured black body with smaller dark brown head. Spicy and very pleasant aroma that had it all - chocolate, coffee, dried fruits, nuts...sweetish anyhow. Flavor didn¬ít fail as well! Very complex palette of malt characteristics are greatly balanced. Finest coffee and chocolate are only the most prominent. Thick and sticky oily body only adds to its quality, while at the same time it remains dangerously drinkable. Again, excellent harmony of flavors is encountered in its finish, with great balance of everything from sweetness even to saltiness. Alcohol is felt here, but not so much as ABV would suggest. Extraordinary stout, although still can¬ít beat my favorite one!

Shared bottle courtesy of gunnar. Pours black with no head. Soy sauce and raisins on the nose. Cellar notes added in the full bodied, oily mouth along with alcoholic, sweet and roasted bitter flavors prominent in the dry finish.

2010. Bottle thanks to Owen. Pours a very oily dark brown. Smallish tan coloured head that disappears very quickly. No lacing to speak off. Aroma of vegemite (probably similar to the saly & soy noted by other reviewers) dark fruits, sweet dark chocolate and some alcohol. Flavours are very sweet initially with lots of dark fruits and sweet dark chocolate. Then some of the saltiness seems to come through followed by a little alcohol on the finish. Mouthfeel is smooth, oily and very full. Great beer.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2012 ¬í10 bottle courtesy kbutler1 - thank you!  Aroma is rich cherry, decadent chocolate, some peat-like dryness, molasses, and rich malt.  Surprisingly light feel in the mouth.  Taste is cherry, chocolate, molasses, raisin, some subtle alcohol toward the finish, and trailing dark fruits.  Excellent.
------ bottle.  Aroma has a heavier char/burnt even roast-type character than the ¬í10 but the heavy, port-like dark fruit raisin notes with molasses are still prominent.  Taste is slightly oxidized with dark chocolate, heavy char and molasses with dense, raisin and dark fruit.  Mouthfeel surprisingly thin but it works for me on the whole.  Unique, over the top imperial stout and quite excellent.  Still a 4.3 for me.   ¬í10 bottle once again on 9/23/12.  Black pour with a dark tan head.  Aroma and flavor are a balance of burnt, char malts with chocolate and rich, sweet dark fruit notes and whispering alcohol.  One of a kind and a personal favorite.  Score remains the same.

¬í09 Bottle thanks to Dalzale.
a lot of cocoa in the aroma. Lighter coffee tones.
Flavour has a rough sweetness,cola, chocolate, coffee.
A little sweet for my liking. Even after a year in the bottle.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 On tap at DLD 2009.

A: Very, very dark with a small dark head.

S: Lots going on here, with pretty much everything dark in this one--chocolate, coffee, molasses, dark fruits. Some very mild touches of vanilla.

T: Very, very complex. The fresh version isn¬ít quite as complex and delicious as aged. I also had a sample of the ¬í08 Dark Lord, and that one definitely would get a 5.0 on the taste scale. This one is still beyond excellent, however. All of the tastes are similar to the smell, and simply envelop the palate with goodness.

M: Very, very smooth. Almost no carbonation, and barely a hint that this thing is 13% abv.

D: Incredible. Definitely got my freebies with the golden tickets. Hats off to Three Floyds for an absolutely incredible beer. It was my first DLD, and I plan on going back every year from here on out.

EDIT: Not changing the original scores but a few notes. Opened up my first 2010 Dark Lord on 11.20.2010. The initial smell was a bit smokey to me and not nearly as sweet as the 2009. Strangely enough, we also opened a Batch 9000, which resembled the 2009 DL more so than this beer did. The 2010 DL also had some faint chocolate, but not really any of the sweet sherry-type notes of the 2009.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 04-28-2009

Very thick, main taste is of soy sauce with pounds of sugar added. Heavy and packed full of flavour. Glad to have tried it, but too sweet for my liking, would not be able to finish of a whole bittle of this on my own.

2010 bottle sampled:

Pours the darkest of browns, nearly black, with a small dark brown head that quickly dissipates.  

Nose is a lovely combination of chocolate, dark fruits, and a light saltiness.

Flavors seem to come in waves.  There¬ís an initial, strong wave of coffee, followed by a few "aftershocks" consisting of the darker fruit flavors, chocolate and some saltiness, fading into a blissful, wine kissed, vineous warmth.  Coats the palate for, quite literally, minutes after a single drink, which chocolate notes lingering on the tongue for a very long time.

Rating no. 700! :-D A stroke of sheer luck enabled me to get a taste of this legendary beer from some very generous beer connoisseurs sitting next to me and a friend @ √òlbaren, Copenhagen. I can¬ít for my bare life imagine the pains I would¬íve otherwise gone through to get hold of this baby, so what can I say...even a dog has its day... ;-) Body is pitch black with virtually no head to speak of. Nose is very "new school" of American imp stouts; heavy salty soy, sweet cocoa and chocolate aroma with only hints of coffee. Taste is even more intense: sweet mocha, cocoa, soy, dark chocolate, wood and hints of port wine. Extremely complex. Palate is, considering the insane ABV and complexity, frighteningly light and drinkable - worthy of an evil Dark Lord trying to pull his minions into mindless addiction... Despite all this, I still kinda felt I¬íve had a similar imp stout before - it¬ís really, really good but considering the near-insane hype my expectations are somewhat...hyped, too. In any case, this is a top-notch, world class beer. But maybe a tiny bit hyped.

Huge taste that is obviously high in alcohol.  My son brought this back from Munster in 2009 (white), knowing that I would be impressed.  Big taste of caramel and malt, lingering finish full of everything that one could ever encounter in an Imperial Stout.

Wow this is one massive stout it sticks to your palate like molasses this is definetly one to share with some friends after your done waiting in line.If you have never experienced Dark Lord day DO IT! Its a day of beer hardcore music and more beer.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2014 65cl, Edition 2008 (Black wax), exclusive American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex sweet Stout, roasted/alcoholic and slightly fruity, heavy, yet balanced, hazy, small head, top class!, yet very expensive!, WOW!

2010 bottle from Cracked Kettle.
Pours black brown redish with a thin head, very oily apearence and mouthfeel.

Complex brew with lots of vanilla, chocolate, mild coffe, red berries and soy.
Bottle. This is a super complex, yet well balanced beer. Smooth texture. Notes of chocolate, bacon, vanilla, coffee (in a pooh coffee-way) and burned syrup. Loved this one!

Oh my!  A great stout.  A bit too sweet for my taste, but it¬ís certainly easy to appreciate something fairly rare and the reputation is deserved.  Very yummy, but I¬ím not sure I¬ím enough of a fan to make the trek to Dark Lord Day...thankfully some of my friends ARE willing to do that and to share one every once in a while :)

Flaske 0,75l. Gave fra Rune og delt med ham 22 Sep 10. Hjertelig takk! Svart med et lysebrunt skum. Aroma av lakris, plommer og annen frukt. Nydelig. Avrundet og innholdsrik smak: Lakris, sjokolade & kaffe. Lite bitterhet.

2009 vintage, bought from √òlbutikken, Copenhagen. Pours pitch black with no head at all. Aroma is dark medium sweet malts, raisins, peat and liquorice. Full bodied. Taste is bold sweetness, fruity and roasted at the same time, here is coffee, chocolate and vinous notes, with a smooth and velvet like mouthfeel. Well hidden alcohol, dries up at the finish. Awesome beer.

Vertical of 07-10. Thanks to Frank for the 07 & 08 and Vince for the 09 & 10. They all pour very thick and black with a very small deep tan head. Big aroma is of sweet chocolate, coffee, caramel, leather and some wood. The flavor is tons of sweet chocolate, malt, caramel and vanilla, there is some bitterness hiding in there too as well as a touch of acidic coffee. The body is about as full as a beer could be. The carbonation changed through the vintages, the older bottles had less and the newer ones had more, which helped tone down the sweetness. I think the freshness of the hops and the extra carbonation made the 10 the best. Overall an excellent beer for being so sweet, although maybe a bit overrated due to the scarcity.

Split a 2010 vintage with a friend, about 6 months old. Appearance: Dark as night, with just a hint of ruby red at the edges. Small, brown, frothy head (regenerates with a vigourous swirl of the glass). Aroma: similar to red wine with sour grape notes; some dark chocolate as well; some rich syrup-like scents (honey, molasses).Taste: Two flavors in one: red wine taste up front; bittersweet dark chocolate on the finish. Very rich. As it warms more fruity flavors open up: cherry, plum, molasses. Alcohol presence noticeable and somewhat distracts from the palette.Mouthfeel: Typical stout consistency, but not as thick as I was expecting. Chocolate bitterness lingers + sour grapeness. I want a glass of milk afterwards!Drinkability: For a 15% ABV beer it drinks like something about half the potency. Definitely an alcoholic presence but it¬ís a gentle warmth - not a burn. Overall: A really good RIS and a really good beer. Not quite second-best-beer-on-the-planet good, but good nevertheless (great, actually).

NOTE: Watch the video version of this review at:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YwzAb0jY_Js

Bottled 650ml. -Trade with shrubber85 (thanks Roger!), shared with Marko and heavy. 
Vintage 2007. Pitch black coloured, dark brown head, chocolate and alcohol in the nose. Strong roasted malt, chocolate, dried fruits and coffee with notes of licorice and smoke. Oily and alcoholic finish. Great imperial stout but Speedway Stout was a bit better.

Bottle, 2009 vintage, kindly shared by gunnar. Black colour, hardly any head. Aroma of heavily roasted malts, dark chocolate, coffee and liquorice. Intense flavour of roasted malts, coffee and liquorice.

Bottle 09 from motortoddhead. shared bottle on bday. when poured it looked like a black hole, so dark and dense simple beautiful. little carbonation, small head. smells great vanilla,oak,coffee,burnt fruit. the taste was very similar. very well balanced considering the alcohol content. just a little warmth on the finish. Just a kick ass beer. wish it was more accessable. If you ever get a chance don¬ít pass on a opportunity to taste.

2004 
Had the most sludge/sediment, and body. Still holding up like the 2006 but is starting to fall apart unlike the 2006 still more in its prime before it starts falling off. 

2005
Was the least balanced and most disappointing one in this vertical. It was a surprise how boozy this one was with licorice flavors. I feel sorry for anyone that got this off ebay. Your in for a disappointment.

2006
Was the best one of the vertical because it had the most balance. Flavors were all over the place. I would not sit on Dark Lord for over 4 years because after that they start losing the flavor profile. 

2007
This is pretty much Dark Lord brewed with chocolate. Lots of chocolate flavors, well balanced with some hint of coffee. Sugar crystals clinging to glass. 

2008
This one can still change a lot. It was probably the 3rd or 2nd favorite overall. Closest to the Russian Imperial Stout. Lots of roasty and robust flavors. Full bodied with some sludge/sediment. 

2009
This is a sweet stout that is tasting lovely. At its peak for sure with all the dark fruit notes with a ton of black cherry. Impressed on how this is tasting 1 yr and 6 mos into it. 

2010
After 6 months it has changed. Less heat, boozy, and its starting to develop. I can see this one changing a lot. I think in 3 years or so it should be at peak maybe less. The 09 got there faster than expected. This one should hold longer than 04 and 05. 

THE BEST ONE WAS THE DARK LORD BLEND. A SNIFTER FILLED WITH ALL 7 YEARS! TAKES A 5 OUT OF 5! ALSO ALL THE PERSONAL BLENDS LIKE 06 AND 08 ETC. 

2

2009 edition, been sitting in my basement for over a year. Pours jet black into the glass. High viscosity, this stuff just looks sticky. Heavy coffee aroma, dark bitter chocolate, dried fruit, burnt molasses. Thicker than the average stout, but the complexity on the tongue makes it highly drinkable. Can definitely taste the alcohol in this, but  its not overpowering. Very enjoyable.

Bottle (silver wax, 2007) received in a trade with shrubber85 (huge, enormous thanks for this!). Shared between me, ogivlado and heavy. Poured a pitch black body witha brownish head. The aroma is immediately complex, oily, chocolate, dry dog food, malt, light raisins, softish and creamy. Very nice indeed. The mouthfeel is the thickest I¬íve encountered, almost kefir-like in texture, but obviously nothing similar in taste itself. Chewy, soft grainy maltiness, rye, m√ºsli, coffee, raisins.... leading to a bitter finish. A lovely sipper that I¬íd want to get again. Not the best beer I¬íve ever had but certainly one of the few most memorable ones, worthy of praise.

2009 Bottle drank on 06.12.2010 - 

Pours black with a 1 1/2 finger, light brown head. It coats the glass with a viscous syrup like consistency with very little carbonation. A good alcoholic, pruney nose. Starts with a nice alcohol warmth then I got a lot of prune and raisin flavor with a subtle chocolate and coffee notes at the end .

Awwww, the great dark lord, what to say about a beer that has become almost legend to beer geeks. 
Well, it is probably the greatest imperial stout I have ever tasted. But it is not THAT much greater. I kinda was under the impression that this stuff was going to blow Stone and Great divide out of the water. It doesn¬ít. But it is EXTREMELY AWESOME!!
Green Wax 2010 bottle. Pours as black as a beer can be with a beige cap that hangs around for a while. The aroma is licorice, caraway seed, anise, pretty much every kind of licorice note you can think of is the smell, with lighter under tones of dark roast premium coffee, dark chocolate, and alcohol. The flavor is eye¬ís roll into the back of your head delicious, straight up, licorice all over the place, ok, i got this one, it¬ís like you took a pile of chocolate covered coffee beans, coated them with licorice, and then blended it into a liquid and drank it, awesome! There is however this distracting apple sauce taste that kind of floats around in the shadows, it distracting, and not welcome, but everything else about the flavor is so great I am able to ignore it. Kind of hoping that it will go away as the beer ages though. The finish is top touch, the best, a bit of alcohol warmth accompanies the licorice coffee flavors into forever, or atleast until the next sip, the mouth feel is bang on creamy, smooth, chewy awesomeness.  Really a fantastic beer, wish I had a fridge full.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2012 Draft at Great Taste of the Midwest. 2008 vintage. 
Pours a nice black/brown color with a tiny bit of sediment in the glass. The head is tan that nicely laces around the glass. Just a stellar nose on this one with hints of bittersweet chocolate, coffee, dark roast, with a touch of some alocohol notes. Nice heavy/medium mouthfeel. The flavors at this point are nicely balanced and compliment each other very well. Chocolate, dark roast, woody, dark fruit, some vanilla, it¬ís all there and is pretty nice tasting. I could see where people would say its a little sweet or too heavy but overall I think this is a pretty good beer and some vintages do deserve the hype. UPDATE: Having had several vintages of this, I have come to the conclusion that this beer is just too damn sweet. I find myself only able to enjoy a small glass and that¬ís about it.

Vintage 2009, white wax 650ml bottle bought at √òlbutikken in Copenhagen. Almost completely black body with some dark ruby highlights. Declining beige-brownish head. Plentiful and rich aromas of deep mocha chocolate with a delicate roastiness. Comprehensive and well blended taste of chocolate malts offset by dried and dark fruits where raisin and prunes can be detected. Deep bitter ending with warming alcohol. Velvet, smooth and silky vinous on the swallow. Full bodied, still with fine drinkability. First class (at Finns in Troms√∏, 22.09.2010).

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2010 Sampled at Rare Beer Tasting II in Denver on September 17, 2010.  Pretty thick and creamy dark-dark-dark brown color with a medium-brown colored head.  This is one gorgeous beer.  I think the attractiveness of the head makes a big difference with deeply dark beers like Dark Lord.  Aroma is of light roasted malts, a little coffee, a hint of chocolate, and is a little musky.  Alcohol is barely detectable.  Very smooth, goes down insanely easy. I can¬ít believe how easy it is to drink.  It has an almost dry, tart, bitter dark chocolate-coffee finish with a very nice, almost bitter back end with that same warm chocolate/coffee presence very noticeable as it goes down the throat.  I was wondering what the hype was about this beer, and honestly was pretty certain that once I finally tried this beer that I would be disappointed.  I can¬ít say that this is the best beer I¬íve ever had, but it¬ís definitely in-league.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2013 Bottle 2010 vintage. Finally. Couldn¬ít wait to try this one. Reddish black pour with little to no head. Complex aroma of coffee, molasses and cherries and  but also scotch (peat, smoke) aged port and a hint of soy sauce. Wonderful flavors of chocolate covered maraschino cherries alongside with dark fruits such as prunes and grapes. Incredibly tasty. The vinous mouthfeel showcase the flavors magnificiently without being too heavy. A beautiful marriage of the intensity of the american style with the drinkability of the European interpretations. Beyond my expectations.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2013 2009 vintage.  Lots of molasses and booze covered raisins on the nose. Chocolate, molasses and sweet fruits in the finish.  A little bit thin, but surprisingly easy to drink.

Too sweet now :(

Darklord Vertical. Beers were provided by three different guys, all tasted side by side. 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009. Rating all these vintages side by side is going to be tough.

The appearances did not vary all that much, of course the bottles are beautiful bombers all with ornate and varied colored wax indicating vintage. Beers are all black with minimal head and apparent low carbonation, no real retention to speak of and there isn¬ít any lacing. Big variants here were the 2004 had MUCH MUCH more sediment in the bottom of the glass than the others and the 2008 was considerably and noticeably browner on the spectrum than the rest. All the beers were hazy (could tell this after someone spilled their 08 on the counter). The beer is noticeably thick (especially the 2004) leaving a syrup-like resin on the sides of the glass. The 2009 appeared to be the thinnest. I did not take gravity readings, just what I see and think.

Aroma, 2004: almost sour, a slight biting lactic smell followed by a slight ash. Some bitterness is detectable and a tiny bit of sweetness possibly from the alcohol.
2005: Much more coffee and roast in this aroma along with some nice chocolate and bitter. Alcohol is more noticable in this one.
2006: Hottest of them all so far, a sting of ethanol in the nose, sweetness is lower here, mostly ethanol.
2007: Back to chocolate, good malt syrupy aroma in this one, a good balance of coffee in the aroma, back to more the way the 2005 smelled.
2008: Weakest aroma of them all (followed by the 2004). Mild sweetness and a slight bit of ethanol in there.
2009: Strong aroma, lots of alcohol, chocolate, coffee and vanilla (didn¬ít pick up anything like vanilla in the others).

Tastes, the 2004 was sweet and thick, completely full bodied beer. Finished slightly dry, had an alcohol flavor in the front of the mouth, but the sweetness won out. I was expecting more roast here.
2005: This was the lightest of the bunch, and the roastiest, if that makes any sense at all. Again, really high body (do you like to chew your stouts). This beer amazes me with the body on it. Less dry than 04 but there is so much more coffee in here, its nearly a completely different beer.
2006: This was the driest of them all. Super sweet up front with a nice trailing edge of slight roast. There is a biting alcoholic taste to this that abbreviates my pleasure.
2007: Still a little dry, very sweet, as sweet at the 2006, this beer is so thick in my mouth it has a syrup like quality to it.
2008: Much more roast than 2006 and 2007 and pulled back on the sweetness. Still super thick but better balanced than the others.
2009: This was probably the thinnest of all the beers in the mouthfeel department. It was nearly medium bodied and had a warmth to it that wasn¬ít as present in the others.

Summarizing and second tasting notes. 2008 was noticeably lighter and hazier than the rest of the beers. 2004 had the most sediment and completely coated the bottom of the glass with it. The 2004 had a soy / bitter and dry taste to it. The 2005 was smooth and like chocolate. The 2006 was more sour than the others. 2007 Sweet and roasty. 2008 - more roast, more heat. 2009 was probably my favorite (with 2007 and 2005). I guess I like odd years. The 2009 did not have time to mute the flavors and let them run together into a single coherent "thought." They were still fragmented but I was able to enjoy the roast, the heat, the sweet, the chocolate bitter all individually making it a really interesting beer.
22 oz. 2010 bottle.  pitch black, roasty, tan head.  hoppy strong full flavor stout.  so smooth for 15 percent.  hints of coffee and  mollasses.  world class stout.

Pours black with a 1 1/2 finger, light brown head. A good alcoholic, chocolatey nose. Starts with a nice alcohol warmth then moves onto coffee. I didnt get chocolate till the end but then it lasted for days. overall the taste was amazing really. The chocolate was the strongest flavor for me and it was good and strong. A full body, left my mouth kinda sticky. This is the best stout i¬íve had(and i am not claiming i¬íve had them all). Maybe a little overhyped but still deserves to be in the upper echelon of Russian Imperial Stouts. Cant wait till next years DLD¬ís i will be trying to get as many as i can...along with thousand of others...

On tap at the Mikkeler Beer Bar, Copenhagen - So dark you should make curtains out of it. This is actually incredible. A progression of amazing flavours with an alcoholic hit pretty early on. Chocolate covered coffee beans are dominant. I get the flavour of the cigar in your mouth, not the smoke but the tobacco touching your wet lips. Plenty of creamy vanilla too. The aftertatse is like a big lump of dark chocolate that you ate a while ago. A beer epiphany. It feels wonderful too. What is wrong with it? Provided the price doesn¬ít count, NOTHING.
So delicious.

Bottle shared by beernbourbon. Pours pitch black with a light tan head. Aroma is hard to pin point. mixture of figs and chocolate. Taste is very complex with hints of chocolate. Very smooth on the palate with  light carbonation. Overall this is one of the best beers I have had. Thanks Vince!

Pours a pitch black with a thin and brief brown head. Aroma is pungent and complex - figs and chocolate-covered raisins. As my wife puts it, it tastes like everything. Surprisingly not roasty, but dark and fruity and very, very sweet. Plum, fig and raisin again. Light vanilla and chinotto. Thick coating body with light carbonation. Wow.

Thick black chocolate body with rapidly fading caramel brown head. Infusion of cherry chocolate on the inhale dusted with chocolate roast. Cherry chocolate liquor flavor flowing through a thick and creamy body. Characterized by vinous and prune flavors throughout. This brew calls to mind the Baltic Porter style as it approaches the panoply of flavor elements, however; Dark Lord is thicker and with more body to it. Incredibly well crafted, considering the ABV% is so well hidden. This certainly does not disappoint!

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2010 The aroma is potent, smoky and boozy with undertones of chocolate. The color is super dark brown with a cappuccino head on top. The flavor is rich, potent, with a thick body and sharp malty sweetness. It is young being 2010, and will evolve well with age.
*Gold wax thanks to Tom. Drank an ¬í06 tonight which was much more tame and delicious. Much smoother to take down with 4 years of good aging in the basement.

A: snifter. obsidian in color, with a huge coffee colored head. good retention level, with some big sticky lacing.

S: huge aromas of coffee, molasses, some black currents, raisins, some bittersweet chocolate, as well as some mahogany wood.

T: tons of molasses, rich roasted malts, leading to tons of coffee, raisins, soy, honey, pipe tobacco, some black currents. Holy shit this beer it so complex.

M: thick and beefy. low to mild carbonation level. massive palate on this.

D: wow! one bottle of this and I am out. So good, but I think it is definitely overhyped. major thanks to Grant and Todd for both bring a bottle out of the blue on the same day. what an experience.

2010 bottle- a good, smooth drinking, RIS- sweet, but not cloying- extremely accessible- had this with non-beer folks, and most enjoyed- however, it was lacking in complexity- probably due to its young age- although there was certainly roast, cherry, vinous qualities- much spice, alcohol heat was up front which is burying the quality that most likely lies underneath and can only be unearthed with time- will age another bottle for 2 years at least.

Huge thanks to daknole once again.  2009, White wax. Bottle pours viscous and deep brown/black with a beige head that quickly fades.  Aroma is intense and rich.  Sweet with notes of chocolate, molasses, licorice, caramel, and alcohol.  Flavor shows the same with some dark fruit and salt.  Overall body is full, moderately sweet and finishes lightly bitter.  Definately lives up to it¬ís name and i¬ím glad daknole "twisted my arm" to taste this one.
From 22oz, 2009 edition, Thank you mspindler,black in color,brown head,salty taste ,Chocolate,coffee,dark fruit.Strong ABV.Love it

Had this one at the UDRBM, 31-07-2010. Thnx Daknole for trading this with me. 2010 version. Black colored brew. Dried fruits and molasses in the aroma. Flavor has a lot of sweetness, dried fruits, caramel, malts and chocolate. Oily mouthfeel. A bit too sweet, could use more bitterness.

White waxed bottle, 2009 vintage, bought@√òlbutikken, K√∏benhavn. Pours a jet black, opaque and oily body. A thin layer of creamy brown foam on top. Aroma is fat, soft and gently sweet.  A refined sweetness from the roasted and honeyed malts, along with a prominent scent of dark dried fruits with raisins in the lead. MIlk-chocolate and mild coffee too. 
Full malt body. Taste has a pure and rounded sweetness, both malty and fruity, balanced by a rounded roastedness, coffee&chocolate, malt bitterness and some spice tones. Also a touch of vinous acidity. Velvetly mouthfeel. Warming, complex and fully balanced finish. An awesome beer, a true sweetheart.

2010 Vintage.  Served from bottle into a Stone nonic.  Pours black as sin with a one finger tan head that remains for quite some time.  Maintains phenomenial lacing throughout.  The aroma was comprised of coffe, malt, alcohol, and licorise.  The flavor was of chocolate, alcohol, malt, bread, caramel, and coffee.  It was heavy on the palate with medium carbonation.  Overall this brew is nothing short of epic in all aspects.  I had this before at a BA tasting thanks to mikesgroove and had to get my hands on a bottle for myself after that.  Now I remember why...  The flavor and aroma one this one is quite awesome and complex.  It is one of the ones that does live up to the hype surrounding it.  It is definitely a heavy hitter and while slightly chilled reminds you of this fact, but mellows out upon reaching room temperature.

Sampled, I think compliments of NobleSquirrel at RBSG 2010. Pours a deep black color with a good head and good lace. The aroma is sweet and malty with coffee and boozy notes well mixed with some dark chocolate and a surprising bit of smokiness. The flavor is dark coffee like roastiness, cr√®me brulee, brown sugar, raisin, some coffee bean, and lots of fruity notes. Thing has everything but the kitchen sink as far as Russian Imperial Stouts go.
This beer packs a punch!  This is one of the heaviest of the heavy darkest of the dark beers on the planet.  Quite an experience, nothing like it!

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2013 Tapped two bottles last night the 07 and 08, and this is now my favorite freakin beer....  I¬ím not going to bore you with all the details like how it leaves an oily sheen on the glass, or the beautiful brown colored head.  You know the legend of this amazing brew.  I will say this, the 08 in my opinion was much more chewy and I thought the flavors of bitter dark chocolate, burnt molasses, roasted malt, vanilla, and expresso were more pronounced.  The 07 was fantastic, but I felt like it was starting to unravel  a bit.  The 09 was not as good as the 08, but still better than I expected considering all the talk.  Dstructo pulled out the vertical at Hunahpu¬ís.  Tried the 04 and 05.  Tons of sediment.  The bodies were thinner with much more soy sauce flavors than the older versions.  Definitely starting to separate and on the decline..
Update.  After sampling the ¬í09,¬í10, and ¬í11 batches I feel that the body has really gone down hill while getting immensely sweeter...

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2014 Bottle 2010 vintage @ meeting, tfs NoiZe!Deep black pour, tiny deep brown head.Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts, peat, bourbon, liquorice, vanilla, caramel, iodine, plum, raisin. Flavour is very full and intense, sweet, sticky and creamy of caramel, roasted malt, sugar, peat, iodine, sweet and salt liquorice. Very intense en full of flavour but overall way too sweet for me.Very glad I got to try this though!

Bottle at Dutch RB Meeting. Thanks a lot for sharing NoiZe. Pitch black pour, no head. Aroma of chocolate, dark fruits, vanilla, bourbon, caramel, roasted malts and some sugar. Flavor is sweet and bitter with loads of roasted malts, sugar, chocolate, dark fruits and caramel. More like a good port than an imperial stout, but still quite good. Very bitter in the finish. Creamy texture and low carbonation. Very full bodied and intense brew. Not bad at all, but the hype seems a little misplaced to me.

¬í09 tap at an event. it is a pretty good beer, the best I dont know close. being an ipa guy I would rather take and say dread is the best beer all time. any way pours deep black with a nice chocolate head with good lacing. heavy soy sauce with coffee and chocolate mixed in. heavy body with a touch of cream on the palate. again a great beer no doubt, the best, close.

Best beer I have ever had.  I live in Munster and have never made it to Dark Lord Day before, but it was worth the wait.  Most people cannot appreciate this beer because they think a beer is to drink quickly, this is to be savored and shared!  As often described it has the appearence of motor oil, but tastes like heaven!

Bottle-green wax, so 2010 vintage. Poured a sheer, jet black color with a medium dark-tan head. Thick, thick like oil. Aroma is dark chocolates, coffee, fudge, alcohol. Flavor is a rich, creamy, coffee and dark chocolate bitter, fantastic all the way around. A bit overrated and overpriced for the beer, but good none the less. I¬íve tried to rate this outside of the hype.

Might be one of the best beers i¬íve ever had, i¬íd quite possibly punch my mom for another drank. tried bottles 06 - 10. Reviewing 2007 as it was my favorite. Poured like ink, beer stained the glass like iodine leaving a yellowy film behind when swirled, Huge aroma of molasses, roasted grain, and anise. Flavor profile was big and bold with tons of licorice, deep burnt molasses, bitter dark chocolate, candied raisins, with a mouthfeel that is heavy and thick, but not cloying.

Small dark brown head. Opaque black body. Sugary chocolatey wild berry aroma is very harmonic with mealy honey notes. Changes with time. Intensely sweet raisiny roasty chocolatey alcohol taste with acidic apple port and prunes notes. Smooth, velvety mouthfeel. Full-bodied, and more than full. Dryish roasty caramelly syrupy chocolate aftertaste with spicy alcohol notes. Incredibly sweet, but still works because of the balancing acid. Wonderful beer. (0.65l bottle shared by Ole_R. Cap has white wax, which means 2009.)

2009 bottle thanks to cquiroga. poured deep black with an nice tan head. Strong bitter roasted coffee aroma. Falvor full of the afortmentioned raost cofee and brunt malt, vanilla and molasses. body is creamy and full without being too sticky. very tasty brew.

2009 bottle courtesy of Braconid from TBS....thanks!  Opaque black pour with dark brown head.  Very impressive all-around.  Not as carbonated as it likely was awhile ago, there wasn¬ít much head.  Chocolate, roasty malts in the smell and taste....very deep and strong flavor.  Sweeter in the finish with a bitter start.  Very good.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 2009 vintage with white wax

A: Dark black body... moderate brown head quickly receded to a nice ring with some skim... very little lacing... looks intense

S: Massive roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and molasses... heavy presence of booze

M: Surprisingly delicate... lots of flavors going on but none of them bash into each other... smooth transitions between the roasted malts and coffee to the somewhat bittersweet chocolate and rich molasses... again, there is no mistaking the 13% ABV on this behemoth.

M: Tingly carbonation, just enough without becoming slightly fizzy... medium heavy body but the finish is short and sweet...

O: Top notch... very deserving of the attention it receives

Appearance-This beer poured an oil black with a thin brown head.

Smell- Wonderful smells of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Nice hints of the 13% alcohol.

Taste- Very good!! Very complex. All sorts of wonderful flavors like coffee, dark chocolate, and maybe molasses. The alcohol is detectable but well hidden.

Mouthfeel-Thick and creamy with low carbonation.

Overall-Incredible! Perhaps worth a trip to Dark Lord day next year? Hmmm. Maybe.

Bottle kindly shared by OleR.
Oily black, low carbonation.
Smoke, tar, molasses. Velvety, tahter sweet. Loads of malty sweetness, to a large extent balanced by invisible dryness and sourness. Too much on the sweet side.

2007 vintage with silver wax. Appearance - Oily and black with no head whatsoever. The occasional rising bubble settles on the surface for a moment, giving the appearance of a bubbling tar pit. Although there¬ís no lace, the beer does coat the glass in an oily residue. Smell - Sweet and rich. Molasses, coffee and milk chocolate come to mind, with undertones of vanilla and raisins. Taste - Mellower than I was expecting and actually downright pleasant. Flavors of licorice, molasses, vanilla and coffee blend together harmoniously, presenting enough complexity to make this an enjoyable beer to sip for several hours. The finish is long and coating, leaving a roasted bitterness on the palate. No noticeable alcohol despite the rather high ABV; the sweet, rich flavors seem to overpower its presence. Mouthfeel - Thick; absurdly thick. Dark Lord gave me a new standard for the term full-bodied. This beer literally has the consistency of whole milk. Carbonation is nearly non-existent and never really felt, which only contributes further to the chewy mouthfeel. Drinkability - The massive mouthfeel, while probably the beer¬ís greatest attribute, also makes it difficult to drink both frequently and in large quantities - I¬íd have a hard time finishing a bottle by myself. Notes - This beer has lost its appeal to me since initially trying it, and my ratings have been adjusted to reflect that. Not a bad beer, just not my thing anymore.

2009 Bottle.  Finishing off a great week of vacation and following the sampling of many tasty DFH brews with this whale.  Pours a black color with a caramel colored head.  Has an aroma of dark fruit, vanilla, and coffee, with hints of chocolate.  I know its easy to get caught up in the hype with this brew.  But as one that has sampled several top IS¬ís, this beer lives up to its hype and high regard.  Starts sweet with the dark fruit.  Then creamy with a pinch of carbonation in the middle.  The coffee is very subdued but gives it that spice right after the creaminess subsides.  Then the gentle bitters carry you to the finish.  The finish is excellent.  The velvety chocolate lingers on the tongue while residue from the dark fruit is still present.  Notes of vanilla on the finish as well.  The creaminess of this brew is what really makes it so special.  Many IS¬ís are this complex but others tend to be more syrupy than creamy.  Damn fine beer.  Will age the other 2009 another year.

2009 vintage; courtesy of fiulijn - dark black colour and with a fast disappearing dark beige foam; robust aroma of tar, chocolate and vanilla, some apparent alcohol and notes of dark cherries; thick and full-bodied, very tasty, the pretty high sweetness is soon overwhelmed by a powerful bitterness; moderate carbonation; aftertaste of dark chocolate, prune and licorice along with some alcohol notes - complex and powerful

About as heavy and flavorful a dark brew as is theoretically possible. Second to the last bomber from my trip to DLD 2009 pours obsidian black with a thin brown layer of foam. A swirl stains the sides of the glass espresso brown. Rich aromas of hierloom cocoa, fresh brewed mocha coffee, smoked beef jerkey, dark cherries, bourbon, and more. Flavor is dense and chewy figs, New England brown bread, and dark stone fruits on a smokey malt base with even a hint of resinous hops. Dark Lord finishes dry all across the mouth, with pronounced alcohol heat.

big props to dstructo for the bottle. Aroma is amazing with a strong cherry smell. alcohol is right in your face with chocolate prevalent too.Black pour with a lighter head. has a chocalate with a very alcoholy cherry taste.pretty awesome. heavy mouthfeel with a strong alchohol burn. this beer is amazing.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2012 2010 vintage. The perfect beer. Opaque dark pour. Aroma of rich oak. Taste is oak and licorice, extremely rich. Unbelievably rich and awesome. 1198 ratings and this is #1 all time. Seriously.

Ok, now after 3500 ratings, I have a little more perspective. Stil love it, but I¬íve had a few that top it. Moving this down a few ticks.

What a great beer!  This beer is very well balanced beer that pours like the motor oil we so much crave.  The head is very deep brown, and it cascades similar to Guinness.  The predominant flavors are chocolate, coffee, and caramel.  This beer is truly amazing, and worth the drive to Munster, Indiana on DarkLord Day (DLD) to get it.  Definitely in the top 2 to 3 beers I¬íve ever tried.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2011 2009 Bottle. Pours black with a small beige head. Aroma is mollasses, licorice, cat food, toffee, and chocolate. Flavor is licorice, mollasses, and chocolate syrup. Full oily mouthfeel with nice heat.

White wax (2009) bottle via trade.  Pours thick oil black with no head or carbonation.  Aroma is strong coffee, fruits, plums, vanilla, malts, and sugar.  Taste is absolutely wonderful.  I had heard the hype, but didn¬ít know if it could live up to it - the beer surpassed all expectations.  Taste is heavy on the coffee, chocolate, sugar, sweetness, vanilla undertones, and light smoke flavors.  It¬ís an almost perfect blend of all that makes an Imperial Stout great.  A new #1 in my book.  Finishes sweet with a hint of lingering viscosity from the oily mouthfeel.  Amazing.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2010 Awesome beer, almost lives up to its hype. The appearance is beautiful black, oily, thin brown head, nice lacing.  The aroma is oak, chocolate, roast, cherries, malty, nice!!  The flavor is sweet, chocolate, cherries, plums, cream, oak.  Too much going on in both aroma and flavor to describe.  Awesome thick chewy mouthfeel.  The finish is sweet, segueing to a moderate but enduring piney hop bittering.  Really awesome.

Had the 07 and 10 bottles next to each other thanks to Oldstylecubfan. Thanks Todd! COMPLETELY different beers and not just because of age.  This rating is for the 2007 because I liked it better.  Poured motor oil black with little to no head.  Aroma of huge rich malt and super rich sweetness.  Palate coating consistency, no real hop aroma or flavor, viscous.  Slight oxidation but not too noticeable or off putting.  Deep, rich, roasted malt flavors. 

The 2010 is much hoppier, over the top sweetness.  Too much sugar and too rich.
After waiting in line for god knows how long at this year¬ís Dark Lord Day, I can safely say the beer was worth the wait. It¬ís absolutely delicious...probably the best stout I¬íve ever had.
I had the 2010 about 2 weeks ago with two of my best friends who i never see. We were all glad to have this beer to celebrate our convergence.  Thanks Alex.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2014 Green wax, 2010.  Loads of roasted malt flavor in a wonderful balance of chocolate, roast and coffee.  Great thick and creamy feel - really incredible.  Flavor is medium sweet without even a hint of stickiness.  Not quite my very favorite imperial stout but very close and I could see a different version or a bottle with some age on it winning me over entirely.

2010 bottle.  Pours completely opaque dark brown with thin tan head. Aroma is dried fruit and oak. Flavor is amazingly complex, seemingly changing with every sip.  Notes of coffee, molasses, figs, dried cherries. Port wine flavor in finish. Hides ABV amazingly well. This one actually lives up to the hype.

Bottle, vintage 2007. Pours a black color with a small head. Has a roasted malty dark chocolate molasses and coffee aroma. Roasted malty oily molasses and dark chocolate flavor with hints of sour fruit and coffee. Has a roasted heavy malty molasses finish.  Thick Thick Thick!  Glass looked like it was coated with motor oil when I was done.  This was my first ever Dark Lord.  Overall it was a very nice stout but certainly not head and shoulders above all others.

Broke the black wax (¬í08) with much anticipation on a weeknight last winter (finally rating, but I remember it well, drank it over 2 evenings). Aromas of turkish coffee, chocolate chip cookies and bread dough persist through the pour. This one is black and viscous like motor oil from a VW bus overdue for a service (but without the char aroma, which actually would have been nice here), and persistent halo of compact beige bubbles. Carbonation is on low side, adding more to the perceived weight of this goopy syrup. Hops are there to somewhat balance with alcohol as slight hot astringency in aftertaste.

Combo Rating.  2009 &2010.  
2009.  Compared to the 2010 this beer is much sweeter.  It is not overbearing, but noticeable right away.  The year of aging must have produced the great balance that this beer pronounces.  Very smooth with little carbonation.  The molasses accents the plum and cherry very well.  Strong taste of chocolate and Intelligentsia coffee in the background. You could probably heat this beer up like coffee and it would be delicious.

2010.  Much more of an aggressive brew.  The ingredients jump off your palate and the "big cherry" seems to jump out creating a euphoric-like experience.  Even though this batch has lower drinkability, I feel it is a much better batch than the 2009.  I will age a few, but for the people saying you must age the 2010, I think it is all a matter of taste.  Perfect beer to pair with desserts.  Best beer I¬íve gotten my hands on.  
DLD was a great time.  My condolences to the man who dropped his box and broke all the Dark Lord he purchased after waiting in line.

I unfortunately find this beer to be cloyingly sweet. I have had several different vintages at several different ages and they are all just too sweet for me. I can commend Three Floyds for how well the alcohol is hidden and I can see why so many people absolutely love this beer. Its just too sweet for me. I would prefer more roast, fig, cocoa, dark molasses, with a hop balanced bitterness and more alcohol influence. All I get is table sugar, and maybe some brown sugar... Easy to drink, absolutely!!! For me, not quite...

Bottle 2010. Pour was pitch black, syrup looking. Dark malt, coffee, with hints of light smoke and fruits.  Very boozy, vanilla flavor that leaves a film in your mouth for minutes afterwords.  I can see how this will improve with age as this seems like a cluster of independant flavors instead of a well balanced brew. Though still very tasty

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2010 2009 vintage. Pours jet black with small quickly dissipating tan head. Nose is vanilla bean, oak, smoke, molasses, coffee and chocolate. Taste is vanilla extract and bean, coffee, chocolate, molasses, brown sugar, smoked woods, oak and a smooth bourbon warming alcohol finish. Good beer.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2011 2009 Vintage Dark Lord recieved in a trade. So much hype and so much anticipation...here we go!!!

A-deep jet black in color pouring a thinner, bubbly 1 1/2 inches of head that is a dark tan in color, almost a coffee colored head, that dissipates quickly but deepens in color as it does. it leaves almost no lacing on the glass and the head is not exactly what I had hoped.

S-brings a huge nose, molasses and dark chocolate up front but light, tons of sugary fruity sweetness in the back.  this smells so sweet.

T-huge flavor in this, molasses and dark chocolate are again faint but try to add some imperial stout quality.  the sweetness is insanely high, boozy in back, lots of sugar, caramel, and dark fruits.

M-the mouthfeel is unbelievable, it could be the thickest beer I have had to date. it is extremely thick and chewy, delightfully smooth and creamy, and a perfect balance of carbonation

D-this is way too sweet, a little one dimensional.  huge body and nice feel but just so sweet.  age helps but still to sweet (did a verticle of 07-10 on 5/22/10, all were too sweet and quite one dimensional, 09 was the worst in everyone¬ís opinion, I like 08 the best but again just candy for grown ups).

Wow! 
A fantastic vinous aroma with lots of dark fruit, roasted malt, vanilla, alcohol, a little liquorice and caramel and somewhat oak like. 
Taking a sip doesn¬ít change much its just a vinous, got lots of raisins, sweet liquorice, roasted malt, caramel, nuts, a little dark fruits and alcohol and a oak like hint. 
Thick as oil body and a sweet and long smooth after taste. 
Great great great!

Got this beauty in a trade. Much hyped and much waited for - but disappointing. And to think people were trying to offer me one of these for four Westvleteren 12s. Crazy.

Poured awesome - black like every other RIS. Tan head that fades fast - like every other RIS. When cool, this thing has the most awesome flavors and mouthfeel. But since it is so strong it won¬ít be cool the entire time you drink it - which is where it turns south fast. The hotness from the alcohol is so pronounced it is almost like drinking bourbon neat. This masks every flavor that you were experiencing previously. The mouth-feel is more watered down than most RISs. Sad.

If it were not for the disappointing last half of my glass, actually more, this would score way higher. I think the lack of availability is pushing the ratings on this higher than they should be. It is an average RIS when considering the whole ¬íbody¬í of this. Considering the first half, when cold - much cooler than you should be expected to drink this, then it is way above average. Too bad it doesn¬ít stay consistent, in good taste, throughout the entire bottle.

Holy sh*t. This is my first beer rating, though not my first beer and my WORD, is DarkLord¬ís 2010 Vintage a rough one. 

It hits you like Jessica Rabbit.....it¬ís not bad: it¬ís just drawn that way. Warm, vanilla smokyness and a heavy boozy aroma hits my nostrils and tells me that this is going to be fine...JUST fine....

And then I sip. And my eyes widen. 

I¬íve made a HUGE mistake.

This is pure alcohol and doom. This is waterier than I expected but by no means watery and the taste of soy sauce and scalded chocolate adheres to my tastebuds. 

I look forward to trying this Vintage in a few years when (hopefully) it mellows out a bit. Then again, with a name like DarkLord......

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2010 Bottled 2008 version. Pours pitch black with a little brown head.Low carbonation Nose of coffee, choclate, vanilla and alcohol. Sweet flavour with roasted malt, dark fruits, coffee and  chocolat. Full bodied. Oily texture. Slightly bitter malt finish. Just great.

THICK! 

 Weak aroma. Likely due to low carbonation. 

 Complex with a good balance.

 Will re-rate after trying on bottle. The tap was flat.

 Purchased on tap at Mikkeller √òlbar openning.

Entered to celebrate my 100th rating, hooray! Tab @ Mikkeller Bar.
Behold, the mighty Dark Lord, honored to be in your presence. I see your opaque black shade with no head. I smell your coffee, chocolate, tobacco, little hops, figs, vanilla, booze. You are very complex and smell so great. 
You taste like coffee, chocolate, brown melasses, roasted sweetness, raisins, vanilla - you have everything and you are so subtly balanced.
You are a big fellow, very viscous, like motor oil in texture and mildly massaging my tongue with your soft bubbles. It covers all of your mouth. You are so awesome!

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2010 [email¬†protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ √∏lbar. Black body with no head. Aroma is sweet, molasses, vanilla, coffee and almost to much soy. Flavor is coffee, vanilla, syrup, hops and alcohol. Well carbonated. I look forward to try a bottle version. 7 3 8 4 18.

RE-RATE:
Bottle 2009 vintage. Black body with a very small head. Aroma is molasses, coffee, vanilla, raisins, dark fruit, ripe fruit, light soy. Flavor is coffee, vanilla, roasted malt, sweet caramel, raisins, dark fruit and light soy. Alcohol is well hidden. Medium carbonation. Smooth palate. Great beer.
Pours out flat black. Smells sweet booze. Taste is seet roasty. Flavors of coffee, bourbon, vanilla, some chocolate with big wood taste. Some alcohol warming. Sticky sweet, Great stuff.

2010 Vintage...

Poured from a bomber into a snifter.  

Before I even take a sip I can tell this  one desperately needs some age on it.  The smell at first reminds me a bit of some sort of cleaning product - this stuff it RAW.

Taste is primarily roasty malts and booze with a slightly bitter aftertaste.  It¬ís good, but I cannot wait to try this one again once its had time to mature for a year to two.  I¬ím very confident it will be amazing at that point, but for now its just a bit too raw for my taste...  nevertheless - a very nice and very complex beer that will undoubtedly only improve with age.

Definitely looking forward to re-visiting this one again down the road...

Fad: Kulsort √∏l med et lille skumhoved. Vidunderlig duft af molasses, kaffe og chokolade. Det giver et lille strejf af vanilie som n√¶rmest peger p√• en veludf√∏rt fadlagring som jeg ved ikke er der. Smagen er s√∏d, kaffe og is√¶r chokolade, igen med et lille strejf vanilie som m√• komme fra kaffen. Fin humlebitterhed bakker op om en velintegreret og meget afbalanceret √∏l hvor de 15% alkohol ikke kan ses. Fantastisk.

Bomber 2009. Black with nice creamy tan head that thins. Aroma of sweet and powerful chocolate, rich toffee caramel, hints of coffee licorice and darker fruits, booze prevalent. Head is completely gone now. Taste is so powerful it would be offensive to many (maybe me). The darkest chocolates, biting big bad booze, dark syrups, coffee, and sticky sticky sticky! Really shocking! Hint at vanilla and all burnt up crispy! Beer really couldn¬ít smell better!

Bottled, 2010. Wow, finally! Black pour, brown head. Nose is smoke, coffee, chocolate, raisins, soy sauce. Flavor is malty, smoky, coffee, bittersweet chocolate. Finish is slightly bitter. Thick, viscous mouthfeel. I¬ím not sure if spending 5-1/2 hours in line coupled with a 4-1/2 hour drive was worth it, but I¬ím happy to be in possession of 5 more bottles. wish they hadn¬ít changed the bottle limit midday.

On tap @ Mikkeller Bar Grand Opening. Pitch black with an elegant dark head. The nose is deep with roasted caramel, raisin, a hint of alcohol and chocolate. All very balanced and rounded. The mouth is sweet, intense with loads of flavors. A pleasant sour is present and follows through to the end rounding off this very enjoyable experience.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2011 Tasted 05, 09, and 10 versions, review is sort of a composite. 

Pours absolutely midnight-black with a nice sized deep-tanned head. Head held up pretty well in a pint glass, not quite as well in snifter interestingly.

Aromas are all over the place, raisins, molasses, coffee, chocolate, plum, bread, you name it. Vinous is definitely a word that applies.

Taste is similarly insane and layered. The 05 had wonderful complexity with chocolate of varying bitterness, smoke, wood, earth, and coffee shining through. The 09 was much fruitier, with raisin, prune, and even I swear some cherry flavors showing through. Incredibly layered and deep, every sip and savor revealing something new.

The palate is absurd, motor oil is an apt description, but while often i recoil from sticky, viscous palates it worked perfectly in this case, coating my mouth in smooth velvety goodness. Alcohol on the 05 and 09 were both in perfect balance already, and overall a nearly perfect palate for me, fitting wonderfully with the deep complexity of the brew. 

Hype aside, this is probably my favorite beer in the world right now, and i really really wish i could get a hold of more of the old vintages.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2010 2010 Release - Pours jet black with a half-finger, chocolate head. Aroma is complex- bourbon dominates with cherries, smoke, molasses, and chocolate. Taste is similar - molasses, chocolate, bourbon, smoke, coffee, and cherries. Mouthfeel is both oily and creamy.

¬í08

Nothing short of one of the best beers in the world. Pours a thick, oilish black with a creamy espresso head. Not the best retention, but  exquisite color and dense viscosity more than makes up for it.

The nose has dark malts, fudge, coffee, molasses, anise, caramel, dark pitted fruits and dank hops. 

The taste is the perfect blend of sweet, bitter and roasted flavors. Vast complexity yet superb balance.

Possibly the thickest beer I have ever had.  So much going on, but nothing out of place.  The epitome of artisinal brewing.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2012 Tasting at Jerry¬ís. Black with good, creamy, tan head / Nose of coffee, chocolate, smoke, dark fruit / Full body, thick and inky, sweet but with good hopping, with long finish with underlying bitterness / Young flavors of smoke, dark roast coffee, tobacco, dark cherry, plum, and caramel / Interesting young, but probably best aged.  Tried as part of 2007-2011 tasting - favorites were 11, 09, and 07.  07 surprisingly still massive.  Would speculate that these will age 10 years or more.

¬í10 draft tasting at DLD. You¬íll have to forgive me for my less than thourough tasting notes... a drunk taster with a destroyed palate does not, a proficient rater, make!
 All I can say is, finally, I have this bad boy under my belt. Thank you Three Floyds!

¬í08 vintage bottle I got in a trade awhile back. Thanks for the opportunity to try this beer- my celebration of 6 months straight of a 7 day a week schedule. So this is the first chance I¬íve had time to sit down and write a review in awhile.

A- From a moderately lit room on a December night the body appears to be pitch almost black- the color of a well made black coffee only much thicker-the appearance does not change when My snifter is held up to the light. Just when you think the Dark Lord will be headless a dark chocolate foamy 1/2 finger thick head arises and fades more slowly but just as ominously and slowly as it arises leaving a thin collar and traces of lacing remain throughout the glass as it is sipped.

S-The nose struck me just as I unsealed the cap. Initially I smelled classic RIS with this one being particularly heavy on anise. From the snifter anise is definitely present but balanced with semi-sweet dark chocolate. Plum and molasses come through as well. The background is a sleeping ominous beast of alcohol that subtly looms.

T- The initial flavor is quite sweet with a complex flavor that I can¬ít quite get my palate around. Certainly RIS in nature with a character where not one flavor stand out the most between vanilla, cocoa, molasses, and plums. As it lingers on the palate more prominent characters of anise, roasted malt, and dark cocoa arise. The finish is consistent with the initial flavor as a hint od dark fruit sneaks its way in as well making. Just then it turns to a dark wine and a quick, mild, lash of alcohol bitterness as it is swallowed. What lingers is hints of the whole flavor put together with an emphasis on the roasted malt.

P-Mild to moderate carbonation with a thick, viscous, and heavy yet smooth body. The alcohol is undetectable in the mouthfeel.

O- For a 13% monster this beer is pretty drinkable...it has had 1.5+ yrs behind it which probably tames it, but its one of the most drinkable beers I¬íve had with this high ABV. This is a rare treat that I doubt I will have the opportunity to have again anytime soon and I really am enjoying it. Best stout ever? No. Worth the hype? debatable. Great, high quality product? Yes.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-22-2009 02:15:47

Absolutely worth the 10 hour drive from Oklahoma.  Had this on tap @ DLD 2010. Pours thick, aroma is of toffee and coffee with hints of chocolate and vanilla. Appearance dark black as expected from a RIS.  Taste and Palate...Hints of toffee, coffee, camel and chocolate. Feels heavy on the tongue and fills the mouth completely . Overall I think this beer definitely lives up to the hype!

On tap at DLD 2010. Pour into 10 oz plastic cup. Thick, dark brown color with small brown head. Aroma is of chocolate, toffee, coffee, a bit of vanilla, and molasses. Taste is a lot of the same, very chocolaty with a small alcohol burn on the end. Super complex, the flavor lasts for a really long time on the tongue. Awesome. Can¬ít wait to try on of my bottles after spending a good bit of time in the cellar.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2013 On tap @ DLD ¬í10. Pours a thick black with a small light brown head. The aroma is mega roasty, with coffee, molasses, anise, chocolate, vanilla, and faint dark fruit. The flavor mirrors it. Very thick body with very soft carbonation. Almost lives up to the hype.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2011 Dark Lord is slowly becoming an instituion based on hype - a beer that¬ís so good it can only be available for one day a year to calm the populous.  Unfortunately, the hype outweights the product.  Don¬ít get me wrong, Dark Lord is one of the best beers in the world, and it truly deserves a great amount of respect.  However, the hype surrounding this beer has outweighed the taste it possesses.  Its aroma is of a thick vanilla / coffee / chocolate hybrid, its black and has the consistency of motor oil, and it has about 13 different flavors going at any point in time.  Its very good, biut I don¬ít think that the hype its receiving can outweigh the taste it has.  But then again, no beer can probably meet that level of expectation.  Dark Lord is very good, but its history will bill itself as one of the greatest...an accomplishment that can¬ít be triumphed, and one that might never be truly met in a popular sentiment..................................OK, it¬ís 2011 and I just came back from Dark Lord Day.  A good friend bought a bottle and decided to chill it on ice, and we enjoyed with a group of people.  There are other beers I rated today, and hands down Dark Lord was the best of the bunch.  Just a fantastic mix of coffee, lactose, brewers licorice, and a whole bunch of other stuff added to the mix that gives it an immensely complex profile.  It really is one of the best beers in the world and since I have a bottle that I¬íll consume at a later date, may be bumping up my rating later...................It¬ís my 30th b-day today and I¬íve decided to bump up my DL rating by 0.3  With the aging, the chocolate notes come out even more mixed with the coffee to give it a flavor that can only be attributed to Dark Lord...it¬ís outstanding and damn near perfect.  Re-rating the taste as 10 because really, there is nothing out there that tastes like Dark Lord.

Vintage 2010:  From the bottle.  Pour produced a thick, dark body, with a small cascade of caramel-colored foam, like an espresso.  As heavy as this beer is, it is a marvel that any carbonation got through.  As expected, there is a strong aroma of coffee, and malt, with a whiff of alcohol thrown in.  Also detected in the mix was a slight aroma of dried fruit (raisin, figs, etc.) At the first sip, you can appreciate the coffee-like bitterness being balanced out by the syrupy sweetness of the malt.  This is a super-thick-bodied beer with a stickiness that should be enjoyed in small doses.

Ok. So first off I have to give a HUGE shout out to Dankman38. He is the reason this bottle was in my possession. Back on June 22 2009, Mike posted a thread saying he would give away a bottle of Dark Lord to the person who could find the glitch on his profile. I managed to be the first one to find the trade feedback he wrote about himself and 2 weeks later the bottle arrived. I am sending nothing but good beer karma to Mike right now. I saved this beer for my 500th rating. This bottle just sat there looking at me in my cellar for 8 months. i would take it out every now and again and just look at it. Well the time in the cellar has done this beer very well. 2009 bottle. Pours like used motor oil. The head is fudge coloured and sticks to my snifter, you can see the residual sugar clinging to the glass. The aroma is fudgey, chocolaty, and musty with hints of berries, vanilla, biscuit, caramel, butterscotch, and molasses. Everything is very well integrated, I could not even smell the 13% alcohol on the nose. The flavor is very sweet, bitter, rich, and absurdly complex. Fudgee-o cookie, black currant, vanilla, coffee, caramel, cookie, molasses, butterscotch, toasted oak, licorice, honey, brown sugar. and all kinds of kick ass. The mouth feel is extremely heavy and sticky. I can feel the residual sugar on my tongue and lips, and in no way is that a bad thing this time. The flavor lingers for a very long time. Wow. Well worth the wait and Thank you so much again Mike!!! I am so glad I had the privilege to try this beer!

I¬ím no stranger to the taste of dog biscuits-- or the smell at that matter, and the Dark Lord laid siege to my nostrils like a tasty treat to my pooch¬ís snot nose.  Luckily the taste could only be fully enjoyed by a biped such as myself, for even Lassie¬ís refined tongue would overlook some of the chocolate, cocoa, vanilla, caramel, smokey raisin and prune subtleties, although I doubt any living creature would miss the malty molasses cavalry that this Dark Lord stampedes over its face.  In a night of drinking, this is a main event, a tasty treat for the boys!  Down the hatch like oil!

2009 bottle (white wax)  Jet black pour ,very minimal beige head , sparse lace . Huge aroma of roasted malt , chocolate ,coffee and alcohol . The flavor is sweet , roasty , coffee , bitter chocolate , anise and a touch smoky . Slick and thick , full bodied , mild carbonation . Good balance , solid bitterness and noticeable alcohol in the finish . Very complex and amazing . thanks Candy

Of course deep black and a big old brown head.  The aroma is raisins, molasses, a bit of soy, and a hint of roast.  The flavor is sweet raisins, maple syrup, and a subtle but wonderful dose of chocolate and smooth coffee.  The coffee lingers nicely and the beer is extremely smooth despite a hint of alcohol.

From a 2007 bottle that¬ís been sitting in my cellar since I¬ím not really sure when. Thank you, somebody. Despite an aggressive pour there are zero bubbles and no outward signs of carbonation... a viscous, light-absorbing sauce. Nose is both sweet and savory, chocolate, coffee, teriyaki, soy. Really round flavor, bittersweet and full, mocha-coffee-chocolate, vanilla, caramel-tootsie roll. There is still a bit of carbonation, just a bit lively despite thick body. Bit of licorice in the aftertaste. Heavy, ponderous, warming stuff.

2009 bottle. Thanks Kegbear. What a way to start my St. Patrick¬ís day drinking. I have been waiting to try this beer for years. Literally. I am very excited by its heavenly aroma. SO good. The first taste is definite chocolate. Like walking into Willa Wonkas living room. Fantastic. The chocolate fades into some fruit. Almost wine but sweet. The aftertaste is some alcohol that you feel in your throat for awhile. Incredible
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: This 2007 bottle pours a thick, deep black body with a very thin but lasting brown head. Flavors include chocolate, roasted coffee, dark fruits like prunes and raisins, and some alcohol warmth. Lives up to the hype.

First off I have to thank fata2683 for hooking me up with this awesome brew.  Pours a pitch black color much like oil.  Aroma is of heavy malts, plums, molasses, bitter sweet cocoa, and dried cherries.  Flavor is extremely smooth which includes matls, cocoa, molasses, dried fruit, and some honey.  Leaves a nice chocolaty malt finish.  I am priveledge to have had this one.  Thanks again Keith.

22oz, white wax bomber, from the three floyds brewery on DLD ¬í09. so i figured rating #500 deserved to be the beer i drove 2000+ miles, round trip, to obtain and the day that truly initiated me as a true beer geek. and here we go...pours a ridiculously thick, oily, jet black with a thin, bubbly dark cocoa head and oily lacing. aroma is, well, unbelievable with massive roasted malts, burnt espresso beans, blackstrap molasses, and dark chocolate with notes of rum-soaked raisins, figs, and prunes and hints of black licorice, cigar ash, smoked wood, toffee, and freshly shelled pecans. i honestly smelled this one for at least 10 minutes before taking a sip because it¬ís so damn complex. and holy hell, what a first sip it was. flavor is sublime, just perfect, with immense roasted malts, dark, brandied fruit notes of cherry, raisin, and fig, and earth up front that transition into the most sublime flavors of dark chocolate, toffee candy, black coffee, vanilla, smoke, and a touch of bourbon with a massive, relentless roasty finish. palate is beyond full bodied but slick and smooth, i¬ím going to have no problem crushing to bomber, with no trace of the 13% aside from a pleasant warming sensation through the belly. overall, this is the brew that all other imperial stouts should be judged by. i can¬ít believe i thought about trading my last bottle...not a chance. bravo, three floyds. bravo! oh, and the proclaimers fucking rock!

Bottle (2009 White Wax). The Dark Lord has arrived! Pours an unforgiving black with a tiny dark brown head that retreated to a handful of bubbles in the glass. This beast even reveals some legs...massive stuff! Aroma is crazy...heaps of soy sauce and molasses off the first whiff, but does mellow out and introduces sweetened dark fruits, honey, chocolate and boozy notes. The flavour is full on - extremely viscous and almost syrup like. The honey character smooths this out slightly but regardless it¬ís definitely a sipper. I found the sweetness is too much and definitely lacked drinkability. The finish is alcoholic with very low bitterness. Having said that I was intrigued by the complexity of the Impy and can appreciate the craftsmanship - it¬ís a huge beer. Big thanks to Jase for hauling this one back to Oz. Cheers mate!

Finally get to try this beast. White wax. Pours with light head though is dark as night. Nose is all alcohol, dark chocolate, soy and honey. In the mouth it is brutally upfront. Dark fruit, molasses, honey, and roast vie with eath other through the thick, viscouse body. Kind of like a mead/imperial stout hybrid - it‚Äôs about as full on as it gets. A bomber would be difficult to finish, but sharing between three was just about perfect. A sipper of the highest quality. Would I line up for it once a year? Yeah, but more so for the event than the actual beer. Still a great event beer. Tanks to the volcanicbeat for bringing this back from Japan.

2008 Vintage.

A: The pour on this beer is thick and black with a finger or so of dark brown head.

S: Aromas of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and surprisingly, raisins. There are also some hints of licorice and perhaps some other dark stone fruits such as plums.

T: This is certainly a sweeter RIS than I am used to. Solid chocolate, roasted malt, and chocolate flavors. But, the most striking feature (once again) is the sweetness of the dark fruits, especially raisins.

M: As you would expect, the body is fantastic on this. Very full, chewy, and thick.

D: This is a tasty beer, but one that you should definitely take your time with. The alcohol is hidden well in the flavors, but it will catch up to you.

09 vintage courtesy of moejuck. black pour with a thick brown head that fades a lil too fast. aroma and flovor both have lots of roast, smoke, peat, bacon, and a tinge of heat and hops.  nice low carb on the palate, thick, rich and creamy with a syrupy mouthfeel. meaty and chewy, warming and pleasent all the way through.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2010 2006 bottle from Zathrus 13.  Pours pitch black with a nice tan head.  strong aroma of molasse and licorice.  Flavors are sweet molasses, licorice, roasted malt, chocolate and some smoke (peated?) and alcool burn at the end.  The bitterness is well balanced with sweetness and alcool and the body is quite thick!  This imperial stout is for sure gargantuan but to my surprise is quite balance nonetheless.  Many thanks Jeff for this treat.

White wax label bottle for my 1000th rating graciously provided by The Bman1113vr. To be honest, I was expecting this beer to be overrated. Whoops. It poured black with a creamy brown head that only stuck around for a little while. The staining of the glass was spectacular! A beautiful yellow tint with a thick alcohol ring above. Then I started to smell this beer, and it was tons of coffee, wood, soy, earth, unsweet bakers chocolate. But as it warmed, it went from being woody and coffee-y to plums and raisins. After 10-15 minutes of smelling this beer, I tasted it. Wow. At first, it¬ís tons of espresso, unsweet chocolate, soy, BBQ, and some nice bitterness with a pleasant alcohol burn in the belly and throat. Then, as it warmed, it became a lot more fruity, with raisins, molasses, some vanilla. A heavy, chewy mouthfeel with some nice prickling alcohol that prickled the tongue. Phenomenal beer. Thanks again, Andrew!

Bomber to large snifter. Pour was oil black with rich tan head and solid lacing. Aroma is earthy oak and and chocolate and mocha scent. Taste is rich sweet coffee and chocolate with just enough booze to it with nice dry fiinish. Palate is full thick and heavy feeling. Overall this is one of my favorite imperial stouts it is just plain delicious. (2009) white wax bottle.

2007 bottle from Decaturstevo. Thanks dude. Picked this up in a trade. Actually, beer wasn¬ít the only thing traded, brewing equipment was mixed in that equation as well. Nice DARK chocolate head. Not much was produced whatsoever. Head fades away very quickly. The pour was extremely viscous. It was like pouring oil. Isn¬ít overrated in terms of appearance. Wow, this beer is fairly pungent. Extreme smore, chocolate, and sugar aroma. Slight touches of bourbon, but not much. The chocolate aroma is unparalleled. Subtle roast is also mixing in. Vanilla and molasses are obviously present. Wow, a little too sweet for me. Molasses and vanilla cut right through. Chocolate sweetness is present. Very interesting beer in terms of its developing qualities. Graham cracker sweetness creeps up and touches the touch. At first it seems a bit light and creamy, and then it turns to a smooth roast flavor. Alcohol is well-hidden. The palate is insane; the palate is very rich. A huge dessert beer. Doesn¬ít have a carbonation bite at all. Has carbonation, but it is just right. Molasses, sugar, cream, vanilla, chocolate, smore, graham cracker, and roast. Only reason it got a "lower" score overall, is that this thing is a little too sweet for me.

2009 bottle, big thanks to puzzl. Opaque, dark chocolate brown pour, nearly headless, putting forth just a skiff of coffee-brown bubbles. Hot alcohol nose harmonizes nicely with some dark fruit malt, overall gives a nice spiced raisin aroma. Flavor leads off with more of the same, plums, cinnamon, nice, but overall is dominated by the molasses. Strong, leathery, blackstrap molasses, somewhat mineral in character. Interesting, but I can¬ít say I care for it as the primary characteristic of a stout. Thick, full body, very smooth and viscous, potently warming.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2011 Silver wax - Vintage. Pours black with a brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, liquorish, plum, raisin, chocolate and coffee. Flavour is roasted malt, liquorish, coffee and chocolate, light alcohol. Palate is quite sticky. Extremely nice. 8-5-9-5-18 4.5.

Black vax. Pours black with a brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, liquorish, soy, chocolate and ash. Flavour is roasted malt, alcohol, soy, chocolate, ash and heavy liquorish. Still nice...

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2010 2009 bottle, sampled at the Great Imperial Stout tasting in Boise 1/16/10 8_4_5_3_15 3.6 overall 
Appearance: Thick, black with a small brown head 
Aroma: Roasted malts, chocolate, coffee and alcohol 
Taste: Bitter (hot) alcohols, sour, roasted malts, coffee 
After a night of having some Awesome Imperial Stouts, this was a disappointment from all the hype. The aroma was great, but the taste was mostly hot alcohols and sour at first. There were several at the tasting that said the same thing. I would like to try this beer again after aging for a few years. I¬ím sure that would mellow out the alcohol. 
7/30/10: I was finally able to try another year. 2007 bottle thanks to footbalm. 
Much smoother mouthfeel. Nice dark malts and chocolate. The alcohol is very well hidden. Aging this beer is a must.
Truly one of the best.  Chocolate, coffee, vanilla, licorice, and other roasty flavors abound.  Drink one now and forget about the rest for a couple of years.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2010 Bottle. 22 oz. (2008 - White Wax) Gift courtesy of my good friend Vinny. This beastly, epic brew comes sealed in a dripping, candlewax-sealed, shiny bottle with a badass evil lord destroying foes on the label. Pours straight cola, dark chocolate black with a thin, creamy amberish-red head that fades quickly. Aroma of raisins, figs, dates, walnuts, plums, vanilla, chocolate, espresso, barley, roasted malts, toffee, caramel, oat, and hints of coriander and pepper. Heavy, deep body with a rich, velvety-full mouthfeel. Finishes with a slow, insane warming through the throat and entire chest. Alcohol is nearly invisible. This is the best beer I have ever drank in my life. Find this brew and buy it now.

2008 vintage.

Pitch black with a small brown head. The liquid is really viscous.

Huge aromas of roasted malts and dark chocolate. Some dark bread, soy sauce and licorice and molasses. A rich and powerful smell.

This one really fills the whole mouth with flavors. Every sip is like getting hit by a tidal wave. Roasted malts all around, sweet dark chocolate, more sweet toffee, coffee and caramel. Every now and then, a slightly burnt flavor develops. Woody notes. The taste is predominantly sweet. The finish is quite bitter with big notes of well integrated alcohol, salt, hints of licorice and soy sauce, and perhaps some hop notes.

Mouthfeel is off the chart on this one. Ridiculously big body, viscous like old engine oil and smooth beyond belief.

So, what to say about this one, the dark lord, one of the white whales? Well, it¬ís just a great beer. Fantastic mouthfeel, rich and powerful taste, and very complex. However, it¬ís a little on the sweet side, so it¬ís not perfect. But I actually think it manages to live up to it¬ís reputation.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2011 My 600th rating.  22 oz. bottle from DLD 2009, tried three times since then (and the 2008 that day), but this was a 2009 edition opened on January 8, 2010.  Wow, this is every bit as good as I remember.  Pours opaque black and looks like motor oil, with a little bit of brown head forming at the top but not amounting to much.  The aroma is beautiful, and so complex: molasses, chocolate, coffee, vanilla, hops (more than I remember), cherries, plums, roasted nuts, smoked wood, and a dirty, earthy note.  So much to take in.  Somehow the flavor is even better, as good as anything I¬íve ever tasted- rich, robust, complex, and smooth.  It starts with chocolate and coffee, with molasses and vanilla followed by some earthy hops, and finishing with roasted malts, dark fruits (especially cherry and plum), more coffee, and a smokiness reminiscent of a hickory-smoked meat.  The alcohol is perfect in this, warming and complementary.  This is absolutely perfect in the mouth: full-bodied, incredibly smooth, oily, warm, and rich.  Finishes with lingering smoke, roast, hops, and chocolate/vanilla sweetness and a sticky mouthfeel.  This absolutely lives up to the hype and I wish I didn¬ít love the drinking experience so much or I¬íd age a couple bottles.  Hopefully my last two can last without being opened.  Worth a trip up to Munster every year for DLD for the experience and the beer, and not many beers are worth such a trip.
