Big thanks to growler for sharing a bottle of the 2007 vintage. Pours deep black with small brown head. Aromas of chocolate, soy sauce and burnt malts. Flavors are similar to the aromas. This is not as sweet as I was expecting and it is also much smoother. Full body with minimal carbonation and a smooth mouthfeel.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2010 Bottle courtesty of StFun. Black wax. Color...Black as black can get, no head. Aroma of malt and minor hint of coffee. Taste is very malty with a hint of vanilla, roasted grains, and chocolate. No trace of alcohol in the taste. The after taste has a nice little bitterness to it. Thick motor-oil texture. Slick and grainy at the same time. Definitley a well crafted beer, that could use some age, I am sure it would only get better. Good beer but not great. Thanks again josh for standing in line for over 5 hours in the blistering sun, just so I could enjoy this beer. I owe you one!****UPDATE*****Green wax bottle.. Pretty much think the same thing as before.... Oily, slick, just a big roasted chocolate beer.

2008 bottle courtesy Rogueone. Is this an evil enough beer for my 666th rating? Good enough! Pours thick and oily black with a dark tan head. Very thck and coating of the glass. Roasted grain, chocolate and vanilla aroma. Thick chocolate malt taste with lots of roasty grains and vanilla. Thick dark chocolate, bitter aftertaste. Worth the hype.

Bottle from ebay.  Black with a fizzy brown head.  Sweet chocolate and coffee aroma. Tastes of dark chocolate, vanilla, coffee, cinnamon, and alcohol taste.  Excellent.  It takes on a really nice tobacco quality as it warms.  This is really quite a good beer!

22oz bottle from 07. Huge thanks to Growler for bringing this. Massive aroma, with tons of soy sauce and dark chocolate. Cherry and figs figure in. Midnight black pour with a nice dark chocolate head. Taste is incredible and matches the flavor. Tons of soy sauce, vanilla, cherry, chocolate and a bit of caramel. Very complex with a thick oily mouthfeel. This is a remarkable beer.

Draft on tap at the Taste of the Midwest.  Extremely dark and slightly reddish.  Thick and rich with little to no head.  Flavor of dark chocolate, molasses, and dried fruit.  Rich palate with long duration.   Very good.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2011 Wow, it has been a long time coming, 2007 bottle shared generously by footbalm. Pours a pure black body with a medium swirling beige head that goes down quickly to nothing almost. The aroma is full of so much; molasses, berries, coffee, chocolate. Basically this is what Brussels would smell like if the whole city was burning. The flavor was simply amazing; tons of fruit, especially berries initially, chocolates, milk, brown sugar and roasted flavors cover everything. A smooth and dry finish of chocolates and coffee. One of the best mouthfeels ever; smooth and creamy and so very full. I was very surprised by how smooth this was, so drinkable I could drink this at six AM. Let me hope I do someday. Amazing. 2009 vintage at the Imperial Stout tasting in Boise. Very sweet, lots of nice flavors, dark fruit and roasted malts, but too thin and sweet. Still nice, but not as good as my first experience. Another 2009: nice, sweet and rich coffee, roasted malts. Pretty damn good. Re-rate again!: 2006 vintage thanks to Patrick. Five years old. Really nice, no sign of age, sweet, fruity, viscous. Awesome. Much better than the 2009s I had. More complex and nuanced, but in a relative way this is no nuanced brew! Huge and sweet.

Scored  two 22oz bottles of this rarity thanks to a trade with TPaliga.  Thanks Tim!  Popped this 2008 bottle at an imperial stout tasting I held and everyone attending was pumped to sample this.  Looks dangerous, completely opaque black, thick and oily with a creamy tan head.  Aroma of whiskey, wood, and cane sugar with just the slightest touch of citrus.  Flavors of raisins, molasses, toast, maple, salty soy, dark cocoa and perhaps some beets.  Really smooth on the tongue and thick and a little syrupy down the throat.  Definitely worth the hype.
Pours black with a dark brown head.  Wow...chocolate, coffee, smoke, oak.  Amazing....I am struggling with the urge to chug the whole bomber it tastes that good.

The single bottle I could acquire after standing in line for hours and hours.  2008 bottle, split six ways between eagerly anticipating beer nerds.  

This stuff is ridiculous, thickest blackest brew I have come across, delightful aromas of coffee, chocolate, molasses, and "dark fruits".  The taste is similar to the smell, but with pleasant hop presence.  Mouthfeel is thick thick thick.  Amazing brew that lives up to the hype.

I wanted to not like it. I really did. I¬ím so very very sorry to disappoint the snooty snoots who¬íd like to de-hype this beer, but...

it lives up. 

If what you¬íre expecting is the most intense RIS you could imagine. 

If you get one, give it a nice aggressive pour or you¬íll miss out on one of the most beautiful shows you¬íll ever see in a glass. The way the had burrows down into the beer is the most amazing trick I¬íve ever seen a beer do, and it lasted a good 2 minutes. 

Yeah, you smell that? Tons of dark fruits, coffee, vanilla chocolate, the aroma of this beer is as complex as an Belgian monk-brew I¬íve ever had. And the taste matches completely. 

No, you¬íre not going to want to pound back a couple of six packs of this shit. that¬ís not what it¬ís about, despite what the 3rd-grader (yeah, I love it) bottle art might suggest. This is a sipper. The head lasted forever and the flavor just kept developing. God, I¬ím looking forward to my other bottles.

A privilege to sit in Copenhagen and taste this monster-hyped dark creature. thx Mikkel.
Bottle 75 cl. Silver waxed - 2007 version
Pours all black with a huge dark and fluffy brown head - perfect. Aroma - Dark chockolate, brown sugar, orange and alcohol.
The palate is penetratingly, heavy and very smooth and oily.
The taste is sweet sweet sweet and rather hoppy, vinoes and salty. I taste Coffee italian style, laquirice, alcohol, ashes burnes nuts and tobacco together with dryed fruits like raisins and plums.
The finish is very sweet and bitter - a bit like an Underberg exept the spirit.
Beware: It leaves you some sticky lips.
Too me this one is a bit too much. It is too sweet and I would never be able too drink much more than a glass of this black monster....even though I normally love heavy imperial stouts....

2008 Bottle @ Dutch Ratebeer Session. Aroma has pure dark chocolate, cherries, vanilla, roast, some coffee, molasses, plums, port... Much there. Pitch black coloured with a lasting, beige head. Taste is sweet, has burned sugar, chocolate, some coffee, cherry fruitiness. Creamy and thick mouthfeel. Very intense. Superb brew.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2009 A big thanks to Emily (my girlfriend), waited in line for hours to get this beer for me.  This one lives up to the hype.  There¬ís so much going on here!  Sweetness, molasses, chocolate, vanilla, coffee, roastiness, and sooooo smooth.  was not disappointed at all.
Bottled, black wax. Black color, short brown head. Chocolat aroma, burnt sugar, molasses, coffee. D-licious.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2010 ¬í08 bottle. Pours oily black with small tan head. Nose fills room with alcohol, raisins, and sweet, tarry malts, then chocolate and vanilla, and then some coffee. Flavor is huge and sweet, with chocolate, raisins, and coffee as the main components, the Lord¬ís alcoholic furnace burning fiercely behind them. The palate is slick, dry, and massive, filling your mouth and sticking to your lips, but it¬ís so damned oppressive that your mouth just has to give in and take the beating. Dark Lord is a malt monster.¬í07-¬í10 blind vertical showed what I feared: a lot worse than memory. I¬íd planned a detailed review of each, but too many Imperial Stouts before this vertical killed my motivation. There was heavy sugar and booze in all cases considered, those still with considerable flavor were overly sweet. The ¬í08 and ¬í10 were sweetest at this point, and at the same time, the best given that they still had something to offer. The ¬í09 is depleted and empty, adding to its reputation as a mistake. The ¬í07 was easily detected due to heavy oxidation. I was pretty drunk and still couldn¬ít finish my four 3-4oz samples.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2009 2008 bottle from Solan, tasted at the DTS in Bunnik. Almost black and opague. Creamy dark chocolate aroma with Kahlua liquor. Thick syrupy malt soup with dark chocolate, coffee, toffee, plums and port. Hint of maraschino cherries. Hint of salt. Sweet but complex and divine brew.

2007 bottle @ EBF 2008. Licorice, roast, cream and maple syrup in the aroma. Creamy, velvety flavor with roast, licorice, lots of chocolate, raisin and plums. Still a good complexity,but more alcoholic as the fresh 2008 version.
(9 4 8 4 16 = 4.1)

2009 bottle, tasted @ RBESG Grand Tasting 2009. Black and opague. Thick viscous, very sweet flavor with mago, malt sugars, overpowering all roasted flavors. Grapes and molasses in the aroma. Very young, still needs a lot of time to develop. (7 4 8 3 16 = 3.8)

Dutch tasting session Bunnik. Bottled. Opaque, brown head. Very complex nose, malts, chocolate, coffee. Initially sweet, but the complex flavour develops to be more bitter towards the end. Thick mouthfeel. Very good.

Bottle of 2007!  I hope this lives up to the hype and the price I paid on ebay!  Pours a brownish-black fluid with a dark tan, coffee-like, head that grows out of the bowels of the beer.  The Dark Lord rising from the bowels of hell?  Methinks so!  The aroma is very strong of fermented raisins, sugar, port, sweet chocolate with touches of black licorice and coffee roastiness.  The mouthfeel is unlike ANYTHING I have ever had!!!  It clings to the side of your mouth like whole milk would but with a little more guts like I was drinking motor oil.  Un-f---ing-believable!  It is almost like syrup.  There is little to no carbonation.  The flavor is highly complex with notes of currants, port wine, molasses, black licorice with hints of coffee and a burnt quality.  Add a sweet underlying flavor (tempation itself), and you get a somewhat sad description of a beer that is indescribable!  Adding to the reaper list: Go to Dark Lord Day!!

2008 - Just getting around to rating this!  Out of 05-08, this is one of my favorites.  This is called Dark Lord for a reason-- it pours black as oil and it does have sort of a demonic, syrupy presence.  Aroma tickles the nostrils with alcohol, molasses, dark fruit, and tobacco.  Flavor coats the palate with deeply roasted and lingering chocolate malt, coffee, vanilla, and a complex sweetness that is simply one of a kind.
user_location: I F&ckin¬í hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text:
Have just run through a three year vertical 06-08 and none will dissapoint. Good thing we took notes! The 07 was midnight dark, looks almost black. Pour slow and extremely aromatic with pronounced tones of everything dark in grain, molasses,and malt. This beer is got allot going on especially present when it‚Äôs temperature gets to 20+ C. Becomes  pretty boozy and the caramel, coffee tones are more pronounced. 
This beer is a big home run in the Imperial Stout world and will not disappoint even the most discerning critic.

Bar none, this is the best brew I‚Äôve ever had. This is my third bottle from the 2008 release and every time I open one i can‚Äôt believe what I‚Äôm drinking. The part that sold me on this is the viscosity/mouthfeel of the beer. It‚Äôs unbelievable. Nothing more needs to be said about this beer, its ranking speaks for itself...and yes it‚Äôs the real deal. In my book, this is the #1 beer in the world.
leaves a nice ring of sediment at the bottom of the glass.  tastes of chocolate mocha with a hint of campfire cooked cherries.  This is the fourth beer i have had from three floyds.  My first rating!

Courtesy of Tony @ OTH.
Silver wax. Pours pitch black, very thick.
Aroma is of molasses and touch of coffee malts. This beer is up there with the best of Imperial Stouts. Too bad it is so hard to get.

Thanks to Thomas. Motor Oil. Coffee. Wine. Very intense stout. The only other I can think of that compares is Bell‚Äôs Expedition. The thick pour. No head. Massive flavor. Excellent. Waited a long time for this one. Tasted during recent Indiana trip.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2008 2008 vintage:  I had one of these earlier but didn¬ít get around to rating it.  I figured I would relax with another one for rating #100.  Pours like the used motor oil I just poured from my car.  Aroma is roasted malt, some sweetness of caramel and vanilla.  Flavor is coffee, vanilla and a nice sweet finish that isn¬ít  bitter or too sweet.  This beer is one of my favorites along with speedway and black albert.  I guess I¬íll be sitting on the rest of em¬í and see how they hold up with a year or three.

Bottled: Traveled a long way for this legendary beer! Pours a black oil color with a syrup texture. Hits the nose with roasted chocolate and coffee. The flavor blasts into your mouth and palate with a huge blast of vanilla and other delicious flavors that stay after the beer is finished. The overall impression of this beer is one that will last forever. Wasnt able to be at Dark Lord Day but met a new friend at Three Floyds and he hooked me up with it. Thanks Mark for this amazing beer!!!!

2008 Bottle, made its way all the way to NC on a long road trip thanks to TikiE.  Pours slow and thick, almost oil.  Color is solid black, with a dark brown head.  good lacing with a smooth body.  Flavor is at first sweet vanilla, then chocolate and a finish of roast coffee, very distinct.  Smooth as hell, this is one of my favorite Impy Stouts.
2007 vintage off Ebay. Dark, roasty malts, coffe, chocolate, and a lot of yeasty sludge. Not impressed for what its supposed to be. The balance just isnt there for me.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2009 sampled with the phoenix crew. big thanks to rustychiles for the two bottles...

2007 silver wax. pours a viscous brown shade of black with no head. this brew stains the inside of the snifter! aromas of chocolate, dark fruit/prunes/black raisins, vanilla, scorch, heavily roasted grains and molasses... smells an awful lot like a baltic porter should! very dark tasting... lots of grain, ash, licorice, tar, prunes and a touch of umami. just dreadfully sweet. tastes a whole lot like an imperial baltic porter?! beyond full bodied. thick, chewy and coats the tongue... (high score given because it resembles a baltic... my favorite style!)...8/4/6/2/13/3.3

 2008 black wax. viscous blackish pour with some orange highlights in the thin brown head. smells kinda like sam adams triple bock only it doesn¬ít make me want to vomit... maple wood smoke, soy, bacon, maple syrup, chocolate and all around sludge. really sweet on the palate to the point my teeth hurt. flavors of vanilla, chocolate, salt, booze and lots of cloying residual/sugars/molasses. hot finish. heavy body with a cloying thick mouth feel... 8/4/5/2/12=3.1

 orange 2005 bottle via footy sampled in 2009 at bill and wendy¬ís. viscous (i¬ím seeing a trend) burgundy black with no head. the nose has some baltic qualities... licorice, molasses and malt powder followed by chocolate, roast and a heap of floral alcohol. the palate is chokingly thick, rich and still way too sweet. ashiness is noted along with the aroma characteristics. cloying and hard to drink....7/4/5/2/12/3.0

gold 2006 sampled next to 2005 in 2009 at bill and wendy¬ís. pours evil with cold maple syrup consistency (even thicker than the 05). it smells and tastes like a rotting grain silo... thick and gross. 5/4/4/2/12/2.7

08 Bottle.   Pours an oily midnight black color with a thin dark brown head.   Aroma is vanilla, chocolate, roast, burnt sugar.   Flavor is chocolate, vanillam burnt sugars, roast, molasses.   Palate is ultra full bodied, almost non-existant carbonation, finished silky smooth.   Wow, whatta mouthfull.   Great stuff.
¬í08 Bomber. Simply put if you haven¬ít tried it, you need to. If you are looking for a great RIS this has it all, the thickest most complex best RIS you may ever taste.

Bottle and WOW.  This is the boldest and thickest beer I have ever had.  Wow again.  Aromas of coffee, chocolate, booze, molasses, and heaven.  Flavors of molasses, coffee, toasted and roasted grains, and raisins.  Yes indeed this lives up to the hype.  Certainly does.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2012 Nice brown sugar, molasses, and chocolate aroma that pours out of the bottle before the liquid.  Appearance is a shade past midnight with the darkest burnt caramel head I¬íve ever seen.  Dense meringue-like foam.  Thick, oily consistency that stuck to the roof of your mouth and easily coated the palate.  You¬íll need a chisel to remove the flavor.  Along with the pleasant bitter chocolate, cocoa, coffee and licorice, there is a noticeable soy presence.  A very tasty beer but definitely doesn¬ít stack up to the best of the style.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2012 rerate 2012 bottle.  One of the sweetest beers I¬íve ever tasted.  It would go well on pancakes, but that¬ís about it.  Actually hard to finish more than 6 oz of this one.  It had no real coffee, hop, or roast flavors at all.  Just sugar, some chocolate nesquik, and alcohol.  Every single year this beer gets progressively worse.  I¬ím letting the rest of these age for a decade or so and will then rerate.  But for now, I¬ím going to go take an insulin shot.   


[rerate 2011] I have to keep dropping this one down every time I drink it.  2009 and 2010 bottles are cloyingly sweet and less complex than 2008.  It seems to be on a steady decline.   
2008 Bottle.  Everything about this beer is overly intense yet it all seems to work together.  Pours like a liquid black hole.  The aroma is inviting but frightening at the same time. It has a simply amazing syrup-like  consistency.  The most astonishing thing about the beer is how smooth it is considering the strength. As stated below, it will make other "strong" beers taste like spring water.

Pours like used motoroil with a micrometer of brown head so don¬ít worry about overflow.  Consistency of warm syrup.  Coffee, chocolate, molasses, figs, smoke, etc.  This beer will destroy your taste for other stouts so don¬ít rate other stouts immediately after drinking this.
UPDATED: SEP 8, 2015 This beer scares me.  I am terrified right now.  I need to call my mom and have her talk me down.

22oz [email¬†protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */#1-pours a dissipating brown head with nice lacing film and black color.  Aroma is roasty smoke, dark malt-anise.  Taste is roasty smoke, dark malt-anise, some acidic.  Syrupy, smooth.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2009 Sampled at Hellbilly¬ís Hellraiser II.  Bottle of ¬í07 and ¬í08 side by side.  Both pour a thick black with a ring of brown head slowly rising to the top.  The ¬í07 was molasses, soy and salt.  Really not enjoyable.  The ¬í08 did have some redeeming qualities.  Notes of roasted coffee, dark chocolate, molasses, vanilla and dark fruits.  Still a bit of the soy coming through, but not in an overpowering way.  Thick oily palate and a long bitter finish.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2009 Ok, finally got around to trying the plain old version.  Black as night, thick, blah blah blah.  You get it.  Flavor was, molasses, vanilla, some cherry, slight coffee, big wall of flavor that came together very well.  I liked the way the flavors melded and then the great lasting finish.  Doesn¬ít quite dethrone expy, but a great beer none the less.    Too much hype? who knows, but darn tasty.

Ok, re-rate here.  Had an 09¬í bottle of this on friday night.  Big thanks to whoever brought it.  Poured mostly black with a little light coming through.  Aroma was lots of soy, some chocolate, and some coffee.  Taste was lots of soy, way too much and the body seemed a bit thin.  Not sure what happened here but I am going to have to bring my scores way down.  Seemed a bit thin and like it was past it¬ís prime.  Not what I expected for dark lord just six months old.

22 oz. bomber 2008 black wax picked up at dark lord day. All the hype,All the forum talk, the sludge,thier overated,jealosy my brothes,malicous slander no sludge just jealosy,over the second best brewery in the f...ing whole world according to this site.shared bottle with undeserving friends they loved it ,we followed this with goose island bourbon county stout followed by new hollands dragon milk and three floyds behemoth barley wine i¬íd say a preety good night. poured black as coal with thick small with lots of lacing thick like a heavy chocolate milkflavors of chocolate wood expresso  so complex i can¬ít even begin to explian so i¬íll have to re rate it on my next bottle i do have 3 left my ending thought real men drink stout. the guy in chicago has spoken

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2009 2008 bomber Thanks to Todd for this one.  Pitch black viscous pour that leaves a molasses like stain in the glass!  Very nice!  Smokey Espresso on the nose.  Big and malty smoke, wood, chocolate, dark fruit, and a hint of hops.  I was expecting a little hops on a bottle this fresh.

2008 bomber thanks a million drewbeerme! Finally got my chance to drink this overhyped bad boy. Really not as impressed as expected. Too much going on in this beer and the bitter finish doesn¬ít help either.  Powerful chocolate aroma. Thick black appearance. This is SO thick, thicker motor oil. Whoa! The flavor is intense! Heavily smoked, woody, chocolately, and full of coffee notes, some figs and dates too, adding to this complex mixture. Very nice, but it does get a bit much. Like KBS and Goose Island Bourbon Stout better.

completely well done such an amazing complex beer swet malty goodness mixed with slightvfruit  and mollassess balanced with the right amount of hops so flippin good i want more perfect for the style
thanks mcbackus

Sampled at Hellbilly¬ís Hellraiser II.  Two bottle vertical (2007 and 2008) courtesy of Rustychiles.  Both versions poured pitch black with minimal to no head.  2007: Nose is alcohol, salty soy and smoky bacon.  Palate is salty soy sauce, molasses and brown sugar.  2008: Nose is vanilla, chocolate and alcohol.  Palate has that soy taste but not as strong as the ¬í07.  Brown sugar, coffee and a touch of hop bite in the finish.  Amazing what a year of aging does to this brew.  Thanks for the opportunity Rusty!

Sampled at Hellbillys Hellraiser II.

Pours a thick viscous black with a medium sized rich brown head. 

Aroma of coffee, roasted barley, brown sugar. 

Flavor is molasses, coffee, powdered cocoa, burnt barley.

A pretty good Imperial stout, but does not live up to the hype.

bottle 2007 from decatursteveo: pours oily black very dark with no head. aroma is fantastic chocoalte great dep dark roast, the aroma is just fantastic. flavour is huge, great coffee roast some chocoalte the malts in the background are also just awesome. the finish is thick and great. i can see why so many people like this one.
Bottle of the 2007.  This stuff is like syrup.  Super thick, super rich.  Chocolate and a little espresso.  Ridiculous and over the top.

2007 bottle.  As I watched this beer pour into my glass, I knew this was something unique.  Dark inky brown black pour that was almost disturbingly thick with only a trace of a dark brown head.  Intense chocolate and coffee aromas with a pleasant malty sweetness.  Flavor is a superb balance of black coffee and semi-sweet chocolate that warms the palate like a thin coffee flavored syrup.  The thickness and body combined with its smooth malty and somewhat bitter finish complete the total experience that is Dark Lord.  A unique beer that was as entertaining as it was delicious.

At long last the Lord has entered my life; the Dark Lord, that is. MrFacto brought a bottle of the 2008 to the Carolina crew gathering and boy was I stoked to try it out. Sludgy motor oil pour, a devilish looking concoction with a jolting coffee nose that was just the ticket at this point in the evening. Viscous and bitter, with not just roasted malts pounding away at the palate but also some anise, mild vegetal flavors (Bells 7K-ish), and some bitter chocolate in there too. So good that Turd and Blackie and I had to go out and toss the frisbee in the midnight air. I¬ím not sure, given all the factors involved (like price and rarity), that it¬ís necessarily better than, say, Expedition. But it¬ís a helluva beer, and I thank you, Matt.

2007 bottle courtesy of Quake1028 and 2008 bottle courtesy of tpd975. Both bottles pour an oily black with a one finger tan head that fades. Upon swirling the glass the beer coates the side of the glass with a tint of orange. 07 - Aroma is roasted malt, licorice, coffee, dark fruit, and a hint of alcohol. Taste is dark fruit, roasted malt, coffee, licorice, and caramel. Full oily mouthfeel with a moderate amount of bitterness and well hidden alcohol. 08 - Aroma of roasted malt, smoke, coffee, licorice, and dark fruit. Taste is the same as aroma but more prominent. Full oily mouthfeel with a moderate amount of bitterness and well hidden alcohol. The 07 bottle was a smoother and more well balanced but the 08 will smooth out and be just as good in a year. Damn good brew.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2011 2008 version.  Black no head.  Nose is bit stale. Taste is very sweet, some chocolate, still a bit hot.  Good. Thanks to MaltOMeal for this silver 07 bottle. My first taste of this trade demon. Stone cold black with no head. Nose is alcoholy, soy, chocolates. Taste of chocolates, cough syrup, dates, thickness, molasses,  and completely different than any other beer I¬íve ever had. I¬ím not sure I can rate this properly on one tasting so someone send me another.This is why they stand in line.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Thanks to Skyview for sharing two ¬í08 bottles!! The beer was opaque black with motor oil viscosity, oily legs, and thin brown foam. In the aroma I got coffee, sweet chocolate, alcohol, and faint dark fruit. In the flavor I mostly got burnt malt, some sweet molasses, and maybe a faint hint of oak. The alcohol was hidden. Burnt malt finish. Palate-wise it was VERY thick and even a little gritty. The empty cups looked like we drank chocolate metamucil! Thanks again Skyview!

From a 22-oz bomber, shared during Cellar¬ís Wine & Spirits¬í Wednesday evening beer tasting in St Paul, Minnesota, this pours a thick dark brown motor oil texture beer with a thin tan head that really stick to the glass. Aroma is complex with so many scents including raisin, dark pitted fruits, molasses, chocolate, coffee and some white pepper. Flavor is thick and fork-wise chewy with no carbonation and has flavors of molasses, raisin, dark chocolate, toffee, vanilla and caramel. Finish is thick and syrupy with a mild bitterness and a lingering molasses and raisin aftertaste. Five hours in line for this? A little over-hyped but still memorable for rate # 2400.

[Bottle ¬í08, huge thanks go to Skyview for bringing this back!] Pours black with a dark tan head--really nice appearance, even if it does leave kind of a sludge on the side of the glass when you swirl it. Aroma is chocolate, light raisin, caramel and a little vanilla. Taste is somewhat sweet, I imagine from the molasses, with light hops, a bit of peppery spice and a fairly harsh roasted malt. Ridiculously thick mouthfeel--thickest I have ever seen. I love a really thick beer, and I¬ím giving the palate a 5, but this is almost too thick. Overall, this beer was good, but not spectacular. The memorable thing about it is the syrupy mouthfeel, which I think I could grow to dislike with a larger sample.

Vintage 2007- Beautiful coloring, a rich dark brown/black. No carbonation at all. Heavy nose of whiskey and coffee. This stuff is THICK. I really didn¬ít enjoy the taste of this vintage, the whiskey character was completely overwhelming to me especially coupled with the viscosity of the brew.

Thanks to MaltOMeal for this silver 07 bottle. Super dark black with no head. Nose of soy sauce and rich dark chocolate. Flavor was very rich dark chocolate and drank like it was 10W-40. This is the thickest beer I¬íve ever had the pleasure of drinking. Didn¬ít know if I should drink it or chew it. Wonderful. Thanks Bill!

the great stout shoot out was finished with a blind test. i gave this beer #3 for the eve.. i will adjust the scores but leave the writing of the first taste.

*did not mind. would pay part of the cost for at least a year old bottle, i hate aging.*

aroma: booze, soy earthy hints of sweet booze vanilla and expenisive bottling.  app: thin brown blood.  Flavor: needs age! boy. all that work and money to get one of these bottles and then! you gotta let it sit for a couple years before its yummy. I think this would make a grand meatloaf marinade.  Palate: thin flat OA: over the top? needs age and balance. let us not forget good culinary concepts when making or brewing beer. this is rich and huge and out of balance. suppose a chef served you a cup of soy sauce, a bowl of cocoa powder a a shot of everclear.. what a good meal.. or not. I would rather have a fine wine and a good desert.

Sampled at Sean and Ryan¬ís tasting, 2008 vintage. Deep black with a small tan head. Rich sweet aroma of malt, brandy, and chocolate. Huge taste of toasted malt, brandy and cognac, coffee, molasses. Lingering toasty bitterness. Fantastic imperial stout.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2009 2005 bottle many thanks to footbalm.  This really is an amazing brew.  Pours a deep black, no light can get through.  Appearance of black oily tar.  Medium dark tan frothy head.  In my opinion the biggest down side to this beer (in fact the only down side) was the aroma.  It was very hot, yes there was chocolate, raisin, cherry and roasted malt in the nose, but there was a large overwhelming presence of alcohol.  Flavors where very complex.. dark chocolate, sweet cherries, vanilla, roasted malt, a bit of smoke, coffee, molasses, oak, toffee, raisin, and dark fruit.  Also notes of hops in the flavor profile.  This imp stout packs a large punch.  The mouth feel is extremely thick, oily, and mouth coating.  The finish lasts and lasts. One sip and you get a huge amount of flavor and it doesn¬ít quit.  I would love to try this again if I can get a hold of it.  This is my #600.

2007 bottle thanks to drmatt.  I¬íd been holding onto this a few months and finally got the guys together to share this bad boy.  This poured dark as pitch with no head.  Aroma was not great.  Soy maybe?  The taste though was all I ever could have wanted and expected from an Imperial Stout.  This was sweet with chocolate and molasses, but not cloying.  Flavors kept coming at you.  What a complex brew!  Mouthfeel was thick and so wonderful it was like my mouth was having an orgasm!

Ok, I¬ím supposed to tell you how great this beer is. But I can¬ít, because I don¬ít like it. Surely, it¬ís an amazing product. A rich malt syrup packed full of chocolate, alcohol, roasted malt, brown sugar and molasses. It tastes expensive¬Öand, to me at least, not good. I just don¬ít enjoy drinking it. It takes effort to sip this sludge. True enough, I don¬ít care for Imperial Stouts in general, and some will argue I should rate this on style guide lines alone. But nobody here does. If people did, macro American swill would have higher ratings and the Imp Stouts wouldn¬ít dominate the top ten list. It pours jet black, with small tan head. Looks nice. Smells of rich leathery choco-malt. The problem is that it also tastes like high concentrate rich leathery choco-malt.  I must point out I drank this young, the 2008.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2009 08 bottle with huge thanks to lb4lb for hooking me up with this beer, I owe you man.  Franksnbeans talked me into opening this...why the hell not?  Poured a thick black color with a slight tan head that slowly receded to a layer but left some light, spotty lacing.  Nice, strong aroma of roasted malt, coffee, light chocolate, light tobacco, and a nice dark fruit presence.  Sweet, malty entry with strong chocolate and molasses and undertones of roasted coffee, nice sweet dark fruit presence (mainly plum, light raisin, a hint of berry) leading into a moderately bitter, dry finish with undertones of roasted coffee and light fruity sweetness.  Solid mouthfeel, not quite as thick as I anticipated, but it still coats the mouth nicely.  Very nice beer, I can¬ít thank you enough for hooking me up Deniz, you are the man.

multiple samples from different years.  Figured I might as well rate the fresh sample,  so this is for the 08.  Pour pours black with a thin tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, coffee,  and a bit of cherry.  Flavor is up front coffee,  chocolate,  molasses,  caramel,  toffee.  Very viscous.  This clings to every part of my mouth.  A bit of hop bitterness,  some hint of the abv.  A very nice beer,  worthy of the praise it gets.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2008 2008 DL. Blows me away every time. So much on my palate. Interesting lacing, yellow fingers like wine, more a skin then fingers.  Zero head. Nose of dates, raisons, toffee, chocolate. Flavors blew up my palate, coffee, tart, dark fruits, Balanced carbonation. The VB and Oaked versions are much more balanced, this one is a bit more of a coffee/chocolate bomb. Need to age for a few years.

2008 bottle.  Didn¬ít expect this one to be as good as it was.  One of the few top ten beers worthy of it¬ís rating.  Smells of faint quality coffee, tart cherries, chocolate, very sweet, vanilla. Wonderful mouthfeel, thick as shit.  Taste is wonderful too.  A huge beer with great balance between all the flavors, with some great hop characters.

2007 vintage with silver wax. Big thanks for Tim (theisti) for bringing this to Iceland! Jet fuel black, almost thich looking. Big dark lacing inside the glass, the biggest I¬¥ve seen since sam adams triple bock. Aroma is coffee-ish, some obvious espresso beans, massive smoke, hops. Very complex flavor. coffee, chocolate, meat, garlic (?), tiny hints of fruit, massive massive sweetness. This is one great brew

2007 sampled at Oldsmar Tap House.  (Thanks Tony!)  What a treat.  An incredible brew with flavors of mollases and caramel. Black as night with only a slight head-almost uncarbonated.  Smooth and delicious.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2008 This is as good as it gets #700 and i am glad to be able to do it, a dark as night pour and a vicious and thick beer very enjoyable and another great beer from Nick and the guys.I have been drinking this since 2003 when it was sold in growlers and it has gotten better each year.CHEERS!!

A synopsis of all the vintages I¬íve had: 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2008.  I¬íve even had this side-by-side with some of the top imperial stouts out there: Kaggen, Expedition, Old Raspy, etc.  Is it overhyped?  Yes.  Are their better, or equal, imperial stouts out there?  Yes.  Is this still a damn good Imperial stout?  Oh yes!

In every year of this beer the hallmark is always the same.  It is an aggressive and in-your-face style of brew.  Complexity?  Not at all.  A mellow and deeply contemplative style of brew?  LOL, far from that.  No, what this beer sells is evident on its label.  It does one thing and one thing very well.  To crush your enemies, see them driven before you, and to hear the lamentation of the women?  Not quite.  Rather, it presents a huge singular flavor that dominates its entire profile.  A gigantic tsunami of viscosity paired with a forceful rush of sweet dates, raisons and dark fruit.  This signature profile is evident in every year of this beer.  Sure there¬ís variances in the product: the turkish coffee/thicker-than-used-motor-oil of the 2004 or the slightly thinner and green apple flavours of the 2006.  However, dispite the variances they all display that one common characteristic that keeps stouties coming back for more.

2007 vintage as gleaned from Theisti¬ís rating (oh, and now I notice the wax code: ours was definetely grey). One of the beers he generously carried across a continent and half an ocean to bring me and Haukur.

Aroma of smoked lamb! Multi-layered flavour; alcohol, dark fruit, but only a little, coffee, dark chocolate, smoked meat... I¬ím at loss for words. Just try and get some. Hijack planes and demand Dark Lord in exchange for hostages. It¬ís worth it.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2010 ++++ Re Rate 17 September 2010 ++++
White wax 2009 Vintage courtesy of tjthresh.  Pour is all black, with a khaki head.  As in times past, nice looking beer.  Aroma is some roast, then a blast of cane sugary sweetness, and  soy.  Taste is mostly sugar sweetness and soy, hardly any roast behind.   Palate is full bodied, mouth coating with a lingering sweet finish.  Still really no evidence of alcohol. (7,5,7,3,14 - 3.6)

++++ Re Rate 27 March 2010 ++++
Black wax 2008 Vintage courtesy of Gregis.  Pour is all black, with a nice khaki head.  Very pretty beer.  Aroma is some roast, but mostly bright cane sugary sweetness, and a little bit of soy.  This really had none of the soft complexity I remember, just a big sweet bomb. Taste is more of the nose, though thankfully somewhat softened.  The taste is mostly sugar sweetness and soy, a whisper of roast under that.  Palate is medium to full bodied, mouth coating with a lingering sweet finish.  Still really no evidence of alcohol.  This was just a really normal sweet imperial stout this time around, and was a lot less enjoyable. (6,5,7,4,14 - 3.6)

++++ Original Rating 9 May 2008 ++++
2007 Vintage. 22 oz. bottle from poolboy, shared with haukur and Kalli at haukur¬ís tasting on 1 May 2008.  Pour is all black, with not much of an off white head.  Aroma of smoked meat, espresso coffee roast and very present pine hoppiness.  Taste is big on the roast, big coffee espresso.  More of the smoked meatiness, molasses, syrup, pine hoppiness.  Some slight soy, some slight milkiness.  Finish is huge, and very lasting.  Spicy aftertaste, almost a leafiness to it.  Incredibly dense and mouth coating.  Taste is everything I want an Imperial Stout to be.  This is a beautiful beer. (8,4,9,5,18 - 4.4)

I¬íll split the difference and go with the rating (7,5,8,4,16 - 4.0)

Draft at DLD08. Jet black with no head and thick as oil. Perfect. Nice sweet aroma. The taste is all over the place. Very complex and very enjoyable. Near impossible to beat. Actually like this more than the oaked.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2009 [08 Bottle - fresh for later comparison - rated 5.7.2008] Pours thick black, a tint of brown, and small brown head, velvety.  The aroma screams complexity coffee, molasses, alcohol, varnish,  bitter dark chocolate.   Wow is that thick and chunky!  Its like Hershey¬ís syrup in the mouth.  I have no idea what to make of this body... nearly set pudding.  First taste is coffee and bitter chocolate, quickly overwhelmed by the rich extremely sweet Swiss chocolate flavor, with hints of raisins / dark fruits, burnt wood and caramel.  Finishes a little bit hot, but the sweetness really takes care of that, licorice / dark chocolate aftertaste, strangely tannic.   A brown sticky ring is forming around my lips.  All I can think of is Augustus Gloop.   
. . . . . . . . . . . . . . .. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
[07 Bottle courtesy of Davinci 6/13/08 - ]  Awesome!!! what a difference a year makes!   notes to follow...9.4.9.5.18
. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
[rating is a combination of both bottles. ] 
. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

[08 bottle tried march 2009]  - cardboard... bleh . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

[09 draft DLD April 09] - green banana, thinner than usual, less hoppy, okay, banana chocolate milkshake . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
[08 bottle tried September 09]  -  soy sauce . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 
[09 bottled tried November 09] - not terrible, a bit oxidized, cardboard

2007 draft version at ¬í08 DLD. Served appropriately in a plastic dixie cup. Black with a brown head. Nice aroma is sweet black raisons, dates. Smooth, medium/full body. Big, sweet vinous flavors of raisons, dates, and earthy molasses. In fact, this beer was very sweet, after about two sips i thought about checking my blood glucose level. Surely the barkeep must have mistakenly dropped some sugar cubes into my cup. I still have a bottle from 2005, hope it¬ís not this sweet.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Had 05,06, and 07 at DLD 08. Pours black with small tan head. Has the consistensyof motor oil. Aroma of Burnt malts, hops, vanilla, molasses and coffee. Flavor is hops, coffee, molasses with notes of vinilla and caramel. Just an awesome brew. I actually think I liked 07 the best of the 3 follwed by 06 and 05. I cant wait to try the 08 but will let it age a bit. Thanks to Rooftoprogue for bringing these awesome brews.

At Atlanta tasting. Pours a dark brown to black and very viscous.   pungent aroma of hops and very seet molasses and coffee.  Thick and sweet flavor again sweet coffee and caramel with some light spicing.  Great beer.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2008 Pours a beautiful deep black color with a constancy of 10W40.  The small tan head quickly dissipates.  Below average lacing and below average carbonation with a smell of sweet roasted dark malts, coffee and vanilla. Tastes of strong coffee, sweet roasted malts, coffee, vanilla, and toffee.  Very complex. Very tasty - This is WORLD CLASS.  Drink and Enjoy!

GA-VA-CA-NY-IN meetup, minus golubj.  22 oz. bottle shared with kleyland.  2008 vintage.  Pours a midnight black.  Very thick coming out of the bottle.  Light brown head dissapates quickly.  Aroma of coffee, licorice, warming alcohol.  Flavor is sweet initially.  Roasted notes, chocolate, light alcohol.  Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy.  Bitter finish lingers for quite some time.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2009 Pours dark oily black. It is extremely thick and full bodied. It¬ís appearance is as motor oil dark as it gets. Loads of chocolate, coffee, dark fruits, molasses, vanilla, some alcohol.  I was lucky enough to get some at Dark Lord Day ¬í08 and it was a fantastic event capped off with this tasty treat of a beer. Very nice Imperial Stout.

this beer poured a thick black substance with little head, but who cares? i have never seen a beer pour so thick and glug out of the bottle.

the smell is exceptional. the smell is of molasses, chocolate, toffee, raisins, dates & other pitted fruits. i¬ím not certain it gets better than this.

the taste is wonderful and consistant with the smell. ultra complex and a bit smokey tasting. little alcohol is present at first, but it settles in quite nicely. 

the mouthfeel is thick, oily, full, & sticky.

as a side note, i have also never seen a beer cling to the side of the glass like this one does. by the time i finished the beer, the entire inside of my glass was coated with a thick molasses like substance that i completely feel like i cold have scraped off and shoved down in a pipe and smoked.

I went to Dark Lord day for the first time and was not disappointed! It smell perfect, it looks perfect, it tastes by far better than anything I¬íve had in this country. It lays on my tounge like chocolaty goodness. I had high expectations for this beer and they were met!

I¬íve tried this gem twice - Once @ the Indiana Microbrewers Fest (July ¬í07) on tap (which is the only other time I¬íve heard of it being available), I figure that this was probably an ¬í07.  It was awesome then and it was awesome @ DLD ¬í08.  When I tried it @ the Microbrewers Fest, I felt it was over shadowed by the Kentucky Breakfast - which is great in bottles but SUPERB from a keg.  Now that I try this again and with a little age on it - its really starting to contend.  It¬ís black as midnight, oily-thick and stains the glass like it was just used to funnel your long overdue oil change or watered-down molasses.  I didn¬ít get much head on my pour, would¬íve liked that.  It smells like chocolate, coffee, vanilla,  hops, and just the slightest hint of alcohol (which isn¬ít bad for 13%).  Taste is quite the same as the smell but with some caramel, roasted and burnt black patent malts, molasses, and a tiny alcoholic bite at the end.  The whole taste starts off sticky and sweet (like Expedition) but then it moves toward bitterness from the roasted and burnt malts and hops - and then finally to the alcohol.  Overall, really, really excellent - worth the trip - but I don¬ít know about the wait!
Outstanding.  This is a classic example of why imperial stouts are at the top of my list.  DLD was a blast as well.

2007 on tap at FFF.  Deepest Darkest brown with a slight foamy brown head, that swirled  nicely down to the bottom of the small round "goblet."  Silky smooth mouthfeel.  Roasted coffee and some alcohol in the nose.  A complex mixture of malt tones ranging from vanilla to coffee, with some nuts and a little fruitiness in the middle.  Smooth drinking.  The 13% does not even begin to bite.  My only complaint is that it¬ís served in such a small glass will have to get back there on DLD sometime to get a proper bottle¬ís worth.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2011 2008 out of the bottle, got it at DLD 2008. Thick n sticky, though nowhere near the bourbon barrel aged version. Very sweet at first and then that strong bite of bitterness comes in. Finishes off sweet with some caramel and dark chocolate. A little too bitter for me at times, though i¬ím proud to say this is my FIRST experience with an Imperial stout. I am not sure it lived up to the hype, but nevertheless an amazing experience. Definitely top 5 beers but i¬ím not ready to say it¬ís the best. Everything is here, but the flavor just does not live up.

2007 bottle from SpringsLicker. Thanks Jay! Pours a viscous black with a dark brown head that goes away quickly. Looks like motor oil. Aroma is vinous with notes of dark fruit, cherries, coffee, molasses, chocolate, burnt malts. It is a very nice aroma. Tastes complex, but close to the aroma. Sweet ripe fruits combined with chocolate, molasses, roasted and burnt malts, some alcohol, wood, earth. A little bitterness comes through in a dry roast and woody hoppiness. It is almost syrupy thick. It oozes down the side of the glass, almost sticking to the sides. It was pretty enjoyable, but it might be a bit over hyped, as I have enjoyed some other Imperial Stouts more. It is still pretty freaking good though!

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2009 2007 release on tap at Dark Lord Day 2008. I was really looking forward to trying this beer! I was beginning to doubt that this could live up to its hype. The Dark Lord proved me wrong... I received this in a 6 ounce cup that was half filled with a completely opaque black beer with a beautiful brown head that left wonderful swirls in the top of the beer that lasted throughout the duration. The aroma was the most complex that I have ever experienced... a wonderful mix of chocolate, vanilla, nuts, bourbon, coffee, burnt wood, dried fruit, and suggary malts. I literally stood there smelling this for a good five minutes. Then I took the first sip... I was hit with an excellent mix of bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, burnt wood, and some alcohol in the finish. It also has a very heavy mouthfeel and is very "thick". It was even able to cling to the side of a plastic cup! This beer definitely looks intimidating but somehow is very easy to drink. I cannot wait to open one of my 2008 bottles! This one definitely lives up to its hype!

2008 bottle shared with nimrod and Illini08. I was a bit scared of this one because the top broke off of the bottle when I was opening it. However, I was definitely not disappointed. Poured a completely opaque black color with absolutely no head. After warming for a bit, I could smell a lot of bourbon, wood chips, dried fruits, vanilla, chocolate and coffee. This beer is by far the most complex I have encountered when it comes to aromas. The taste is absolutely incredible with a LOT of bitter chocolate and dried fruits with hints of vanilla and bourbon and coffee. The viscosity of this beer really boggles my mind. It clings to the side of the glass. Illini08 poured the beer and left a bit of sediment in the bottom. We tried drinking that after the initial brew, but was unable to because of its bitterness. I cannot wait to open another bottle in a year or two! This stuff is really enjoyable!

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2011 Poured the blackest i¬íve ever seen in a beer with a very dark brown head. Aroma of burnt coffee, chocolate, fruits, and a hint of alcohol.  Everything melds so well together in the flavor its so easy to pick out seperate things but so hard at the same time. Went into this thinking theres no way it could live up to the hype and it did.

Got this 2007 Dark Lord on tap at DLD 2008. Looked very dark with a burnt orange tint to the head. Smelled of soy sauce and swirled like a syrup. First taste was thick and dark but smooth and delicious. Great tasting beer, but it coated my stomach. One beer was enough for me, but since this beer is so rare, I would drink it over and over again.

So I went into this thinking it cant be worth all the hype and learned that it might not be worth the hype, but its definetly holds up as one of the best in the world.  Doesnt have the aged smell of Goose Island BCS, so thats the only reason it gets a 9.  Yes its better than Expedition, this has more flavor and doesnt get as sticky when sipping.  Easily worth the trip, cant wait for next year.

Vintage 07 on tap at DLD08.

Big and thick.  Very very dark, very viscous, coats the glass permanently with a brown layer.  Some thick head.
Smooth complex aroma: chocolate, roast, coffee, some sweetness, some fruitiness.
Brilliantly big and also somehow balanced.  Sweet, roasty, lightly alcoholic.  Coffee and chocolate.  Dates or raisins.
Thick but amazingly not too cloying.

2007 on tap @ Dark Lord Day 2008. Poured motor oil black with thick lacing, even on the plastic cup. Aroma of molasses, coffee, toffee, dark chocolate, and even some fruits. Taste extends the aroma with rich blend of fruit, malts, coffee and chocolate with an extremely surprising clean finish. Even though it was a heavy bodied, it was dangerously drinkable. I¬ím trying to rate this by memory, so I¬ím looking forward to my first 2008 bottle.

It is worth the trip and time in line to get...

It is not something I would drink every day (even if I could). The mouthfeel is what really stands out about this beer, it is very coating and penetrating, a very different sensation from most other beers. The taste and smell are all wonderful, as I could remember the taste and smell for hours after drinking the beer. (that or it dried up on my nose and no one told me).

Put simply if you get a chance to drink a beer like this you should.

2007 bottle thanks to CaptainCougar.  Pours thick as motor oil and dark with very small brown head.  Nose of prunes, raisins with toasted coffee.  Flavor is much the same, so much happening from each drink.  Thick as thick can be on the texture.  Finish is molassess and very much dried dark fruit.  What a wonderful thing to share thanks!

On tap DLD 08. Pours black and oily with a thick brown head. Aroma is filled with coffee, molasses, chocolate, and some dark fruits. Taste is much of the same, coffee, molasses, chocolate, and some dark fruits all playing nicely off of one another with some alcohol for good measure. Mouthfeel is thick, heavy, and a lot of alcohol warmth. Overall it is a good imperial, but it definitely didn¬ít live up to the hype around it.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2009 2007 on tap at DLD. Don¬ít get me wrong - this is an awesome IRS. Full of coffee, toffee, and molasses flavors. Excellent stuff. But is it worth the hype? I¬íve had others that were better, ones that are available year round, and in four packs. Still, its a great Impy Stout.  Pours black with minimal head. Goes down very smooth and very quickly - dangerous too because it will hit you. After sharing a 2008 - the new recipe is better, more dry, less sweet.

ON SECOND ANALYSIS: They changed the recipe for 2008. It¬ís much better, less sweet, more coffee, more dry. In short, yummier. It¬ís still not worth the hype, but it¬ís better than 2007.

2009 - Much more bitter than I remember it. Lots of coffee, cherry, currant and oak notes. Ends on that coffee note.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2008 DLD 2008, 22 oz bomber 2008 vintage. Saved a few for aging. Pours the blackest of blacks, like motor oil with little head. What little head disappears very quickly. Aroma is burnt, chocolate, coffee, plums, raisons, cherries, molasses, other dark fruits. Taste is everything you could imagine: chocolate, coffee, molasses, tobacco, plums, dark fruit, cherries, cinnamon, spice, with a well-hidden alcohol burn. Mouthfeel is thick like the pour with little carbonation. Incredibly smooth. Yes, this is my first dark lord. Yes, this is the best beer I¬íve ever had.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2012 Bottle - DLD2008 - 2007 & 2008 tasted.  Very very impressive beer.  Honestly might as well be motor oil.  Terrific blends of malts, chocolate, and coffee.  Saved one to age for a year but this beer is insane

6/17/12 - After 4 years, we opened out last 2008 DL.  Unbelievably complex - worried it wasn¬ít stored correctly but it help up great and definitely took on a thicker, almost caramel finish that coated the palate.  The coffee note wasn¬ít as pronounced, but there.  Not sure I noticed all the differences in aging but it tasted amazing.  Worth the wait

2008 Bottle tasted at Dark Lord Day 08.  Pours pitch black with a nice tan head.  Has smells of licorice, chocolate, roasted barley, and alcohol.  Has a heavy mouthfeel and coats the glass like a thick syrup.  Tastes like candy, licorice, molasses, caramel, coffee, vanilla, and alcohol.  Has a smooth finish for being fresh.  I would have thought it would have more pop being fresh.  It was an unexpected surprise and enjoyable to have such a smooth brew this early in its infancy.  I tasted a 07 while waiting in line and it had a much more pronounced licorice taste and flavor than a fresh dark lord.  Perhaps its just that the 08 will be a better batch.  Only time will tell.  Great beer.  Worth the hype.

22oz bottle, 2007 vintage consumed on DLD 2008 with one year. Supremely disappointed... pour is motor oil/ chocolate syrup black with a minimalist head, taste is sticky sweet, of port and mess of flavors, some vanilla peaks through and some coffee, beef jerky taste finishes the back end.. goes down velvety smooth tho and with 1 year there is no alcohol burn... very interesting beer, not worth the hype... score is in no way reflective of the true meaning of this beer.

2007 bottle.  Big thanks to Tony at Oldsmar Tap House for this one.  Pours jet black with little head.  Aroma is alcoholic with some oak character.  The flavor is huge; sweet and dry with roasted coffee and chocolate, along with a good deal of hoppiness as well.  Very complex and bold.  I finally got my hands on some DL, and I believe it lives up to the hype.  Wow!  Thanks again Tony!

2007. I have been saving this beer for this odd moment. My 666th rating and Dark Lords 666th rating. Pours thick black with a faint dark tan head. Aroma is dark cocoa, molasses, licorice, mild soy, ripened fruits. Flavor was nothing special. Nice? Yes. Special? No. Burnt nutty malts, boozy fruits, molasses, bourbon.

Taster from 22 ounce bottle in snifter at Oldsmar Tap House.  Back with no head. Port chocolate coffee earth aroma.  Port coffee chocolate raisin earth (and something I can¬ít read in my notes) flavor.  Full body and low carbo.  Well hidden alcohol.  Awesome.   Thanks Tony.

(From Long lost notes just recovered!!) Thanks to acrdz for bringing this back on the miraculous stolen truck trip. 2004 Slow thick pour, with tons of sediment. Black with no head. Aroma is nice, but burns like bourbon. Nice tobacco, coffee, and even prune in the flavor, heavy on the palate with too sweet a finish.

2006 bottle, courtesy Tony at Oldsmar Tap House. You¬íre the man, Tony. Pours a pitch black color with a creamy, caramel-colored head. Prominent lacing remains on the glass and draws you in for more. Rich caramel aroma, with brown sugar, licorice. Milk chocolate arouses the senses, as does strong roasted malts, mainly showing off chocolate. Flavor is through the roof. Roasted malts, caramel is very rich and substantial. Licorice and chocolate is present. Really the chocolate is big and just fantastic. So rich and smooth, obscenely easy to drink. Simply an unfair beer from Three Floyds. Laws should regulate this company from being able to create such incredible beverages.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2012 Bottle from 2006 (Gold Wax) thoroughly enjoyed April ¬í08. Pours a dark brown, near black with a large, lasting brown head. Aroma is simple and complete. Sweet and chocolatey with roastiness and molassess. Wonderful. I can begin to rate the flavor as smooth and balanced. A blend of sweet, roast, vanilla, molassess, and I begin to lose all interest in rating while I sit back and savor this brew. So simple, yet so full of everything. There is a reason this brew is so highly regarded. Thanks to a great trader - Footbalm - for sending this gem.

Re-rate from 4/1/2009: Bottle from 2008 (Black Wax) sampled fresh another time and this one with about a year on it. I really don¬ít think it can get any better than this. After working my ass off to try as many imperial stouts as possible, this is the best one to date. Massive aroma and taste with tons of complexity and well balanced. Just the mouthful is ridiculous... At this point, why rate it anymore? Sit back and enjoy the ride.

Re-rate from 4/19/2012: Bottle from 2008 (Black Wax) sampled with four years in the cellar. Nose is rich and sweet, dark pitted fruits, brown sugar, chocolate, and molasses. Very silky, creamy, and rich mouthful. Tastes a little more balanced than prior tastes; malty, toffee, molasses, roast, chocolate, and light bits of dark fruits. Delicious. Still my only rating at "5" and I can¬ít say this taste would quite be a perfect score, but in summary of these tastings I¬íll let it stand. With confidence.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2008 I wanted to like this beer....being all hyped and such...but....
it had a strong soy sauce taste....
It almost tasted like a good IRS mixed with a old sam adams triple bock......

but thanks to whoever shared this with me at the BA alesmith release.....I forget his BA name...but thanks so much for letting me try your valuable dark lord!

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2008 Can¬ít say enough good things about this beer. It has a smoky aroma, a wonderful gravity, and menacingly black appearance. Highly-complex flavor of chocolate, coffee, cherry,  and maybe some soy. I love this beer. It¬ís only drawback is that you can only buy one six pack on one day out of the year.  The years you really want are 2005(orange) and 2007(silver).
Very dark brown, almost black with no head ! Notes of soy sauce and fish. Taste of wood, coffee and some sweetness. Full body with a bittersweet finish.

Bottle, 2006 Edition. Huge thanks to Dough77 for hooking me up with this guy; I¬íve been looking forward to this day for a long time. Jet black pour, beautiful tan head. Decent aroma, roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. Very complex, dynamic, vinuous taste - thick, creamy mocha, molasses.. not getting much vanilla though. Can¬ít believe it¬ís 13%... the alcohol is barely noticeable.

Incredibly smooth mouthfeel, long lingering . Sick patterns form on the head after every sip; the bubbles swirl into new galaxies every time I put it down. Absolutely delicious, I wish I could drink this all the time.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2010 This is worth the hype for sure.  I¬ím now glad that it took me so long to get my hands on one (2007 bottle) because it gave me plenty of time to try most of the other highly rated stouts.  What really impressed me about this was:  (where to begin...) - palate - had a great, thick mouthfeel that really set it apart (I guess oily maybe).  Flavors - has all of them, it seems, yet nothing too overpowering.  Chocolate, nutty, fruity, coffee, licorice, on and on.  Every sip I would notice another flavor.  Seemed like that more lasting flavor at the end was licorice but early on it is cocoa/coffee/nutty.  

Update on 2009 bottling - tried one of those bad boys the weekend after DLD.  It was cloyingly sweet and syrupy.  Definitely needs to age quite a bit.  I¬íll let the rest of mine sit for about a year.  I couldn¬ít finish the bomber.  Most of the other DL¬ís I¬íve had from other years have been aged for some time, so I¬íll know better in the future to avoid drinking it fresh.

Update for 2010 - I think this beer is going downhill.  This was not nearly as gooey and sticky as in years past - not a lot of lacing or carbonation.  The complexity of flavors just wasn¬ít there - not many hints of other flavors like with 2007 or 2008.  2007 was fantastic and each year has declined.  I¬íll let this age further but I am not overly optimistic.  I¬ím dropping my rating on this brew significantly.  Still a great imperial stout, but not the world¬ís finest.

Bottle. Black colour with a brown head. Aroma is alcohol, licorice, roasted, smoked, coffee. Flavour is coffee, licorice, alcohol, hop, smoked, coffee. Very nice beer which need a long time to drink and enjoy because of the rich flavours.

Ya, I know. This beer is a badass. Not only does it contain every ingrediant under the sun, and maybe some from the underworld, that I enjoy in a stout, but it seems like I can pick out any flavor I want at any time or just let them all blend together to make a fine brew. Like the wizard of beers all I say is, "there is no thing like a cherry stout" and I take a sip. Bam, a top notch cherry stout flavor. Can do that with so many flavors its unbelievable. Fantastic beer. I would say it is worth the hype, but there is no hype over this beer, just fact.
I had to wait in line a long time for this one.  I was hoping for something really good, but I don¬ít see how this is much better than Guinness as it is rather sludgy.

2007 bottle.  Thanks to Lamunche for sharing this one.  First off probably the best beer I¬íve ever had.  perfect beer for my 100th rating.  color is dark brown and looks like dirty motor oil. has the consistency of motor oil as well.  very complex flavor of fruit, chocolate, carmel, coffee, and vanilla.  it tasted different every sip I took.  I can¬ít wait for DarkLord Day!

2006 Bottle from apoptosis: Pours a very deep black with a creamy brown head. Sweet on the nose with aromas of burnt fruit, molasses, chocolate, carmel, coffee, roast, and vanilla. Body is very heavy with taste of fruit up front. Heavy molasses flavor. Then fade to sweet chocolate, carmel, and roast. Finish has alot of hops to it.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2011 2010 bomber thanks to TheBeerSommelier.  pours black with light brown highlights and a slim tan bubbly head. settles quickly to an oily black with a light rim.  brilliant nose with layers of licorice, currants, dark cherries, molasses, roasted malts and chocolate.  thick chewy body with tons of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, licorice, molasses, dark fruits, light vanilla and a bit of heat.  sweet, roasted alcoholic finish with a decent bitterness and spice that lingers through.

2006 bomber with gold wax on top... the almighty Dark Lord.... well it lives up to the hype and high rating.... it is quite amazing.  pours a thick black oil consistency... strong aromas of licorice, currants, dark fruits and a touch of alcohol... the licorice really shines through the most for me across the palate.  this is followed by faint tones of plums and raisins.  a near perfect palate with a soft velvet approach, while offering the tip of the tongue some numbness.  It flows down the back of the throat with excellence, finishing with a blast of licorice and a touch of alcohol.  overall, this beer is definitely one of the best available in the world... what a great way to ring in my birthday...

this beer is like black blood pouring into a glass.  Myself and a good friend enjoyed this for breakfast the day we saw Down play New Orleans.  A very thick, malty beer with a strong aftertaste.  Very bocky.  Bock with huge nuts.  We split a double deuce and it woke me up.  It gets a perfect rating because I¬íve never had anything as extremely evil and awesome as this.

2007 version thanks to eaglefan538.  Dark pour with little head and lacing.  Moderate vinous aroma.  Overpowering flavor of sweet dark fruit and raisins.    Bordering on sickly sweet, with no strong hop presence to balance.  This beer is so ridiculously overrated...I could name a dozen imperial stouts off the top of my head significantly better than this.  Disappointment doesn¬ít begin to describe.  I don¬ít get it.

Pours a totally opaque thick black color with thin light brown head. Aroma is very roasty, thick, full of dark malts, notes of ash, toasted oak, fair amount of dark caramel, roasted dark coffee, cream, faint dark chocolate, slightly salty. Flavor is full of roasted coffee, bit of dark chocolate, burnt oak, toasted caramel, cream. Palate is fairly thick. Finish is mildly sweet. Overall a very nice imp stout, doesn¬ít quite live up to the hype, up still very good.

Bottle, 22oz, 2007 vintage. (Big thanks to the_epeeist) Even though this is a heavenly beer, I can¬ít get myselves to rate it higher. The reason is that it¬ís just too much, even for a lover of imperial stout like me. Like Sam Adams Triple Bock, I think it¬ís over the top. Packed with flavors and aromas, but there¬ís a limit for everything. I shared my bottle with friends, but drank half of it on my own, but that took me some two hours. Two fine hours, but still...The pour was black as the original sin, with a small, lasting tan head leaving nice lacings. The flavor was as expected full of the dark stuff with licorice, molasses, burnt malt, chocolate and coffee doing most of the job. Actually, the licorice and roasted malt is trying to overpower all the others, and they do a good job on that attempt. There¬ís molasses, some warming alcohol, licorice and lots of sugary dark flavors in the mouth, also here it¬ís lacking a bit on the hoppy bitterness I think. Still it¬ís the beer being closest to a perfect 10 on flavor of those I¬íve had so far. It¬ís thick and chewy on the palate, one of the chewiest I¬íve had, and it has a long finish with all the flavors found initially, and finally, there¬ís my longed-for hoppy flavors too. It sort of deserves the hype I think, yet I think it might be overrated. (080215)

Rudy, you are the man amigo. Thanks for this 2007 bottle of brewskie =)
DL pours thick and viscous but a little weak in the froth producing only a shortlived copper sheath at the end that quickly disappears. Aromas are heavy and dense like a foggy night with tons of roasted chocolate. Full, chunky, chewy, nectar with soft carbonation that just hits the mark. This is like drinking pudding. A huge malted chocolate bar in every serving. I mean, seriously man...PUDDING THICKNESS. I have the phone next to me incase I need 911 to revive me from choking. This is aboslutely drinkable. It¬ís amazingly balanced despite it¬ís decadent, hedonistic disposition. I wouldn¬ít say this beer is complex but it¬ís right in your face and demands to be heard. Theres a defined roasted coffee bean component along with some vanilla waffer. The pudding turns a bit acidic on the finish which is a good thing as it helps to tame this beast. The high abv is  well hidden. Overall: I will Trump this as the head is weak and wouldn¬ít get a full 100 for that alone. As for this being the best. Not in my book. It¬ís fractions away from Dark Horizon. It¬ís just not a complex beer by flavor or aroma. Bottom line: it¬ís in my top ten IS list.

Thanks to two guys who run a website that shan¬ít be named here. Big chocolate, molasses and coffee flavors with some nice balancing roasted malt smokiness. Thick, chewy mouthfeel and a nice finish. Outstanding beer!

650 ml bottle w/silver wax (2007). Black body with a thin brown head. Powerful and pleasant aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and coffee, but actually dominated by sweet roasted liquorices. Complex flavor, dominated by sweet molasses but also warming alcohol, lots of chocolate and coffee. A classic. Thanx to Yngwie who managed to get a hold on this treasure.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2009 Wow thanks a lot there Alldaydrinker for sharing this amazing beer with me. Im glad we could sit down on your birthday and drink a nice snifter full of this 2006 bottle. When poured out it was blacker then the blackest black times infinity. The beer did have an initial nut brown head that was thick but it faded very quick and it left no laceing along the sides of the glass due to its thick viscus syrup like texture. Dont be fooled though it is still an amazing brew. I must have smelled this for a good 10 minutes before i took my first sip since it was so rich on the nose and the alcohol was evaporating in my nostrils I could have got drunk off the smell alone. It was full of rich mocha chocolate, roasted coffee, cherry and raspberry with some other hints of dark fruits. You could also pick up that minor hop bitterness over all the other complex flavors. When i took my first small sip my mouth was blasted with coffee to the max. I feel like i just ate fresh coffee grounds and chased it with the creamiest coffee ice cream. This is probably the most intense coffee beer I have ever had. The more you drink it the more you want to savor the rich flavors in your mouth. Personally enjoyed the coffee film that was left around my entire mouth. After each sip the film just got thicker and thicker. I could still taste the beer flavor long after I had finished it. Since it is extremely think almost like drinking rich chocolate mocha, Irish cream, and coffee sludge but with that taste of heaven in your mouth. It starts out smooth and nice then gets rough and extremely bitter with a finish that is creamy and refreshing, almost like your having sex. I cant say enough about this amazing imperial stout.  Just glad i got a chance to try it considering its limited distribution.

2006 Bomber courtesy of Saarlander thanks Aaron!  Much appreciated for the hookup!Shared with my good buddy emerica56!. Thought this would be a great 

treat on my birthday. Pouring a visible syrupy texture with a dark opaque brown color with medium dark tan creamy head that resides to small head 

retention. Nose is pungent, from opening of the bottle was very noticeable. Complex and depth of this aroma is outstanding. Initial breakdown of the aroma 

hits the nose with strong display of alcohol, liqourish, lactic and cherries. Vinous qualities. Moving in underlying layers mocha, cappuchino, macadamia nuts 

and dark malts. Deepest layer is resembling some characteristics of a rauch, with sweet bbq smoke that brings salvation to mouth. Initial mouthfeel oflots of 

microbubbles and slushing over the mouth with smooth velvety touch.  Moving into a delicate melt of chocolate, cherry, fermented fruit mash, black currants 

and coffee. Enhancing heavily into the mid palate is creamy coffee icecream and mocha-cappuchino. The finish retains the coffee cream but bitter hops takes 

control in the bargaining mix displaying a bitter lactic. Roasted characteristics sit the background aggravated and sensitive. The aftermath is of stickiness of 

the mouth and lips. 
Palate duration is perfect, palate is scorched with flavor and complexity. Full body that is hearty but easy to drink. 
Alcohol is heavily attended in the nose but well masked in the taste. Great experience, cheers to another awesome birthday!

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2008 06. Poured thick with a deep brown head. Malt and coffee to the nose. Drinks like Pepto and finishes with some chocolate. Could drink all day if it wasn¬ít so hard to get. Thanks to TheRealBastard for sharing!
Re-rate* 08. Poured exactly like all the other years, black and like oil with a thick brown head. Aroma of alcohol, coffee, and some chocolate. Flavor was dominated by sweetness. Other than that, awesome beer.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: UPDATED: JUN 18, 2011 22 oz bottle, 2007.  My 2nd Ratebeer anniversary and the last of the top-rated coffee-ish stouts i had planned for a blind tasting.  Maybe an unfair advantage for the younger DL.  Pours an ominous black with no trace of head.  Nose is an interesting blend of coffee, licorice and leather with hints of Turkish tobacco.  Full bodied and velvety with a trace of carb.  Taste is sweet coffee and dark chocolate.  Roasty finish with grapefruit.  The last 6 ounces were thick and chalky sludge.  Wow, but i¬íd prefer not.  Given the choice i¬íd go with the Speedway. 6 /17/11 - 2009 bottle.  Nose is molasses, chocolate, hay and light coffee.  Medium to full body with moderate carb but nowhere near as thick as the 07 i had.  Taste is dark chocolate, espresso and slight pine.  Still a 4.2 for me.  The ultimate dessert stout.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2009 Pours like used motor oil.  Dark brown head.  Nose is mostly coffee with hints of chocolate behind it.  Coats the entire mouth, very easy to drink.  Did not want this glass to end.  Very impressive, lived up to the hype everyone gives it.  Still not my favorite beer though.  Re-Rate 2008 vintage on April 12, 2009 for Easter.  Pours blacker and thicker than any stout I¬íve seen.  Taste is burnt sugar, maple, and heavy coffee/chocolate flavors.  Smell is mainly chocolate and malt.  Palate and appearance made this one just ok.  Flavor is too sweet, not as good as any other vintage I¬íve had.

2006 bottle. Poured nearly pitch black, with a small brown head that dissipates to a rim of bubbles around the snifter. Wonderfully complex aroma, with plum and raisin in the forefront, along with coffee, molasses, and vanilla. Aroma reminds me of a tawny port. Dark fruit and very sweet malt flavors are nicely complimented by coffee, chocolate, apple, and some hops. Flavor is much sweeter than i expected based on the aroma (and sweeter than I remember from a previous bottle). Syrupy mouthfeel. Roasted malt and hop bitterness finally overcome the sweetness in the finish. It¬ís a nice stout overall, just a bit too sweet for my liking. (Via Dough77 in Nearly Perfect 10 deux - Big thanks, Tim!)
Bottle @ the wolf tasting. Black with a small film which diappears quickly. Aroma and flavour of rye bread, (smoaked salmon?!) chocolate and very sweet and oily (a bit too sweet and sticky)

thank arvin! split a bottle of this with three old cook friends of mine and couldnt have been happier.  this beer has legs, legs i tell you! pours like molasses, tastes like a chocolate terrine with port cherries arvin used to make.  what a beer, what a night.  makes me miss the ohio river valley. go cards!

Red Wax-2004 - This is by far and away one of the most amazing Imperial stouts that I have ever had in my life.  This beer pours a very heavy and oily blackness into the snifter.  The aroma is chocolate and cherries, coffee, licorice, lots and lots of dark fruits, raspberries and black berries.  Rich and exotic on the palate, and the flavors just keep going and going and you get a completely different taste profile from sip to sip with flavors fighting for the forefront on your tongue.  Extremely well-balanced for as big a beer as it is.  Extremely complex, rich chocolately and roasty, but very smooth, detecting just a hint of heat and hop bitterness in the finish.

07 [email¬†protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */....last one of the night, and yes I paid the price!  Was it worth it?  Of course.  Poured dark with no head.  Smelled and tasted of sweet molasses, chocolate, and roasted coffee.  Over the top.  What a night.

Silver wax, 2007 bomber, courtesy of badbeer. Pours jet black and thick, used oil thick. Very thin brown head that doesn¬ít do much. Leaves an oily coating on the glass. Super dark malty smelling with alcohol. Tastes like it smells... Dark, oily, malty, thick, sweet, super sweet, maybe some coffee but maybe not. This is officially the thickest beer I¬íve ever had, not alot of carbonation to it. It¬ís tasty but damn, super sweet... and thick.

sooooo overwhelming. there was no sense of enjoyment drinking this. how anyone is able to get through an entire bottle is beyond me. blew out my taste buds...just too much going on without any real balance to me. i couldnt finish the 4 oz sample i had. i think they should stop putting this in bombers, and maybe use the smaller bottles like 375ml or even the 6oz bottles like KRE are in. just makes more sense. i can appreciate it for what it is...but if you take away the hype it just isnt that good. ive split 2 bottles with 2 completely different set of beer geeks who arent really familiar with the breweries across the country, so they dont know about all the hype...and pretty much everyone that it was too much and not very enjoyable. the same people that liked abyss, expedition, and jah-va that i let them try. a damn shame i traded 2 cuvee de tommes for 2 of these

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2008 2-1-08 bottle shared with lb4lb thanks to acertain!!! (my #500 rating)  2007 bottle 
Thick pitch black pour with little light tannish brown head on the first pour.  Small spotted lacing - good appearance, thick and dark.  Rich, roasted malt and sweet alcohol aroma.  The alcohol in the nose is well balanced with the sweet malt smell.  I get no coffee, but a little vanilla and some molasses as well as it warms.  The flavor is quite sweet, not nearly as roasted as I had imagined.  It has that rich, decadent dessert sweetness.  It almost tastes like a rich dark chocolate, alcohol infused cake.  The mouthfeel is memorable - very thick, very syrup-like.  It is quite creamy and rich and dense on the palate, but is on that thin line of being just too much.  It actually feels weighty on the tongue.  No real carbonation but I don¬ít miss it in this - it is fitting here.  Finish is nearly tart, it is so sweet.  Aftertaste has the sweetness as well as the residual alcohol taste - not really my favorite aspect of this beer.  Feels like slightly watered down molasses on the tongue.  Overall, very well made - but the hype leading up to trying this for the first time may have spoiled it a bit for me.  Obviously a good brew but not the best Imperial Stout I have had (in fact there are at least 4 or so that come to mind that I feel are much more amazing than this).  Aside from that, a great beer for my 500th rating.  Thanks again acertain! 
10-18-08 bottle (2008 bottle)
